HEADLINE: THE WINE REGIONS: SOUTH AFRICA;
Long History of Wine Emerges From a Cloud

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

DATELINE: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa

 BODY:
SOMETIME in the next few days, a container filled with South African wine will arrive at Savannah, Ga. It is the first South African wine shipped to the United States since sanctions were imposed on the South African Government in 1986 because of its policy of racial segregation.
Wine makers in this verdant southwest corner of Africa have been looking forward to this first shipment since the sanctions were lifted last July, looking forward with joy and apprehension. Will the Americans like their wine? Will the deep-seated American revulsion toward apartheid linger on in the form of antipathy toward their products? Will it persist even though, they say, the tide has turned in the long fight here against institutionalized racism. 
 "We know it will take time, perhaps a long time," said John Platter, a wine grower and author of a definitive guide to South African wine. "But we are proud of our wines and we are proud of what we have done to bring South Africa back into the family of nations."
Like most white South Africans, the winegrowers of the Cape hailed the referendum on March 17 in which an stunning 68.7 percent of the white voters called for continued negotiations with the country's blacks toward a new majority government. South Africa has about five million whites and 30 million blacks.
South Africa is a very old wine-producing nation. In fact, South African wine makers know the exact date that their history began: Feb. 2, 1659. On that day, Jan Van Riebeck, who had led the first Dutch settlers ashore seven years earlier, wrote in his diary: "Today, praise be to God, wine was pressed for the first time from Cape grapes."
In the 18th and 19th centuries, South African wines, especially Constantia, were among the most famous wines in the world. According to the English writer Nicholas Faith, when the wine cellar book of Louis XVI was discovered many years after his death, it showed that he owned some Burgundy, almost no Bordeaux and many thousands of bottles of Constantia from the slopes of the Cape of Good Hope.
The first vines were planted not by the Dutch, but by the second group of immigrants to the Cape, French Huguenots, who brought vine cuttings with them from Europe. Their traditions live on in the lovely Franschhoek Valley, 40 miles east of Cape Town, where the wine makers call themselves vignerons and wineries bear names like Clos Cabriere, La Motte and Haute Provence.
From the earliest days, the white settlers strove to distance themselves from the blacks they found here. To insure the division held, the whites imported workers -- slaves, actually -- from Southeast Asia to toil in the vineyards. Intermingling between the Malays, as they were called, and the white settlers produced the ethnic group known as the Cape colored, who continue to provide most of the farm labor in the western Cape.
Indeed, under the byzantine laws of apartheid, especially the Group Areas Act, the western Cape was designated as a preferential area for the Cape colored. This meant, in effect, that blacks were barred from the region. Blacks work in the Cape now, but the Cape colored predominate, particularly in agriculture.
The history of South African agriculture, like that of sharecropping and mining in the United States, is one of exploitation. Workers usually lived in housing provided by the farmers, with rent and food costs deducted from their wages. The system gave rise to a practice called the tot, in which overtime, and sometimes a part of regular wages, was paid in cheap wine.
The tot, which kept workers drunk and in debt, has disappeared from most wineries and vineyards but persists in outlying areas, on many small farms that supply grapes to the industry but make no wine themselves. "It's a terrible practice," Mr. Platter said, "but it is still around."
Even the practice of housing workers on the vineyards and farms is coming into question. Most wineries are proud of their worker housing and are eager to show the little cottages to visitors. Many are building additional or larger worker homes. But one of the area's oldest -- and newest -- wineries, Vergelegen, in Somerset West, will have no on-premises housing for workers when its current rebuilding is completed.
"That's the wave of the future," said Francis Wilson, a professor of economics at the University of Cape Town, who has written extensively on rural poverty on South African. "Agricultural workers are getting better wages; many have cars. It's a different life now."
One of the most persistent advocates of change in the wine country has been Mr. Platter. With his wife, Erica, he owns and operates Clos du Ciel, a winery and vineyard on a mountain slope south of Stellenbosch, about 25 miles east of Cape Town. Previously, he owned Delaire Vineyards, in the hills west of town.
But most of his energy has gone into the regular revision of his book, "John Platter's South African Wine Guide," and to agitating for reforms in the South African wine industry.
Beginning in the mid-1980's, he led a small group of wine makers who dedicated themselves to ending exploitative industry practices that stemmed, the group believed, from the Government's racist policies.
They drew up what they called the Winelands Committment, a statement in which they pledged to end racial discrimination and unfair labor practices in their business. They were, the statement said, "dedicated to the constant improvement of South African wines, recognizing our objectives cannot be properly achieved in a country dominated by issues of race and inequality."
They said they were committed to "the principle that all land and vineyard ownership be opened unconditionally to all races, and that the Group Areas Act be removed," as it has been; to "freedom of association for all our colleagues and employees," and to "the ending of apartheid policies in South Africa."
When the Winelands Committment was first made public, in 1989, only four winegrowers would sign it: Simon Barlow, whose family owns Rustenberg, one of the oldest estates in Stellenbosch; John Younghusband, at Haute Provence in Franschhoek; Tim Hamilton Russell, whose vineyards are at Hermanus, about 40 miles east of Cape Town, on the coast, and Mr. Platter.
As the country moved toward an end to official discrimination, more wine makers signed up. Still, Mr. Platter keeps a file of letters from colleagues who agreed with the Winelands Committment but felt it might not be wise to say so publicly.
The conservative side of the wine industry is represented by the Cooperative Winegrowers' Association, commonly known by the abbreviation of its Afrikaans name, K.W.V.
The K.W.V., with some 5,000 members, is a uniquely South African body that exercises immense power over what wines are made and who makes them. It was organized in 1918 when the industry was depressed by weak markets and overproduction.
The association produces nearly 80 percent of all South African wine and spirits aside from beer. But beyond that, it has been given regulatory powers by the Government to set quotas based on grape tonnage that apply to all growers, whether K.W.V. members or not.
Thus, when Mr. Hamilton Russell wanted to plant his vineyards near Hermanus, he could not because he had no grape quota. He had to wait until he could buy someone else's unused quota. When he produced his first Burgundy-style pinot noir, he found that the K.W.V. forbade the use of any foreign grape names on wine labels. So he called the wine Grand Vin Noir. That rule was rescinded, but he still cannot mention Burgundy in his literature or on his labels.
Under the production quota system established by the association in 1957, grape-growing was banned outside the existing hot-climate regions, where high yields of grapes were normal. When a new breed of wine makers wanted to plant the more delicate fine-wine grape varieties in cooler regions, they discovered that there were no quotas for those areas, so no planting was permitted. They found, too, that the noble varieties they had hoped to plant, like chardonnay and pinot noir, would have to undergo 10 years or more of testing for diseases by the association before they could be used commercially.
Despite the bans, vines were smuggled in, and eventually the K.W.V. relented and permitted their use.
"The K.W.V. system is to pay for high yield," Mr. Hamilton Russell said. "It's outmoded -- soul-destroying, actually -- for serious wine makers."
The ban on French names was part of deal struck with the French Government in the 1930's. France agreed to import South African lobsters if South Africa would ban the use of French names for its wines. Grape types and French geographical references were barred from the labels.
Some of South Africa's most prominent wineries have regularly paid enormous sums to permit them to go over their quotas. Pieter Malan, whose family owns Simonsig, a famous Stellenbosch winery that is often fined for overproduction, has taken the association to court over its statutory right to review all his winery records.
K.W.V. officials defend their restrictions, noting that they brought order and relative prosperity to a business that was degenerating into chaos earlier in the century. They agree that the fine wine business has different criteria, note that restrictions have been eased and hint that even more changes are imminent. The word among the winegrowers is that even the despised quota system may be on its way out.
South Africa's problems are far from over. With the lifting of the Group Areas Act and two Lands Acts in 1990, blacks were free to move anywhere in the country. Some 500,000 headed for the Western Cape because of its relative prosperity. A handful found jobs; the rest did not. They live in a vast squatters' camp stretching eastward from Cape Town for almost 20 miles.
Somehow, they must be absorbed into the region's economic mainstream. Few will find work in the vineyards. In spite of the challenges facing the region, the wine makers remain optimistic. "Changes are coming," Mr. Malan said. "We don't know what all of them will be, but they are long overdue and we welcome them."

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

Five Days to Platinum
Record retailers are rubbing their hands together with glee: five albums released last week have created a real burst of buying. Three of the albums -- Bruce Springsteen's "Human Touch" and "Lucky Town" and Def Leppard's "Adrenalize" -- were predictable successes. But the other two -- Wynonna Judd's "Wynonna" (Curb/MCA), her first since the breakup of the Judds, and "Totally Krossed Out" (Columbia), a debut album by a young black pop group called Kris Kross -- were a surprise. 
 "Wynonna" has been almost shockingly successful. MCA reported sales of more than a million copies in the first five business days of the record's availability, and in some markets it has been out-selling Mr. Springsteen's albums.
"I've been involved in platinum albums before, but to achieve it in five days is pretty remarkable," said Bruce Hinton, president of MCA- Nashville. "Certainly no prior Judds' album had that sort of impact in the first week."
MCA originally shipped out 600,000 copies of the album, and within two days virtually every record chain came back for more. Mr. Hinton said that the Musicland chain started on Tuesday with 28,000 copies, ordered 15,000 more on Wednesday, 44,000 on Thursday and on Thursday afternoon ordered 11,000 more.
In "Wynonna," Ms. Judd moves toward Bonnie Raitt territory: spare and clean pop music with a Southern accent. Industry observers say the album probably has the power to keep on selling.
"I trust Tony Brown, who produced the record," said Ms. Judd. I wanted so badly to improve and change, but not go too far. I knew what I didn't want, and on several tracks I'd change things around, usually taking out instruments or making a track rely on piano instead of guitar. I've always believed that the voice is the main instrument, and I wanted it heard. And I wanted a live feel to it. I've always believed that if you can't do something live, don't do it on record."
Ms. Judd started the album last May, in the middle of the Judds' farewell tour. It took her 10 months to make.
"I had to ask myself 'Do you want to be the Entertainer of the Year or do you want to make the Album of the Year?" she said. "I went back to the time when I first discovered music and tried to figure out what I liked. Tony Brown and I went to publishing houses looking for material, and I was frustrated because I was walking in as if I were new, and they didn't know what I wanted. So it took a long time to get songs. But we finally worked it out, and each one of the tunes strikes a chord in me now. I really live these songs. I bleed them."
 
A Family Affair
 Not too many pop groups can get their audience to speak in tongues, though most probably wish they could. The Winans, who are appearing at the Beacon Theater for three shows this Saturday, can do just that. The group, pop's foremost pop-gospel band, tears the house up, putting on a show that, if it weren't for the preaching and the references to Him, acts like a classic soul group. Pleading and crying and shouting, the singers turn the audience into a frenzied mass.
The group, made up of the brothers Marvin, Carvin, Michael and Ronald, is part of a larger entity, the entire Winans family from Detroit. The family, comprising 10 children and the elder Winanses, Dolores and David, will be performing at the Beacon. The three-hour show features spots for two of the Winans daughters, BeBe and CeCe, who have a flourishing career of their own.
"This is something we'd talked about for years," said Marvin Winans. "God's made all things beautiful; it was time to do it. So far, everywhere we go it's been sell-out or near sell-out crowds. It's a great commentary that in these economically depressed times this country needs to see a family that's functioning. That needs to be seen. Our faith isn't a hobby, and we hope it's something that imparts inspiration."
That faith comes across in concert, where the brothers do some preaching. But it also comes across in the singing, which displays a passion rarely heard in secular music. The group is one of the great live shows working in American music today.
"I think live is what we do best," Mr. Winans said. "You're able to get that spontaneity that exists with a live audience. They give and you give back to them. We want people to have a great time because we have a great time. We want people to know that Jesus is real. We want people to know that you can be a church and have a blast, have a great time. Music is spiritual; it's uplifting music, very, very powerful. It moves you to change."
 
Diamanda Galas on Record
 The singer Diamanda Galas has just released a new album, "The Singer" (Mute/Elektra), that features blues and gospel tunes from Screaming Jay Hawkins's "I Put a Spell on You" to "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot." The versions aren't precisely faithful. Ms. Galas screams and contorts her voice until the tunes haven't a shred of idiomatic consistency; instead, they're anguished.
"The gospel stuff is cries in the dark," said Ms. Galas. "It's consistent with what I've been doing a lot of -- work related to AIDS, for example. I could say I'm reappropriating that music for what's happening in my community, the AIDS community. Gospel music is military music in the sense that the people doing it are in the front lines; they stay alive in the face of despair and overwhelming oppression. And it's the music of ecstasy."
The blues pieces are a little less dire. Ms. Galas, who accompanies herself on piano, knows the material well (she played piano in her father's dance band when she was a teen-ager in San Diego) but she redoes the melodies, keeping some of the words. There's a real attempt to make over the tunes to fit her own needs.
"All of that music, I understand from personal experience," said Ms. Galas. "I've never done love right. I get the music right, but when it comes to love I'm a total failure."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Showalter Gives Short Notice, but Yanks Deliver

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
The season opener game was an hour away and Buck Showalter still did not have a Yankee lineup. Was the rookie manager kidding himself? Roger Clemens would soon be pitching for Boston, so this was no joke. Decisions had to be made.
Showalter made them when he was ready. He waited for updated reports on two injured players, then cobbled together a lineup that rapped Clemens for three runs in the sixth inning to thrust the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium. 
 It was only one game in the standing, but it included the glamour of opening day and the rare conquest of Clemens, so the Yankees had reason to rejoice.
When it was over, before 56,572 fans had spilled out into the Bronx, Showalter, the new decision-maker, did not leave the dugout. He savored his first victory by sitting back and watching his players congratulate one another. He might have been pondering the odyssey that took him from being unemployed to being manager, or he might have been thinking about his father's recent death, but he would not say.
 
Going My Way?
 "That was their moment," said Showalter, when asked why he did not join the celebration. "I had nothing to do with the way they played. Besides, I knew they had to pass by me to get to the clubhouse."
And Showalter had several hands to shake when the players reached him. There was Roberto Kelly, who embraced the third spot in the order by driving in three of New York's four runs. There was Randy Velarde, who neatly replaced the injured Mike Gallego at shortstop, batted leadoff and scored twice. There was Scott Sanderson, who pitched six stellar innings and baffled Boston with off-speed pitches. And there was some spirit.
"There were things we did right today that we wouldn't have done last year," Sanderson said. "We had a little bit more of a fighting attitude. Believe me, that starts from the top."
It was actually the top of the 11th hour lineup that lifted the Yankees back from a 2-1 deficit in the sixth. Velarde bounced a single to center to open the inning and moved to third on Don Mattingly's tricky single by third baseman Wade Boggs. Mattingly slapped at a pitch, the ball spun toward the line and Boggs seemed to tangle his feet as he moved to the right in hopeless pursuit.
Mattingly's single set up the pivotal inning as Kelly followed with a double that rolled to the wall in left center field. That double gave the Yankees a 3-2 edge and gave Kelly a confidence boost.
"I want them to expect a lot from me because I do too," Kelly said. "When there is a situation like that, I want to be the guy they look to."
Kelly advanced to third on a groundout and scored the inning's third run on another strange hit. With the infield playing in to reduce Kelly's chances of scoring on a grounder, Danny Tartabull fisted a broken bat, 100-foot looping single that bounced in front of second base and barely eluded Boston's infielders to make the score 4-2.
"Things were pretty bizarre in the sixth," Clemens said. "They found a way to get things in there."
Tartabull almost did not play because of a sprained right wrist and declined to speak to reporters before the game because he was confused about his status. Then the player who is being paid $5.1 million to drive in runs poked one of the cheaper run-scoring hits he will ever manage.
 
Taking a Firm Stand
 "I thought it looked great," said Tartabull, who is 6 for 36 in his career against Clemens, with a deadpan expression.
Boston, which had taken its 2-1 lead on home runs by Phil Plantier and Mo Vaughn, scored once in the seventh and forced the Yankees to stave off a comeback bid in the ninth. This time Steve Farr and Mattingly snuffed out the rally. After Tony Pena singled, the Red Sox attempted to sacrifice him to second, but Mattingly rushed forward to grab Luis Rivera's well-placed bunt and nail the lead runner at second. Then Farr finished the game by striking out Boggs looking on a 2-2 fastball and getting Jody Reed on a foul pop.
That's when Showalter relaxed and remained in the dugout, suspending himself in the joyous moment and then dismissing the victory like a veteran. He knows there are 161 games left. Plenty of time to lose a few.
"It was a great afternoon for the organization and the club," said Showalter, "but I don't want to make too big a deal out of it."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 MIKE GALLEGO was placed on the 15-day disabled list before the opener because of a bruised right heel. The transaction is retroactive to March 28, meaning he is eligible to return on Sunday. Utility infielder ANDY STANKIEWICZ , a six-year minor leaguer, assumed the roster spot. . . . Yankee Stadium ushers, who also provide security, picketed outside the park before the game and Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS did not attend the game, refusing to cross the line, according to a spokesman for the Mayor.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$1.4 Billion in Debentures Are Priced by Fannie Mae

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced for sale a total of $1.4 billion in debentures, equally divided between 5-year and 10-year maturities, through various securities dealers.
For the five-year issue, the interest rate is set at 7 percent and offered at a price of 99.875 to yield 7.03 percent, or about 28 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. 
 The interest rate for the 10-year isssue is set at 7.9 percent and offered at 99.875 to yield 7.918 percent, or about 51 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities.
Fannie Mae says the five-year debenture is callable on or after April 10, 1995, while the 10-year is callable on or after April 10, 1997. Both issues begin making interest payments on Oct. 10 this year.
In a separate development, the agency also announced that it planned to provide Great Western Bank of Beverly Hills, Calif., with up to $6 billion in mortgage financing money, by purchasing mortgages from the bank for cash.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 502 words

HEADLINE: The Man With the Ball

 BODY:
Almost everyone could find some comfort in yesterday's Democratic primary results.
Republicans could relish the complex new evidence that the Democrats seem never to tire of finding ways to tarnish their chances for victory in November.
Paul Tsongas supporters were entitled to a genuine "Wow! What a moral victory!" Their man wasn't even running, yet he ran twice as well as expected in New York. They are alive with hope that the announcement he promises for this morning is that he's getting back in the race. 
 Jerry Brown supporters could say, "Hey, look how far we've come!" Only weeks ago, the only number they could count on began "1-800." Now, with almost no money and no organization, the former California Governor has gone from nowhere to winning about a quarter of the vote in New York and about a third in Wisconsin.
And even people who favor None Of The Above, who hope to manipulate the entry of a new candidate in a brokered convention, could say: "Look -- Six voters out of ten voted against the front-runner. That proves we need someone else if we're to beat George Bush in November."
Even so, once all sides have put their particular spin on the results, those results need to be calculated -- not in moral victories, momentum or restless dissatisfaction but rather in the inescapable arithmetic of wins, losses and delegates. And almost any way one slices the results, Bill Clinton won.
Yesterday did not give him the clarity or acceleration he must have hoped for. Dismayingly, half the New York Democratic voters told exit poll-takers that they doubted he had the integrity to serve effectively as President. Even among those who voted for him in New York, half did so with reservations.
The new results are so muddy that he'll have to slog through Pennsylvania three weeks hence and then on and on till the closing California and New Jersey primaries in June.
Still, once all yesterday's calculations are complete, Governor Clinton will have won something like 1,300 of the 2,144 delegates needed for nomination, and will have a strong start on winning many of the rest. He may not be winning cleanly; each win leaves its scars. But he's the man with the ball. Even his foes acknowledge his endurance and organization.
Those may, finally, be Bill Clinton's decisive qualities, more important than his intelligent program for the country. His endurance is likely to mock the easy pirouettes of people eager for a brokered convention that can anoint some unblemished, irresistible savior.
Abdicating to such a choice would be like ordering the fullback, muddy and bruised after driving the ball close to the goal line, to hand it over to someone, uniform still sparkling, who wasn't willing to get in the game from the start.
Paul Tsongas, who preached his own sound economic sermon for months before dropping out, deserves more consideration than that. Bill Clinton, who has resolutely stayed in and surmounted one obstacle after another, surely does.

HEADLINE: Come to Kiev. Listen to Ukraine.

BYLINE: By Volodymyr Lanovoy; Volodymyr Lanovoy is Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Economy of Ukraine.

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Ukraine has been determined to become a full member of the world community. But in the West, Ukraine is seen as unpredictable and unreasonable, particularly in its dealings with Russia.
We are often charged with reckless nationalism but the claim is seldom examined. Ukraine has been losing the propaganda war, creating unwanted and unnecessary dangers for everyone.
A principal explanation for the misperception is that news accounts and expert opinion in the West have a pro-Russian bias. For example, the $24 billion Western program of assistance announced last week was reported as aid to Russia, with little attention to Ukraine's share in it.
The explanation for this tilt is that the West has long had strong contacts with Moscow and poor contacts with Kiev. The former Soviet Government and Communist Party funneled everything through Moscow; the Government and party are gone, but the funnel remains.
The U.S. Government's presence in Russia is substantial, but not in Ukraine, which is the size of France. Hundreds of members of the international press corps are permanently stationed in Moscow, but only a handful are found in Kiev. Western business and academic ties have been almost exclusively with Russia.
There is alarm in the West when Ukraine questions the fate of tactical nuclear weapons that are being removed to Russia. But Western accounts never ask if Ukraine's questions have merit. What is happening to the weapons? Are they being destroyed, as agreed, or simply being relocated in Russia?
It surprises Ukrainians that the West, with its history of demands for verification in arms control, finds such concerns surprising. Western representatives talk only with officials in Moscow about removal of the weapons. If the West does not talk with officials in Ukraine, aren't Ukrainians right to raise their own alarms?
The West parrots the charge that Ukraine wants to create an army of 400,000 troops. It would be easy to talk with Ukrainians and find out that this would mean a more than two-thirds reduction in troops now in Ukraine. Such a rapid reduction will create enormous problems. The difficulty of finding work and housing for the former soldiers is the principal reason that the immediate reduction cannot be greater. The long-term plan is to have an even smaller army.
Western press reports have repeated the propaganda that Ukraine was unwilling to carry its share of the debt of the former Soviet Union. Anyone who has visited Kiev knows that Ukraine has always agreed to pay its share of the debts. But Ukraine also demands its share of the assets.
Nonetheless, the West cooperates when Russia takes all the assets. The Soviet seat on the U.N. Security Council is now the Russian seat. Possibly the seat could not be divided. But is this true for Soviet embassies that are now Russian embassies, for Soviet hard-currency earnings that are now Russian, for Soviet gold -- and for the Black Sea fleet, over which Boris Yeltsin reasserted control yesterday.
Perhaps the most revealing complaint associated with the Western misunderstanding of Ukraine involves its plan to replace the ruble with the hryvna, the new Ukrainian currency.
Those few Western experts who have been to Kiev and have listened are convinced that everyone, including Russia, will be better served if Ukraine moves quickly to a new currency that can support its economic reforms. Introducing a new currency is not reckless nationalism; it is responsible and necessary in order to preserve trade and develop economic relations with other countries, including Russia.
Russia must understand that it has truly independent countries on its borders. The challenge Ukraine faces is to act as responsibly as possible and to strengthen contacts with everyone, including Russia and the West, while it transforms its economy, politics and society.
The challenge for the West is to work at strengthening ties with new countries like Ukraine. Just four months ago, Ukrainians voted overwhelmingly for independence. Ukraine won't go back. Neither can the West. Throw off old habits, come to Kiev and talk with Ukrainians about Ukraine.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: What's Right With Brown's Proposed Flat Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Mr. Brown's Flat Tax: Tilted" (editorial, March 27) is itself tilted. As a practicing certified public accountant in New York more than 35 years, I have long been in favor of a flat tax. We accountants have much better things to do than continue to account for the ploys of politicians who change the tax code for their constituents' special interests; for the unions, the Government employees and all the rest who would derive advantage from loopholes.
The Robert Hall-Alvin Rabushka plan you favor is a poor solution. Once you start to have exemptions, credits and progressive rates, you again start the ball rolling for complexity and change. I find that taxpayers, generally, would much prefer to know there is one set rate with an unchangeable code to rely upon, rather than a constantly changing code, continually amended. 
 The rich would not be able to shelter a dime (particularly if a flat tax is at the source, on gross income); the poor and middle classes could depend on a constant rate.
You, like most economists and politicians, have yet to define a middle-income taxpayer. When my father was working three jobs in the 1950's, for an income of $40,000 to $50,000, we thought we were a typical middle-income family. Now, 35 years later, people still consider figures of $25,000 to $50,000 a year as middle income. If that is so, how would it have been possible for me to attend college for $5,000 to $7,500 a year in those days, and for today's "middle-income" parents to afford $18,000 to $22,000 a year for the same schooling?
Finally, a value-added tax, much in use in Europe, and much like a national sales tax, would, to me, put the burden on the rich, who are the big spenders. One might exempt the V.A.T. on the staples of life, food, clothing and shelter. To these I'd even add one additional staple -- education.
 
HAROLD L. WOHL
New York, March 27, 1992

HEADLINE: What's Right With Brown's Proposed Flat Tax;
Increase Savings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The tax law changes that the Bush Administration and the Democrats propose address short-term voter appeal. The tax packages do not focus on a way to increase savings, which will allow for long-term capital investment in production and for rebuilding infrastructure.
Inflation devalues our savings, and then savings are taxed as income. A deduction should be allowed for the yearly average rate of inflation from our gross earned income. And it is time for our elected representatives to remove the taxes on income derived from savings accounts. This is seed money for investment in a more productive future. 
 It will encourage our dwindling middle class to embrace the ideal of thrift again.
 
HAL A. DORFMAN
New York, March 15, 1992

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Are Mixed Once Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were mixed for the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor. It was the third straight week of mixed results.
"With the demand for loans down at banks, there is no pressing need to pull in more cash," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "In fact there is a bountiful amount of money, and the lending institutions are awash with cash." 
 "Low interest rates and the lack of borrowers have placed banks in a hard place," Mr. Heady said. "Rates show no sign of snapping up, since there doesn't seem to be a need to replenish funds."
 
Busy Time of Year
 April is traditionally a month high in rollovers of certificates of deposit, and low interest rates may cause some erosion in banks' customer base as depositors seek higher yields elsewhere.
Yields at New York area banks slipped, with the average yield on a money market account at 3.63 percent, down 5 basis points, and three- and six-month certificates, down a basis point, to 3.65 percent and 3.80 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Among commercial banks, the slippage was not as great, with money Market accounts down an average 3 basis points, to 3.37 percent, and six-month certificates down a basis point, to 3.55 percent. Three-month certificates, however, were up 2 basis points, to 3.48 percent.
At savings insitutions everything was down, with money market accounts off 7 basis points, to 3.89 percent, and three-month certificates at 3.85 percent, down 2 basis points. The six-month certificiate dropped a basis point, to 4.05 percent.
The biggest movers this week in the New York area included Emigrant Savings Bank, which cut 50 basis points off its money market account, to 3.5 percent, and Chemical Bank, which raised the rate on its three-month C.D. by 31 basis points, to 3.4 percent. The Bank of Tokyo in New York cut 22 basis points off its six-month certificate, to 3.4 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York area, yields were up for a six-month certificate and off only slightly on money market accounts. The average money account was down a basis point, to 3.56 percent, and a six-month C.D. rose 4 basis points, to 3.95 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction on Monday, interest rates slid further, with the average rate of three- and six-month bills at 3.95 percent and 4.02 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Peru's Maoist Drug Dealers

SERIES: Second of two articles

BYLINE: By Stephen G. Trujillo; Stephen G. Trujillo, a former Army Ranger and Green Beret, is writing a book about his work for the Drug Enforcement Administration in Peru. The views expressed in this article are his own.

 BODY:
Some well-meaning analysts still ignore the truth about Shining Path, the Maoist revolutionary movement terrorizing Peru. While the guerrillas may be ruthless, those who romanticize them claim they are untainted by the drug trade that poisons Peruvian society. This is a myth.
I know from my experience working for the Drug Enforcement Administration in Peru that the guerrillas are systematically involved in all levels of the drug trade in the Upper Huallaga Valley, where most of the world's coca is grown. 
 This state of affairs is important for the U.S. to keep in mind as it re-evaluates its policy toward Peru in light of this week's military-backed crackdown. The Peruvian military, itself implicated in drug corruption, has argued that fighting Shining Path is the key to stabilizing Peru. The U.S., which temporarily suspended assistance on Monday, has emphasized the war on drugs. As we will see, the two fronts are intricably linked.
On July 2, 1990, I was advising a detachment of the Peruvian drug police southwest of the village of Nuevo Progreso in the Upper Huallaga. We torched a drug laboratory owned by a Shining Path cell called Los Tigres.
Plates of rice on the table were still warm, the cocaine base residue in the drying filters was moist, and there were fresh notations on Maoist lesson plans left in the house. More important, ledgers were found with up-to-date payments to coca farmers and income from Colombian-dominated trafficking organizations. The guerrillas escaped into the jungle.
I have direct knowledge of other labs and secondary knowledge of many more. This and other evidence directly implicates Shining Path in the Peruvian cocaine industry.
Its control of coca cultivation in the Upper Huallaga is such that it can force farmers to plant the crop. Other peasants, called cocaleros, are ordered to grow less or more coca or to plant other crops altogether. The farmers defy the rebels at their peril.
Evidence about the guerrillas' links to the middle tiers of the Peruvian cocaine industry -- notably, the traffickers -- is more oblique. The Upper Huallaga town of Uchiza, the cocaine capital of the world, is dominated by the Peruvian Army during the day, but is surrendered to Shining Path after nightfall. The guerrillas have respected Uchiza's status as an army town, but only after they made the point that they can enter it at will and punish "enemies of the people." Traffickers who export from Uchiza's airfield and other army-controlled airstrips, give both military officers and Shining Path cadres sizable sums of money.
The local police pose no obstacle to this arrangement. One night in March 1989, the guerrillas attacked the Uchiza police post and publicly beheaded its corrupt police commanders. The police station remains vacant today. The commanders there had unwisely cheated the drug traffickers, who appealed to the only other source of justice in the Upper Huallaga Valley -- Shining Path.
Whether through arrangement or cowardice, the Peruvian Army unit about a half-mile down the road did nothing, though the soldiers must have heard the echoing gunfire and jeers of the hundreds of Uchiza citizens who gathered to watch.
The Colombian cocaine syndicates prefer dealing with the Peruvian Army, because, unlike Shining Path, it does not complicate its corruption with ideology. But the narcos have to deal with the rebels, who decided nearly a decade ago to align themselves with coca farmers and regulate drug commerce in areas they control.
Indeed, Shining Path has succeeded in intimidating the Colombian-dominated drug mafias, or firmas. The rebels have enforced limits on the number of Colombian narcos working in Upper Huallaga and imposed strict rules of behavior. The guerrillas kill those who displease them, as they did in late 1988 when they butchered 19 Colombian narcos.
Upstart revolutionary rivals have been similarly treated. Shining Path fought a rare pitched battle with elements of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement outside Tocache in July 1987. Shining Path's victory banished the smaller revolutionary movement to the Northern Huallaga.
Shining Path's domination of the firmas enables it to tax all levels of the cocaine industry in the Upper Huallaga: subsistence farmers, speculators, middlemen and lab owners, firmas and Colombian traffickers. In addition, the rebels process and refine cocaine in their own drug labs.
It is clear that Shining Path is financing its revolution with cocaine. According to conservative estimates, the rebels' annual revenue ranges from $15 million to $35 million. One Pentagon source thinks the amount might be as much as $100 million.
Revolutions are expensive, and very little foreign money reaches Shining Path, which is highly xenophobic. Yet the revolutionaries manages to finance "people's committees," which supplant legal government in many Peruvian villages and city neighborhoods, as well as the its armed component, the Guerrilla Army of the People. It can mobilize thousands of sympathizers with little notice. Without cocaine revenues, the inexorable growth of the movement would have been slower.
Shining Path's involvement with drugs is opportunistic. The rebels, unlike the military factions, are not corrupted by greed. And they will turn on the cocaine mafias one day.
Cocaine is crucial to the Peruvian economy, which is essentially bankrupt. It accounts for a conservative 35 to 45 percent of export earnings. The central bank is estimated to take in $4 million to $5 million daily in narco dollars from the streets of Lima alone.
Given Shining Path's control of drug commerce in the Upper Huallaga, the rebels could precipitate the collapse of the country's economy. The gross domestic product shrank by 22 percent from 1988 to 1990, and catastrophic inflation has wiped out what legal income the country has.
Yet Peru has not missed one payment on its international debt since the summer of 1990, when Alberto Fujimori was elected President. Even the resumption of foreign aid to Peru may not have accounted for its return to solvency. Many experts believe the country's creditors are being paid in narco-dollars, a prospect that inevitably undermines counternarcotics efforts in Peru.
We must anticipate the impact a possible Peruvian economic collapse may have on its Andean neighbors, not to mention its creditors. In Peru, such a catastrophe could presage a seizure of power by the rebels. The Shining Path is undoubtedly the most ferocious revolutionary movement in the world, and it controls the valley producing most of the world's most lucrative cash crop.
There are some people who think that the military-backed state of siege declared this week in Peru is the only way to fight Shining Path. But it is clear that a regressive military approach will not work. In 1983 and 1984, the Peruvian military killed thousands of suspected guerrillas in Ayacucho, the cradle of the revolution, and declared a victory. But Shining Path simply went underground and migrated up the Andean spine of the country. After only a brief period, the rebels had managed to infiltrate most provinces.
Today, the Peruvian military may make the mistake of unleashing a new regional "dirty war." The United States, as it weighs what to do next in Peru, must realize that the war on drugs, as it has been waged, may only abet this repression.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Aid for Yeltsin and Russians: A Package with Loose Ends

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE with THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The Russian aid package announced last week by the Bush Administration and some Western allies is less concrete and less complete than many officials made it seem, interviews with Administration officials, American lawmakers and senior officials in Europe, Japan and Canada indicate.
The officials said eagerness to show support for President Boris N. Yeltsin before his crucial encounter with the Russian Parliament this week accounted for the hasty announcement. 
 There is still considerable confusion among the allies about what the final package will contain, who will pay for what and precisely how much of the money goes beyond pledges previously made. For instance, many Group of Seven officials, saying they are uncertain how the $24 billion figure announced by the White House will be reached, are still counting on other nations, especially those in Scandinavia, to contribute.
 
'We Are in Midair'
 British officials say the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations will provide $6 billion of the package, German officials say those organizations will provide $5.5 billion, and American officials say they will contribute about $4.5 billion. Some allies, particularly the Japanese, are still chafing that the package was announced before there was final agreement on all the details.
"All the figures that the United States has provided are hypothetical," said an official in Japan's Finance Ministry.
A British Treasury official said, "If you take a snapshot, at the moment we are in midair, about three-quarters through our double spin."
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went to Brussels on March 11 for arms-control discussions, Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev of Russia informed him that at a Congress of People's Deputies scheduled for this week there would be a real campaign by "old thinkers" to attack Mr. Yeltsin's reforms. Mr. Kozyrev said if there was ever a time for the West to give Mr. Yeltsin a strong signal of support, it was before that Congress.
While that conversation was taking place in Brussels, former President Richard M. Nixon was circulating a memo describing the Administration's aid efforts as pathetic.
For weeks President Bush had shied away from foreign-aid inititives as Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate, attacked him for paying too much attention to foreign affairs. But after Mr. Nixon's memo received wide attention, Mr. Bush for the first time acknowledged publicly that he was ready to consider a large-scale aid package. In many ways, the package seemed to be intended to shore up two Presidents: President Bush and President Yeltsin.
"Nixon did not hurt," said an Administration official. "But we wanted to get it out before Yeltsin's meeting so that the impact would sink in and give him several days to take advantage of it. He needed some time to work the crowd over there."
Officials say President Bush also rushed to announce a package before the leading Democratic Presidential contender, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, criticized him for foot-dragging on Russian aid. Mr. Bush announced the package at a White House news conference last Wednesday, moments before Mr. Clinton delivered his foreign-policy address in New York.
"Of course one sees the electoral logic of the day he chose," said a German official about the timing of President Bush's announcement.
Indeed, some of the lingering confusion over the aid package and where the money will come from may stem, at least in Washington, from the Administration's reluctance in an election year to be clear about exactly what taxpayers will have to contribute.
The Bush Administration had been considering various aid programs for Russia since September, but it vastly sped up its efforts in recent weeks to meet Mr. Yeltsin's deadline.
 
New U.S. Attitude After Failed Coup
 While acknowledging that many of the numbers in the aid package are rough, Administration officials underline that the Group of Seven -- the world's seven leading industrial nations -- has made a commitment to meet the $24 billion in financing that Russia is estimated to need this year. They also say that while little of the $24 billion requires new authorizations by Group of Seven governments, much of the money will be new aid as far as Russia is concerned.
By some estimates, about $10 billion of the $11 billion pledged in bilateral aid has already been announced by Group of 7 nations, while other estimates put that figure at $6 billion. According to the Treasury Department, the aid includes a $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble, $2.5 billion in debt rescheduling, about $4.5 billion from international organization and the remainder in bilateral aid.
The Administration's attitude toward Russian aid has come a long way since July's economic summit meeting in London, when Washington opposed aid to Moscow, arguing that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was not committed to serious reforms.
But the Administration warmed up to the idea after the August coup in Moscow, when the United States and other Group of 7 countries began looking for a way to bolster Mr. Gorbachev's shaky rule by discussing a plan to reschedule the huge Soviet debt.
In the fall, Secretary Baker, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, visited Moscow and discovered that the country was rapidly running out of hard currency to pay its debts and finance crucial imports.
At the Group of Seven finance ministers' meeting in Bangkok, Thailand, in October, Mr. Brady threw his weight behind efforts to help Russia with its debt burden, but he remained frustrated that the Russians were not providing enough data to determine how much aid they needed.
 
Large-Scale Aid And I.M.F. Role
 After Mr. Yeltsin effectively took power in December, discussions about aid became more serious. During Mr. Baker's visit to Moscow in late December, Mr. Yeltsin appealed to the Secretary of State for any advice he could give on how to garner more Western aid.
Mr. Yeltsin informed Mr. Baker that he was developing a serious economic plan and intended to remove state price controls. American officials were inclined to help but were still dubious, having heard such promises before.
Still, on Jan. 3, Treasury Secretary Brady announced that the Administration had changed its mind and now supported Russia's becoming a full member of the International Monetary Fund, which includes virtually all the industrialized democracies. In late January, the Group of Seven finance ministers seconded that call, believing that the global fund should spearhead the Russian aid effort because of its expertise on economic reform.
They agreed that large-scale aid would flow once Russia joined the fund and once the fund gave its seal of approval to Moscow's reforms. Their hope was that Russia could become a member when the fund held its spring meeting in Washington in late April.
On Feb. 2, President Bush and Mr. Yeltsin met at Camp David in early February, and Mr. Bush and the Treasury Department became more convinced of Mr. Yeltsin's seriousness about economic reform. Secretary Brady also came away impressed with how eager Mr. Yeltsin's chief economic adviser, Yegor T. Gaidar, was to press ahead with reform.
 
A Financing Scheme With a 60's Fund
 Mr. Yeltsin was clearly disappointed that President Bush was not ready to give any firm promises on aid after the meeting. When Mr. Yeltsin went to Canada that evening, he grumbled about unspecified countries that "talk and talk" but "for the past five months we have been asking for help, and it hasn't happened."
"Camp David was a pivotal time," said a senior Treasury official. "It was clear that Yeltsin was putting a real program into place."
It was about that time that American officials started thinking that aid should be not just debt rescheduling, but also aid to help finance crucial imports like medicine, machinery and spare parts.
A few days later Secretary Baker, while heading for Frankfurt for a Western airlift of food and medicine for Russia and other republics, tentatively broached the idea with reporters that the State Department was exploring support of a fund to stabilize Russia's economy. Administration officials say Mr. Baker, who had been the most forward-leaning on helping the Russians, floated the idea to prod the the White House and the Treasury. But Treasury officials say they were already working hard on Russian aid and needed no prodding.
On Feb. 27, the Group of 7 deputy finance ministers held a crucial meeting in Germany, where they began sketching details of an aid package that Russia would receive after joining the global lender. At the meeting, the Americans proposed a novel way of financing the $6 billion ruble stabilization fund the Russians had asked for.
In the 1960's, 10 major industrial countries set up a fund now having $23 billion -- known as the general arrangements to borrow -- that they could draw from to help stabilize their currencies, and the Americans proposed that $6 billion from that fund be used to stabilize Russia's ruble.
 
Tokyo Criticizes 'Rough Numbers'
 The Group of Seven embraced that plan because Washington, Bonn and Tokyo were not hungering to appropriate $6 billion in new funds to underwrite the risky currency.
The momentum for a package picked up in March. In addition to the Nixon memo and Secretary Baker's meeting with the Russian Foreign Minister, the American Ambassador to Moscow, Robert Strauss, returned to Washington to lobby Congress and Mr. Bush to provide large-scale aid. And several key Senators pressed Mr. Bush to move aggressively on such aid.
All those factors seemed to finally spur the Administration into action. Mr. Baker had the State Department begin drafting a legislative package that would combine all of the American contributions, those already committed and some new ones.
Behind the scenes, the Group of Seven finance ministries were working feverishly to put together an aid package before Mr. Yeltsin confronted Parliament. They finally got the monetary fund and Russia to provide some data on how much for balance-of-payments support Russia needed to finance its debt service and crucial imports like medicine and spare parts. The monetary fund said Russia needed a minimum of $12 billion in aid, and perhaps as much as $18 billion.
On March 27, the Group of Seven's deputy finance ministers met in Paris, where they spent a whole day discussing a Russian aid package. They discussed terms for Russia's joining the monetary fund and they approved the $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble. They also tallied up how much direct aid each of the seven nations would contribute
According to figures provided by Group of Seven officials, Bonn is to provide $3 billion of the $11 billion in bilateral aid, Washington and Tokyo will provide $2 billion each, Italy $1.2 billion, Canada $1.1 billion and Britain $400 million. That comes to $9.7 billion before including France's contribution, which has not been disclosed.
 
Japan's Reluctance And Island Dispute
 Group of Seven officials say that at the meeting, the Germans and Americans said that they would announce aid packages a few days later to give Mr. Yeltsin some support before the Russian Parliament met. Bonn and Washington said the aid package should also be timed to the monetary fund's endorsement of Russia's reform plan, which the fund announced on March 31.
Nonetheless, once President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany made the packages public, Japanese officials said that the announcement was premature because, in their view, not all the details were hammered out.
American, German and British officials suggest that Japan does not want to appear as if it is being pushed into backing Russia. Tokyo has been reluctant to grant huge aid until Russia agrees to return the Kurile Islands that the Soviet Union seized toward the end of World War II.
"To a certain extent, everyone is addressing their domestic political audience," said a British official. "They are addressing the gallery."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Heard by Few, Clinton Speech Shows Candidates' Quandary

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
About 12 minutes into his victory speech in Manhattan Tuesday night, Gov. Bill Clinton exhorted a crowd of cheering supporters: "Tonight when you go home, when the celebration stops, when you finish looking at the numbers and reveling in the success, in the quiet moments before you go to bed, remember that nothing has yet been done to change the lives of the people, and our battle has just begun."
With this exhortation, and indeed, with his entire 14-minute prepared speech, Mr. Clinton seemed to be trying to chart a more high-minded course for the next phase of his campaign, reviving the themes of hope and hard work with which he began the race six months ago. 
 But except for several hundred supporters and the throngs of reporters who attended his victory celebration at the Ritz, very few people actually heard the Arkansas Governor's remarks. Four minutes into his speech, only the Cable News Network and C-Span still had their cameras trained on Mr. Clinton. Five minutes after that, only C-Span was left.
The clipping of Mr. Clinton's speech into progressively smaller sound bites, until on NBC's "Today" show it was reduced to "I love Wisconsin and Minnesota and Kansas, and I really love New York!" is illustrative of the difficulties that Presidential candidates face in communicating a sustained thought to voters.
 
Chances Are Few
 Some of the most revealing coverage of the campaign has come from those forums, like the novel one-on-one debate staged by Phil Donahue on Monday, in which the two main Democratic Presidential candidates were simply allowed to rattle on uninterrupted. But it is rare that the candidates have the chance, either on the air or in print, to speak to the voters for a sustained time in their own voices, unless those voters happen to be C-Span junkies.
For those die-hards who did tune in to C-Span's post-primary broadcast Tuesday night or the rebroadcast at 7 A.M. yesterday, both Mr. Clinton and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California demonstrated a grace and eloquence that often seemed to be missing in the rancorous New York primary.
Mr. Brown used his concession speech, which was broadcast live by WABC as well as the two stations that carried Mr. Clinton's speech, to explain in a more compelling way than he had during the rest of the New York campaign just what he was doing in the Presidential race.
"I want to reiterate this is not about one person," Mr. Brown said. "It is not about a candidate reaching for some brass ring of ambition. It's about ordinary people taking back what belongs to all of us, and that's our democracy, it's our country, it's our dreams, it's our ideals."
"A woman in Laconia said it better than -- Laconia, New Hampshire -- said it better than anything I could say," he continued. "She said to me, as I walked out of the door of her house, she said: 'Governor, you know how the system works. You have a voice that can be heard. You have to speak for me. Will you promise me that?' And I told her -- I looked her right in the eye, and I said, 'I will speak for you, and I will speak for people like you who don't have a voice that can be heard.'
In his speech, Mr. Clinton spoke in the tones of a man who believed himself to be the Democratic nominee. He used his address to reach out to those Democrats who had voted against him, praising opponents he had just recently ridiculed and stressing their unity of purpose.
"Tonight every person who voted in the Democratic primary -- every person -- voted for change," he said. "Every vote for Jerry Brown was a vote that recognized the power of technology through his first-derided and now respected 800 number that the power of technology can give dignity to ordinary people and can give the average voter a say."
"Every vote for Paul Tsongas tonight was a vote for change," he went on. "A vote that respected his courage in getting into this race when George Bush was at over 70 percent in the approval polls, a vote that recognizes these are serious economic problems we face that require a serious response.
"Tonight I ask you to reach out to those who did not vote for me but voted for change. We want to be their campaign, too. From Manhattan, Kansas, to Manhattan Island, people said tonight: 'We want Americans to be able to earn a decent living, to walk on safe streets, to educate their children and to have them do better than they did. We want our country to win again and to be one again.' "
Marvin Kalb, director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on Press, Politics and Public Policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, was watching ABC's primary special Tuesday night when Mr. Clinton appeared live before a giant flag and started his speech. Mr. Kalb said he saw that the Governor, in an uncharacteristic move, was reading from notes.
"I assumed this was a significant statement -- something that had resonance," he said.
But, Mr. Kalb complained, he never had a chance to find out. After about three minutes, the station cut away from the speech to more analysis of the primary results from New York, Wisconsin and Kansas. Yesterday morning's papers made only brief mention of the speech. Mr. Kalb said he called his cable television company yesterday and added C-Span to the list of stations he received.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Pennsylvania;
Quirky State Is Setting For Next Primary Battle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 8

 BODY:
The Presidential candidates are now turning their attention to Pennsylvania, the next state to hold primaries, and one that has a cranky, pessimistic and unpredictable electorate.
This is the state, after all, that just last November elected its first Democrat to the United States Senate in 30 years. Harris Wofford, a relatively unknown state official when he was appointed to fill the seat of the late John Heinz, rode a wave of anti-incumbent sentiment in a special election to defeat former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, a Republican closely linked to President Bush's domestic policies. 
 The engineers of Mr. Wofford's upset victory, James Carville and Paul E. Begala, are also top strategists for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. That team also ran Gov. Robert P. Casey's two successful campaigns here in 1986 and 1990.
The primary is scheduled for April 28, but there is a possibility that it may be postponed as a result of litigation carrying over delays associated with the court-ordered remapping of Congressional districts. A Federal court held a hearing here today on the issue.
 
Tsongas as Wild Card
 Mr. Clinton and his main rival who is actively campaigning, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, have just begun to vigorously court Pennsylvania. But former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts is also on the ballot, and political experts say he could be influential if he re-entered the race.
"Tsongas is really the wild card here," said Michael L. Young, a professor of politics and public affairs at Pennsylvania State University at Harrisburg, "but I don't think he will be a serious factor unless he actively campaigns."
The conservative cast of the Democratic electorate may help Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, he said.
But it was here -- in front of the Liberty Bell -- that Mr. Brown announced his candidacy last October, and some analysts say he still has a chance to do well in Pennsylvania, which prides itself as being independent.
 
Fond of Protest Votes
 "We like to stage protest votes at the end of the primary process," Professor Young said. He noted that in the state's 1980 primaries, Pennsylvanians voted for Senator Edward M. Kennedy and George Bush after Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan had all but clinched their parties' nominations.
Pennsylvania, the nation's fifth-most-populous state, has a conservative-leaning electorate of 5.3 million registered voters. Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by 330,000, but Republicans have been narrowing that margin for years, and many registered Democrats vote for moderate Republicans. In surveys, half of the voters identify themselves as conservatives, one of three call themselves liberals and the rest call themselves moderates.
The issues of most concern to Pennsylvania voters, according to survey data, are jobs and unemployment, the economy and health care, which, poll takers say, is an issue that captures specific concern about health care costs as well as a general uneasiness about the economy. The recession had hit the state hard; Pennsylvania's unemployment rate in March was 7.2 percent, slightly less than the national rate of 7.3 percent.
The lingering recession has increased frustration with incumbent politicians and any candidate who sounds like the incumbents. "We're still seeing a very strong anti-incumbent feeling, perhaps because Pennsylvania voters, by a three-to-one margin, think their own financial situation will worsen next year," said G. Terry Madonna, director of politics and public affairs at Millersville University of Pennsylvania in Lancaster.
Mr. Madonna, who polled 673 likely primary voters over the last weekend, also found that Mr. Clinton has a 13 percentage point lead over Mr. Brown but that 31 percent of the voters remained undecided. Mr. Tsongas was not included in the survey. The statewide poll, sponsored by Millersville University and WHTM-TV in Harrisburg, was conducted by telephone from April 2 to 4; it has a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
The two big voting blocks here are labor union members, with about 22 percent of the voters, and the elderly, with about 20 percent of the voters. Blacks make up about 9 percent of the voters and Jews about 3 percent; both groups are overwhelmingly registered as Democrats.
Mr. Brown appears to have attracted more labor support than Mr. Clinton, who is meeting with local A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials here tonight, but none of the major unions have made endorsements yet.
As for Pennsylvania's Republicans, they consistently give Mr. Bush a higher approval rating than he receives nationally. In last weekend's survey, Republican respondents gave Mr. Bush a 66 percent approval rating, compared to a 26 percent approval rating for Patrick J. Buchanan. "This is Bush country," Mr. Madonna said.
In the last decade, Pennsylvania Democrats gave primary victories to Michael S. Dukakis over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in 1988, to Walter F. Mondale over Gary Hart in 1984 and to Senator Kennedy over Jimmy Carter in 1980. But in four of the last five Presidential general elections, Pennsylvania helped elect Republicans. This is an old tradition for Pennsylvania, which, for example, was the only big state that stuck with Herbert Hoover over Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
The tilt in voter registration toward the Republican Party may reflect a shift in the Pennsylvania economy. The state may conjure up images of coal or steel, but Pennsylvania now has more jobs in research and high-technology areas than it does in manufacturing. And agriculture is the largest industry in the state, with 3.7 million of its 11.8 million people living in rural areas.
In the 1988 primary, Mr. Dukakis defeated Mr. Jackson by 67 percent to 27 percent, but Mr. Jackson carried Philadelphia, where a quarter of the state's Democrats live. Mr. Brown, who has said he would like Mr. Jackson as a running mate, could benefit from Mr. Jackson's popularity.
At stake in this month's primary are 110 Democratic delegates and 63 Republican delegates. But Pennsylvania, which has many media markets at some distance from each other, is a hard place to campaign. "Candidates end up spending a lot of money," said David L. Buffington, publisher of a political newsletter in Harrisburg, "for a relatively small number of delegates."

HEADLINE: Editors Take On Conflicts of News Staff Diversity

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The nation's newspaper editors, a group overwhelmingly white and male, got some unusually frank instruction today in the complex task of communicating effectively with their increasingly diverse staffs.
"Diversity is at the soul of what we are all about," said David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Miami Herald, who is president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which includes about 900 active and retired daily newspaper editors. 
 But today's program at the group's annual convention, "Face to Face: Race and Gender Communication in the Newsroom," marked a new candor in addressing the frustration, resentment and inadvertent miscommunication that diversity of race, sex and sexual orientation can create for editors and reporters.
Tom Kochman, who wrote "Black & White: Styles in Conflict," (University of Chicago Press, 1983) said the dialogue between a new black reporter and a white editor could easily be predicted because of different starting assumptions.
Mr. Kochman said the black reporter would probably assume the editor was racist unless the editor proved he was not; the white editor would probably assume he was not viewed as racist unless he proved himself to be.
Without understanding each other's assumptions, an editor and a reporter can inadvertently be deeply offensive to the other.
The society has reported that 9.4 percent of the nation's newsroom employees are black, Hispanic, Asian American or American Indian journalists, as against 8.7 percent last year and 4 percent in 1978.
Such an increase at a time when there was an overall decline in newsroom jobs because of the recession indicates the importance of minorities at many of the nation's newspapers in recent years. But more than half the newspapers, mostly smaller papers, have no minority staff members.
While the increased presence of racial minorities, women and homosexuals in a newsroom may have broadened a newspaper's grasp of its community, the editors acknowledge that the internal communication problems have been largely unaddressed.
 
Problems Raised Anonymously
 As part of the program, editors from around the country were invited to raise questions anonymously about the problems they face in their newsrooms that in many cases they feel cannot be directly broached.
The 38 questions, which were distributed to the editors to fuel further discussion in their own newsrooms, included a black female news editor's complaints about Hispanic journalists and a gay Hispanic city editor's demand to know how long homosexuals "are doomed to second-class lives" at newspapers.
One of the two questions taken up came from someone identified only as a white male editor in Pennsylvania. He said: "I know the sad racial history of our country and I want to do what I can to fix what's broken. But why is it that many black journalists are so defensive when we try to help them improve their work? Editors are supposed to critique the work of reporters. But at our paper, if you do it with a black reporter you can get accused of racism. All the editors are walking on eggs. Blacks say, 'Look, just treat us like everyone else.' But when we do, we get hammered. What can we do about this?"
Dorothy Gilliam, a black columnist at The Washington Post who was part of a panel, said the black reporters would probably not feel threatened by criticism if the editor had demonstrated in other ways he was not racist.
Mr. Kochman said that airing the conflict between the editor and the reporter would probably be much more unsettling for the white than for the black. He said blacks, culturally, are accustomed to such verbal conflicts whereas "anglos," who he described as the descendants of Anglo-Saxon ancestry, usually avoid them lest they be denounced as racist.
Deborah Tannen, a professor of linguistics at Georgetown University who wrote "You Just Don't Understand: Women & Men in Conversation" (William Morrow & Company, 1990), said that men and women, blacks and whites, and many other diverse groups have difficulty communicating because of deep cultural differences that can easily be misunderstood.
"You are told, 'How dare you treat me different, I'm the same as you; How dare you treat me the same, I'm different from you,' " Ms. Tannen said, characterizing the double bind editors sometimes face.
She added, "In some cases, it is true that anything you say can be offensive."
But Robert J. Haiman, the program's organizer who is president of The Poynter Institute, a journalism education organization in St. Petersburg, Fla., said that open, even angry, discussion was essential if there is to be real progress.
"Unless we raise the questions, there is little chance to get the problems resolved," Mr. Haiman said.
