HEADLINE: U.S. Chip Makers Stem the Tide In Trade Battles With Japanese

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 8

 BODY:
American semiconductor manufacturers, the bedrock of the nation's high-technology industry, have stopped the Japanese erosion of their competitiveness and might be poised to make a comeback after a decade of decline, according to a growing number of industry executives and analysts.
The new assessment represents a sharp contrast from the prevailing view five or six years ago, when many executives and analysts were saying that the American producers of silicon chips were in danger of being driven to extinction by the Japanese. 
 That prospect raised concern among Government and industry officials because semiconductors are critical for national defense, given their use in advanced electronic weaponry. And since chips are the basic building blocks of computers, telephones and robots, there was concern that if the American chip industry faltered, it would weaken the entire electronics industry, one of the nation's largest employers.
For now, the American share of the world semiconductor market has leveled off at just under 40 percent, up from recent levels but down from more than 60 percent in the 1970's. For the first time in years, there was even a gain in 1990. And some executives expect to see gains for 1991 and 1992 as well, although preliminary figures for 1991 do not show this. Meanwhile, the Japanese share of the world market peaked at 51 percent in 1988 and has dropped a bit since.
 
Equipment Makers Gain
 American companies that make the equipment used in semiconductor production also appeared to be making a comeback. Today in Washington, Sematech, the semiconductor industry consortium, and VLSI Research Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., announced that leading American makers of such production equipment registered an increase in 1991 worldwide market share to nearly 41 percent from 38 percent in 1990.
The big question now is whether the American semiconductor industry can actually gain ground or whether, after a hiatus, it will begin sliding again. Many executives and analysts say they expect a stalemate, with neither the Japanese nor the American producers gaining much ground.
Still, even that would be good news, given the trouble some other industries, like consumer electronics and automobiles, have had in stemming a slide.
"I don't consider it a comeback, it's a stabilization," said Andrew S. Grove, president of the Intel Corporation, a major American chip producer. Still, he added, "I think the auto executives would kill for this."
Indeed, the playing field today seems vastly different than in the middle 1980's, when Japanese companies had driven most American companies out of the business of making the most widely used chip and when even the Central Intelligence Agency concluded that the American industry could not compete in its present form.
The American resurgence stems partly from a shift in the economics of the business in a way that favors products that the American companies specialize in. Also, American chip quality has vastly improved. And Government programs to help the industry, such as the Sematech consortium and the semiconductor trade agreement with Japan, have played some role as well.
But the main factor appears to be a victory of sorts of brain over brawn, as American companies have continued to lead and even increase their lead in cleverly designed and highly profitable chips. These include microprocessors that serve as the central calculating chips in personal computers, as well as chips that specialize in displaying images on a computer screen, processing sound and video signals for computers and transmitting information.
The Japanese companies have surged to dominate the market for memory chips, which store information in computers. But they require huge investments and produce little profits. Surprisingly, the Japanese have not been able to follow up their success in that business by moving strongly into others kinds of chips.
Instead, the Japanese find themselves overly dependent on the market for memory chips. The result is that many Japanese companies are believed to be losing money in their semiconductor operations and may no longer be able to maintain their high investments.
"It is possible to build a case now that you couldn't make five years ago -- that the American semiconductor industry is in a better position than the Japanese," said Michael Borrus, an industry expert at the University of California at Berkeley.
 
Difficult Future Is Still Forecast
 But others say danger still lies ahead. Ian M. Ross, chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, said the recent rise in American market share and fall in Japanese share stemmed largely from declines in the prices of memory chips, which hurt Japanese companies disproportionately.
In a report issued in February, the committee, which was formed to develop a national strategy to help the industry, concluded that the American industry "continues to be under intense pressure from its international competitors."
The report also said that Japanese companies continued to heavily outspend American producers on research and capital equipment, an indication that the Japanese could surge ahead again in the future. Moreover, the primary customers of the American chip companies, the American makers of computers, telephones and other electronic equipment, have been losing market share.
Even when they are successful in selling chips, many American companies, particularly the smaller ones, do not make them. Rather, they contract out manufacturing -- often to the Japanese. In the last half of the 1980's, American employment in the semiconductor industry dropped by 27,000 jobs, or about 10 percent.
But even the most pessimistic say the situation is not as bad as six or seven years ago, when most American companies were abandoning the market for the main type of memory chip, the dynamic random access memory , or D-RAM, and it seemed the Japanese were unstoppable.
Back then, the American Government, prodded by the industry, took several steps to try to help. In 1986, it signed a trade agreement with Japan intended to raise prices of Japanese chips and help increase sales of American chips in Japan. The next year, the United States Government agreed to contribute $100 million a year to Sematech in a move to improve the manufacturing skills of the American industry. And in 1988, Congress formed the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors to draft a comprehensive strategy for the industry.
 
Government Help: Some Falls Short
 None of these programs have fulfilled all of their goals. Sematech is credited with helping to make chip makers more competitive. But the consortium got off to a slow start and a couple of members are now dropping out. Sematech, they say, does not satisfy their needs.
The trade agreement has also fallen short of insuring that 20 percent of the chips sold in Japan come from American and other non-Japanese companies. And virtually none of the recommendations of the advisory committee has been carried out.
T. J. Rodgers, president and chief executive of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation in San Jose, said the American industry had stabilized itself through its own efforts and that Government assistance was neither necessary nor effective.
"Nobody does anything because of the U.S. Government and Sematech," Dr. Rodgers said. "You do it to survive."
Indeed, he said, most of the sharp decline in American market share ended by 1985, before Sematech was formed and the trade pact signed.
Still, the trade agreement has helped raise the American share of Japan's market from 8.5 percent in 1985 to 12.5 percent in 1991. That 4 percent gain is equivalent to nearly $1 billion in sales.
Similarly, the trade agreement, while setting floor prices for certain Japanese chips, came too late to keep most American companies from dropping out of the D-RAM business but it was not too late to help American companies that were making another type of chip, known as Eprom's, which stands for erasable programmable read-only memory.
Indeed, after declining for several years, American market share in Eprom's began rising precisely in 1986, the year the agreement was signed. Some experts say that the trade agreement may have also had a more subtle effect in persuading the Japanese to be less aggressive.
To some extent, the decline of the American industry was always overstated. That is because the market share figures do not include the International Business Machines Corporation, which is probably the nation's largest chip maker for its own products. The market share figures also measure sales in dollars, and the yen has about doubled in value against the dollar in the last decade. If a constant figure were used to convert yen to dollars, the gains in Japanese market share would not be as great.
 
An American Edge In Innovative Design
 The main reason analysts are hopeful about the prospects for the American industry is that it has maintained the edge in innovative designs of chips for computing, displaying graphics and transmitting data.
Most significant has been Intel, which is by far the leading producer of microprocessors, the central calculating chip in personal computers. Intel has declined to license its most advanced designs to others. Its semiconductor sales have increased from $1 billion in 1986 to about $4 billion in 1991, a gain that alone is responsible for the American market share being about 5 percent higher than it otherwise would be.
American companies have also pioneered in several new fast-growing markets. Intel has more than 80 percent of the market for flash memories, a new, fast-growing type of memory chip that could one day replace computer disk drives. Another fast-growing product area is chips that users can program themselves. These field programmable logic chips are pioneered by Silicon Valley start-ups such as Xilinx Inc. and the Altera Corporation, both in San Jose.
Clever design and management is helping some small American companies make up for lack of size. LSI Logic in Milpitas, Calif., a maker of customized chips, said that it could now produce chips smaller than those produced by the Japanese. LSI uses computer simulations, rather than huge production runs, to hone its manufacturing techniques.
Cypress Semiconductor, which competes in high-speed memory chips, gives factory managers an ownership stake in the factory. That gives them a financial incentive to economize.
Micron Technology of Boise, Idaho, is managing to remain profitable in the D-RAM business, the Japanese bastion. The secret is that Micron designs its chips to be smaller and to require fewer manufacturing steps than those of its competitors.
Japanese companies, meanwhile, have by and large been unable to move into some new areas, although it is too early to count them out. They have remained mainly producers of memory chips, as well as some simpler microcontrollers used to control cars and consumer appliances.
"The Japanese don't know where to go," said Lane Mason, an analyst at Dataquest, a market research firm in San Jose. "They have not been able to follow the new markets."
 
Koreans Duplicate The Japanese Leap
 A big part of the problem is that Korean companies are now duplicating what the Japanese did a decade ago, building huge plants and competing by offering low prices in a bid to gain market share.
Samsung, the leading Korean company, came from nowhere to become one of the largest suppliers of D-RAM's in the world. It is the leading D-RAM supplier in the United States, according to Victor de Dios, who runs the D-RAM Market Advisor service in Newark, Calif. Mr. de Dios estimates that in the American market, Japanese suppliers saw their share of the D-RAM market drop from 52 percent in the first quarter of 1991 to 45 percent by the fourth quarter.
Dr. Rodgers of Cypress said the Japanese companies once enjoyed a huge lead on American companies in terms of the percentage of working chips on a wafer of silicon. While these figures, known as yield, are closely guarded secrets, Dr. Rodgers estimated that in the early 1980's, 75 percent of the chips produced by Japanese companies might have worked, compared with only 25 percent for American companies. That meant that an American company would need a $300 million factory to produce the same number of working chips that a Japanese company could produce in a $100 million factory.
That edge was multiplied by the fact that Japanese companies could raise money at 4 percent interest rates while American companies were paying as much as 12 percent. Now, he said, American company yields are nearly as high as those of the Japanese. And the difference in the cost of capital has dissipated as Japanese interest rates have risen and American rates have fallen.
"I'm not sure we can recover the lead," Dr. Rodgers said. "But are we going to be better off in the semiconductor industry at the end of the 90's than we are at the beginning? I truly believe we are."

HEADLINE: G.M., Missing $436 Million, Accuses L.I. Dealer of Fraud

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I. April 8

 BODY:
Life in this Suffolk County village hasn't been quite the same since sheriff's deputies began removing 700 new cars from John McNamara's sprawling dealership on Friday and General Motors accused him of fraud in obtaining hundreds of millions in loans from the company.
As a car dealer, developer, newspaper publisher, Republican Party insider and philanthropist, there was no one to match Mr. McNamara, the "Mr. Big" of this community and a quintesentially American small-town entrepreneur. 
 "Everybody is abuzz," said Frank Frasca, the village's Mayor. "There are rumors flying all over the place, but nobody really knows what is going on."
 
A Court Order
 For now, all that is clear about Mr. McNamara's problems can be found in papers filed in civil court by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which charged him with obtaining loans to finance cars that did not exist, falsifying documents and failing to divulge his business dealings.
General Motors said Mr. McNamara owes it $436 million, and it obtained a court order from State Supreme Court in Hauppauge to have his dealership, McNamara Buick-Pontiac, shut down and 700 cars and trucks in his lot, worth $13 million, removed.
Neither Mr. McNamara, 52 years old, nor his lawyer, J. Timothy Shea, returned repeated telephone calls today seeking comment.
The case, however, may raise as many questions about the world's largest auto maker as it does about its dealer here.
In its court papers, the company said that Mr. McNamara had presented it with false documents saying he had shipped new cars overseas but that the cars were never delivered to anyone. G.M. declined today through a spokeswoman in Detroit, Lynda Koskinski, to say why such a vast amount of credit had been extended to a single dealer.
It was unclear from the company's court documents how the huge debt that G.M. said Mr. McNamara owes had piled up. If the money had been borrowed recently, it could have financed more than 20,000 vehicles.
Even among the nation's largest car dealers, "that amount of outstanding credit is extraordinary," said Ted Orme, a spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association, a trade group. Normally, he said, credit subsidiaries of the large auto makers extend loans to their dealers only for the purchase of cars to be delivered to customers, and sometimes for improvements for new shops, showrooms or other properties related to the business.
People in Port Jefferson and the surrounding communities that meander along Long Island's North Shore can only wonder what will come next. Some compare the drama to the plot of "It's a Wonderful Life," the Frank Capra film in which Mr. Potter, a malevolent tycoon who owns most of a small town, forces its savings and loan association, run by a beleaguered but honest man played by Jimmy Stewart, into insolvency.
"I'd say John McNamara comes closer to the personality of Jimmy Stewart," Mayor Frasca said. "I'm sure he is a shrewd businessman, but I've never seen him take advantage of anybody."
 
Favored Project
 No one denies that Mr. McNamara has been a leading light in Port Jefferson philanthropy. In his favored project, officials here say, he has been the chief contributor to Hope House Ministries, a home for wayward boys. He has made large cash contributions and been the host of an annual fund-raising cocktail party.
But unlike the plot of "It's a Wonderful Life," in which an adoring citizenry comes to the aid of its business leader, chipping in dimes and dollar bills, the case here seems unlikely to reach a simple, heartwarming end.
Whatever the outcome, Mr. McNamara's encounter with the law comes after a decade in which he invested huge amounts outside the automobile dealership, which he took over from his father in the early 1980's. He accumulated a portfolio of holdings that checker the Suffolk landscape.
As a real-estate investor and developer, he is the largest owner of stores, apartment houses and condominiums in Port Jefferson, and applied to build more than 5,000 condominiums in the town of Brookhaven, which includes Port Jefferson, during the 1980's.
Though most of the condominiums have been built, Mr. McNamara postponed construction of many when the real-estate market sank into deep recession, starting in 1988. "I just can't see any major impact" of his legal problems on the area's real-estate market, Mayor Frasca said, adding that Mr. McNamara "doesn't have much of anything in the pipeline."
Mr. McNamara's battles with conservation groups in Suffolk County are still smoldering, however.
Critics say he has used his political influence, enhanced by generous campaign contributions to most of the Republican Party's elected officials in Brookhaven, and his business clout to gain approval for his projects.
"There was always the strong indication he used undue political influence," said Richard L. Amper Jr. executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, one of several environmental groups that have battled Mr. McNamara over his real-estate development proposals.
Some here are still angered by his purchase in 1986 of The Port Jefferson Record, the village's weekly newspaper, and The North Shore Record, a sister publication. Mr. McNamara sold the newspapers last year after an unsuccessful effort to expand the publishing venture to nine separate weeklies in Suffolk, and in the face of widespread criticism that he was using his newspapers to promote his pro-development policies.
"To my knowledge, there was no effort to influence" the news coverage of the papers by Mr. McNamara, said Kathren Schmoller, managing editor of The Port Jefferson Record, who worked as a lower-ranking editor while Mr. McNamara was publisher.
During the peak of the region's real-estate boom in the mid-1980's, Mr. McNamara won approvals for projects that were opposed by officials in Suffolk County and endorsed by those in the town of Brookhaven. They include Rocky Point Meadows, a 450-unit condominium project adjacent to a state nature preserve, and another major condominium complex, next to the Grucci fireworks plant in Yaphank.
Spokesmen for both the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Manhattan and the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn said they would not comment on a report in Newsday today that they had initiated a criminal investigation into Mr. McNamara's affairs. The Suffolk County District Attorney, James M. Catterson Jr., said his office was not now investigating the case, saying it had received no complaint from General Motors or others to warrant a criminal investigation.
And in Detroit, Ms. Koskinski of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation said the company would adhere "to a long tradition of not violating the confidential relationships we have with our dealers."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Sidelines;
Tsongas II: Ex-Senator Ponders Revival

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas was pondering a re-entry yesterday after his surprising second-place finish in New York's Democratic primary, but many Democrats said they were hard put to see how a revived Tsongas candidacy could wrest the nomination from Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
As a result, some of Mr. Tsongas's aides said yesterday that they expected the former Massachusetts Senator to decide against re-entering the race, although they cautioned that he is known for last-minute and closely held decisions. 
 There was a spirited case being made for Tsongas II, with some of his allies arguing that a revived campaign could further his influence in the party and keep the former Senator well-positioned in the event of a Clinton collapse.
Mr. Tsongas is expected to announce his decision at a news conference today.
Despite the strong showing of his sidelines campaign this week, Mr. Tsongas would face numerous obstacles, many Democrats said yesterday. His campaign is carrying a debt of about $400,000, according to his campaign manager, Dennis Kanin.
And before Mr. Tsongas suspended his campaign on March 19 he was decisively defeated across the South and in Illinois and Michigan, suggesting more serious flaws in his candidacy than a simple lack of money.
For example, while Mr. Tsongas often ran well with affluent, educated suburbanites, he had difficulties with core Democratic constituencies like blacks and organized labor, which will play an important role in the coming contest in Pennsylvania.
On top of all this, Mr. Clinton is leading Mr. Tsongas in delegates by better than 2 to 1, with only 17 primaries and caucuses remaining and with party rules of strict proportional representation that make it extremely difficult to overcome such leads.
Mr. Tsongas has been given those particular facts of life by many Democrats, including Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, who spoke to him Tuesday night.
 
'Mathematical Realities'
 "I did talk to him," Mr. Brown said, "about the mathematical realities of this thing, which are that Bill Clinton's got about 1,400 delegates; that it's certainly impossible for anyone not in the race to accumulate sufficient delegates, and that it's virtually impossible for anyone in the race, other than Bill Clinton, to accumulate a majority before the convention."
Mr. Brown, who has long said that an early end to the nominating battle would be a big plus for his party in November, asserted that his conversation "wasn't an attempt to encourage or discourage" Mr. Tsongas, but rather "a good, open conversation about the lay of the land."
David Wilhelm, the Clinton campaign manager, said there were "no behind-the-scenes negotiations" between his camp and Mr. Tsongas's, but added: "We try to keep the lines of communications open. Typically, it takes the form of friends talking to friends."
Mr. Wilhelm was taking a careful but cordial tone yesterday. "We respect him and we're not going to thrust ourselves into the middle of that very personal decision," the Clinton campaign manager said of Mr. Tsongas.
But Mr. Wilhelm added, "It's definitely true that if he were to get into the race, it would prolong a process that I believe would ultimately lead to a Bill Clinton nomination nevertheless."
 
'Spoiler' Role Debated
 When Mr. Tsongas left the race last month he said he had no desire to be a "spoiler" by pressing a doomed crusade for the nomination that would only end up helping President Bush in the fall. Mr. Kanin, the Tsongas campaign manager, suggested last night that much of the internal debate revolved around that issue.
"I think you've got to decide what being a spoiler means," Mr. Kanin said. "If you have the view -- and I'm not saying Paul has this view -- that the reservations the electorate has about the most likely nominee make it unlikely that this person would win the election, perhaps you're not being a spoiler by making it possible for the party to choose someone else."
This argument reflects the concern among many in the party about Mr. Clinton's image among the electorate, including the doubts and reservations about his integrity that many polls have found.
Mr. Kanin added that while this argument had been made to Mr. Tsongas, "I'm not sure that's an argument he subscribes to."
Mr. Tsongas is hearing other rationales for reviving his campaign. Some of his allies assert that he could return with a scaled-back campaign that would, at the very least, carry his message forward.
The former Senator campaigned as a "pro-business liberal" who combined the party's liberal stance on social issues with such economic measures as support for a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment.
 
Power to Shape the Party
 Nathan Landow, the state Democratic chairman in Maryland, a prominent fund-raiser and a Tsongas supporter, said he believed that returning to the race would increase Mr. Tsongas's power to shape the party "at the negotiating table in New York," where the Democrats will hold their national convention in July.
Ted Van Dyk, an adviser to Mr. Tsongas, said he had urged the former Senator to consider a re-entry, but added: "He's got to be committed; it would be painful. It would be a knock-down, drag-out battle."
He said his impression was that Mr. Tsongas was most worried about seeing his message fade away.
Mr. Brown, the Democratic chairman, said he had told Mr. Tsongas that "I didn't think we could win without him and his supporters," and wanted to see the former Senator take an active role "in the fall campaign and in the convention."
Amid all the political maneuvering, Tsongas aides said he was simply trying to analyze Tuesday's vote. There were signs that much of it in New York was rooted in protest: 48 percent of the Tsongas voters categorized themsleves as disliking the other candidates, compared to 24 percent who said they liked their candidate but with reservations, and 27 percent who said they strongly favored their candidates.
Jim Ruvolo, a Democratic national committeeman from Ohio, said: "There will always be a significant vote for somebody else, and Tsongas is more palatable than Jerry Brown, so his vote may be higher. But it will not stop Clinton's march to the nomination -- he doesn't have the money or the time."

HEADLINE: France Suspends Its Testing of Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 8

 BODY:
France announced today that it was suspending its 32-year-old program of nuclear weapons testing in the South Pacific until the end of this year and suggested that it would extend the moratorium in 1993 if other nuclear powers followed suit.
In his first address to Parliament since taking office last week, Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy said President Francois Mitterrand had written to leaders of the other nuclear powers urging them to conclude their strategic disarmament negotiations and halt nuclear testing.
He added that France would retain its independent nuclear deterrent as "the keystone of our defense policy," but would continue to press for global arms reductions. "In 1993, we will see if our example is followed and if common sense has advanced," he said. 
 While the French decision is a direct result of the end of the cold war, the announcement was immediately interpreted here as a move by the Socialist Government to court two fast-growing environmental parties, which have long opposed France's nuclear testing policy.
In regional elections last month, the two parties, the Greens and Generation Ecologie, won 13.9 percent of the vote against just 18.3 percent for the Socialists. The Government's defeat prompted Mr. Mitterrand to dismiss Edith Cresson as Prime Minister and name Mr. Beregovoy in her place.
With parliamentary elections 11 months away, the main conservative coalition currently looks likely to win a big victory. But political experts say they believe that the Socialists have a small possibility of retaining power if they can form a coalition with the two environmental parties.
With an eye to next year's elections, Mr. Beregovoy also pledged today to give priority to fighting unemployment, currently running at 9.9 percent of the work force, and he reduced the sales tax on luxury goods from 22 percent to 18.6 percent to help the auto industry.
Aware of public disenchantment with the country's political class because of several corruption scandals, the new Prime Minister further announced plans to legislate against conflict of interest and to require officials to disclose their wealth.
The decision to suspend nuclear tests was predictably welcomed by the green parties as well as by Greenpeace, the international environmental group. "It's fantastic," Lena Hagelin, a Greenpeace director, said. "Now we hope to be able to work together to convince the remaining countries to follow France's example."
While Russia suspended its nuclear testing for one year last October, the United States and Britain have not adopted a similar policy. France, which exploded its first nuclear device over the Sahara in 1960, has carried out 196 nuclear tests in French Polynesia since 1966.
Over the last 17 years, all tests have taken place underground, with successive governments arguing they were needed to maintain France's nuclear deterrent. In recent years, an average of six tests have been held annually.
But the policy proved costly in diplomatic terms. France's relations with New Zealand touched rock bottom in 1985 after French agents sank a Greenpeace ship, Rainbow Warrior, in Auckland harbor as it prepared to travel to Muroroa atoll to protest a scheduled nuclear test.

HEADLINE: Union Leader Takes Case To Caterpillar Shareholders

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., April 8

 BODY:
The management of Caterpillar Inc. engaged in a tussle of words with a top official of the United Auto Workers at the company's annual shareholders meeting here today. And by the end of the tense meeting, it seemed as unlikely as ever that the two sides would sit down soon to try to resolve a five-month-old strike by 12,600 union members that may cost them their jobs.
Bill Casstevens, secretary treasurer of the union, appeared at the meeting, seeking to address the stockholders in response to a long presentation given by the company on the labor dispute. 
 Caterpillar's chairman, Donald V. Fites, repeatedly asked Mr. Casstevens to sit down when the union leader tried to speak. Ultimately, Mr. Casstevens, who is a company shareholder, was allowed to have the floor during a question-and-answer period.
Mr. Fites, who has relegated the day-to-day statements regarding the strike to other company officials, repeatedly said that Caterpillar was not trying to break the union and that the company would still like to see a negotiated settlement to the strike. He said the company would be willing to review a union proposal if one were submitted.
 
Replacement Workers
 "Breaking this union is the last thing we want to do," Mr. Fites said.
Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment, announced last week from its headquarters in Peoria, Ill., that it would start to replace striking union members if they failed to return to their jobs by April 6.
The company has asserted that more than 400 of the striking workers have crossed the picket lines since then and, according to Mr. Fites, newspaper advertisements about the job openings have attracted about 47,000 telephone calls from people seeking information.
Caterpillar executives said that more union members crossed the picket lines today to return to their jobs but that the company would no longer give figures on the number of workers who cross the picket line.
"We think that it would be counterproductive to do so," Mr. Fites said.
But the United Auto Workers, whose members are keeping vigil at each entrance to the company's plants throughout the Midwest, said that the company figures had been far too high.
About 100 members of union surrounded the hotel in downtown Wilmington that was the site of the shareholders meeting carrying picket signs reading "Will Rogers Never Met Don Fites" and other slogans. Security was tight, with a team of security guards hired by Caterpillar surrounding the ballroom at the Dupont Hotel, where the meeting was held.
 
'Our Side of Story'
 Mr. Casstevens, speaking to the shareholders, complained that the company was seeking to provide far less generous health care and retirement benefits than Deere & Company workers had recently won and that the company had unfairly portrayed the terms of the offer and the course of the negotiations.
"Why don't you let us tell these shareholders our side of the story?" he yelled at Mr. Fites from the middle of the audience, as the chairman implored him to be seated.
In Washington, a group of 15 Senators today asked Labor Secretary Lynn Martin to intervene in the labor dispute. The 15 Senators, including two Republicans, cautioned that hiring non-union workers to replace the strikers would lead the strike to become "a far more contentious struggle," adding that the existence of the company could become an issue.
"Surely the experience at Eastern Airlines, Greyhound and the New York Daily News and countless other, less publicized disputes has shown that the introduction of permanent replacements is counterproductive," the Senators said in a letter to Ms. Martin.
In a news conference after the annual meeting, Mr. Fites said he had kept the Labor Department informed of the company's activities in dealing with the union. However, he added that "we don't see a role for them to play in this process at this time."
Both at the press conference and at the annual meeting, Mr. Fites continued to attack what he called the union's insistence on pattern bargaining, under which a union seeks similar agreements from a number of companies in the same industry. He complained that the U.A.W.'s demand that Caterpillar match a labor pact reached last year with Deere, would render the company uncompetitive with the foreign makers of machinery against whom Caterpillar competes.
Mr. Fites denied that the strike had crippled the company's production, saying that demand had dropped sharply from the economic recession in the United States and the slowdown in the economies in other parts of the world. "We have not lost a single sale, as far as we can tell, as a result of this strike," Mr. Fites said. "Our problem isn't supply, it's demand."
He said that Caterpillar executives have discovered that they could operate their plants with 10 to 15 percent fewer workers, as a result of efficiencies that have been gained from upgrading the company's operations. The company's plants are now being operated by 4,000 salaried personnel.
 
'Gone Overboard'
 During the two-hour annual meeting, several shareholders expressed confidence in the company's handling of the labor dispute. One shareholder said that he considered the company's proposed contract too generous to the union. "I'm concerned that you're pricing yourself out of your competitive position," said the shareholder, Harry W. Craig, a dealer of Caterpillar products. "I urge you to consider that maybe you've gone overboard."
But several Caterpillar workers were among the shareholders and they complained that the company had not treated workers fairly in the contract negotiations.
"You've laid out a lot of things that are false," Mr. Casstevens said in a thunderous voice early in the meeting before he was finally allowed to speak. "You've told your side. They're entitled to hear the other."
Mr. Fites shouted back: "This is not a debate and it is not a bargaining session. It is not a press conference."
The annual meeting dealt principally with the routine affairs of the company: the election of directors, voting on various resolutions and a report on the company's profitability. But the strike was at the center of most shareholders' interest.
After the meeting, Mr. Casstevens met with reporters and said that there were no plans to present Caterpillar with a contract proposal. "They said their offer is final," he said. "But we are willing to sit down and negotiate with management as long as they agree that there are no preconditions," meaning that the company would first have to withdraw its most recent offer, which the union has rejected.

HEADLINE: Bush Fights Long-Term Change in Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today opposed Congressional efforts to make permanent changes in the unemployment insurance system and urged instead prompt enactment of a third temporary extension of benefits to the long-term jobless.
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin called for the extension, under which jobless workers could collect up to 59 weeks of benefits. She called for bipartisan efforts to move the legislation quickly and wrote Congressional leaders, "I am prepared to work immediately with you and your colleagues in the Congress to develop and enact an extension." 
 But at the same time she declined to testify at a House hearing on the issue scheduled for Thursday. A spokesman for Secretary Martin, Steven Hofman, said she had a schedule conflict and would be unable to appear when a Ways and Means subcommittee would be considering a bill to make it easier for workers to get extra benefits than it is under the current arrangement.
A long-term change is supported by most Democrats and many Republicans because it would remove the need for repeated emergency benefits measures during a recession.
 
Mending vs. Fixing
 Ms. Martin said, "Action should not be delayed by consideration of controversial structural reforms this year." Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who heads the subcommittee, replied: "We have dramatically learned throughout this recession that the unemployment insurance system is broken and needs to be fixed. If we do not do this now, then when does the Bush Administration think is the right time?"
Under emergency measures enacted last November and again in February, extended benefits are paid by the Federal Government after a jobless worker exhausts the basic 26 weeks of compensation most states provide. Jobless workers can get 26 weeks of extra benefits or, in states with especially high unemployment, 33 weeks. Benefits, which are taxable, average about $170 a week nationally but vary greatly from one state to another.
After President Bush killed two earlier versions, the emergency measures were enacted because few workers ever qualified for the 13 weeks of extended benefits allowed under permanent legislation. Last year, only eight states had the required conditions -- high unemployment plus a sharp increase in a particular state's joblessness. Mr. Downey's bill would make those extended benefits much more readily available.
Ms. Martin proposed an extension of the emergency benefits through Dec. 31 of this year. Mr. Downey's bill would continue the emergency benefits at least until next February, when Congress would be in session to continue them longer if necessary.
 
Timing Is Questioned
 Some Congressional Democrats grumbled that the Administration proposal was timed to get the issue out of the way before the election, a charge Mr. Hofman denied. He also said that as the economy improved "we're hopeful that people won't need the extension" being proposed today.
The Administration's stand was also criticized by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee. He said: "There's little doubt we'll extend it again, for the third time in less than a year. What I'm interested in doing is making some permanent changes to end some of the doubts and ease the minds of unemployed Americans. I also want to know how the Administration plans to pay for this."
Ms. Martin's statement and letter said the extension should be paid for without increasing the Federal deficit and without raising taxes. Mr. Downey's proposed legislation would raise payroll taxes to pay for making extended benefits more readily available.
The payroll tax to pay for extended benefits is now eight-tenths of 1 percent of a worker's first $7,000 in earnings, or a maximum of $56 a year. Under Mr. Downey's proposal, the rate would drop but the taxable wage base would be raised. Under his bill the tax would go to three-tenths of 1 percent of the first $27,000, or a maximum of $81 per year.
Mr. Downey would pay for his extension of the current emergency benefits program by continuing tax benefit provisions for some high-bracket taxpayers now scheduled to be phased out in 1996 and 1997.
With unemployment nationally at 7.3 percent, workers in 18 states and Puerto Rico are now eligible for 33 weeks of extended benefits. Elsewhere workers are eligible for 26. The unemployed in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are eligible for 33 extra weeks.

HEADLINE: Senators Question Proposal to Cut Reserves

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
In the first political skirmish over a Pentagon plan to cut 140,000 military reservist positions this year and next, senators today criticized the proposal as ill-conceived, unfair and a threat to each state's ability to respond to natural disasters.
Forgetting for the moment Congressional calls for reductions in military spending, Republicans and Democrats on a Senate Armed Services subcommittee criticized two senior Defense Department officials over details of a plan that the Pentagon announced March 26 that would eliminate or shrink 830 National Guard and service Reserve units in all 50 states. There are a total of 1.2 million reservists. 
 The Guard and service Reserves are among Congress's most sacred political cows, partly because of the economic benefits that constituents reap from part-time salaries and armories.
 
'No Rationale Behind It'
 The Defense Department expected Congressional criticism, but the officials seemed ill-prepared today in a subcommittee hearing to explain in detail both assistance to reservists who lose their positions and reliance on reservists in the future military, as well as how specific reserve units were selected for cuts.
"All we saw was a list of cuts and no rationale behind it," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, which would lose 805, or 6 percent, of its reservist positions.
Over the next five years, the Pentagon wants to eliminate 234,000 reservists positions, at a savings of $20 billion, a move that Congress would have to approve. Last year, Congress approved only about one-third the reductions the Pentagon requested, and a senior Defense Department official said only "about half" of the request for 1992 and 1993 was likely to win approval.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and his senior military advisers say that Guard and Reserve units must be reduced to balance cuts made in the active-duty armed forces. The Pentagon plans to reduce the active military to 1.6 million troops in 1995 from 2 million now, though some Democrats are pressing for deeper reductions.
The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Force Management and Personnel, Christopher Jehn, said today that 80 percent of the units to be eliminated supported active-duty forces in Europe that were being phased out.
Stephen M. Duncan, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Reserve Affairs, said the military services tried to balance the reservist cuts to avoid hurting one state more than another. But six states lost more than a quarter of their reservists while 12 others lost less than 5 percent.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the Pentagon plan "offers haphazard cuts that devastate the Guard in some states, while leaving others virtually untouched." Massachusetts stands to lose 8,473 reservist positions, about 31 percent of all reservist positions in the state.
 
Effect on States
 New York State would lose 9,685 reservist positions, about 18 percent of all reservists in the state; New Jersey would lose 4,725, or 20 percent, of its reservist positions, and Connecticut would lose 2,836 positions, 27 percent of reservists there.
The Army National Guard accounts for about 50 percent of all the reservist positions cut. The President can activate the National Guard during national emergencies, like the Persian Gulf war, but in peacetime the states' governors rely on the Guard for tasks like disaster relief and controlling riots.
Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee's Manpower and Personnel Subcommittee, said that under the Pentagon plan the Ohio National Guard would lose 82 of its 103 helicopters, potentially undermining the Guard's effectiveness in civil emergencies.
The Defense Department and Congress have devised assistance plans for active-duty service members whose military careers are being shortened by early retirement. But lawmakers criticized the Pentagon for failing to take similar steps to protect retirement or education benefits of reservists who have served 10 or 15 years.

HEADLINE: Gay Rights Groups Take Aim at Restaurant Chain That's Hot on Wall Street

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITHONIA, Ga.

 BODY:
Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. offers "good country cookin' " in its 118 restaurants and giftware made to look like antiques. On Sundays, particularly, families wait in line for dishes like "country ham n' biscuits n' taters" for $4.89, while many tables stand empty at nearby Burger King and McDonald's restaurants.
And on more and more Sundays, other people have been showing up at Cracker Barrel outlets and have been arrested for various forms of civil disobedience. On a recent Sunday, 90 people occupied a Cracker Barrel near Fredericksburg, Va., and 50 picketed the restaurant here off Interstate 20, just east of Atlanta. 
 The demonstrators say Cracker Barrel is refusing to hire workers who are gay. The company has said various things in response, but if it is discriminating against homosexuals who want work, it is within its legal rights. No Federal law protects gay people from such discrimination, and only five states and about 100 municipalities have such statutes.
 
Push for Public Scorn
 Like the civil rights activists of the 1960's, most of the nation's homosexual-rights organizations are trying to string a noose of public scorn around companies that discriminate.
And Cracker Barrel -- which has traded on traditional values to become a hot stock on Wall Street -- is their No. 1 target.
Half the demonstrators here wore raven-black T-shirts imprinted with a large electric-yellow Q, the emblem of an advocacy group known as Queer Nation. "We're here!" they chanted. "We're queer! Get used to it!"
A mother, hurrying from the restaurant with her husband and two children, said: "It's sad. It's sad the kids have to listen to it."
 
Chants and Arrests
 As if on cue, the protesters, marching along the road 50 yards in front of the restaurant, chanted, "You're teaching your kids to hate! You're teaching your kids to hate!"
The management had the police arrest five demonstrators for criminal trespassing after they set foot briefly on the edge of the parking lot. A few days later, a DeKalb County jury dismissed similar charges against 10 men and women who were arrested after picketing the same restaurant last June.
Increasingly, heterosexuals are joining these rallies. One here was Geri Allen, a shop steward for Local 3204 of the Communications Workers of America in Atlanta. "Civil rights for all," her sign said. Another was Emily Nussbaum of a group called Straight but Not Narrow. "This is everybody's issue," she said.
 
Companies Enact Gay Rights
 Over the past few years, many prominent companies, like American Telephone and Telegraph, International Business Machines, Citicorp, Eastman Kodak, Digital Equipment, Pacific Gas and Electric, Levi Strauss, General Motors and Disney have adopted policies opposing discrimination against homosexuals in hiring and promotions.
Some companies encourage the formation of homosexual employee associations. A leading computer software company, the Lotus Development Corporation, permits homosexual employees to include their companions in their company insurance plans.
But in most of industry, discrimination in hiring and promotion is "very widespread and very subtle" when people are perceived to be homosexual or are open about it, said Tim McFeeley, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign Fund in Washington, a lobbying organization for gay men and women.
"People face it every day," he said. "It has a chilling effect that causes people to stay in the closet, so its very hard to measure."
The advocacy groups say that individuals have sued many employers for discrimination but that only Cracker Barrel has become a target because of company-wide policies.
 
'Blatant Case of Bigotry'
 "Usually companies try to hide what they're doing," said Representative Barney Frank, the openly homosexual Democratic Congressman from Massachusetts. "This is as blatant as any I've heard of. It's a blatant case of bigotry. They'll take money from homosexuals, but they won't give any back."
Early last year, Cracker Barrel dismissed 10 or more workers -- no one outside the company knows the actual number -- because they were homosexual. In a public notice, Cracker Barrel stated that it would no longer employ people "whose sexual preferences fail to demonstrate normal heterosexual values which have been the foundation of families in our society."
In the outcry that followed the Cracker Barrel dismissals, the company said it had rescinded the policy. The vice president for human resources who announced the policy has left the company, for what reason the company will not say. It said then that a few dismissed employees would be offered their jobs back.
But none are known to have been rehired. Cheryl Summerville, 34 years old, a Cracker Barrel cook for nearly four years, was one of those dismissed. She was handed a termination notice that read: "This employee is being terminated due to violation of company policy. The employee is gay."
Then, she recalled, she was invited to reapply, not once but twice. "Then I'd get back home," she said, "and they would call and say they changed their mind."
Samuel E. Hare, 25, had worked his way up at an outlet in Charlotte, N.C., to the point where he was training new workers and was in line for promotion to management. "I went in to look at my schedule for the next week," he said, "and I wasn't on it. I went in to see the general manager. 'Obviously there's a mistake,' he said. He said, 'Come in tomorrow, we'll put you on.'
"I went in and the district manager was there. They took me into an office. The general manager said, 'We have a new policy. Cracker Barrel no longer employs homosexuals. Are you gay?' I said yes. I never deny being gay. That's like denying yourself. He said, 'If you're gay, you're fired.' I asked for a pink slip with a reason. I've never gotten one."
George Frisbee, 26, was training new workers as well, at a Cracker Barrel in Tallahassee, Fla. He said he had an argument with a waitress about his homosexuality.
"She said I was going to burn in hell," he said. "I said, 'I don't have to listen to this.' "
On his next day off, Mr. Frisbee said, the general manager asked him to come in. The manager and another manager were waiting in the parking lot.
"One of them said, 'It has recently come to my attention that you are a homosexual, and since it is against our policy to hire them, we're going to have to terminate you,' " Mr. Frisbee said, adding: "There's absolutely no legal recourse. What they did is perfectly legal."
Cracker Barrel routinely refuses to comment about the issues. "I think that we would decline an offer to speak with anyone here," Ellen Cozark, director of employee relations, said. She refers inquiries to the last official statement of the company's chairman, Dan W. Evins, at the annual meeting in November.
"Let me state once and for all for the record," he said. "Cracker Barrel Old Country Store is an equal opportunity employer that adheres to the letter and the spirit of the law regarding non-discrimination in the workplace. We hire and promote men and women solely on the basis of their qualifications and performance."
But homosexual groups say Mr. Evins has merely camouflaged the policy. Federal civil rights law, they note, protects women, racial and ethnic groups, religious groups, older workers and the disabled from workplace discrimination, not homosexuals. Of the 15 states where the company has opened restaurants, none include the five -- Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Wisconsin, and Hawaii -- that have banned discrimination against homosexuals.
Mr. Evins has also ignored an appeal from a major investor, the pension funds of the City of New York, which hold more than $6 million in Cracker Barrel stock.
Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, and Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Finance Commissioner, wrote to him in March 1991 asking for the company's policy concerning the sexual preference in employment. Mr. Evins answered that the earlier policy had been rescinded and that the company had apologized. "We have no morally discriminating policies in this company," he said.
Ms. Holtzman and Ms. O'Cleireacain wrote twice more seeking an unequivocal statement that the company prohibits discrimination and asking what remedial steps it had taken for the dismissed employees. Mr. Evins did not answer either letter. They have now submitted a resolution, to be voted upon at the company's annual stockholders' meeting in November, that would mandate a nondiscriminatory policy.
"This is a classic example of why we need some kind of Federal protection against this kind of discrimination," said William B. Rubenstein, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's National Lesbian and Gay Rights Project. "It's not that Cracker Barrel is saying they're not good employees, just that there's a societal dislike of them."
 
Legislation Before Congress
 Legislation to extend Federal civil rights protection to homosexuals has been introduced in the House of Representatives, with 115 sponsors, and the Senate, with 15, but no one expects it to be enacted anytime soon.
Whatever the company's strategy, it has not hurt growth. Last year, amid the recession and demonstrations at the restaurants, Cracker Barrel's sales climbed to $300 million from $226 million and its profits to $23 million from $15 million. Unlike the stock market routs that public relations nightmares caused the Dow Corning Corporation after the controversy over silicon breast implants or the Exxon Corporation after the oil spill of the Exxon Valdez, Cracker Barrel's stock has marched right along with its ever-growing business.
"The feedback they get from their customers might be in favor of not hiring homosexuals," said Steven A. Rockwell, a securities analyst at the Alex Brown & Sons brokerage firm.
Indeed, many customers at the store here seemed sympathetic with the company. Bill Copeland of Loganville, Ga., who was going in for lunch with his mother and his children, said: "It tells us in the Bible homosexuality is a sin. It's unnatural. I support Cracker Barrel. As a Christian, I believe in God's laws, and God's laws do not provide for immorality."
A Cracker Barrel executive who would not give his name stood beside the row of oak rocking chairs selling for $99.99 in front of the store here and said: "The only comment I would make is, you see all these cars here? They're going to continue to support this business."
Some people in gay advocacy groups speculate that the Southerners who run Cracker Barrel have a masterful grasp of finance and marketing but are baffled by the outcry over equal rights for homosexuals. To keep growing, the company, with headquarters in Lebanon, Tenn., is heading north and west -- opening stores this year in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri and Ohio -- where it might find police departments and courts more reluctant to apprehend and punish the protesters.
"They don't understand it," said Teresa Nelson, executive director of the Atlanta office of the A.C.L.U. "They don't understand they're doing something wrong with this type of discrimination. They're so confused now."

HEADLINE: An Emotional Ashe Says That He Has AIDS

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
Arthur Ashe, the former United States Open and Wimbledon champion and a pioneer in sports and social issues, said yesterday that he had contracted AIDS, apparently from a blood transfusion, and that he had known about his condition for more than three years.
Although he had told several close friends about his condition, Ashe said he decided to disclose his illness publicly only after learning that a newspaper was preparing an article about it. 
 Accompanied by his wife, Jeanne; Mayor David N. Dinkins, a close friend; three physicians, and his attorney, Ashe told reporters at an emotional news conference in midtown Manhattan that doctors informed him that he had the disease after he underwent brain surgery in September 1988.
The surgery was performed in an effort to determine the cause of a sudden paralysis in one arm. A biopsy revealed the presence of toxoplasmosis, a parasitic infection that often indicates an AIDS infection. Blood tests confirmed Ashe was infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
The infection and the test results, together, led to a diagnosis that Ashe had AIDS.
Ashe had previously undergone cardiac-bypass operations in 1979 and again in 1983. He said yesterday that the virus had been transmitted through blood transfusions, most likely after the second operation.
 
Cites 'Rumors and Half-Truths'
 Reading from a three-page statement, Ashe alluded to "rumors and half-truths" he felt existed about his health for the last several years.
"Beginning with my admittance to New York Hospital for brain surgery in September 1988, some of you heard that I had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. That is indeed the case," said Ashe, who won the first United States Open in 1968, captured Wimbledon in 1975 and became the most prominent black male tennis player in history.
Ashe, 48 years old, said he decided to make the announcement yesterday after a reporter from USA Today called to ask about rumors that he was suffering from the disease. And while not blaming the newspaper, he said he was angered about what he considered to be an intrusion into his privacy.
"I am angry that I was put in the position of having to lie if I wanted to protect my privacy," said Ashe, who works for HBO and ABC Sports as a tennis commentator. He also writes occasional columns for The Washington Post.
"Obviously, I operate in the role of press myself, so I understand it," he said. "Still, I didn't commit any crime. I'm not running for public office. I should be able to reserve the right to keep things like that private. After all, the doctor-patient and lawyer-client relationships are private."
 
Second Major Sports Figure
 Ashe's disclosure marks the second time in five months that a major sports figure has publicly stated that he has been infected with the virus that causes AIDS. Magic Johnson announced his retirement from professional basketball last November, saying he had become infected through heterosexual intercourse. Johnson's doctors say he has not developed the actual disease. However, Ashe and his doctors said yesterday that the former tennis champion is suffering from AIDS itself.
Ashe said that he had chosen to conceal the disease from all but a close circle of family members and friends because "any admission of H.I.V. infection at that time would have seriously, permanently and -- my wife and I believe -- unnecessarily infringed upon our family's right to privacy.
"Just as I'm sure everyone in this room has some personal matter he or she would like to keep private, so did we," Ashe said. "There was certainly no compelling medical or physical necessity to go public with my medical condition."
In a conversation earlier in the day, Ashe said he felt a number of reporters who cover tennis, as well as players and officials, knew or suspected he had AIDS but did not press the subject.
"What I came to feel about a year ago was that there was a silent and generous conspiracy to assist me in maintaining my privacy," he said, still reading from the statement. Then speaking about his wife and 5-year-old daughter, he said, "This has meant a great deal to me and Jeanne and Camera."
At this point, Ashe began to weep. After several seconds, his wife, who had moved to his side, completed the thought, saying: "Arthur and I must teach her how to react to new, different and sometimes cruel comments that have very little to do with her reality."
Charles Pasarell, a former top-ranking American player and one of Ashe's closest friends for more than 35 years, confirmed that Ashe had told him he had contracted AIDS shortly after being given the AIDS diagnosis in 1988. Another longtime friend and former player, Cliff Drysdale, also said he knew.
"He knew then that his time was limited, but on the positive side, he wanted to keep writing and traveling and felt he could do that with more focus if things were handled this way," Drysdale said from Amelia Island, Fla.
Drysdale said he had talked with Ashe about whether to disclose his illness.
"We talked about it again after Magic Johnson's announcement, and Arthur was closer but still not prepared to go public," Drysdale said.
 
A Phone Call From Reporter
 Ashe, known for his unflappable demeanor as a player and as someone who had spoken out on a variety of subjects ranging from apartheid to academics to athletics, said he received a call on Tuesday from a USA Today reporter. He said the reporter was seeking to confirm a tip that Ashe was suffering from AIDS.
Ashe said that as a result of the call he fully expected to see an article in the paper yesterday.
Gene Policinski, managing editor for sports of USA Today, said yesterday that the paper had compiled information indicating that Ashe was "very ill" and that he had assigned the paper's tennis writer, Doug Smith, to check the story.
Policinski said he also talked with Ashe Tuesday afternoon for about 20 to 30 minutes. "I asked him if it was true," Policinski said. "He said, 'Could be,' but he did not confirm nor deny it." The editor said he told Ashe that "USA Today does not print unconfirmed stories from unattributed sources, but in the absence of a hard denial, or confirmation, the information seemed credible and we would continue to pursue the story."
By 11 P.M. Tuesday, the editor said, he decided there was insufficient information to print the story.
In the meantime, though, Ashe assumed that the article would in fact run and started calling friends and family and arranged for yesterday's news conference.
"I'm not picking on USA, it could have been anybody who had received this call in the middle of the night," he said. "Somebody just called and ratted on me. And so USA Today felt, journalistically, that they had to follow up and I was the victim. I did not want to have to go public now because I'm not sick. I can function very well and I plan to continue being active in those things I've been doing all along -- if the public will let me."
Since learning he was infected with the virus, Ashe has done extensive scholarship on blacks and athletics, the highlight being a three-volume work on the history of black athletes called "A Hard Road to Glory."
He has written papers and appeared in numerous forums in connection with academic reform in intercollegiate athletics. A longtime crusader against apartheid, Ashe recently visited South Africa and remains opposed to that country's readmission to the Olympic movement.
Ashe said he received a phone call from President Bush this morning, wishing him and his family well.
Ashe said he he would become involved in the President's commission on AIDS. But he said he had not felt compelled to come forward in order to help the cause of AIDS awareness.
"I knew even before Magic that if I wanted to go public I could possibly help," Ashe said. "But I wasn't ready to go public with it because I had some things that I wanted to do, unfettered, so to speak. I knew that with the public still learning about AIDS, that would have been impossible, once you go public."
"The crisis period was yesterday afternoon, from 3:15 to 2 A.M. it was nonstop. I thought something would be in the paper this morning; I was convinced I would wake up this morning and see some announcement about this in USA Today. To the extent that they did not do it, I thank them."
Ashe said that he did not ask to have the hospital blood supply checked before his 1979 and 1983 operations, nor was he advised to. He said he had no plans to sue. Standard testing of blood donated for transfusion to detect evidence of H.I.V. infection began in mid-1985. "It's something that never came up," Ashe said.
Ashe has played a monumental role in tennis. In 1968, with the nation divided by riots fueled by economic racial tensions, Ashe, at the time a 25-year-old Army lieutenant, won both the United States Amateur and then the Open. His Open victory marked the first time a black male had won a Grand Slam event.
In recent years, he has vigorously crusaded against the exploitation of college and high school athletes. He was instrumental in forming a New York-based sports organization aimed at high school athletes.
Dr. Stephen Scheidt, Ashe's cardiologist at New York Hospital, said yesterday he was optimistic over how Ashe would deal with yesterday's revelations.
"Anyone who gets to win the U.S. Open has seen more pressure than any of us can imagine," he said. "He is the most calm, collected, introspective, marvelous person you could imagine. If there's anybody who can handle pressure, it's Arthur Ashe."

Chronology: "Arthur Ashe: A Hard Road to Glory"
 
Tennis Career
1943: Born July 10 in segregated Richmond, Va. His father is a parks
 supervispor and Arthur begins playing on public courts.
1953: Begins summers of intense training at camp operated by Dr. Robert
 Walter Johnson in Lynchburg.
1960: Wins first of two straight United States Junior Indoor Boys' Championships.
1963: Becomes first black named to United States Davis Cup team. On team through 1970 and in 1975, 1976 and 1978.
1966: Wins NCAA singles and doubles titles for U.C.L.A.
1968: Becomes first -- and only -- black man to win United Amateur and United States Open. Finishes the year ranked No. 1.
1970: Becomes first -- and only -- black man to win Australian Open.
1975: Upsets heavily-favored Jimmy Connors to become first -- and only -- black man to win Wimbledon.
1980: Retires from competitive tennis, begins five-year tour as captain
 of United States Davis Cup team.
1985: Inducted into International Tennis Hall of Fame.
 
Political Activism
1955: Tries to defy color barrier by entering whites-only tournament in Richmond park. Is turned away.
1968: As officer assigned to Army Adjutant Generals Corps at West Point is outspoken in defense of civil rights. His speech to Washington church group about protests planned by militant black athletes at Olympics in Mexico City criticized as too political by West Point superintendent. Helps found National Junior Tennis League to develop tennis programs for inner-city youngsters.
1969: Works with Whitney Young and National Urban League
1972: Helps found Black Tennis Foundation in South Africa.
1973: Three years after his initial application is denied, becomes first black pro granted a visa by South Africa to play in national championships.
1974: Helps found Association of Tennis Professionals and serves as president until 1979.
1981: National chairman of the American Heart Association.
1985: Arrested at South African Embassy while protesting apartheid.
1988: Started inner city tennis programs for black youths in Newark, Detroit, Atlanta, Indianapolis and Kansas City. After six years of research, his three-volume history, "A Hard Road to Glory: A History of the African American Athlete," is published by Warner.
1990: Helps start Athlete Career Connection to help college athletes careers.
 
Medical History
1977: Surgery to remove bone spur and calcium deposits from left heel. Develops eye infection during recovery, off circuit for a year.
1979: Is hospitalized in New York after suffering an apparent heart attack on July 31, but is released. Suffers further chest pains in Miami in early December and undergoes quadruple bypass in New York.
1980: Further chest pains during training leads to retirement.
1983: Undergoes second heart operaton, a double bypass, in New York.
1988: Is hospitalized at New York Hospital with what is described as a severe bacterial head infection causing numbness and loss of all motor function in right hand. He revealed yesterday that after brain surgery, a biopsy revealed toxoplasmosis, a marker for H.I.V., and further tests showed that he was infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

HEADLINE: Arbitration Considered By M.T.A.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would seek arbitration to obtain a new contract with the transit workers' union if labor leaders continued to press for financial concessions.
The threat came after the two sides briefly resumed negotiations for a new contract. The meeting -- the first since the union's 32,000 members decisively rejected a tentative contract three weeks ago -- lasted about an hour. 
 Afterward, Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A. chairman, said in a statement that the transit agency had no money to sweeten its offer. "Unless the union comes to its senses and recognizes the intense financial pressure that our mass transit network is under, I cannot see how continued bargaining may result in a settlement," he said.
 
Seek New Benefits
 The tentative agreement reached by the union's leaders and transit officials in January called for a raise of 4.5 percent this year and an additional 2 percent next year. It included a $1,000 payment to cover inflation since the old contract expired last May but called for no retroactive raise.
In endorsing the January agreement, leaders of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union said they had obtained the best contract they could from the financially pressed agency. But the union's members disagreed, rejecting the proposal by a 2-to-1 ratio.
Sonny Hall, the union's president, said that he asked M.T.A. officials yesterday for a larger wage offer and that he had sought elimination of a worker-productivity agreement included in the tentative pact. He also said he had asked for the creation of a union-management committee to study parental leave and child care; union members recently criticized Mr. Hall for not pushing for such new benefits.
 
Wants More State Aid
 Mr. Hall said in a statement that transit officials should join the union in lobbying in Albany for more state mass-transit aid to finance a better contract. He also proposed using money from the M.T.A.'s capital budget to increase transit workers' salaries.
But Mr. Stangl said, "There is no more money available." He added that he had told union leaders that unless they withdrew their demand for additional increases in salary and benefits, he would invoke state law and seek to have the dispute settled by arbitration.
Under the Taylor Law, either side can ask the State Public Employment Relations Board to declare that talks have reached an impasse. The board appoints a mediator to determine whether an impasse has been reached. If the mediator and the state board decide that additional negotiations are fruitless, the board will submit the dispute to binding arbitration.
