HEADLINE: Where You Are What You Wear;
At the Sunglass Hut, Selling Image and Status by the Pair

SERIES: Modern Mecca -- Fourth in a series of occasional visits to a regional shoppinf mall.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
A stylish woman swept past Kristian Matz at the mall.
"Christian Dior, $275," he said.
He meant the sunglasses.
He would. 
 Malls have given a whole new meaning to the term "specialist." There are stores that sell only shirts. There are sneaker shops, jeans joints and pocketbook parlors. Each is staffed by people who cultivate an unusually narrow expertise and tend to get distracted by particular passing body coverings.
At the dawn of the consumer age, Vance Packard's 1957 book "The Hidden Persuaders" detailed how automobile dealers peddled hope, status and sexual image. In the day of the mall, the new persuaders are places like the specialty shop where 21-year-old Kristian Matz works: Sunglass Hut.
The Hut, in some 540 mall locations from coast to coast -- including two here at the Danbury Fair Mall -- decrees that shades are the "health product of the 90's." It seems to scream that, sags and bulges notwithstanding, anyone can look like Tom Cruise (in "Rainman," L.A. Eyeworks, Botta, $120) or Susan Sarandon (in "Thelma & Louise" L.A. Eyeworks, Cornu, $150) or, should the need arise, Arnold Schwarzenegger (in "Terminator 2," Persol Wraparounds $198).
"Our goal is to make sunglasses like owning shoes," said Jack B. Chadsey, the president of the Sunglass Hut Corporation, which is based in Miami. "Men could have four to five pairs. You tell me how many pairs women could have."
If the Hut fails to make sunglasses essential, it will not be for lack of trying, recent visits to Danbury Fair proved. From the bottom of the organization, to the top, the sunglass mantra rings.
"Sunglasses are mysterious. They're sexy. It's a fun product," said Steve Lemack, the Sunglass Hut regional director, whose territory includes the Danbury Fair stores.
At the Danbury mall, Kristian Matz and the other sunglass sales associates, whose average age is 21.8 and who all look as though they just came in from the beach, can deliver a sunglass spiel in person that is nearly as convincing as the ones Mr. Chadsey and Mr. Lemack made over the telephone.
They analyze the "function" and "fashion" components of sunglass desirability. They explain the relationship between the depletion of the ozone layer and the need for sunglasses. And they provide fashion advice. But with the accent on the positive.
There is the occasional double-chinned customer, just sliding toward middle age, who is intent on the surfer's specs (like Bausch & Lomb's Killer Loops with polycarbonite lenses, $89). Such a prospect, Mr. Matz said, is likely to receive the advice that a tamer pair might look, well, better with his features and skin pigmentation.
"You don't want to put down your product," Mr. Matz said.
 
Different Perspectives
 All the attention on sunglasses, some of the Hutmen admitted, does slightly skew their view of the world. Leo D. Mueller, an earnest 23-year-old who is the manager of both of the Danbury Fair's Sunglass Huts, recently went to Florida on vacation. Along the route, he said, he stopped at other Huts just to visit. And on the beach, he said, "You look at 'em. Everyone's got 'em on. 'He's got $200 ones on; she's wearing cheap ones.' "
Edward Wheeler, who is, at 25, the oldest of Danbury Fair's Hut salesmen, says Leo Mueller sometimes gets carried away with his sunglass zealotry. "He likes 'em," Mr. Wheeler said of his young boss. "He wants you to like 'em. 'Everyone has sunglasses? The world is great,' " according to Leo, Mr. Wheeler said. "I can't get that worked up about them"
Mr. Wheeler and Mr. Mueller, it is true, do not have much in common.
For one thing, Mr. Wheeler has a college degree in economics and says he is working at Sunglass Hut "in between" jobs as a junior accountant. Mr. Mueller has temporarily suspended his college studies and is "shooting," he said, to be the president of a company like Sunglass Hut someday.
 
Different Specs
 For another, Mr. Wheeler wears Revo's modified cat's-eye style graphite sunglasses, while Mr. Mueller has Revo's Shapes Combo Round in mock tortoise shell with orange lenses.
Despite this gulf between them, however, when tested, Mr. Wheeler showed a true Hutster's ability to discern the link between personality and sunglass preference.
Behind the counter at the Hut's lower level location at Danbury Fair, called Sunglass Place, even though it is really a Sunglass Hut, Mr. Wheeler looked down at the selection. In the display case, where an ordinary person might see only plastic and glass, Ed Wheeler saw much of the human condition.
To him the Serengeti graphite goggle represented "an older guy, whose looks aren't primary, conservatively dressed." The Ray-Ban Clubmaster: "That's going to probably be a lady in her late 20's, who's fairly well-off." The 60's retro-look wire rims, like one manufacturer's John Lennon line, brought to Mr. Wheeler's eye this picture: "Late teens, early 20's. Jeans. Sweatshirts. Flannel."
But, despite the Hut's carefully crafted health pitch, another point of common ground between Mr. Wheeler and Mr. Mueller is their experience that something other than ozone-layer anxiety is the real persuader. "The No. 1 factor: Looks," Mr. Wheeler said.
Mr. Mueller agreed. "We have a lot of girls," he said, "who come in and say, 'What would make a guy look at me in a car?' "
Back when Vance Packard was writing, car dealers had a way of exploiting people's secret yearnings. They would, he wrote, put buffed convertibles in their windows. One study he cited said men were drawn into the showrooms by this "possible symbolic mistress," though most ended up buying practical, clunky sedans.
Sunglass Hut has its own version of the '57 red Cadillac Eldorado convertible with the big fins.
Always glowing in the display cases of the Danbury Fair's Sunglass Huts, are the shields of Oakley's Mumbo Heaters ($135) that come in Blue and Red Iridium and other electric colors. Mumbos are the M-shaped wraparound high-tech shades ("effective against wind, rain, mud, snow and thermonuclear explosion," according to their maker) that are favored by the speed-skater Bonnie Blair, who wore them in the Olympics, and the skier Glen Plake, who sometimes adds iridescent colors to his shoulder-length hair.
"Your introvert will not get a pair of Mumbos," Mr. Wheeler has concluded.
 
A Dose of Hut Reality
 Yet, all day long at the Danbury Huts, the Heaters' Plutonite lenses draw people willing to try on danger. They even draw people who are not in the Hut's prime demographic target group, which consists, according to Mr. Chadsey, of relatively young, white-collar people with "a strong fashion sense."
Tino Sinap, 15, from Brewster, N.Y., went for the Heaters right away the other day. "It goes with good hair," he said. "On the beach, you see guys with lots of muscles wearing 'em."
When Tino was finished, a man who had been spending a good deal of time around the Hut finally stepped up to the counter to take the Heater challenge. The man had come to think of himself as part of the Hut's target demographic group.
Leo Mueller put the Heaters on the counter.
Then, he put out a much tamer pair.
The man tried them both.
Leo Mueller studied him.
Then came the dose of Hut reality. The tamer pair, Leo Mueller said, looked, well, better with the man's features and skin pigmentation.
Defeated, the man put the Heaters with the Blue Iridium lenses back on the counter. He had really thought, until then -- even though he remembered when John Lennon was a Beatle and not a line of sunglasses -- that he was still young enough to be a Mumbo man.
But he did not say anything.
Until now.

Series So Far
The first article in this series about the Danbury Fair Mall appeared on March 27. It described the mall, in Danbury, Conn., as one of the region's new "town squares," a place that draws people not only to buy, but to stroll and to meet friends, a place where some succeed and others fail. The second article, on April 1, told of a woman who became a successful drapery saleswoman at the mall after her husband lost his job. The third article, on April 5, described the young people who have made the mall the center of their social life.

HEADLINE: 73.4% of New Jersey School Budgets Win Approval

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
In a striking retreat from their revolt against school spending in 1990 and 1991, New Jersey voters approved 73.4 percent of local school budgets on Tuesday, the highest rate of passage since 1987.
The returns, which surprised even the most optimistic state education officials, may be a sign that anti-tax sentiment is mellowing in New Jersey. But some school superintendents suggested that the anti-tax fervor, which has gripped the state's politics since Gov. Jim Florio pushed through a $2.8 billion tax package nearly two years ago, remained, with voters were content to focus their anger on politicians -- not school systems. 
 "I'm delighted, obviously," said New Jersey's Education Commimmissioner, John Ellis. "The taxpayers responded admirably to school needs, especially in light of the recession. It's a very positive message for education in New Jersey. Thank you, New Jersey, for caring about kids."
In a statement, Governor Florio praised school officials, teachers and board members for what he called living within their means. "We need to build on this success by making sure we keep on delivering the best education at the most reasonable cost," he said.
 
Some Sharp Swings
 Dr. Ellis's office reported that 405 of the 552 school budgets were approved. The passage rate exceeded 60 percent in all but two of the state's 21 counties. In Middlesex, a growing suburban county in north-central New Jersey and a hotbed of resistance last spring, 11 of 22 budgets were approved; in Hudson, a blue-collar urban county, 2 of 6 budgets were approved.
Only 56 percent of local school budgets were approved last year, and only 52 percent were approved in 1990. On the eve of the vote, there were few signs of a significant change in the taxpayers' mood.
But some counties showed sharp swings from 1991's anti-spending atmosphere. Bergen County's voters approved nearly 62 percent of its budgets after rejecting 66 percent last year. Monmouth, like Middlesex a hotbed of tax protest, approved nearly 76 percent after rejecting nearly 63 percent last year.
Robert E. Boose, executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, expressed surprise.
"School boards recognized citizens' concerns about taxes and the economy and generally responded with lean budgets," he said in a statement. "At the same time, school district personnel are becoming increasingly adept at explaining the budget and its impact on educational programs and taxes to their communities."
Dr. Ellis and other officials attributed the results to three factors: School districts tightened spending in the face of growing taxpayer hostility since 1987; the state imposed limits on increases in local school budgets, and the Florio administration provided $341 million in extra state aid for the 1992-93 school year by revaluing the assets of state pension funds.
That new money, which still must be approved by the Republican-controlled Legislature, improved the financial picture for scores of districts. Without it, 304 districts would have faced cuts in state aid for the next school year. Now, 153 will have reductions.
The spending limits, or caps, restrict budget growth to between 5.6 and 6.8 percent for all but the 30 poorest districts. Those caps were created by the Quality Education Act, the Governor's controversial two-year revision to the state's school spending formula, which shifts millions in aid from the richest suburban districts to less wealthy systems.
The caps have forced districts to become more frugal, helped cut salary increases for teachers and consequently reduced annual tax increases.
Teacher contracts for 1991-92 that were negotiated before 1991 provided an average annual pay increase of 9.04 percent, the school boards organization said. The increases negotiated in 1991, however, declined steadily through the year -- from 8.7 percent in contracts settled in the first quarter to 7.63 percent in those negotiated in the fourth quarter, the association said.
Some superintendents believe the taxpayers are satisfied with the program cutbacks made in the last two years. In Ridgewood, a wealthy district in Bergen County, the $35.6 million budget was approved by 76 votes. About 2,500 residents voted, about half the number that turned out last year when Ridgewood's budget was overwhelmingly rejected. The budget grew by 4.6 percent, well below Ridgewood's cap of 5.9 percent, and it will increase school taxes by $185 on the average $308,000 home. That increase is the lowest in five years, the superintendent, Frederick J. Stokley, said.
To keep the increase that low, Ridgewood eliminated 16 teaching jobs and 8 administrative posts, ended courses in Japanese, Russian and Chinese, canceled a camp for sixth graders, reduced science electives, increased high-school class sizes and hired private companies to operate its cafeteria and buses. It is hoping to save as much as $1 million more by hiring janitors from a private company.
"People are getting concerned about reductions," Dr. Stokley said. "I think they may feel enough is enough and let's get on with providing a quality education."
In Bogota, a blue-collar district in Bergen, voters approved the budget for the first time in a decade after the board voted to close one of its three elementary schools to save about $400,000 in staff costs and keep the increase in the 1992-93 budget of $5.9 million to about $500,000.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Rules to deregulate the natural gas industry further, which are expected to lead to lower prices for consumers, were approved by Federal regulators. [Page D1.]
U.S. semiconductor makers may be poised for a comeback after a decade of decline. [A1.] 
 Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said that in her first month on the job she had begun a push to ease American controls on exports and planned to lift controls on 11 types of products. [D1.]
A bill that would give control over cable TV prices back to local governments was approved by a divided House panel. [D1.]
Seeking more money for selling or liquidating S.&L.'s taken over by the Government, lawmakers worked on new bills. [D5.]
Markets
Stocks fell sharply for the second day. The Dow dropped 32.20, or 1 percent, to 3,181.35, its lowest close since Jan. 2. [D8.]
The plunge in Tokyo share prices continued today and the Nikkei stock index lost more than 3 percent of its value to fall below the 17,000 level, its lowest close in more than five years. [D8.]
Stock markets around the world fell sharply, with the worst drop in France. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities fell, hurt by weak demand at an auction of new seven-year notes. [D15.]
Platinum futures prices sank to a two-and-a-half-month low. [D16.] The dollar rose except against the yen. [D16.]
 
COMPANIES
Hallmark agreed to sell Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language TV network and station group, to a group headed by A. Jerrold Perenchio, a Hollywood producer, for $550 million. [D1.]
John G. Smale played down speculation that G.M.'s board planned an expanded role in daily operations. [D2.]
G.M. has accused a Long Island dealer of fraud in obtaining hundreds of millions in loans from the company. [A1.]
American Airlines is reportedly likely to lower some unrestricted fares and increase some advance-purchase fares. [D4.]
Dime Savings is being investigated by the Massachusetts Attorney General's office for the way it is evicting tenants from buildings it seized after borrowers defaulted. [D5.]
Dow Jones said its quarterly profit climbed 58 percent from a year ago, and Media General reported a 15 percent increase. [D18.]
Offers for LTV's missile and aircraft businesses were raised by French and U.S. rivals in bankruptcy court. [D4.]
Alexander's is seeking a delayed-payment plan for about $25 million in trade debt in an effort to coax wary suppliers and their financiers to ship spring merchandise. [D4.]
Cracker Barrel Old Country Store refuses to hire gay workers, say demonstrators picketing its restaurants. [A12.]
Caterpillar's management engaged in a tussle of words with a top U.A.W. official at a shareholder meeting. [D20.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
The U.S., Canada and Mexico have narrowed differences on issues ranging from autos to energy in negotiations on a North American free trade area, ministers said. [D2.]
A modest French theme park is quietly marshaling its forces in a bid to survive the onslaught of Euro Disneyland. [D1.]
The Russian aid package announced by the Bush Administration and some Western allies appears less concrete and less complete than many officials made it seem. [A1.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hallmark to Sell Its Univision TV Group

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 8

 BODY:
Hallmark Cards Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell Univision Holdings, the nation's largest Spanish-language television network and station group, to a group headed by A. Jerrold Perenchio, a Hollywood producer, for $550 million.
The deal includes the Univision network, which is carried by local affiliates and cable systems nationwide, and 13 Spanish-language broadcasting stations, including WXTV, Channel 41, in the New York area, and KMEX-TV, Channel 34, in the Los Angeles area. 
 If approved by the Federal Communications Commission, the deal would end Hallmark's five-year involvement in Spanish-language broadcasting, a business that analysts have said has tremendous potential for growth but that has proved financially problematic in the last few years for Univision and its main competitor, the Telemundo Group.
Hallmark has spent well over $550 million in acquiring and running Univision. The company paid $286 million in 1987 to acquire five Spanish-language stations and another $265 million the next year to acquire the Univision network. It also spent tens of millions of dollars acquiring smaller stations and on new broadcasting studios and programming.
Hallmark, which is a private company, declined to say whether the network and the stations were profitable. But a spokesman for Hallmark, Steven Doyal, said it would post a "modest loss" on the sale.
Hallmark said Univision Holdings had revenues exceeding $200 million last year. Mr. Doyal said the broadcasting operation's cash flows had remained level since being acquired by Hallmark, a performance that he said was below the company's expectations.
Mr. Doyal said Univision and the stations had been hurt by the recession and the resulting weakness in advertising sales, the need for continuing investments in programming and equipment and increasingly stiff competition from Telemundo.
Mr. Perenchio, who is leading the group buying Univision and the television stations, is best known as the former partner of Norman Lear in producing such hit shows as "All in the Family" and "The Jeffersons." At different times, he has also owned small Spanish-language stations in New York and Los Angeles.
Mr. Perenchio's group includes Venevision, Venezuela's largest broadcaster, and Grupo Televisa, Mexico's largest broadcaster. Federal regulations prohibit foreign companies from controlling television stations in the United States.
A spokesman for Mr. Perenchio, Brian Regan, said the deal would be structured to avoid foreign control of the stations. He said Mr. Perenchio would have a 75 percent equity stake in the stations, with the foreign partners holding the remainder. A spokeswoman for the F.C.C. said the regulations allowed foreign owners to hold a stake as large as 25 percent.
Mr. Regan said Mr. Perenchio would own 50 percent of the Univision network, with the two foreign partners splitting the remainder.
"The U.S. Hispanic marketplace is growing dramatically and is ready to support the highest quality in television entertainment, news and public affairs and cultural and children's programming," Mr. Perenchio said in a statement.
Mr. Perenchio's group declined to say what changes it might have in mind for Univision's operations and programming. But the presence in the investor group of Venevision and Televisa suggested that Univision could buy more programming produced by those companies for their home markets, slowing the trend toward greater use of programming made in the United States.
"Hallmark has done an excellent job of developing Univision's resources, which are its superb talent and outstanding management," Mr. Perenchio said. "Now, with the investor group, we have an even broader range of capabilities to support the next stage in Univision's development."
Univision can be seen in 90 percent of the nation's Hispanic households, making it larger than Telemundo, which is seen in about 84 percent of homes. Although Telemundo's ratings are strong, Univision remains the ratings leader and produces the nation's most popular Spanish-language program, "Sabado Gigante," a variety and game show.
Like Univision, Telemundo has been hurt by the soft television advertising market. Telemundo, which is 80 percent owned by Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings Inc., missed a debt payment in January and is currently in negotiations with bondholders to restructure its debt.

HEADLINE: Export Curbs Will Ease, Official Says

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said today that in her first month on the job she had begun a push to ease American controls on exports and planned to lift controls on 11 types of products, including some computer chips.
Ms. Franklin, a management consultant and Republican fund-raiser tapped by President Bush in December, said the White House was in the final stages of reviewing her export control plan. 
 A final decision, which could eventually allow up to $3 billion a year in additional American exports to former Communist countries, may be reached by the end of this week, she said.
 
No Plans for Reorganization
 In recent years, the Commerce Department has lost much of its influence over trade policy to the Office of the United States Trade Representative. But Ms. Franklin said she had no plans to reorganize her sprawling department and expressed no enthusiasm for proposals made in Congress and by the late Malcolm Baldrige, the Commerce Secretary from 1981 to 1987, to rebuild the agency as a Department of Trade and Industry.
Ms. Franklin criticized the draft agreement reached last week with the European Community that would limit but not abolish Government subsidies to commercial aircraft makers. She said it should not be a model for future agreements because it would reduce but not eliminate subsidies.
By a voice vote, the Senate adopted a resolution today condemning subsidies and implicitly criticizing the deal with the European Community.
The office headed by the trade representative, Carla A. Hills, negotiated the pact. Ms. Franklin has known Mrs. Hills for years and served for six years on one of the trade office's private-sector advisory committees.
Ms. Franklin has had a slow and sometimes difficult start in her job, including a Senate confirmation process that featured strong criticisms of her competence from Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia.
During a short press briefing last week on commercial relations with the former Soviet republics, she repeatedly showed little awareness of such basic issues as the status of trade agreements.
But this morning, in her first interview since President Bush nominated her on Dec. 26, Ms. Franklin took pains to demonstrate a detailed knowledge of her huge department. She had on her Government-issue walnut desk a copy of the highly technical agreement on aircraft manufacturing subsidies, and said she had been reading it earlier in the morning.
 
Likes Moratorium on Regulations
 Ms. Franklin also said this morning that the Administration's 90-day moratorium on the issuance of new regulations should be extended and that export promotion policy should be reviewed at the Cabinet, not the sub-Cabinet, level.
Ms. Franklin, who used to sit on the audit committees of several large corporations, said she would urge the Financial Accounting Standards Board to consider the effects on American competitiveness before changing accounting rules. She expressed particular concern about the board's decision to begin forcing companies to recognize as a liability the eventual cost of retirement health benefits for current employees.
But American companies have already fought that battle and appear to have lost. I.B.M. and many other corporations have already made the move, which results in a charge against earnings although no cash is actually set aside.
In discussing the aircraft manufacturing accord, Ms. Franklin said the pact should have forced the European Community to eliminate subsidies entirely. The pact limits cash advances from governments to 33 percent of the cost of developing an aircraft, and requires that the money be paid back with interest as planes are sold.
"I don't want a precedent for the future out of this agreement," she said.
A separate provision limits indirect subsidies to aircraft manufacturers through military contracts and other government deals. An informal understanding on limits for these subsidies broke down this week, and secret negotiations continued today as American and European Community officials tried to resolve their differences.
Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who sponsored the nonbinding resolution condemning subsidies today, said he hoped the new round of talks "totally breaks down."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, said he would schedule a hearing on subsidies in aircraft manufacturing and other industries. Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the subcommittee on international trade and has often supported the Administration, said that last week's deal signaled to foreign trade negotiators a new American willingness to compromise.
Ms. Franklin also said that she would be overseeing some trade issues involving auto parts even though her husband, Wallace Barnes, heads a large auto parts company. Only issues affecting specific products made by the Barnes Group will be off limits, she said.
Two thick metal springs for engine valves sat on the coffee table in Ms. Franklin's office; four more, painted blue and red, were perched on the edge of her desk.

O.E.C.D. Fails on Ships
 WASHINGTON, April 8 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The United States and other members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have failed to negotiate an agreement that would eliminate government subsidies to shipbuilders.
The O.E.C.D. members concluded negotiations today without an agreement, according to an announcement by Michael H. Moskow, a deputy United States Trade Representative. The United States also declined to commit to future negotiations at this time, the release said.
The negotiations foundered on "differences over a number of key elements," the United States trade office said in the announcement, which did not elaborate on the sticking points.
Japan, South Korea, Finland, Norway, Sweden and the countries of the European Community participated in the negotiations with the United States. Together these countries cover about 80 percent of world shipbuilding production, the United States trade office said.

HEADLINE: Progress Reported in Talks On North American Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTREAL, April 8

 BODY:
The United States, Canada and Mexico have narrowed differences on issues ranging from autos to energy in negotiations on a North American free trade area, ministers of the three countries said after three days of meeting here. The Bush Administration is hoping for a pact before November.
Despite reports from Washington that the Administration is getting cold feet because an agreement might give capital to political opponents, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today in a meeting with reporters that the President wanted to "complete negotiations as soon as possible." 
 "I think we could complete our negotiations and initial an agreement and subsequently sign it by November," she said.
 
Progress in Technical Areas
 With Mrs. Hills were Canada's International Trade Minister, Michael H. Wilson, and Mexico's trade minister, Jaime Serra Puche. All three spoke of progress in narrowing differences in technical areas.
While they took a generally optimistic tone, the negotiators declined to provide evidence of emerging accords on specific industries, emphasizing that nothing was final until everything was agreed.
One contentious issue relates to the way rules defining North American content are worked out for automobiles, computers, textiles and other products.
In autos, the United States wants Canada and Mexico to accept a 60 percent content rule -- which means that at least 60 percent of the value of a car would have to be produced in North America for it to avoid tariffs.
In the existing United States-Canada free trade accord, 50 percent was agreed on. Canada and Mexico both want the 50 percent maintained, arguing that at 60 percent the United States would take Asian investment away from them.
Washington is also seeking to open parts of Mexico's energy industry, which was nationalized in 1938 and is protected as part of the national patrimony in Mexico's Constitution.
While Mexico does not want to be seen giving away control of oil to the United States, its oil industry needs huge sums to modernize and increase output.
Negotiators are looking for ways to allow for foreign investment and other participation in the industry without touching off a domestic political storm.
 
The Political Consequences
 Mrs. Hills said she thought the political consequences of an agreement could be positive. "Those voters who believe that it is good for the region to find ways to become more competitive globally will mark that as a plus," she said. "Those who are resigned to the belief that a free trade area is not in their best interest will mark it as a minus."
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has expressed support for North American free trade, but some political analysts say he could make any accord negotiated by the Bush Administration an issue by promising to renegotiate to get a better deal.
Edmund G. Brown Jr., who is fighting Mr. Clinton for the nomination, has said he would delay a North American trade deal until he had a job protection strategy in place.
Some experts say the agreement will provide more jobs in the United States, but it could create some dislocation for a number of lower-skilled workers in sectors in which the United States competes with Mexico, like agriculture and apparel.
A recent study by the Institute for International Economics found that the free trade agreement would create 600,000 jobs in Mexico and 130,000 jobs in the United States. Canada would undergo a net loss of 4,000, the study said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lucasfilm Subsidiary Loses Chief Executive

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Lucas Arts Entertainment Company said yesterday that R. Douglas Norby had resigned as president and chief executive. A wholly owned subsidiary of Lucasfilm Ltd., Lucas Arts has products and services that include visual effects, sound and sound effects, television commercials, licensing, computer-game software, audio systems and educational multimedia products. Lucas Arts is based in San Rafael, Calif.
Mr. Norby, who is 56 years old, was not available for comment. The company said only that he had determined that it was "an appropriate time to pursue other professional challenges." 
 But Mr. Norby is the second executive to resign in recent months, following Scott Ross, who managed Industrial Light and Magic, the special-effects unit, and Skywalker Sound, which provided sound recording for both Lucasfilm and contract customers.
"I appreciate Doug's dedication to the company during the past seven years and wish him the best in his future endeavors," George Lucas, Lucas Arts' chairman, and founder of Lucasfilm, said in a statement. "I'm tremendously proud of the accomplishments Lucas Arts has achieved under Doug, and I am committed to preserving its innovative spirit and maintaining its creative and technical excellence."
Lucas Arts said that a search for a successor to Mr. Norby was under way, and that he would continue to serve on the company's board and assist in the transition. In the interim, the board appointed Gordon Radley, 45, as acting chief operating officer. Mr. Radley joined Lucasfilm in 1985 and for the last two years has served as group vice president of Lucas Arts responsible for business affairs, legal, finance and accounting.
Mr. Norby's departure follows a year of achievements for the various divisions of Lucas Arts. Industrial Light and Magic and Skywalker Sound garnered eight Academy Award nominations and won three Oscars for visual effects, sound and sound-effects editing.
Mr. Norby came to Lucasfilm in 1985 from the Syntex Corporation, a pharmaceuticals manufacturer based in Palo Alto, Calif., where he was chief financial officer. He created the Lucas Arts subsidiary in 1989 and oversaw its growth into new businesses such as software and educational materials. But he said recently that Lucasfilm was not immune to the economy or competition and predicted a period of slower growth.
Mr. Radley began his career in the entertainment industry in 1973 as a business lawyer. Before joining Lucasfilm, he served as senior business and legal counsel at 20th Century Fox for its theatrical and television divisions.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Taxable and Tax-Free Funds Post Mixed Yields in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the last week.
After posting gains the week before, tax-exempt money fund yields reversed direction and fell significantly. However, analysts noted that even with the decline, tax-exempt yields were still about 25 to 30 basis points, or hundredths of percentage points, higher than they were about a month ago. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for tax-exempt funds fell 12 basis points, to 2.92 percent, with the simple yield down 11 basis points, to 2.88 percent. The 30-day compounded average tax-exempt yield and simple yield were both up 9 basis points, to 2.81 percent and 2.77 percent, respectively.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in portfolios remained unchanged last week, at 51 days.
According to Donoghue's statisticians, assets of tax-exempt funds for the week grew by $2.3 billion, bringing total assets to $98.6 billion.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable-equivalent yield of the current seven-day compounded average tax-exempt yield is 4.05 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 4.23 percent.
 
The Best Performer
 Among the tax-exempt funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Market Fund, frequently among the best performers, showed the top return for the week. The fund posted a yield of 3.90 percent, down 5 basis points from the previous week.
Among taxable funds, the average seven-day compounded yield was up a basis point, to 3.81 percent, with the simple yield also up a point, to 3.74 percent. The 30-day compounded and simple taxable yields remained unchanged, at 3.80 percent and 3.73 percent, respectively.
Assets of taxable funds grew $13.7 billion, to $495.6 million, regaining much of the cash outflow from the week before, Donoghue's said.
Like the previous week's outflow, the bulk of the inflow in the most recent week was attributed to institutions, which placed $11.4 billion into taxable funds last week.
 
Influence of Jobs Data
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, said institutions were influenced by last week's employment numbers, which showed only a nominal increase in jobs and raised expectations of further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
However, Mr. Frank said that "expectations that we may be getting action from the Fed is premature." He added, "The Fed will need more evidence than it now has that the recovery is stalling before making any further moves."
Among the taxables, the Fidelity Spartan Money Market Fund was the best performer last week, with a return of 4.39 percent.
By comparison, the average yield of bank money market accounts, prime competitors of money funds, was at 3.71 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: Japan's Troubles Contribute to Declines Around the World

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stock markets around the world fell sharply yesterday, with analysts saying that the spillover from this week's plunges in the Japanese and American markets unsettled investors.
The worst fall was in France, where an index of 40 blue-chip stocks dropped 3.4 percent. Blue-chip indexes also fell more than 1 percent in Germany, Italy, Sweden and Switzerland. The leading Hong Kong index was off 2 percent and markets in Singapore, Australia and New Zealand also fell, some hitting their lowest levels since last fall. 
 British blue chips fell just under a half of a percent, but they had already fallen about 7 percent since an election was called March 11. Investors have worried that the Conservatives may lose in today's balloting.
But analysts also said they had yet to see signs signaling that the falls in Japan and the United States will spread around the world.
 
Local Factors Important
 One reason is that the declines in many markets also resulted from local factors, including the British election and the recent electoral setbacks for the ruling parties in France, Germany and Italy. Disappointment in the maiden speech of the new Prime Minister of France, Pierre Beregovoy, was also a factor there.
Another reason is that many markets do not follow Japan's lead. Although the Nikkei index of 225 leading shares plunged 17.4 percent in the last four weeks, its decline had little impact elsewhere, even in the United States, until this week. But the 2.9 percent decline in the Dow Jones industrial average over the last two days, after it had held fairly steady all year, is a little more worrying.
This is because stock markets, especially those in Europe, follow the American market more closely, particularly when the daily moves are quite volatile. And if the United States is seen to be reacting to Japan, then the Japanese falls can take on more signficance.
 
U.S. Trend Watched Closely
 "In terms of contagion, the United States has been more significant," said Sushil Wadhwani, the international strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in London. "No one really has paid any attention to Japan until this week."
But he argued that if the Dow settled down, then European stock markets, outside of Britain, should be able to recover. The British outlook depends on the election, with some analysts arguing that the Financial Times Index of 100 leading stocks could fall to the 2,200 level if the Labor Party wins. The index closed down just 11 points yesterday at 2,393.2, recovering from a steeper fall on rumors that a last pre-election poll would show the Conservatives in the lead.
In France, the market was hit by both the falls in Japan and the United States and Japan and local problems. Christian Picot, the head of equities for Paribas Capital Markets in New York, said disappointment in the first important speech by Prime Minister Beregovoy helped send the market down about 1.7 percent, half of the day's fall, at the end of the session. The CAC 40 index closed down 67.90 at 1,907.48.
Investors, he said, were hoping for more positive information on a savings proposal similar to the American system of individual retirement accounts and more details on the Government's effort to accelerate plans to sell state-owned or -controlled companies to the public. But there were no such details.
 
Time to Sink In
 But Mr. Picot also said the effect of the falls in New York and Tokyo had plenty of time to sink in and undermine the market. He noted that French brokers, as well as others in Europe, end their day with the news of what has happened in the United States and begin the next one with news from Japan, and that has been bad all week.
In Germany the DAX index of 30 leading shares fell 1.1 percent, or 19.41 points, closing at 1,720.01. Traders said they were relieved that the market had not fallen further. But trading ended before New York opened and the Dow fell 32.2 points, or 1 percent, which means that Germany could fall further today.
Like other countries, Germany has local problems that already made the market vulnerable. One is new inflation numbers that may delay a cut in interest rates there even into next year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Retreat

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Weak demand at an auction of new seven-year Treasury notes and a slight recovery in stock prices from their lows for the day helped to push down prices of Treasury securities and force up interest rates yesterday.
The $9.75 billion of new seven-year notes were sold at an average yield of 7.11 percent. 
 The rate was well above the average yield of 6.40 at the last seven-year note sale in January, but dealers said the higher rate failed to attract any real interest from institutional accounts. The only source of demand was from arbitragers, and it was tepid, the dealers said.
The selloff came on the heels of stronger prices during the morning, as market participants bought securities when the Dow Jones industrial average moved sharply lower. Treasury securities were also purchased overnight in Tokyo as Japanese equity prices slumped.
Traders and some analysts said the steep slide in the Japanese stock market was casting a pall over Treasury bond traders.
Even though Japanese investors have been net sellers of Treasury securities over the last few years, they still own significant amounts of 30-year bonds, some analysts said.
"The Japanese could do some significant damage if they decided to sell out and take their money back to Japan," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "As long as that threat is there, it has a negative effect on long-term Treasury securities."
But others said those fears were overblown, adding that other markets were far more vulnerable to Japanese selling than the Government securities market.
For the first three quarters of last year, Japanese were net buyers of American stocks and of mortgage-backed securities, said Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm.
The pace of buying fell off abruptly in the fourth quarter, and in the first two months of 1992 the Japanese were net sellers of equities and mortgage-backed issues, Mr. Crandall added.
"The American bond market has been used to the flow of securities back to Japan for a couple of years now," he said. "But for other markets it is more of an abrupt shift. As a consequence, the Treasury market actually stands to lose less than some of the others."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 1012/32 , down 10/32 , to yield 7.90 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Tuesday.
 
10-Year Notes Are Off 1/4 Point
 Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10021/32 , down 1/4 point, to yield 7.40 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, down 5/32 , to yield 6.72 percent. And the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/8, down 1/32 , to yield 5.27 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched a bit lower, as investors leaving the stock market continued to buy these highly liquid debt instruments.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.83 percent late yesterday, down two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates dipped by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 3.93 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as lead manager on an offering of $250 million worth of subordinated notes from LKB, a German finance agency.
The 7 7/8 percent 12-year notes were priced at $99.27, to yield 7.971 percent, 55 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Chicago Finance Authority offered $170.07 million worth of bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Prudential Securities won the bonds.
Serial bonds reoffered to investors carried yields from 3.50 percent on securities maturing in 1993 to 6.50 percent in 2007.
A 6 1/4 percent term bond maturing in 2009 was priced to yield 6.55 percent.
The bonds are backed by insurance from the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, and are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues slipped by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
By contrast, municipal bond traders said the slide in stock prices had stimulated demand for tax-exempt securities. Prices of most widely quoted issues were up by about 1/2 point, the traders said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum at 2 1/2-Month Low As Japanese Stocks Slide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices sank to a two-and-a-half-month low yesterday as speculators viewed plunging Japanese stock prices as a sign of sagging demand for the precious metal.
Platinum investment and jewelry demand is centered in Japan, where the metal has the same cachet as gold in the United States. 
 Platinum for April delivery fell $7.10, to $342.10 a troy ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was the lowest daily settlement for near-term platinum deliveries since Jan. 17.
Several analysts agreed the retreat was tied to yesterday's 3.5 percent plunge in the Nikkei stock average, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index, to its lowest level in five and a half years.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, the widely followed measure of the United States stock market, dropped about 32 points yesterday after tumbling nearly 62 points on Tuesday.
Platinum's drop was "pretty much a knee-jerk reaction to the Japanese stock market," said Tom Griffo, metals analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York.
"The popular theory is that when that goes down, platinum goes down," he said.
He said platinum's decline mainly reflected speculative selling of futures rather than sales of physical platinum.
The Nikkei's steepening decline and the drop in the Dow raised fears that the recent recovery of the United States economy might stall, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York. That would result in weaker industrial demand for platinum, which is a key component in car pollution-control systems.
Economic fears were also behind yesterday's 2.05-cent drop in April copper deliveries on New York's Commodity Exchange to $1.0010 a pound, said Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
Gold for April delivery fell 80 cents, to $337.90 a troy ounce, on the Commodity Exchange; May silver rose 0.5 cent, to $4.088 a troy ounce.
Crude oil, meanwhile, reached a new high for the year on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders responded to shrinking United States supplies and more Middle East tensions.
Crude oil for May delivery rose 39 cents, to $20.62 a barrel; May home heating oil rose 0.81 cent, to 56.26 cents a gallon; May unleaded gasoline rose 0.39 cent, to 62.71 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Late in Day But Drops Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies except the Japanese yen in busy trading yesterday after a late technical rally made up the dollar's losses earlier in the sesson.
Most of the action in the foreign exchange markets focused on the relationship between the dollar and the yen. Rumors that the Japanese were aggressively selling dollars for yen dominated trading for much of the day. 
 Stephen Flanagan, a vice president and currency dealer at Mitsubishi Bank, said the reports of Japanese dollar sales had encouraged others to sell the dollar. But he added: "Those yen repatriation rumors really are unfounded. The magnitude of the Japanese repatriation flows are considerably overstated."
The dollar was also undermined by another weak performance by stocks on Wall Street and nagging worries about the economic outlook.
A sense is spreading in financial markets that the Federal Reserve will trim interest rates sometime soon to stimulate growth. Lower rates reduce returns on dollar-denominated holdings and tend to curb demand for dollars.
But after several hours of trading in New York, the sentiment shifted and buyers flocked to buy dollars. The buyers reportedly included short-coverers who had bet the dollar would drop in value. They were buying to pay back dollars they had borrowed then immediately sold in hopes of buying the dollars back later at a lower exchange rate.
The dollar got off to a weak start in world trading. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 132.75 Japanese yen, from 133.35 yen at Tuesday's close.
Later, in London, it fell to 132.60 yen. By the time trading was done in New York, the dollar was quoted at 132.65 yen, down from 133.10 yen late Tuesday.
Sterling, meanwhile, continued to be weighed down by political concerns ahead of the coming British election. A pound fell in London to $1.7480, from $1.7490 late Tuesday. At closing in New York, the pound fetched $1.7500, compared with $1.7505 on Tuesday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Tuesday's late levels, were: 1.6270 German marks, up from 1.6235; 1.4950 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900; 5.5110 French francs, up from 5.4950; 1,227.00 Italian lire, up from 1,224.00, and 1.18925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18795.

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS;
Dow Jones and Media General Profits Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter profit climbed 58 percent from a year ago and Media General Inc. reported a 15.1 percent increase. Both media companies cited improved earnings from their newspapers.
Following are the details of the two companies' results:
 
Dow Jones
 Dow Jones said its results reflected higher advertising volume at The Wall Street Journal, lower interest expense and improvement at its community newspapers and its electronic financial information service, Telerate Inc. 
 Earnings of the New York-based company rose to $28.4 million, or 28 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, from $18 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 4.7 percent, to $436.1 million, from $416.6 million a year earlier.
Michael Ellman, who follows Dow Jones for Wertheim Schroder & Company, said the linage gains hadbeen driven by the improvement in Wall Street's performance, a trend that has been in evidence since last fall. "That precipitated a flurry of ads for initial public offerings and mutual funds advertising," he said, adding, "I suspect that image advertising and classified ads are under pressures, consistent with other companies."
He said that Dow Jones had worked very hard on the cost side, at least in terms of reducing its payroll.
"My reservation is that linage clearly was negative in March, and that for the third consecutive quarter, the information services sector, led by Telerate, reported sluggish earnings," Mr. Ellman said.
Operating income from business publications including The Journal and Barron's more than doubled, to $24.6 million, as revenue rose 8 percent, to $186.6 million.
Ad volume at The Journal rose 9.2 percent in the quarter, which included one more publishing day than the year before. Operating income was up 4.5 percent, to $40.3 million at the information services segment, including Telerate, as revenue rose 2.2 percent, to $196.3 million.
 
Media General
 The Richmond-based media company earned $2.7 million, or 11 cents a share, in the three months ended March 29, up from $2.4 million, or 9 cents a share, a year ago, even though revenue slipped 2.7 percent, to $141.7 million, from $145.6 million a year earlier.
Media General said its results reflected improved earings from its daily newspapers, continued strength in its cable TV systems and cost controls.
But it added that its TV stations "have yet to realize any significant strengthening in advertising revenues, which typically accompany an improved economy."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
He's Offering Some Hope To Agencies

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
DESCRIBING himself as "positive, in a cautiously optimistic way," Alex Kroll said he believed that the advertising industry's severe recession was ending.
And that is largely because "the industry's leadership has righted itself and gotten back to its fundamental mission," Mr. Kroll, the outgoing chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said in an interview before the group's 74th annual meeting opened yesterday in Naples, Fla. 
 That mission was described by Mr. Kroll, the chairman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Inc., as "the brand-building power of advertising," the ability of ads to create consumer loyalty to a client's product. He offered thoughts on that subject and others as he reflected on his year as chairman of the Four A's, as the national trade association is known.
As planned, at the end of the annual meeting on Saturday Mr. Kroll will be succeeded by Robert L. James, chairman and chief executive of McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York.
Mr. Kroll's cautious optimism comes amid a growing sense among industry executives that they are slowly beginning to climb out of the slump into which their business fell in 1989, a year earlier than the rest of the economy.
One statistic being greeted with hope: about as many people are expected at this year's meeting at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Naples, as at last year's gathering at the Greenbrier resort in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., when 420 attended. This indicates a leveling off after last year, when attendance plunged by a third from 1990.
During an interview last week at his New York office, Mr. Kroll said that agencies and their clients had been distracted from "the classic partnership necessary to build brands" by the "financial preoccupations" generated by the spate of mergers and acquisitions that dominated their businesses in the 1980's.
Then came what he called "the first 10-month year in the history of advertising," as the Persian Gulf war put the nation into suspended animation during January and February of last year.
Case studies of the advertising budgets for about 20 products over three decades, adjusted for inflation, demonstrate the decreasing emphasis on brand-building, he said. A study of this "underspending" trend will be presented at the meeting today.
"Advertisers don't put as much pressure behind brands as they used to," Mr. Kroll said. "It's perfectly hideous."
But "that period of distraction is over," he asserted. "Agencies and clients are beginning to realize how essential they are to each other." One way to hasten that process, he said, is to re-establish the identities of individual shops, which were blurred by the agency agglomerations of the 80's.
Mr. Kroll spoke approvingly of recent remarks by John E. O'Toole, the president and chief executive of the Four A's, longing for "the days when agencies were individual brands."
Those were the not-too-distant days of "Bill Bernbach, saying advertising is an art," Mr. Kroll said. "There was Rosser Reeves, saying that the worst thing about advertising is that it's an art. And David Ogilvy was saying it's a science." The references were to the diverse creative legends at, respectively, Doyle Dane Bernbach, Ted Bates and Ogilvy & Mather.
"Each one of them stood for something," Mr. Kroll said, "and clients had their choice of competing philosophies. It is my hope that agencies will again deal with things in more individual ways."
Another topic concerning Mr. Kroll during his term as chairman has been political advertising. For the current Presidential primary season, the Four A's has joined the League of Women Voters and the Markle Foundation to test Project Run Fair, which has enabled voters to call a "900" telephone number to register objections to negative political ads.
But the first test, in New Hampshire, was plagued with problems, from a dearth of public-service messages in local media to publicize the project, to what Mr. Kroll termed the "barrier" of the $1.15-a-minute charges for the calls. Details were modified for a second test, in the Wisconsin campaign that ended Tuesday, and Mr. Kroll hopes it will continue "beyond my leadership, if it proves to be useful."
The Four A's board of directors voted yesterday on leaders for the 1992-93 year. In addition to Mr. James, who was vice chairman, being elected chairman, Roy Bostock, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, was elected vice chairman. That places Mr. Bostock in line to succeed Mr. James in 1993.
In brief remarks following his election, Mr. James told the meeting that "we have a long hard year ahead of us," adding that there can be a "great future for this business only if we make it so."
He is scheduled to deliver a speech today sounding a theme he plans to address often during his term as chairman: the need for agencies to convince marketers of the importance of advertising in selling their products, rather than diverting ad dollars to promotional programs aimed at retailers.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Promotion Industry Salaries Are Rising

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Salaries paid to executives who work in the promotion industry show little sign of being affected by the recession, according to the industry's third annual salary survey by Promo magazine.
Respondents reported salaries last year averaging $69,434, compared with $66,500 in 1990, and pay increases averaging 9.8 percent, compared with 7.8 percent in 1990. 
 The survey was conducted for the magazine by Gallup & Robinson in Princeton, N.J., which mailed questionnaires to 4,000 readers at consumer-product manufacturing companies, promotion agencies and marketing services companies.

HEADLINE: WHERE TO FIND IT;
Yes, You Can Get a Toaster Repaired

BYLINE: By Terry Trucco

 BODY:
BUSINESS has been good lately at Riverside Housewares in Manhattan, and Stanley Stern, the owner, cannot decide whether the recession or concern for the environment is the reason. Mr. Stern, in business for 45 years, repairs small appliances like toasters, percolators, hair dryers, blenders, vacuum cleaners and fans.
"I think the use-it-and-throw-it-away philosophy is changing," he said, standing by a shelf of rehabilitated waffle irons from the 1940's and 50's. "People are more willing to have old things repaired." 
 By old things, Mr. Stern can mean really old things. His specialty is finding and restoring kitchen gadgets that date from the 1930's. Sometimes the touches are cosmetic -- new pot handles, new whistles for tea kettles, new suction cups for a meat grinder. He will also remove asbestos wiring in older appliances.
It does not pay to fix all home appliances, Mr. Stern said. "If the motor goes on a can opener, we don't bother." But a $10 or $15 repair can often be worthwhile for a $50 or even $30 item, particularly if the customer is fond of it.
Appliances made of metal, like fans or cannister-style vacuum cleaners, are almost always worth fixing, Mr. Stern added. Most old motors were built to last longer than the newer ones, he said, patting a rehabilitated metal table fan. "I'll sell that for $100," he said.
Typical repairs entail new switches or new wiring. Mr. Stern has an inventory of parts, including glass tops for percolators. The store also sells vintage Pyrex glassware.
 
The Unusual, Too
 "A lot of people don't realize they can get their appliances repaired," said Stan Benson, an assistant manager at Solomon's Appliance Repair in Brooklyn.
In business for more than 40 years, Solomon's is a factory service center for about 100 companies, including Black & Decker, Braun, Dirt Devil, Kitchen Aid, Norelco and Waring. Besides obvious products, like shavers, vacuum cleaners and toaster ovens, the company repairs unusual items, like contact-lens sterilizers and mobility carts for the elderly. There's also a knife sharpener on staff.
Items need repairs for all sorts of reasons, Mr. Benson said. "The owners put coffee in the water compartment of the coffee maker, or they immerse the entire coffee maker in water to clean it." People also drop appliances, and some items just wear out.
For products under warranty, there is no repair charge if the customer provides a receipt. Other repairs depend on parts and labor. A new switch on a Hamilton Beach 10-speed blender, for example, costs around $13.
 
Don't Throw It Out
 A large part of George McNally's business is parts and accessories for small appliances. "It's silly to throw the whole coffee maker out because you break a glass decanter," said Mr. McNally, who has owned Electra-Craft, a Manhattan appliance repair shop, for seven years. New decanters can range from about $8 for a four-cup Mr. Coffee to $18 for a Braun.
Electra-Craft, a licensed service center for close to 40 manufacturers, stocks parts for appliances made by Braun, Hamilton Beach, Mr. Coffee, Proctor-Silex, Sunbeam and Waring, among others. The company repairs items both in and out of warranty. Many of the appliances Mr. McNally repairs develop problems because owners did not care for them properly. Blender blades, a common repair, go bad because the unit is not cleaned correctly or because they sit in liquid too long. "Milk can act like an acid on blades," he said.
Others simply get too much wear. Cords on irons frequently fray, he said. To repair them costs around $14.
Mr. McNally accepts items when the cost of repair is 50 percent or less than the replacement cost of the item. "You should really buy something new if it's more," he said.
Old appliances can also be difficult to repair, particularly if parts are not available. "We prefer that customers with antique appliances call before bringing them in," he said.
 
Here's Where

SOLOMON'S APPLIANCE REPAIR 1701 86th Street, at 17th Avenue, Bensonhurst, Brooklyn 11214; (718) 236-5065. Hours: Monday through Friday, 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturday until 2 P.M.; closed Saturdays, May through August.

HEADLINE: Essay;
How to Save Russia

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Hastening to beat Bill Clinton to the foreign-policy punch, President Bush proposed to assist democracy in the former Soviet republics with a package that not even James Baker could price or explain.
As it stands, the Bush-Kohl-I.M.F. proposal seems to be a project by an international bureaucracy to prop up the Russian Government in its hour of need. The payoff to us, under this theory, is that our aid will produce a less dangerous Russia, which will let us save money on defense. 
 That's the governmental way to think and a negative way to sell.
Our purpose should be both more idealistic and more practical: to help root private enterprise in the new republics and to encourage their prosperity. The payoff to us is in expanded trade and a stable world economy, which in turn will provide incentives for peace and limit wasteful arms spending.
You might expect that the first American President who once headed an oil company in Texas would zero in on the resource the new nations have in abundance: oil. Their oil reserves are their money in the bank.
Their current crisis is caused largely by their inability to get their oil and gas out of the ground and onto the sea lanes and pipelines. Twenty thousand wells capable of producing hundreds of thousands of barrels per day stand idle for lack of parts. Once in production, along with the development of new fields already identified, this resource would produce hard currency that would dwarf any foreign assistance now contemplated.
The central economic question of the year: How do we help the new republics get oil out of the ground and to market? For them, the right answer means the salvation of nascent democracy; for us, as Gary Hart points out, it also means the end of the OPEC cartel's ability to inflict inflation on the West.
The answer: a bit of "industrial policy," the use of government coordination to direct free enterprise toward a global economic goal.
A few of our major oil companies are held back by the influence of Saudi Arabia, but most oil importers are eager to invest in joint ventures with Russians, Kazakhs and the rest. Daniel Yergin, who just won a Pulitzer for his book on oil, says, "the former Soviet Union is the best bet going to add to reserves."
From the Caspian Sea to Sakhalin, the future of cheap non-nuclear fuel is in the land mass that is presently down on its luck. There's money to be made and jobs to be had for owner, developer, seller, transporter, buyer and user.
What's obstructing development? The vestige of Communism is one obstacle. The old apparatchiks at Pravda denounced "White Nights," a Siberian joint venture of a Russian company and the U.S.'s Phibro Energy, for "plundering Russia's underground riches." Former Communists see only a zero-sum game.
The reformers have been slow to make decisions about contracts and ownership, and Boris Yeltsin blundered by imposing an oil export tax instead of encouraging exports.
President Bush has been half-hearted and uncoordinated. His Energy Department was helpful in setting up January meetings between U.S. and Russian oilmen, but not until last week did the State Department sign an agreement that gives some impetus to the kind of investment incentive that will get new wells drilled.
Now the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC, not OPEC) is authorized to make loans and sell risk insurance to U.S. companies that establish ventures in Russia. OPIC's Fred Zeder contends that 200 companies have registered interest in investing $7 billion so far, many of them centered on oil and gas.
That's one way to start profitable enterprises in the U.S. interest when risks of expropriation or tumult are otherwise too great. OPIC's loss ratio is less than 1 percent, and it adds needed official coloration to meetings between U.S. businessmen and overseas public officials. "We don't lend money to governments," says Mr. Zeder. "That's how you lose your shirt."
The only way to help the new republics build free markets is to stimulate private investment. The main magnet is oil. The White House and the Kremlin should set up a joint task force to focus on this and start the wells and hard-currency profits pumping.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
'Time for a Change'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The message coming from the Democratic primaries could not be clearer. It is a cry of discontent -- of anger -- with things as they are. The voters are saying, "It is time for a change."
People coming out of the polling booths in New York were asked whether they agreed with "Jerry Brown's criticisms of the political system"; 70 percent answered yes. It was a clumsy question, because voters would have very different understandings of what "Jerry Brown's criticisms" were. But the overwhelming answer surely showed a high level of discontent. 
 The question is whether Bill Clinton, the now almost certain Democratic nominee, can channel that discontent into a constructive and persuasive vision of change in this country. I think it is going to be the crucial question of the campaign.
Americans are troubled by many things these days: by the way the rich have grown richer while most people have lost ground, by the arrogance of Congress members and Presidential aides in their enjoyment of perks, by the sense of falling behind other countries economically, by fear of illness without adequate health insurance . . .
A people so troubled may come to think that the whole system is rotten and must be overthrown. That is what Jerry Brown essentially stands for.
Nihilism can be appealing in painful times. It appealed to many in the late 1960's and early 1970's, when the established politicians had produced -- and most continued to defend -- the irrational horror of the Vietnam War. But "burn, baby, burn" was not a solution.
We are not today in an emotional crisis like that of the Vietnam period. But public disaffection from government is profound. Americans in large numbers think the system is incapable of solving the problems that are grinding them down. They see in Washington a Government that barely even pretends to deal with the hard issues of investment, unemployment, education, health and the rest.
The challenge of leadership is to make people believe again that government can make a difference. That is what Franklin Roosevelt did in far darker times: He offered not specifics but hope, and the feeling that someone in Washington was listening.
Voters are skeptical now, resistant. But they are far from writing off the system. After all, 70 percent in New York may have said they agreed with Governor Brown's criticisms of the system, but 70 percent voted for candidates who argue that government can work: 41 percent for Bill Clinton, 29 for Paul Tsongas.
Can Governor Clinton offer voters a believable vision of change? Can he persuade people that we can have effective government again, within the constitutional system that has kept us free for 200 years?
The answer turns in part on whether the press and television will allow Mr. Clinton's message to get through. Journalism has seemed lately to be in a competition to see who can produce the most frivolous, distorted, out-of-context attack on his "character." But that is another subject.
It is up to Mr. Clinton, in any event, to get a message across. There is no question of his intelligence or his ability to function in the give-and-take of politics. Other governors, Republican and Democratic, considered him the most capable in their ranks.
What remains to be seen is whether he can convince Americans that he offers hope. He can and should talk about economic growth and medical needs and political spending and other particulars. But the underlying question is belief in government.
Few of us are naive enough anymore to think that any President, any government, can quickly transform our society. The problems are beyond instant solutions.
But government can make a difference. The President of the United States can face up to the environmental dangers menacing the world, or he can hide from them. He can try to ameliorate our racial differences, or he can agitate them for partisan reasons. He can choose as judges men and women of varied backgrounds and politics, learned in the law, or he can pick judges from a narrow ideological caste.
If and as Bill Clinton works free of the mudslinging, he will have to make Americans believe again in the possibilities of government.
