HEADLINE: Japan Fears Decline in Stocks Will Undermine Its Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 10

 BODY:
The plunge in share prices here has grown so unnerving in the last week that a number of Japan's top Government officials and business leaders have begun to say the market's deepening malaise may soon start dragging down the Japanese economy and weakening the financial system.
It has long been an article of faith here that the stock market ultimately hewed to the dictates of powerful Government bureaucrats, and that the heart of the economy, manufacturing and industrial corporations, was little influenced by market ups and downs. 
 But the failure of a Government effort to halt the nose dive last week, and then the sudden fall here again late Thursday, just when it seemed to bottom out, have shattered that confidence. It is now clear, financial experts said, that the Government and leading banks simply do not have a means to arrest a decline that has wiped out more than 50 percent of the market's value since it peaked at the end of 1989.
The market soared today, however, aided by a rally in American markets. When the Federal Reserve reduced interest rates in the United States, that also heartened Japanese investors, analysts said today. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks closed today at 17,850.66, for a gain of 1,252.51 points of about 7.6 percent
But welcome as this news was, analysts said it would take more than one rally to erase the damage done to confidence here over the last two weeks. In addition, they said the market would probably have to recover about 25 percent of its value, putting the Nikkei well over 20,000, before the pressure on the economy and banks would be relieved.
"There are still reasons to be nervous," said Liam Newberg, a senior analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan.
If the market merely stabilizes or rises slightly, experts warn that the harm to the economy will persist and the blow to confidence will not be forgotten.
"We have been thinking about nothing else for several days, but there is nothing we can do," said a senior Finance Ministry official. He conceded that the Government's forecast for moderate economic growth this year was based on the assumption that stock prices would be at least 20 percent higher than they are now.
"If the stock market does not recover quite dramatically, we will have to reconsider those figures," he said.
Especially discouraging to many here was the way the market was whipsawed here on Thursday. After a tentative rebound, the Nikkei index turned, and ended down 577.38, or 3.4 percent, at 16,598.15. The close was the lowest since October 1986, and left the Nikkei down 10.6 percent this week.
Tokyo's plunge contributed to the big drops on Wall Street and in other world markets earlier this week. Those declines resulted in part from concerns that weakened Japanese financial institutions might be forced to sell holdings of foreign shares and that foreign investors who own Japanese shares might be forced to liquidate their holdings in the United States and elsewhere to cover big losses in Japan.
All this comes against a backdrop of signs that the Japanese economy has been slowing steadily in recent months after a five-year boom.
"I continue to believe in the fundamental strength of the Japanese economy and that it will rebound," said Hideo Ishihara, deputy president of the Industrial Bank of Japan, one of the country's most powerful financial institutions and architect of a stock market rescue plan after a crash in the 1960's. "But there isn't much we can do for the market now. I feel very helpless."
A deeper slowdown in the Japanese economy will clearly be felt in the United States and elsewhere. Slack demand in Japan is likely to crimp imports and increase exports. That could force Japan's already record trade surplus to soar and hurt American manufacturers exporting goods here. It could also worsen trade tensions with Washington.
 
Fear Feeding on Itself
 One reason for the new attitude is that most say the market appears to be responding not to economic factors, but to a frightened psychology that is feeding on itself.
The market began to slide in early 1990 when the Bank of Japan was raising interest rates. It then tumbled further after Iraq invaded Kuwait later in 1990, which threatened Japan's oil supplies.
No such factors are at play now. If anything, the economic outlook has brightened slightly after the Bank of Japan slashed interest rates last week as part of a stimulus package.
"I can't say precisely at what point it happened, but there was a point recently when the psychology of the market just changed," said Yasuhiko Jinza, manager of the stock investment department at the Nippon Life Insurance Company, the largest stockholder in Japan with 3 percent of all the shares here. "People just began to think prices would fall further because of all the fear, so they would sell."
Another sign of this psychology is a campaign by some brokers and Government officials to blame foreign securities houses for the depth of the decline. Some have claimed that program trading involving the use of stock index futures contracts have accelerated the downward trend. The foreign brokers here are among the most active program traders.
No one has produced evidence yet that this computer-assisted trading is responsible for the market swings, but there has been speculation that the Government will halt or dampen stock index futures trading. A number of Japanese portfolio managers have admitted that they are also heavy users of these securities.
Small investors have generally watched the decline from the sidelines, brokers say, with some who have borrowed heavily being forced to sell at big losses. The manager of a branch for a major securities house said his business had been drying up. "Some people are calling but most are just not coming in," he said. "They are astonished and frightened. They don't know how long they can afford to watch this without being forced to sell."
 
Making Consumers Cautious
 There are several ways the falling market may affect the economy, analysts say. The simplest is that by worrying consumers it causes them to be more cautious. There are already signs of a slowdown in consumer spending, particularly on imported luxury goods.
More important is the effect the market can have on banks. Japanese banks are permitted to own up to 5 percent of the stock in industrial and other companies. The unrealized gains on these shares, often acquired several decades ago, can be counted as part of the banks' capital, the cash cushion banks use to cover loan losses.
But the severe drop in the market has slashed the value of those portfolios and thus reduced capital. That makes them more vulnerable to problems from loan losses -- at a time when bankruptcies are running at a record level -- and slows their ability to provide new loans. A slowing of credit to the economy could squelch a recovery.
In addition, there are widespread expectations that the market's tumble is likely to force a number of second- and third-tier brokerage houses to cut back sharply or even shut down. There have even been rumors that one of the largest firms might be facing financial difficulties.
"We've already started seeing signs of these problems," said Yasuhiro Oshima, chief of one of the stock portfolio management groups at the Bank of Tokyo, a big investor. "They haven't fully emerged yet, but if the market stays at this level just a few weeks, financial institutions will suffer potentially severe difficulties, that is for sure."
Mr. Oshima added: "I've thought about, but I can't find the precise words to describe what this market feels like. It's scary. There's no precedent in Japan."
In addition, the weak market has made it impossible for industrial corporations to raise capital by selling new shares. The Tokyo market was a fountain of capital during the late 1980's, helping to finance a heavy wave of investment by corporate Japan in new plants, more efficient equipment and new technology.
 
Investment Budgets Cut
 With that source of funds closed down, corporations are reducing capital investment budgets, another factor in the slowdown in demand for goods in Japan.
One irony is that some features of the financial system that were meant to create confidence in the past are now undermining it. For instance, Japanese banks disclose few of the financial details that American banks are required to provide to investors.
Regulators in the Finance Ministry have argued for years that such information would only frighten the public, which they say does not know how to evaluate the information accurately. However, many market experts are now saying that the lack of clarity is spooking the market.
"Because people don't know for sure, they are assuming the worst-case scenario" about the level of banks' loan losses, said Akio Mikuni, president of Mikuni & Company, a credit rating agency here.

HEADLINE: Fed Moves Again to Spur Growth And the Markets Respond Briskly

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Amid concern that the economic recovery remains dangerously weak, the Federal Reserve moved today to stimulate growth by pushing down an influential interest rate.
The Fed pumped more money into the nation's banking system to reduce the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks lend each other money overnight -- to 3.75 percent from 4 percent. 
 "The Fed has to be worried about keeping the little recovery we have going," said Allen Sinai, economic adviser to the Boston Company. It cannot afford to have a 'triple dip' or anything like that."
 
Dow Gains 43.61
 The cut surprised and cheered the financial markets. In the stock market, the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average rose 43.61 points, to 3,224.96, regaining almost half of the 94 points it lost on Tuesday and Wednesday. In the credit market, long-term bond yields fell and short-term interest rates plunged to their lowest levels in nearly 20 years. [Pages D6 and D15.]
Nervous that the sluggish economy could hurt their election chances this November, the White House and many Congressional Republicans and Democrats have in recent weeks urged the Federal Reserve to cut rates again. They repeatedly said that one reason the weak recovery that began last spring petered out last fall was that the Fed had moved too slowly to lower rates.
"This being a Presidential election year might explain why the Fed didn't want to run the risk of doing nothing, because that could abort the recovery," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist, at the PNC Financial Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based bank holding company. "But at the same time, the Fed might have learned something from what happened last year."
The cuts in the funds rate could help bring down rates for consumer loans, adjustable-rate mortgages and loans to companies as banks pass on to consumers the lower rates they pay for money.
"Today's cut in the Federal funds rate implies a reduction in short-term interest rates across the board," said Hugh Johnson, chief economist for the First Albany Corporation, a New York-based brokerage.
Economists also said that a small increase of two-tenths of a percent in March producer prices that was announced today helped pave the way for the rate cut by reducing fears that inflation would ignite as the economy grows.
And some analysts speculated that an aim of today's action was to calm domestic investors shaken by the effect on American markets of Japan's plunging stocks. But a Fed spokesman said, "The Japanese stock market had nothing to do with today's action."
Over the last two months, the Administration and many economists have voiced optimism that a recovery is taking hold based on a pickup in retail sales and housing starts. But analysts said today that the Fed had apparently become alarmed when it discovered that for the second straight week the money supply had fallen sharply. Economists say the Fed is concerned that the weak money supply numbers could push up interest rates and hamper the already fragile recovery.
 
Money Supply Cited
 "The primary motivation in my view was their increasing worry about the weakness in the money supply," said Robert Giordano, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs. "It's really the Fed's need to demonstrate that they're on the job more than a genuine sign that the weakness in the money supply means the recovery was in deep danger."
Today, the Fed reported a sharp $7 billion drop last week in the most closely watched measure of the money supply, which followed an even steeper drop of more than $10 billion the previous week.
Economists said the central bank was no doubt also concerned about the lack of growth in employment in March that the Labor Department reported last Friday.
The Fed's most recent rate cuts came last Dec. 20, when it drastically lowered the Federal funds rate and the discount rate -- the rate at which it lends money to banks. It lowered the discount rate a full percentage point, to 3 1/2 percent, from 4 1/2 percent, and the Fed funds rate by a half percentage point, to 4 percent from 4 1/2 percent.
 
Some Added Insurance
 In recent months, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has often said he thought the cuts announced on Dec. 20 would be enough to insure a recovery, but today's move signaled that the Fed had become convinced that some additional insurance was needed to protect the recovery.
"It is a preventive, pre-emptive move to support this fledgling recovery," said Mr. Sinai, the economist. "The danger that another failure in the recovery would have to confidence, psychology, the economy and world markets is great."
Today's move could also strengthen the American economy by helping to weaken the dollar and thus spur exports, economists said. Lower interest rates discourage demand for dollars, but a weaker dollar then encourages foreign purchases of United States goods. The export sector has been one of the strongest sectors in the economy, but economic slowdowns in Europe and Japan are threatening export growth.
Some economists also suggest that today's move was designed to help Japan's central bank lower interest rates further to buoy Tokyo's falling equity markets. The Fed's rate cut reduces fears in Japan that the yen will plunge if the Japanese central bank cuts rates.
"For a whole bunch of reasons," said Mr. Hoffman, the economist, "the Fed decided to take out another insurance premium in the form of lower rates."
 
Meeting in March
 Economists said today's move was probably approved at the March 31 Federal Open Market Committee meeting, the central monetary policy group composed of the seven members of the Federal Reserve board and five presidents of Federal Reserve districts.
The central bank does not announce changes in the Federal funds rate, but the Fed added money to the banking system this morning, making clear that it was cutting that rate.
Some economists said it was understandable that the Fed would insist that today's move had nothing to do with Japan's markets. They said that if today's rate cut was construed as trying to support domestic markets -- which would be a highly unusual move for the Fed -- some investors might say the Fed must think the situation was extraordinarily grave.
In addition, if the Fed's move wasviewed as seeking to buoy American markets against Japan's shocks and if the American markets continued to fall, then it would appear the Fed was weak and had wasted its ammunition.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Canadians Cut Prime
 TORONTO, April 9 (Special to The New York Times) -- Three major Canadian banks announced today that they were cutting their prime rate by one-quarter percentage point, as the Bank of Canada, the country's central bank, signaled further relaxation of its monetary policy.
The Royal Bank of Canada, the Toronto-Dominion Bank and the Bank of Nova Scotia said they were dropping the rate they charge their most creditworthy customers to 8 percent, from 8 1/4 percent, where it has been since early March.
The Bank of Canada set its bank rate today at 7.21 percent, down from 7.41 percent last week and the lowest since Jan. 23. This rate is set each week one-quarter percentage point above the average yield on 90-day Treasury bills sold at auction to financial institutions.
"These moves are designed to address economic weakness," said Robert Palombi, economist with MMS International, "and could alleviate some of the selling pressure in the stock market."
Toronto stocks have been depressed in recent weeks by uncertainties related to the real estate and resources empire of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which is expected to present a plan to restructure its debts at a meeting of nearly 100 creditors in Toronto on Monday.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Gives the Nikkei a Break

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 10

 BODY:
The rally on Wall Street appears to have given the Japanese stock market a respite. Share prices soared today after two weeks of relentless declines.
The Nikkei index of 225 stocks ended the week at 17,850.66, up 1,252.51 points, or 7.6 percent, on the day. Volume was about 380 million shares. For the week, the index fell 709.05, or 3.8 percent. 
 Reuters credited the day's gains to a huge amount of index-linked buying and bargain hunting.
Analysts and traders said they were heartened by the rebound, but said it had not yet ended the possibility of further declines. They attributed much of the enthusiasm to a spillover from the New York rally set off by the Federal Reserve's move to lower interest rates. In turn, Japanese interest rates dropped, contributing to a rally in bonds here.
"We think the bloodbath is over, but there is certainly a possibility that we could go down to 16,000," said Alan Bell, deputy head of research at Baring Securities here. "We just think it is likely to be more orderly from now on."
A move Thursday by the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates in the United States sparked that rally. In turn, the Fed's action helped push Japanese interest rates lower early today, contributing to a big rally in the Japanese bond market, analysts said.
The market here also jumped up on rumors that the Finance Ministry and other authorities might change rules that permit investors to bet on a falling market. The process is called selling short, and it involves selling borrowed shares in the hope of profiting by replacing them with shares bought later for less.
According to the unconfirmed rumors, the authorities would ban investors from borrowing the shares they want to sell short. This rumor started heavy buying by investors with short positions.

HEADLINE: The Noriega Verdict;
'Appalling Chapter' Ends for Panama

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, April 9

 BODY:
President Guillermo Endara of Panama said today that the conviction of Panama's former strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, on drug-trafficking charges "closes an appalling chapter in the history of Panama."
But many other people here gave only passing attention to the outcome of the trial in Miami. 
 President Endara, who was sworn in as President hours after the United States sent troops to Panama on Dec. 20, 1989, to capture General Noriega, also said today's verdict in Miami was "a call to reflection."
"The only way to govern is according to the law and in favor of the people," he continued. "Those who don't follow that path will encounter the fate of the Noriegas."
 
'Crime Doesn't Pay'
 As news spread here of the outcome of the seven-month trial, radio interviewers began to gather comments from a number of people who played a role in the events leading to the trial.
The Rev. Javier Villanueva, the priest who picked up General Noriega after the general decided to seek asylum in the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve 1989, said the verdict was evidence that "crime doesn't pay."
Several public figures expressed anger that the murder and corruption charges still pending here against General Noriega in about 30 cases had not moved forward with the same speed as the Miami trial even though Panamanian law permitted trial and conviction in absentia.
The Panamanian cases that have received wide publicity involve accusations that General Noriega ordered the 1985 killing of Dr. Hugo Spadafora, a prominent political opponent, and the executions of about a dozen members of the Panamanian Defense Forces who tried to overthrow him in the rising political tensions here in 1988-89.
 
'Various Cases' Pending
 Attorney General Rogelio Cruz said in an interview on Wednesday that some of the pending cases were still being investigated while others were already in the courts. He said that "various cases" would be resolved before the end of the year.
While Panamanians widely accept that it is unlikely General Noriega will ever be brought back here to stand trial or to serve a sentence, political leaders and legal experts said convictions here would help to amass information to use against his collaborators and to demonstrate that the justice system in Panama was improving.
While Panamanian news organizations -- now freer and more informative than at any time in modern memory -- have given daily coverage to the Noriega trial, with several sending correspondents to Miami, most people appear to view General Noriega and his era as being over and done with.
Although President Endara said last week that if General Noriega was acquitted of all charges in the United States, Panama would bring him home and prosecute him, most Panamanians saw that as unlikely.
Ricardo Arias Calderon, the Christian Democrat who leads the opposition to Mr. Endara but who was his ally in opposition to General Noriega, said having General Noriega here for trial and possible imprisonment would "stir up things" while Panama is trying to rebuild the economy and build democracy.
"Panama today is concerned with the present and the future," he said. "Noriega being here would mean having to worry with the past."
Mr. Cruz, noting that General Noriega had made the decision to give himself up to the United States for trial instead of the new Panamanian authorities after he sought asylum in an embassy, said the former strongman "didn't want to confront the ire of the people."
"Up there, in Miami, he was allowed to dress as a military man," the attoreney general said, "and wrap himself in the flag of nationalism and pretend to be a war prisoner. Here, he wouldn't have been allowed to do that."
Other people today generally praised the outcome, but some complained about the fact that he had been removed from Panama for trial.
 
Thoughts Under the Sun
 A group of construction workers near one of the numerous high rise buildings going up in Panama City paused under the intense afternoon sun and one of them said that while he had not approved of the way General Noriega ran Panama he wondered "why, if a Panamanian does something wrong here, they have to come get him and send him up there to be tried."
The Endara Government, which has said it believes that most of General Noriega's wealth is deposited or invested outside of Panama, has also initiated a number of civil suits in the United States and one in London in an effort to recover some of that wealth.
One seeks to recover $20 million estimated to be impounded in Florida from the bankrupt Bank of Credit and Commerce International, where General Noriega is said to have deposited many millions of dollars.

HEADLINE: Bush and Baker Press Aid to Russia but Meet Worries About Costs

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The Bush Administration began a campaign to win public and Congressional support for its aid package for Russia. But some lawmakers, who weeks ago had been urging the Administration to do more for Russia, expressed worries today about the costs of the program.
President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d used separate public appearances to make their most spirited and forceful argument yet in favor of American taxpayers' helping Russia achieve a free-market democracy, with Mr. Bush terming it "the most important foreign policy opportunity of our time." 
 Many of the lawmakers pressed Mr. Baker to detail what the package would cost the American taxpayer, something that he has never really done. In part, this is because the Administration apparently is not anxious in this election season to have a specific price tag associated with the plan -- at least until it has the stamp of approval of the Democratically controlled Congress.
And in part it is because of the complex nature of the aid -- a combination of credits, loans and cash programs, in the form of new money and old money -- which makes coming up with a single price tag complicated. A rough calculation, though, suggests that the package involves between $3 billion and $4 billion in potential outlays.
The overwhelming reaction of lawmakers whom Mr. Baker addressed in an appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee could be summarized as supportive but wary, with several senators arguing that they would have a lot easier time selling Russian aid to taxpayers if the Administration were doing more at home.
"Let me suggest that for an awful lot of people in this country, defining moments are happening every day," Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said after Mr. Baker told the committee that this was a defining moment in relations with Russia.
"I've introduced legislation to deal with cities -- far less than what we're talking about here over five or six years," added Mr. Dodd, who is running for re-election this year.
"I'll guarantee you that there'd be no rush to deal with legislation by July or August to provide some assistance and encourage economic development in the Bridgeports, the Hartfords, the Detroits or San Franciscos. I would guess public support for this is not very high, because people are disappointed that we're not doing enough on the domestic agenda."
Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said at the outset of Mr. Baker's appearance, "The American people are fed up with foreign aid, and they want to know what the American people get out of it."
Many other senators, though, including Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, expressed more unreserved support for the Administration's efforts, or as Mr. Biden remarked: "I suspect everyone else here intends to work energetically with you to enact this program. I think it's going to go through here like a hot knife through butter."
Both Mr. Baker and President Bush, who spoke to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, urged Congress to pass the Administration's contribution to the $24 billion allied effort to aid Russian democracy in time for Mr. Yeltsin's Washington summit meeting with Mr. Bush on June 16 and 17. The Administration today also gave a green light for Mr. Yeltsin to go to Munich for a meeting with the Group of Seven major industrial democracies, after their summit meeting there on July 6.
 
How Russia Fits Vision
 In their appearances today, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker, sought for the first time to counter opposition to Russian aid, and press their agenda, by sketching a vision of America's role in the post-cold-war world, and how aid to Russia fits into that vision and enhances basic American strategic and economic interests. This comes after months of either garbled or very low-key support for Russian assistance.
Echoing themes of Administration critics, including Gov. Bill Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and former President Richard M. Nixon, Mr. Bush argued that passage of the Freedom Support Act, as the American-Russian aid package is known, would be the keystone of a post-cold-war American effort to "build a democratic peace" with all the former Communist lands.
The peace in the cold war, Mr. Baker argued, "was not a genuine peace at all," but rather "the avoidance of war was achieved only through confrontation, tension, and the haunting shadow and threat of nuclear holocaust."
Today, he added, "we face a wholly different and novel situation, a chance to build a genuine peace based on common democratic values, to build a democratic peace with Russia and Eurasia. A democratic peace would be a genuine peace; it would not be just the absence of war. That is a purpose that is worthy of the American people, and that is a purpose that we think all Americans will be willing to support."
Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker offered several arguments, including the notion that "real democracies" do not go to war with one another and that the growth of democracy and free markets in Russia and Eurasia can be a new source of trade and investment for American businesses.
 
Warning of a 'Dark Future'
 "The success of reform in Russia, and Ukraine, Armenia and Kazakhstan, Belarus and the Baltics will be the single best guarantee of our security, our prosperity and our values," Mr. Bush said. "The failure of the democratic experiment could bring a dark future, a return to authoritarianism or a descent into anarchy."
When pressed for the bottom-line American contribution to the package, Mr. Baker said it consisted of "old money" -- that is, funds previously requested by the Administration by not yet approved by Congress -- and "new money" requests. The old money is $620 million in technical and humanitarian assistance and $3.75 billion in credits for the former Soviet republics to purchase American grain, which have already been spent.
Also in this old-money category are $12 billion in loan guarantees for the International Monetary Fund, which have also been requested by the Administration before, but not forcefully. The I.M.F. will be supervising the overall international aid effort, and this $12 billion would be used to help finance imports to Russia at a time when it is short of hard currency.
Mr. Baker said the new-money requests in the package consist of $1.1 billion in new grain credits, $1.5 billion as the United States share of the $6 billion currency stabilization fund, and about $500 million to $1 billion in expanded authority for the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank to underwrite American businesses wishing to invest in the former Soviet Union.
Some of these funds are hard dollars and others are simply credits or loan guarantees that will have a big impact for the Russians, but cost the American taxpayers little. For instance, the $12 billion for the I.M.F. actually involves the United States' extending a line of credit for this amount to the fund. The fund would then loan this amount to Russia and would be responsible for overseeing the debt.

HEADLINE: DISTRUST OF U.S. HINDERS IRAN CHIEF

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, April 9

 BODY:
The boulevards are no longer clogged with demonstrators tramping over American flags and the vitriolic condemnations of United States foreign policy in the press have lost some of their sting.
But distrust, even fear, of the United States run deep in Iran, sentiments that have slowed the efforts of President Hashemi Rafsanjani to expand trade ties and foreign investment and perhaps even to open a political dialogue with Washington. 
 A visitor returning to Iran after a decade found that many Iranian officials and ordinary citizens are still seized with the image of the United States as an overwhelming superpower bent on humiliating Iran and dominating the region.
Why is it, they want to know, that the United States pinned a medal on the captain of the ship that shot down an Iranian airliner, killing 290 people, during the Iran-Iraq war in 1988? And was it just a coincidence that the State Department announced a few days later that Iran would remain on the list of nations supporting terrorism?
 
A Double Standard Is Seen
 They accuse the United States of a employing a double standard on democracy because of America's refusal to embrace a popular Islamic movement in Algeria, and they find it inconsistent that Washington justified its invasion of Panama but went to war over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
They do not understand why the Bush Administration was poised to intercept a North Korean ship carrying Scud-C missiles to Iran, while at the same time it is preparing to sell advanced F-15E fighter planes to Saudi Arabia. And it is difficult to convince even Iranians sympathetic to the United States that the Administration did not purposely leave President Saddam Hussein in power in Iraq.
They cite statements by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during a recent visit to Central Asia that new predominantly Muslim republics of the former Soviet Union should look to Turkey, not Iran, as a model, as proof that the United States wants to dominate the region through what they call its "puppet ally" in Ankara. And they bemoan the United States military presence in the Persian Gulf, particularly now that the Soviet Union no longer exists -- a situation, a diplomat said, "that genuinely frightens them."
Perhaps the biggest frustration faced by Mr. Rafsanjani and his group of supporters is trying to figure out why they received what they regarded as a small return for helping to free American hostages being held by Iranian-backed terrorist groups in Lebanon.
"All along, the American Government told Iran that the hostages were the main obstacle to an improvement in relations, so Iran helped free them, and then nothing happened," said a Western diplomat who refused to be named. "In a way, its diplomacy backfired, because the United States turned around and said, 'See, they were in control of the hostages all the time.' "
Mr. Rafsanjani personally intervened to help win the release of the last American hostages, expending not only political capital but, according to United States officials in Washington, also spending about $1 million for each hostage released. But he had little to show for his efforts.
 
Inconsistent Statements
 "How could he make another move?" said a Foreign Ministry official who deals with the United States.
Since becoming President in August 1989, Mr. Rafsanjani has shifted signals on future relations with the United States, depending on the domestic political winds. In March of last year, he said Iran was ready to improve relations with the United States as soon as it abandoned its "hostility toward Iran." Two months later, he told the seminary at Teheran University, "Iran is not thinking about restoring relations with the United States."
Foreign diplomats in Teheran are convinced that if Mr. Rafsanjani could have his way, he would move to improve ties, particularly if it helped Iran to acquire much-needed economic aid and foreign investment.
But discreetly and slowly, Iran has already moved closer to the United States. In 1991, Iranian imports of American goods totaled $527 million, a nearly ninefold increase from just two years before. American-made goods are creeping back into Iran -- from Pontiac Firebirds in the streets to Marlboro cigarettes in the shops.
It has been left to Mr. Rafsanjani's supporters to go further. Mohammed Javad Larijani, a senior presidential adviser running in parliamentary elections Friday, last year suggested "a marriage of convenience" without a resumption in formal ties.
 The issue of contacts with America is so sensitive, however, that Mahmoud Vaezi, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Europe and the Americas, found himself on the defensive after he met with Cyrus R. Vance, a United Nations special envoy and former American Secretary of State, during a trip through Azerbaijan and Armenia this month.
Mr. Vaezi successfully deflected the criticism, calling the meeting "absolutely correct," and adding: "It was nothing important, just a quick hello."
No one is talking about a warming of relations with Washington during the current campaign for the Iranian Parliament, or Majlis. In the weeks leading up to the elections, Mr. Rafsanjani has avoided the subject. His opponents, however, have used the current campaign to accuse him of straying from the goals of Ayatollah Khomeini's revolution and to voice their fierce opposition to a reconciliation between Iran and the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Iran is not thinking about restoring relations with the United States," President Hashemi Rafsanjani said. But foreign diplomats in Teheran are convinced that if he could he would move to improve ties. (Kazemi/Safir/Saba)

HEADLINE: House Adopts Major Changes in Its Management

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
After hours of partisan wrangling, the House tonight approved Democratic proposals to put its day-to-day administration under new management, with Republicans given an unheard-of veto on the hiring of two new high-ranking officials.
Republicans, seeking to exploit Democrats' embarrassment over the House bank scandal and charges of drug-dealing at the House post office, said these concessions were not enough and refused to agree on a package drawn up by a bipartisan study group. 
 They demanded that Democrats not only make further concessions on administrative matters but also on legislative rules changes intended to give them a more effective voice when the House and its committees consider bills on the floor and in committee.
On two party-line votes, the House adopted the Democratic plan, 269 to 81, with 64 Republicans voting present, after defeating the Republican measure, 254 to 159. On that vote, no Democrats voted for the proposal and no Republicans voted against it, although there were 22 absentees. On the second, 16 Republicans and three Democrats voted with the other party.
The tone of the debate was unusually bitter, even for a session that has been marked by intense, personal divisive controversy since it began in January, and which has produced almost no legislation that will end up on the statute books.
The House minority leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, scoffed at the Democrats' claims of generosity in sharing power. " 'Unprecedented' isn't enough," he said. He said the Democrats were adopting half-measures "out of panic." He promised that if the Republicans won control of the next Congress, they would adopt all the concessions he asked from the Democrats tonight.
The majority whip, Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, argued "Republicans are not really interested in reform at all." He said "Stop the hypocrisy. Stop the posturing. Stop the political games and let's get on and do something about the Republican recession."
 
Administrative Changes
 The major changes in the Democratic package would create a director of nonlegislative and financial services, to run such activities as pay and benefits for members and staff, internal mail and office furnishings and supplies, and establish an inspector general with wide auditing responsibilities.
Both of those posts would be filled only on unanimous agreement of the Speaker and the majority and minority leaders -- a sharing of power with Republicans that would have been unimaginable before the scandal at the House bank was disclosed.
The Republican proposal created similar offices under slightly different conditions, and called for sharing more administrative powers between the parties.
But the major thrust of their substitute was on legislative matters, seeking to get more Republicans on the Rules Committee and other committees, reduce committee staffing and prohibit voting by proxy in subcommittees and committees. Proxy voting is not permitted on the House floor. The Republicans also sought to prohibit franked mailing outside a member's district, a provision included in the campaign finance bill that the House passed earlier today over their solid opposition.
Renewing complaints they have made steadily all year, Republicans argued that 38 years of Democratic control of the House had produced corruption, and, as Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of upstate New York, said, "breakdown of the legislative process and growing procedural unfairness."
But Democrats argued that the Republicans' problem was that they could not win enough elections to control the House. Though power may corrupt, said Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, "The absence of power can make people very cranky." He added, "With a lack of power comes irresponsibility."
Speaker Thomas S. Foley defended the Democratic plan as "the most far-reaching reforms of the non-legislative administration of the House of Representatives" in history.
But Representative Tom Ridge, Republican of Pennsylvania, insisted that the auditing powers of the new inspector general were so hamstrung that he or she would be "a lap dog." Instead, he said, the House needs "a pit bull."
Both the Democratic plan and the Republican plan promised an end to perks for House members. One lonely voice defended such privileges as parking and franked mail. Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio, said he did not want to leave his car in the Reflecting Pool. He needed franked mail, he said, because "town criers don't cut it any more."
But most of the evening was devoted to snarling exchanges.
Representative Craig T. James, Republican of Florida, said the Democratic plan amounted to a "continuing coverup."
Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, accused junior Republicans of "McCarthyism."
Representative Jerry Lewis of California, the third-ranking House Republican, assailed the "corrupt administration" of the House.
And one Republican after another assailed proxy voting as "ghost voting."

HEADLINE: Mother Is Bludgeoned to Death

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
In the 10 years that he lived with his mother in a spacious Washington Heights apartment, Darren Lee was an unobtrusive, if familiar presence, best known to his neighbors for swaying to the silent beat of his headphones and toting a large valise he said carried his artwork.
But Wednesday night in a rage that stunned residents of his well-kept building at 330 Wadsworth Avenue, the 25-year-old man bludgeoned his mother, Gloria Lee, 53, to death with a hammer in the apartment they shared, the police said. Mr. Lee was charged with murder yesterday. 
 Detective Joseph McConville, a Police Department spokesman, said Mr. Lee had a history of mental illness and had been treated at Harlem Hospital as recently as last month.
Stephanie Mack, deputy executive director of Harlem Hospital, said she could not confirm whether Mr. Lee had been treated at the hospital because of patient-confidentiality rules.
Lieut. Joseph Reznick of the 34th Precinct said Ms. Lee made an urgent telephone call to another son, Martin, around 9 P.M. on Wednesday, saying she was having problems with Darren. When Mr. Lee arrived several minutes later, he found his mother dead in her bedroom, Lieutenant Reznick said. Ms. Lee had been struck numerous times in the head with a hammer, which was recovered at the scene, the police said.
Relatives told the police that Darren Lee was unemployed and had been treated in city hospitals for mental illness, the lieutenant said. He said there was no evidence Ms. Lee had called the police in the past to complain about problems with her son.
Neighbors said Ms. Lee moved into a five-room, second-floor apartment in the Wadsworth Avenue building, at West 190th Street, in 1982 and raised her four children there by herself.
Three of the children later moved away, but Darren, the youngest, stayed with his mother. Described by neighbors as a short, stocky man who walked with a boxer's swagger, Mr. Lee told the building's porter, Felix Ramos, that he was attending art school. But the police said there was no evidence he was in such a school.
Mr. Ramos observed, "He never, never threatened anybody."

HEADLINE: Dow Rebounds 43.61 on Rate Move by Fed

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks rebounded yesterday, as anxiety eased, at least for a day, over a market downturn and weakness in Tokyo. After the Federal Reserve moved to ease interest rates, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered nearly half the 94 points it lost the two previous days.
The Dow drifted upward at the opening, and suddenly vaulted more than 30 points just before noon. It floated to a peak at 2 P.M., and remained well above 3,200 for the rest of the day, closing at 3,224.96, up 43.61, or 1.4 percent. 
 Analysts and money managers voiced concern, however, that the day's rebound might not prevent a further fall in the near future.
"I don't think this market is yet out of the woods," said Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "What happened in Japan was more of a catalyst than anything else. The market was responding to its own problems."
Yesterday's surge was accelerated by computer-driven program trading that was touched off when news hit the market that the Fed had cut its target for the Federal funds rate to 3.75 from 4 percent. The bank does not announce such shifts, but economists saw the change.
The sudden rise "was a pretty broad movement, involving about 950 stocks," said Philip Smyth, an analyst at Birinyi Associates.
Trading was heavy, at 232.3 million shares, down slightly from Wednesday's 249.2 million. Gaining issues outpaced losing ones by 1,280 to 523.
The Nasdaq composite index climbed 13.07 points, or 2.28 percent, to 586.75, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.14 points, to 400.64. The American Stock Exchange index rose 5.04 points, to 385.94, while the Russell Index of 2,000 stocks went up 3.20 points, to 196.23.
"A lot of it was pure bounce from the last two days," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Mutual Funds. "People are getting used to buying on a dip."
Trude Latimer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, warned that further declines might follow. "It may take more than a day or two to bring back confidence," she said. "The bears in this market are not going to be convinced after just one day."
One of yesterday's most active stocks was First Data, which was one of the market's largest initial public offerings ever, with 44 million shares sold. First Data began trading in midafternoon at 22 1/8, and closed up only 1/8, at 22 1/4, with more than five million shares traded on the day.
That price was well below the $24 to $26 originally forecast by the stock's underwriting group, led by Lehman Brothers, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Transport stocks rose sharply, pushing the Dow Jones transportion average up 36.99 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,338.56.
AMR, the holding company for American Airlines, rose 3 1/8, to 71 7/8, after announcing new fares that the company said would add $300 million to $350 million to its annual revenue. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, also rose 2 1/2, to 133 1/4. Delta Air Lines went up 1 1/2, to 60 3/4, and Airborne Freight rose 2 1/8, to 23 7/8.
In other areas, Molecular Biosystems rose 3 3/8, to 27 1/4, after the company announced that it had received a positive Food and Drug Administration evaluation for Albunex.
Brokerage stocks, which have fallen sharply in recent sessions, also gained some lost ground. Morgan Stanley went up 1 7/8, to 50 5/8; Merrill Lynch rose 2 1/4, to 51 3/8, and Salomon Brothers climbed 1 7/8, to 28 7/8.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Many Fears Of the Electorate

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THOUGH the recession appears to be ending, the voters remain anxious and angry, as this week's primaries showed once again. What explains their mood?
Daniel Yankelovich, president of the Public Agenda Foundation, said in an interview that the unusually high level of voter anxiety stemmed not from current economic conditions but from fears about the economy's future. Usually, he said, the American people look at a recession like a traffic jam; they expect that as soon as the jam is broken they will soon be speeding along the highway as before. But this time, people are afraid that something has gone terribly wrong with the system, and their future and their children's future are in real trouble. 
 High on their worry list is a shortage of savings, especially among the baby-boom generation. Young families have most of their savings, if any, in the equity value of their homes. While the boom was on in the 1980's, their "savings" were rising year by year, as housing prices went up. Now, with real estate values falling, they see their life savings disappearing.
And people are worried about the security of their jobs. In this recession, they have seen not just blue-collar, factory or construction jobs wiped out, but also white-collar jobs, positions in middle management and in services. And they are afraid the jobs will not come back, under pressure of technological change and foreign competition. Job worries spill into worries about health care; people are asking, Mr. Yankelovich said, "What do we do if I lose my job and somebody in the family gets sick?"
A recent survey sponsored by the private, bipartisan Council on Competitiveness, a group of business executives, labor leaders and university presidents, documents these anxieties. Of 1,094 people polled nationwide, 60 percent said the standard of living of the average American family was "getting worse."
Eighty-one percent said job security among older workers was "just fair," "not so good," or "poor." And 80 percent also said job opportunities for young people who are starting out were "just fair," "not so good," or "poor." Nearly three-fourths of those polled said the challenge to America posed by foreign economic competition was "still ahead," while only 18 percent said it was behind us.
What does this mood of public anxiety over the economic future mean for America's political future? The historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. contends that American politics runs in "generational" cycles, with anti-government, laissez-faire waves giving way to pro-activist government waves over a 30-year span.
In an interview in the November-December issue of Challenge magazine, he contends that the tide is now turning toward a demand that Government play an activist role in solving a list of problems "impressive in scope and breadth." These include "the widening disparities in income and opportunity; the multiplication of the poor and the underclass; the slowdown on racial justice; the decline of heavy industry before competition abroad and the microchip at home; the deterioration of education; the pollution of the environment and the decay of infrastructure; the rotting away of the great cities; the health crisis; the mounting burden of public and private debt; the spread of crime and violence."
Indeed, so formidable is the list of problems that it leaves voters in a state of skepticism, even cynicism, that the politicians can tackle and solve them. Thus far, the Presidential candidates, racing from primary to primary, have sought to convince voters that they do know the names of the problems and have plans (but they do not mention money) for solving them.
Even apart from the costs of servicing the debt, most of what the Government takes in through the existing tax system is committed to entitlement programs, military programs, and the costs of bailing out the savings and loans, with little left over for major new initiatives.
The no-tax-increase commitment of President Bush, which has been reinforced during the campaign by the taunt of Patrick Buchanan that the President had gone back on his word, leaves the Republicans in a box from which there appears to be no escape -- except by deep cuts in expenditures, which they are loath to make with the economy moving so sluggishly out of recession.
The Democrats, facing an electorate that in its anti-government, anti-politician mood does not want to fork over higher taxes, are in much the same bind as the Republicans. Jerry Brown tried to escape by a combination of a flat tax and a value-added tax. But once its regressivity and burdens on the poor and aged were understood, he was forced to run for the hills before the political dam broke over his head, which it now seems to have done anyway.
The radical change in the generational political cycle toward an activist government may be living a kind of shadow existence. With voters distrusting the politicians at the same time that they are angry with them for doing nothing to solve the problems that have been accumulating for a generation, the political cycle may be stuck in its anti-activist-government phase. But that could change after the election, as happened after 1932 and 1960.

HEADLINE: North Korea Assembly Backs Atom Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 9

 BODY:
After six years of delay, the North Korean Parliament ratified an agreement today to allow international inspectors into nuclear installations, starting the clock on a 90-day deadline to open up the plants where the Communist Government is believed to be developing atomic weapons.
Parliament's action, reported today by North Korea's official news agency, came with an assurance from Choe Hak Gun, the Minister of Atomic Energy Industry, that his country will now "accept nuclear inspection without delay." 
 Nonetheless, the agency said Parliament had attached a condition to approval, saying inspections would be permitted only if no other country threatened North Korea with nuclear attack.
It was not clear whether that condition would be invoked to try to slow an initial survey of the country's nuclear apparatus. A senior official of the International Atomic Energy Agency, however, said today that he believed that there would still be several roadblocks to overcome before inspectors are allowed to visit Yongbyon, the nuclear complex near Pyongyang, the capital.
 
Agency Awaiting List
 "We are still awaiting a complete list from North Korea of its facilities so that we can make the inspections," said the official, who said he was still fearful that North Korea might try to hide key nuclear installations. "If the list does not appear complete, then we can turn to the United Nations Security Council for help."
The official said the Atomic Energy Agency "fully expects" to have the list by the end of May, in time for its next full meeting, which is scheduled for June. Hans Blix, the agency's chief, is expected to travel to North Korea in the next few months.
North Korea signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty six years ago, but never approved an inspection plan for its nuclear installations. It long maintained that it would not allow inspection until the United States removed all its nuclear weapons from bases in South Korea. At the end of last year, Seoul announced that the American forces South Korea had done that and said its soil was nuclear-free.
In recent months international pressure on North Korea has grown rapidly. Japan has refused to consider a restoration of diplomatic relations, much less deep economic ties, until North Korea dismantles its nuclear installations.
 
Satellite Evidence Cited
 Satellite evidence gathered by the United States and shared widely with its allies suggests that North Korea is near completion of a large nuclear fuel-reprocessing plant. When complete, the plant could produce weapons-grade plutonium, which in turn could then be fabricated into nuclear weapons. The size and configuration of the heavily guarded plants at Yongbyon suggest that most of the elements that President Kim Il Sung would need to assemble a bomb are in place.
But little is known about North Korea's technical talents, and there is a raging debate in Washington -- pitting the State Department, the Defense Department and the intelligence agencies against one another -- over how much time is left before the first weapon is within reach. Recently Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress that North Korea could produce a weapon in a number of months, but the more commonly accepted estimate is one to three years.
North Korea has denied that it is trying to build weapons, arguing that the scare over a North Korean bomb is being fabricated by the Bush Administration. In its dispatch today, Pyongyang's news service quoted Mr. Choe as reiterating that denial and saying North Korea simply planned to step up development of nuclear power plants.
The Atomic Energy Agency's inspection would be separate from a series of inspections between North and South Korea that the two countries agreed to in principle in December. But talks on setting up those inspections have only sputtered along.

HEADLINE: Peoria Journal;
Dreams and City's Image Are Threatened in Strike

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 9

 BODY:
From the barbershops and health clubs to the banks and bowling alleys, the talk of this quiet Midwestern city has been the Caterpillar strike.
Everyone, it seems, in this city of 113,000 people, knows someone who is walking the picket line at Caterpillar Inc., the construction machinery company whose workers have been on strike since November. 
And while every resident seems to have an opinion on who is to blame and what it will take to resolve the crisis, all seem to agree that the conflict is tarnishing the image of a city that had been busy trying to build up its self-esteem.
"We were listed in U.S. News and World Report two years ago as one of the boom towns of the United States," said James A. Maloof, the city's 72-year-old Mayor. "We had worked so hard to make this a city with the image of having a cohesive relationship between labor and management, a place that people should think about expanding their businesses or opening new ones. Now comes this strike, which is going to damage our reputation."
To some, the strike has damaged more than Peoria's reputation. For the strikers, of course, there are the lost dreams of new cars, larger homes and college educations for their children. Along with that has come the emotional duress of not knowing if their jobs are forever lost in the aftermath of the company's vow to replace strikers with nonunion permanent workers.
But the sense of discomfort here is even more widespread than that. The 12,600 workers at Caterpillar, most of them in the Peoria area, account for about a tenth of the city's work force. That is down from 25 percent two decades ago, but more than enough to tamper with the steadiness of the city's fragile economy.
For a city in which people still occasionally speak to each other while walking down the street, everyone seems affected in some way by the strike. "I have friends who are Caterpillar workers and I feel so bad for them," said Dianne Richardson, manager of the Crossroad Bowling Alley, near the city's mall. "They have to decide if they're going to lose their jobs or stick by the union."
Discussions of the strike is virtually incessant at Rafferty's barber shop, near Bradley University in the center of town. "From college students to retired judges, it's simply what everyone is talking about these days," said Bill Rafferty, the 51-year-old owner who has run the barber shop for 23 years. "It's a difficult situation for everyone because many of these people at Caterpillar are our friends. It's tough on us here."
The Caterpillar labor dispute seems to be considerably less tough on Peoria's economy than when members of the United Auto Workers Union struck for 207 days in 1982. That strike, retailers and city officials say, caused spending and housing purchases to plunge and led some businesses to close.
Mayor Maloof said the 1982 strike led a group of businesses and unions to form an organization to seek ways of promoting better relations between the two groups. "We thought that this organization would help promote the image of Peoria being a place where labor and management could work together," he said, referring to the Peoria Area Labor Management. "And now we're stunned by this."
Some economists and retailers say they have seen some slippage in Peoria's retail sales, to varying degrees.
Many here are fearful that the worst may yet lie ahead. Even if there are replacement workers to fill the jobs of striking Caterpillar union members, that will leave thousands of those strikers with lost jobs and insufficient resources to pay mortgages, to buy clothing, let alone go to movies. "We don't see any great sweeping decline in our economy yet," said James F. Bubert, chairman and chief executive of the First National Bank of Peoria. "But some people wonder if it's coming."
Fred Carrell, a manager of Mr. Steak Restaurant, near the city's mall, said: "Our business is off 10 to 15 percent from before the strike. You could shoot a cannon through the mall on some nights and not have anyone get hurt.
"I see the union's side in this and I see the company's side and I don't think either is 100 percent right or wrong. I think it's already creating a disaster economically. And like everyone else, I just want it to end."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Sidelines;
TSONGAS DECLARES HE WON'T RE-ENTER DEMOCRATIC RACE

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 9

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas announced today that he would not re-enter the 1992 Presidential race, despite his surprisingly strong showing in the New York primary Tuesday.
The former Massachusetts Senator, who pulled out of the campaign three weeks ago after losing to Gov. Bill Clinton in Illinois and Michigan, said he believed he could have raised enough money and reassembled a big enough staff to have resumed a limited campaign. 
 But ultimately, he said, he had to face Mr. Clinton's commanding lead in delegates and the strong possibility that a renewed Tsongas campaign might do more to destroy the Democratic Party than to slow Mr. Clinton on his winning way.
 
Rejects Spoiler Role Again
 Mr. Clinton's victories in the primaries Tuesday, Mr. Tsongas said, "removed the argument that my re-entry would rescue this party."
"Indeed, Bill's winning took me back to the option I rejected three weeks ago -- the role of spoiler," Mr. Tsongas said. "I reject such a role. It is less than worthy."
But he said his pro-business message had continued to win support among the voters.
If the Democratic Party does not now embrace his pro-business message wholeheartedly, he said, President Bush will be re-elected in the fall, along with many other Republican candidates.
"Hear me well: Do not turn your back on this great energy field," he said in a news conference here after 36 hours of pondering the results of the voting Tuesday with advisers, friends and party leaders.
"There were very strong feelings as to what I should do," he said. "But there was absolutely no consensus."
In the end, he added, he reached his decision without cutting any deals with Mr. Clinton, of Arkansas, or former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, the two remaining Democratic contenders.
"I talked to Bill," he said. "He congratulated me and I congratulated him and we said we'd meet again some time down the road."
Dennis Kanin, Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager, said the former Senator had talked with "dozens and dozens" of people throughout the country before making his announcement today. He declined to name any other than former President Jimmy Carter, a Clinton supporter. "I don't think Mr. Carter tried to push him one way or the other," Mr. Kanin said. "They just discussed options."
Mr. Tsongas urged his supporters to discontinue efforts to draft him back into the fray.
"To hope that I will re-enter is a false hope," he said. "I will not re-enter. Preserve the message, yes. But we must heal the party as well. Both are noble purposes and I hope to be part of bringing both into reality."
Some of his supporters who came to hear him speak were unpersuaded.
"We want Paul! We want Paul!" they chanted.
"Hey," he shouted back, flashing his crooked grin. "You can't keep doing this."
 
He Encourages Support
 But while he said he would not re-enter the race, he pointed out that one way his supporters could continue to keep alive the Tsongas message was to vote for him in the remaining primaries.
"My name will remain on future ballots," he said.
Mr. Tsongas said he was not turning his back on those who had urged him to resume the campaign he abandoned three weeks ago when, out of money and poorly organized, he was faltering under the political onslaughts of Mr. Clinton.
Asked whether he would like to be the Vice-Presidential nominee, since he had ruled out any further Presidential effort, Mr. Tsongas answered that he would "defer" addressing that because he did not expect such a bid.
In any event, he continued, he plans to support the Democratic Presidential nominee in the fall, "with enthusiasm," but he said he would not endorse a candidate under the nominating process is over.
Mr. Tsongas, the first major candidate to get into the 1992 race, won the New Hampshire primary and fared well in some of the other early primaries and caucuses, despite his low-key, self-deprecating campaign style that left some voters wondering what manner of politician they had met or heard. But however unconventional his style and delivery, his message of economic growth and fiscal discipline found ready ears in economically depressed states like New Hampshire.
Still, as the primary season wore on and he began to offer more details of what he had in mind, many voters began to turn away, particularly blue- collar workers, blacks and organized labor. Those constituencies would have played an important role in the next primary, April 28, in Pennsylvania.
Members of these constituencies said his message seemed aimed more at the well-off and the well-educated than the hard-hit working class. He began to falter and, after finishing poorly in a series of primaries in the South and Midwest, he pulled out on March 19. Mr. Clinton is leading Mr. Tsongas in delegates by better than 2 to 1, with only 17 primaries and caucuses remaining and with party rules of strict proportional representation that make it extremely difficult to overcome such leads.
Since Mr. Tsongas dropped out, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown, for all the successes they have enjoyed, have also shown serious weaknesses, particularly in the negative ratings many voters give both.
Those weaknesses were never more apparent than Tuesday, when Mr. Tsongas, without any campaigning, finished a second in New York and Kansas. He finished third in Wisconsin.
Immediately, many of Mr. Tsongas's friends and supporters began urging him to get back into the race to provide an alternative to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown.
Many of those supporters felt that Mr. Tsongas probably would not get the nomination himself but would perhaps force a brokered convention. Others believed his strong showing on Tuesday gave him leverage, at the least, to affect the campaign dialogue and the writing of the party's platform.
But however he chose to use his leverage, most of his friends and advisers said, it would carry little or no force unless he was back in the race. And if he re-entered, they warned, he should be prepared for particularly bitter and battering political experience.
Further, they said, there not only was no guarantee of success but he could end up deep in debt, one of the fears that originally drove him from the campaign. His campaign is currently carrying a debt of about $400,000, Mr. Kanin said. The advisers also warned, as did Mr. Clinton's supporters, that if he re-entered the race he risked going down in political history as a sore spoiler who refused to help heal an already badly fragmented Democratic Party.
"I told him all this and I also told him I thought he should get back in," said Ted Van Dyk, a Tsongas adviser. "I told him there would be money problems and organizational problems and all the stuff he had to deal with before he ever got out. And I told him it would be worth it all if he was really committed."

HEADLINE: Congress Getting Cold Feet About Cutting Weapons Programs

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
After pressing the Bush Administration to make deeper cuts in military spending after the cold war, Congress is now having second thoughts about immediately canceling costly weapons like nuclear-powered submarines and fighter jets.
The pressure to hold the line against job losses in the weapons industry during a recession-plagued election year is intertwined with the military's needs, declining Pentagon budgets and a growing debate over preserving the design and construction skills to build America's complex weaponry. 
For instance, members of Congress eager to delay layoffs in Southern California have softened their opposition to spending more than $2 billion each for four more B-2 bombers built by the Northrop Corporation of Los Angeles. And the Texas Congressional delegation wants to reverse plans to end production of the F-16 fighter, a program that employs 16,000 General Dynamics workers in Fort Worth.
Republicans and Democrats have voiced concern over the increasingly volatile political issue in House and Senate hearings in the past two weeks. A House panel took a preliminary step today to keep financing for one of two Seawolf submarines the Pentagon wants to cancel.
"This is a national security issue, an industrial base issue, a jobs issue and a budget issue," Senator William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican who is a member of the Armed Services Committee, said last week.
But no program better illustrates this quandary than the Navy's Seawolf attack submarine, which is assembled by the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn. President Bush said in January that the Pentagon would reap $17.5 billion of $50 billion in proposed military savings through 1997 by canceling the submarine after the first one was built.
Many lawmakers initially applauded the decision on the Seawolf, which was originally intended to hunt advanced Soviet submarines. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney asked Congress to rescind about $3 billion that lawmakers approved in earlier years.
But Congress is agonizing over unemployment. And lawmakers are growing more and more nervous that the country's ability to retain the technology and expertise to build nuclear submarines could wither and die during a seven-year gap between production of the last Seawolf and Los Angeles class submarines, and the Navy's next submarine, the Centurion, a smaller and cheaper version of the Seawolf scheduled for production in 1998.
To address both problems, lawmakers are considering buying the second and third Seawolf submarines, which Congress had already paid for, or continuing to build attack submarines of the earlier Los Angeles class. The bulk of the Seawolf program would still be canceled, yielding more than 80 percent of the savings Mr. Bush proposed.
The House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for military spending voted in closed session today to keep more than $2 billion for the second Seawolf, which the Pentagon wanted rescinded. The vote was a preliminary step that needs several more approvals in the House and Senate to take effect.
"The major question for Congress is whether the nation's submarine industrial base can survive the gap between the end of the Seawolf and the beginning of the Centurion," Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat who is a member of the Armed Services Committee, said at the panel's hearing.
In addition to today's House panel vote on the Seawolf, there have been other indications in the past two weeks that members might be getting cold feet about deeper cuts. The House soundly rejected a proposal to shift nearly $7 billion in military savings to domestic programs. And the Senate Budget Committee also narrowly defeated a plan last week to double the cuts President Bush has proposed for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
General Dynamics says that building the second and third submarines will bridge the production gap and preserve the engineering expertise until the Centurion program starts.
Although the Defense Department officially endorses canceling the Seawolf, some Navy officials have challenged their bosses. In an unusual public break with President Bush and Mr. Cheney over the submarine's future, Adm. Bruce DeMars, the Navy's director of nuclear propulsion, said at House and Senate hearings this week and last that it would make more financial sense to build the next two Seawolf submarines and then end the program.
 
Question of Bottom Line
 Roger E. Tetrault, the general manager of Electric Boat, said in an interview that even before the Seawolf cancellation, the company was planning to cut its work force in Connecticut and Rhode Island to about 10,000 by the end of the decade from the current level of 21,500 employees. Mr. Tetrault said that if the Seawolf was canceled the work force would drop to 5,000 employees by 1997.
The Seawolf's bottom line may ultimately tip the balance. At last week's Senate hearing, the Navy's senior acquisition official, Gerald A. Cann, said that contract-cancellation fees and money already spent on the Seawolf program totals $1.8 billion.
By spending about $2.5 billion more, Congressional and Navy officials say, the Administration would not only buy two more submarines, but also preserve the future production ability, as well as saving thousands of jobs.
Mr. Tetrault said the two additional submarines might cost only $1 billion to $2 billion more than paying the cancellation fees.
The Defense Department is sticking to its decision. "There is no revival being considered for the Seawolf program," the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said last week.
