HEADLINE: A Hard Sell: Students Try to Market Themselves;
5,000 Attend City University Job Fair With Their Hopes High and Expectations Low

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Michael Pollicino had a crisp new gray suit on, 60 freshly copied resumes stashed in a bright blue folder and very low expectations as he stood 16th in line yesterday afternoon to talk to representatives of McGraw-Hill at a job fair run by the City University of New York.
Asked what kind of job he was hoping to get, he paused. "Some type of editorial kind of work, I guess." Another pause. "Actually, I guess whatever they'd want me to do." 
 Traditionally, the City University system has been a gateway to a better life for the sons and daughters of blue-collar workers and the immigrant poor. "About two-thirds of all of our students are the first in their families to go to college," said Jay Hershenson, City University's vice chancellor for university relations.
 
Interviews With Radio Shack and the C.I.A.
 Mr. Pollicino, who is 21 years old and works part-time in a delicatessen to help pay for his education, was one of some 5,000 college seniors and recent alumni at the university's Big Apple Job Fair who bombarded representatives of 81 companies and government agencies, from Radio Shack to the Central Intelligence Agency, with resumes and questions. Mr. Pollicino, an English and journalism major who will graduate in June from Brooklyn College, said his long-term goal was to have "a nice job, a nice wife and a family."
The event in the Gold Ballroom of the Ramada Hotel in midtown Manhattan provided a fast-forward glimpse of the bruising rite of spring performed by college graduates around the country. As the students' hopes of putting their educations to work went head-to-head with the reality of the job market, the results were not always pretty.
Behind Mr. Pollicino was William Levis, 23, who graduated from Queens College in January with a degree in history. "I've already put out 350," he said of the number of resumes he had distributed. "I've had 30 to 35 written responses. Interviews: two. And they were for mail-room jobs."
He said he was doing no better yesterday. "All that economy-is-turning-around bull is just part of the election," he said. "When I went back for my bachelor's, I was hoping for some sort of upper-middle-class status. I don't know what that is anymore."
Christopher Lynch, 26, had the same complaint. "People come here with high expectations after going to school and working hard and expecting to be able to work, and they can't," he said. "I look at a bachelor's now as the same as a high school diploma." Mr. Lynch, who has a master's degree in clinical psychology from Hunter College, said that one advertising company at the fair had said it would consider him for an opening -- as a secretary.
 
Making an Impression
 In general, jobs are not parceled out at the fair. Instead, the event gives students a chance to pick up information about different companies, drop off resumes and in the bedlam, hold out the eternal hope of making a good impression. The encounter with the man from the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the representative of the Museum of Modern Art may have been brief, but the briefcase-toting, suit-wearing students, who waited in lines for up to a half-hour, prepared carefully and let no opportunity slip by. Several asked a reporter if his newspaper had any openings.
In the lobby, dozens gathered around a television screen that played a video on "How to Make a Job Fair Work for You."
"You have to be proactive to make it work for you," said the narrator. "Dress appropriately. Maintain good eye contact. Have a firm handshake."
Sidney M. Sussan, assistant director of the division of banking supervision and regulation of the Federal Reserve Board, said he was impressed with the students who lined up to meet him. "Good eye contact," he said. "Good handshake. Good first three sentences." He said that the Federal Reserve was looking to hire several types of workers, including communications analysts, electronic data processing auditors and litigation and regulation attorneys.
 
'We'll Get Back in Touch
 After waiting in line 20 minutes for a handshake and a one-minute talk with a McGraw-Hill representative, Mr. Pollicino said he had gotten the same response he received from other publishing companies: "All right, we'll get back in touch if any editorial positions become available."
"I think it went O.K., though," he added with a shy grin.
Thomas L. Thomas, president of City University's Career Counseling and Placement Association, said that about 35 percent of the students who responded to surveys distributed at previous job fairs had found work through the events. He said many students, apprehensive about the job market this year, were considering graduate school or adjusting their expectations to aim for what he called "back-office-type-jobs."
"Look, you have to make yourself marketable," he said. "You have to entertain different fields."
Laura Caminito, 22, who will graduate this July from Baruch College, did not sound too particular about the kind of work she wanted. "Hopefully in the research area of marketing," she said. But Ms. Caminito, 20th in line to talk to representatives from Tribune New York Radio, Inc., said the one company she had visited so far was not hiring.
A fellow applicant returning from the front of the line said: "If you want, you can just drop off your resume. She said there has not been a job available in two years."
Ms. Caminito then asked no one in particular: "So what are we waiting for? I guess this one isn't going so good either."
Ten minutes later, she was still waiting.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Interest Rates Plunge

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The decline in the important Federal funds rate yesterday surprised and delighted skittish financial markets. Prices of long-term bonds rose and short-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels in nearly 20 years.
The move by the Federal Reserve Board was its first effort to cut interest rates since Dec. 20 and came in the wake of recent reports suggesting to some analysts that the economic recovery, which appeared to be building during the winter, was losing momentum. 
 "I am a little surprised, but taking out a little insurance is not a bad idea," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation, shortly after the Fed sent a signal to the bond market that it had pushed its target for the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market to 3.75 percent, from 4 percent previously.
 
'Very Risky Business'
 "It is very risky business for the Fed to risk failure on the recovery," said Allen Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc. "And recent reports suggest the momentum on the economy is negative."
The Fed moved forcefully on Dec. 20 to help the economy by slashing its discount rate, which it charges on loans to banks by a full percentage point and lowering the funds rate by half a point.
Since then, some reports on retail sales and housing construction have suggested the economy is beginning to recover. But concern about the pace of recovery began to mount last month, as auto sales figures remained at low levels. Last week the Labor Department reported that outside the public sector, employment growth was extremely weak during March. And for the last several weeks the nation's money supply has declined, following rapid expansion in January and February.
That trend continued yesterday, as the Fed reported that all three monetary aggregates fell in the week ended March 30. The $7.1 billion drop in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was in line with market expectations. The drop in M-2 left its growth at the low end of the Fed's 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent target range for the year.
 
Impact on Prime Rate
 By itself, the cut in the funds rate was not large enough to have an impact on key lending rates like the prime rate.
But Mr. Sinai and others said the Fed might need to push the funds rate down further. And another quarter-point cut in the funds rate would almost certainly prod commercial banks to bring down their prime lending rate, currently at 6 1/2 percent.
Coming on a day when the Government reported that producer prices rose a scant two-tenths of a percent last month, the Fed's move could not have been timed much better, analysts said. But some questioned whether the cut in rates, the 17th since December 1989, would have much of an impact.
"No one can say they are fanning inflation," Mr. Beck said, "because the inflation numbers are good and are expected to stay that way."
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said the sluggishness currently enveloping the economy could not be easily cured by ever-lower interest rates.
"There is a lack of credit extension" by banks and other lenders, he said, "and there is a restructuring going on in labor markets. These things tend to keep conditions sluggish, and monetary policy is not a tool meant to fight those restraints. This cut in rates doesn't change my view of the economy one iota."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10122/32 , up 5/8 point, to yield 7.85 percent, compared with 7.90 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 7/32 , up 18/32 , to yield 7.31 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 10/32 , up 21/32 , to yield 6.56 percent. And prices of the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by 3/8 point, to 101 1/4, to yield 5.07 percent.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.65 percent late yesterday, down 18 basis points, or 18 one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 20 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.73 percent. And one-year bill rates plunged by 21 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.89 percent.
The big day in the government market overshadowed the first sale of a 50-year bond in the investment-grade corporate bond market since 1988, and the first ever issued by a Government agency.
The $500 million worth of 50-year bonds was part of a $1 billion offering by the Tennessee Valley Authority.
The bonds, which mature April 15, 2042, are callable in 20 years. The 8 1/4 percent securities were priced at $96.935 to yield 8.515 percent, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021.
The most recent 50-year bond was sold in 1988 by Swedish Export Credit, a Swedish Government export agency.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are not rated by either Moody's Investors Service or by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Despite the length of the maturity, the 50-year bonds sold out quickly.
"We didn't buy it because we are bullish on interest rates," said Greg Smith, a partner at Brinson Partners Inc., a Chicago money management firm with $7 billion in fixed-income assets under management. "We bought it because it looks like good value to us."
The strong rally in the Treasury securities market helped to push up prices of corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds outstanding.
Corporate bond traders said prices of most issues rose by 3/8 point to 1/2 point.
Meanwhile, prices of widely quoted tax-exempt municipal bonds rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mexican Stock's Underpinnings

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE largest construction company in Mexico became a hot new stock issue in the United States yesterday, largely on the basis of profits that will not be realized for many years, if ever, but that were reported as having been earned last year.
Empresas ICA Sociedad Controladora went public at $17 per American depository share. That was above the range of $14 to $16 that the company said it would seek when it filed to go public last month, but it did not begin to describe the investor interest in the company, commonly known as ICA. The shares traded as high as $20.625 in New York Stock Exchange trading, before dropping back to $19.75. 
 Big Board volume in ICA came to 6.8 million shares, or nearly as many as the 8.4 million shares that were sold in the American offering. A total of 25 million shares were offered, with 8.3 million sold in Mexico and the remainder in other countries. The lead underwriter of the United States portion was Morgan Stanley & Company.
For buyers, the deal was a chance to get into an established company in Mexico, where the stock market has been booming and where the economy is growing at a steady clip. ICA's closing price yesterday was 16 times reported earnings of $1.22 a share last year.
ICA has been in business since 1947, but its recent boom in revenues began in 1990, when revenues, as measured in pesos adjusted for inflation, leaped 79 percent. Then last year they soared another 34 percent, to the equivalent of $1.4 billion. Reported net earnings in 1991 were $92 million, nearly 10 times higher than in 1990.
That surge in revenues and profits reflects the Mexican Government's innovative way of getting public-works projects built. It puts out for competitive bids such projects as highways and bridges, and awards concessions to companies that agree to build them and then charge tolls, until the construction costs and reasonable profits have been recovered. Then, ownership of the road will revert to the Mexican Government.
Rather than wait until the tolls roll in to post the profits, ICA reports them as soon as it spends the money to build the highway. Last year, 44 percent of the company's reported profits came from such earnings. The company's accountants approved that treatment because the tolls are set by Government regulators, under a contract with the company.
The potential problems with such contracts concern cost overruns and the possibility that toll revenues will not be up to forecasts. In such cases, the company must go back to the Mexican Government to try to get a revised deal, effectively allowing it either to charge higher tolls or to charge them for a longer period of time.
So far, the company has completed two construction projects under such deals, and in each case there has been problems. "Construction of the Plan de Barrancas Highway involved substantial cost overruns as a consequence of difficulties with the terrain not contemplated by the specifications," the company's prospectus states. At a highway designed to bypass Tampico, the cost overruns were blamed on "design adjustments necessitated, in particular, by pressure from conservation groups."
Those overruns are substantial. Costs exceeded budget by 73 percent on the Plan de Barrancas Highway and 51 percent on the Tampico bypass. Those overruns did not damage reported profits. On all its concession business in 1991, the company reported profits that came to 39 percent of revenues, a far higher profit margin than on other construction business.
In addition, fewer travelers than expected have paid the tolls on each road.
ICA "currently is seeking to renegotiate these concessions to have the Mexican Government provide the additional funds necessary to permit the company to recoup its cost overruns and to grant the company an extension of the original terms of these concessions," the prospectus states. It does not detail the financial repercussions of a failure to get a new deal.
Concessions are far from the largest part of ICA's business, which ranges from owning Sheraton and Radisson hotels to building the Mexico City subway, but they have recently provided a big piece of the reported profits. Buyers of the stock are clearly betting that the Mexican Government will continue to be friendly in negotiating and renegotiating concessions, and will not decide to take a hard line regarding who should pay for cost overruns.
Notwithstanding the fact that the company has already booked the profits, ICA does say that things could go wrong. "There can be no assurance," the prospectus states, "that the company will be able to realize its anticipated return or recover its equity investment."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up Modestly Again

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The prices received by American producers edged up two-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month in March, suggesting that inflation remains under control, Labor Department figures showed today.
The results, which meant that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods advanced in the first quarter at an annual rate of just seven-tenths of 1 percent, appeared to contribute to a move by the Federal Reserve to further ease monetary policy to try to solidify an economic recovery. 
 Another Government report, meanwhile, showed that the number of newly laid off workers making trips to unemployment offices fell 24,000 in the last week of March, to 432,000. The drop from the previous week was somewhat bigger than had been expected and followed two straight weekly increases. The improvement was led by Michigan, which reported that unemployment claims fell by 7,500 as a result of fewer layoffs in the auto industry.
In a third report, the Commerce Department said businesses planned to increase spending for new plants and equipment by 4.6 percent this year, down from 5.4 percent reported in the previous survey.
The March rise in producer prices reflected a five-tenths of 1 percent decline in food costs, as the price of vegetables retreated after a surge in February because of floods in Texas and California. This was offset by a 1.2 percent increase in energy costs, the biggest increase since an identical one in October.
On Friday, the Government is to report on consumer prices for March, with analysts expecting figures similar to today's. For the year, they expect an increase of 3.5 percent, compared with 3.1 percent for 1991.
"We are forecasting good inflation news, lasting probably until 1994," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic consulting company.
In addition to a 2.1 percent drop in vegetable prices, which came after a 26 percent jump in February, fruit prices were down 3.8 percent last month, with prices also falling for eggs, beef and turkey.
The increase in energy prices reflected a rise of 1.1 percent for gasoline and a 1.2 percent climb in prices for electricity, natural gas and home heating oil.
 
Little Pressure in Other Areas
 Excluding the erratic food and energy sectors, producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported.
Car prices climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, while tobacco prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. Higher prices were also registered for light trucks, shoes and prescription drugs.
Nor was there any significant inflation pressure at the earlier stages of production. Intermediate goods, like a bolt or cloth or a sack of flour, showed no change in March after a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in February and a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in January. Crude goods dropped 1.5 percent, nearly erasing a rise of 1.7 percent in February.
The finished goods index now stands at 122 compared with 121.9 in February. That means a market basket of goods that cost $10 in 1982 now costs $12.20.

HEADLINE: First Union Bank Reports Record First-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., a leading bank in the Southeast and the 13th largest in the nation, said yesterday that it earned a record first-quarter profit as its problems with bad loans fell sharply.
First Union's results were stronger than analysts are predicting for other large banks, mostly because First Union's home markets in the Carolinas, Florida and Georgia have not suffered as much from the recession as have other regions, particularly the Northeast. 
 First Union also benefited from a reduction in expenses, a trend that is widespread in the industry, particularly among banks that are closing branches and computer centers following mergers.
"For many banks in the Southeast, I expect there will be a gradual reduction in write-offs of bad loans as the year progresses, but in other parts of the country, improvement will be harder to find," said John Mason, a banking analyst at the Interstate/Johnson Lane Corporation, a securities firm in Charlotte.
Many bankers and analysts also expect that improvement in bank profits will be erratic. Although delinquent loans are not rising as rapidly as in the last few years, bank profits will be limited by a high level of troubled loans not paying full interest and weak demand for new loans, they say.
First Union's profits in the quarter ended March 31 were $107.9 million, or 81 cents a share, up 33.4 percent from $80.8 million, or 67 cents a share, in the first quarter of last year. The gain helped lift the company's stock on the New York Stock Exchange to $37.625, up $2.375.
The higher profit reflected a sharp drop in write-offs of bad loans, to $68.8 million, from $107.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1991, and a cut in the amount the company added to its reserve for future loan losses to $83 million from $125.3 million. Holdings of badly delinquent or troubled loans and real estate acquired as a result of foreclosures dropped to $1.18 billion in the first quarter from $1.20 billion in the fourth quarter.
"We feel a lot better about our loan portfolio now than a year ago," said Malcolm Murray, chief credit officer at First Union. He noted that the company lost about $100 million last year from loans for commercial real estate projects outside its home region, but that those problems would not be repeated since the troubled loans have been sold or written off as losses.
Although total loans at First Union were about unchanged at $31.2 billion in the first quarter, Mr. Murray said that demand for new loans from consumers had started to increase.
"Eventually that will spread to the business side," he said, "but for now the increased level of customer inquiries we are seeing has not led to any increase in real live loan applications."
At a time of weak loan demand, First Union and many other banks have been reducing their overhead expenses. In the first quarter, expenses for rent, salaries and other costs totaled $435.8 million, down from $458.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1991.
Since acquiring the Southeast Bank of Miami last September, First Union has closed 26 of the 120 branches it expects to close as part of a program to cut costs in Florida by $260 million.

HEADLINE: Chip Indicator Drops Slightly

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9

 BODY:
Orders for computer chips reached a record high in March, but were balanced by a strong increase in shipments, which caused the semiconductor industry's leading indicator to decline slightly, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.08 for the three-month period that ended in March, down from a revised figure of 1.11 in February and 1.09 in January. 
 The ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1.08 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $108 was ordered. A ratio above 1 indicates that demand is increasing.
Average monthly orders in the three-month period that ended in March, at $1.53 billion, were up 3.4 percent from $1.48 billion in the period that ended in February, and 10.5 percent higher than the comparable figure a year earlier.
Average monthly shipments in the three-month period ended in March totaled $1.42 billion, up 6.5 percent from February's figure of $1.33 billion. At $1.65 billion, actual domestic market shipments in March were up 26.2 percent from February's $1.31 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plunges as Fed Acts; Price of Gold Rises in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday after the Federal Reserve signaled that it was pushing interest rates lower.
Gold prices climbed on American markets after moving mostly lower overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $339.50 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from Wednesday's settlement of $337.90. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $339.40, or $1.85 higher than Wednesday's late bid. 
 The Fed added money to the banking system just before noon, as European foreign exchange trading was almost done. The plunge in the dollar was exaggerated because currency trading volume was light, as usual for that hour, dealers said.
"The market reacted pretty violently," said Kevin Lawrie, chief currency dealer for the Bank of Boston. "It wasn't a very good time for that to happen. It happened in a thin market."
Falling American interest rates usually depress the dollar. Reduced rates cut returns on dollar-based holdings and tend to erode demand for the American currency.
Mr. Lawrie said trading in the dollar calmed as the afternoon progressed and the currency seemed to find adequate support at lower levels.
The British pound strengthened against most major currencies as British voters held a national election. The pound was pushed higher by speculation that the Conservative party was leading the opposition Labor party.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7635, from $1.7480 late Wednesday. Later in New York, a pound fetched $1.7665, compared with $1.7500 a day earlier.
The dollar began its world trading day without taking a decisive direction. In Tokyo, the dollar ended unchanged, at 132.70 yen.
But after the Fed acted, the dollar dived, and late in London it was quoted at 132.15 yen. It fell even further in New York, closing at 132.05 yen, down from 132.65 yen Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late levels, were: 1.6165 German marks, down from 1.6270; 1.4860 Swiss francs, down from 1.4950; 5.4775 French francs, down from 5.5110; 1,221.00 Italian lire, down from 1,227.00, and 1.187555 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18925.
At New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.105 a troy ounce, up from $4.078 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Advertisers Urged to Battle Practice of Trade Promotion

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla.

 BODY:
THE advertising industry, already fighting foes ranging from recession to mediocre creative output, is being urged to battle another villain, one portrayed as a masterful pickpocket.
At the 74th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies here yesterday, Robert L. James, chairman and chief executive of McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York, sought to stir his colleagues with a call to arms against a practice known as trade promotion. 
 "More and more money is getting pulled permanently out of marketing communications and getting parked inside the vague, unmeasurable nether world of trade promotion," said Mr. James, the incoming chairman of the Four A's, as the national agency trade organization is called.
His crusade is aimed at recapturing for his industry some of the estimated $150 billion that consumer product marketers pay retailers annually to buy, stock and display their products. For example, a beer company may pay a supermarket chain to put up a special display near the checkout, or a drug company may pay drugstores to carry a new pain reliever, despite their reluctance to add another product.
That expenditure is about the same amount estimated to be spent annually on promotions aimed at consumers -- and $25 billion more than is spent annually on the traditional types of advertising campaigns that agencies create.
Trade promotions are self-destructive, Mr. James asserted, because "if you don't spend money to advertise brands, over time you are going to weaken those brands."
"Less marketing dollars available for advertising means less media advertising," he added. "When media advertising goes down, market share also goes down. Then the ad agency gets blamed because the market share has declined."
And that hurts the manufacturers as well as their agencies, he continued: "If a retailer realizes that he can get more money from a manufacturer now, what's to stop that retailer from doing more of the same in the future?"
Mr. James took pains to differentiate trade promotions that involve cash or discount incentives directly from manufacturers to retailers from other programs "enlisting the support and cooperation of the retail trade." The latter, he said, are "indisputably of paramount importance in marketing," while the former, he added, are "dangerous."
One reason trade promotion is more prevalent was described by John O'Toole, president and chief executive of the Four A's.
"There are too many brands," he said in a speech preceding that of Mr. James: for instance, 1,300 brands of shampoo, 200 brands of cereal and 250 of soft drinks.
As a result, Mr. O'Toole added, "the trade can charge almost anything it chooses in return for a few inches of space on its shelves."
Yet, Mr. O'Toole was even more blunt in his criticism of trade promotions like slotting allowances, by which supermarkets charge marketers for adding new products to their shelves. He called them "forms of extortion."
Both men said the advertising industry's dilemma over trade promotions typified the larger problem of marketers shifting ad dollars out of traditional advertising. Mr. O'Toole complained about Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company, who is slashing ad spending and increasing promotional spending after a decade of rising profit margins that followed increased ad spending.
"Tony, it's the Devil's own work you're doing," Mr. O'Toole chided.
Mr. James disclosed results of a pilot research study by the Value of Advertising Committee of the Four A's. Studying 12 well-known brands' ad spending from the 1960's through the 1980's, with spending adjusted for constant dollars, "the results are shocking," Mr. James said, because advertisers were spending less in real dollar terms.
For instance, a dry soup brand that reduced ad spending by 20.3 percent saw its market share plunge 54.7 percent, Mr. James said, and a salad dressing that cut ad spending by 26.6 percent saw its market share drop by 44.9 percent. The study showed that the 12 brands cut their ad spending by an average of 12.4 percent in real dollars, which resulted in a 19.9 percent decline in market share.
Mr. James said he could not disclose the names of the brands involved in the study, which the Four A's hopes to continue. But "when we realized what brands they were," he added, "and who the manufacturers were, we were really, really shocked."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Deadlines Come And Deadlines Go In N.H.L. Talks

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
Face-to-face discussions are expected to resume today between John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, and Bob Goodenow, executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, which has been on strike against team owners since April 1.
After a 3 P.M. deadline imposed by Ziegler had passed without the hockey season's being declared finished, Ziegler told team owners in a conference call yesterday that Goodenow would come to New York today to continue talks, which broke off on Tuesday as both sides turned down each others' most recent proposals. Goodenow and Ziegler spoke by phone several times yesterday. 
 "Mr. Goodenow and I have communicated, and we are to have further communications through the course of this evening and early morning period," Ziegler said in a statement released by an aide at the Plaza Hotel. "At this time, there is nothing specific or further that I am able to report."
The discussions today are not to be considered formal negotiations, according to Paul Costello, a spokesman for the union.
 
'There Will Be No Winners'
 Meanwhile, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service stepped up its effort to bring the sides together. Bernard E. DeLury, the director of the agency, sent a letter to both Goodenow and Ziegler that said in part: "I am compelled to attempt to bring you together in a final effort to work out your differences. This is the final period in hockey's most important match and there will be no winners if you don't take the ice."
The strike began on April 1, postponing the last five days of the regular season and the Stanley Cup playoffs, which were to begin on Wednesday. The post-season tournament, which involves 16 teams and lasts four rounds, was scheduled to end in early June. If the season resumes, it is likely that the championship could not be concluded until mid-June.
Among the major issues still unresolved are free-agent mobility, distribution of revenue from trading cards, the length of the agreement and the use of money from a pension-fund surplus.
Both sides held lengthy conference calls yesterday to discuss possible solutions. After the union's morning conference call, several teams met among themselves in the afternoon and many players postponed plans to leave their team cities and head back to their off-season homes.
William Wirtz, the owner of the Chicago Blackhawks and chairman of the board of governors, canceled an evening press conference at which he was to explain the ticket-refund policy.
Norman Green, owner of the Minnesota North Stars, said Goodenow had initiated the new discussions.
"For those of us eager for the playoffs to carry on, this is good news, depending on what Mr. Goodenow has to offer," Green said. "The most encouraging thing is that a lot of us have heard that the players are really eager to get back to work and that Mr. Goodenow is responding to those opinions. Where there's a will, there's a way."
 
Owners Want a Salary Cap
 Green said that "there's nothing more that John has been authorized to offer" and that the owners wanted a salary cap, although it isn't a precondition for a settlement.
Among the reports that continued to circulate last night were that the players were willing to agree to a shorter contract if both sides were willing to submit to binding arbitition on the unsettled issues and language that guarantees no lockouts and no collusion against them.
Arthur Griffiths, vice chairman of the Vancouver Canucks, said "I hope this isn't another roller-coaster ride. Let's keep our fingers crossed."
 
Sentiment for a Settlement
 Barry Shenkaro, owner of the Winnipeg Jets, said some owners suggested during yesterday's conference call that Ziegler be given more power to complete a deal. That was rejected, said Shenkarow, who is a member of the owners' negotiating committee.
"There's a lot of will to try to do a deal," he said. "A substantial majority would like to see a deal, but we don't know how to do one."
Marcel Aubut, owner of the Quebec Nordiques, said: "There is no agreement in sight and nothing to indicate that we are on the verge of ending this dispute."
Neil Smith, general manager of the Rangers, the team with the best record this season and the most to lose should the playoffs be called off, had mixed feelings about the situation.
"I've learned not to be anything but numb," Smith said. "Every time I'm optimistic, something pessimistic happens and the other way around, too."
Donald Fehr, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said "what has happened recently suggests that the hockey owners are making an attempt either to destroy or to destroy the effectiveness of the N.H.L.P.A. and that is their primary goal.
"Getting an agreement and resuming the season is secondary to that," Fehr said. "Some people might call it 'union-busting.' I've used the term myself. I say that because what seems to be reasonably clear is that every time the players took a step toward them, they took a step either backwards or sideways."
Fehr went on to ridicule Ziegler's contention that the players must agree to salary limitations to protect the owners from spending themselves out of business as they compete with each other for talent.
"The notion that somehow, with a totally free market, you can end up paying more in the aggregate than what the players' market value is, is sort of contrary to the central thesis of economics," he said. "The owners could have made a deal more favorable to the owners than anyone else has in any sport. And they didn't take it. Instead, they found new issues and stepped sideways and raised this idiotic licensing issue. The conclusion seems to be that their interests are in other than making a deal."
Fehr said he has communicated with Goodenow on a regular basis, but said he has not advised him on strike stratgegy.
"Absolutely not," Fehr said. "I don't give him suggestions on collective-bargaining proposals. We try, at his request, to give him the benefit of whatever experience we have had that is relevant." He said such interaction between sports union is commonplace.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Two Leading Candidates
The list of candidates to succeed J. Carter Brown as director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington is getting shorter. After the initial round of interviews ended last week, the two favored names seem to be John Walsh Jr., director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., and Earl A. Powell 3d, director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, a number of museum officials say. 
 Franklin D. Murphy, the chairman of the gallery's board, said in a telephone interview this week that he hoped an announcement would be made after the trustees meet on May 1. Mr. Murphy said he had disqualified himself from the search committee because he was also a trustee of both the Getty and the Los Angeles County Museum.
Speculation about a new director began on Jan. 24, the day Mr. Brown shocked the art world with his resignation, saying he wanted to become involved in various activities, at Brown University and elsewhere. And it hasn't stopped. Everyone from museum curators to prominent collectors and auction-house experts has an opinion on a successor, although few are willing to talk for attribution. At first, the favored candidates were thought to include Edmund P. Pillsbury, director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth and founding director of the Yale Center for British Art, who turned down an offer to become the director of the National Gallery in London a few years ago, and Roger Mandle, currently the deputy director of the National Gallery in Washington. Also on the list were John Wilmerding, who was deputy director of the National Gallery in Washington for five years and is now a professor of American art at Princeton University; Anne d'Harnoncourt, director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and James N. Wood, director of the Art Institute of Chicago.
"We're working as diligently as possible," said Ruth Carter Stevenson, a trustee of the gallery, who is married to John R. Stevenson, the gallery's president and chairman of its search committee. "But so far no decision has been made."
Among those candidates who would comment on the selection process, Mr. Wood said he had withdrawn his name from the race early on. "I was asked whether I wanted to be considered for the job, and I was flattered," he said. "Although it was a hard decision, I had to say no. I'm halfway through something here in Chicago, and I want to see it through the next stage." He was referring to the Art Institute's renovation and expansion plan.
Mr. Wilmerding said he had also declined the museum's overtures. "I indicated at the outset it was not for me," he said. "The timing is just not right. With my involvement as a visiting curator at the Met and my teaching responsibilities -- I've just gotten my first group of graduate students rolling -- it would be irresponsible to leave now. Besides, Washington is a very different place now than it was when Carter began as director, and it's going to be a very different kind of directorship."
Mr. Pillsbury said: "I was told last week that I am still a candidate, but I am not being invited back for a second interview. Actions speak louder than words." He also said the recent emergence of Mr. Walsh's name had puzzled many people. "That he would be prepared to abandon the Getty midstream, before the new building opens, is surprising," Mr. Pillsbury said, referring to plans for a new $500 million building complex in Brentwood, Calif., scheduled to be completed in 1996. Through the press office at the Getty, Mr. Walsh declined to comment.
The new director will be just the fourth in the gallery's 50-year history. It is a coveted position. In his more than two decades as director, Mr. Brown expanded the gallery from a quiet museum into a complex institution with an international reputation for its full schedule of shows and scholarly programs. Mr. Brown was also a successful fund-raiser and was able to attract donations through his impeccable social connections. (He is a member of a prominent family from Providence, R.I., and is a descendant of the family for whom Brown University was named.) At a time when money is scarcer, a new director will need to be at least as adept at raising money.
That's something Mr. Walsh "doesn't have to do at the Getty," said one prominent museum expert, who would speak only on condition of anonymity. "But John is low-key, and that's what the board may want now, since the era of the blockbuster is certainly a thing of the past."
 
Dispute Over Signature
 Two of the world's leading experts on prints are locked in a complex legal battle over the authenticity of the signature on an impression of Picasso's famous 1935 print "The Minotauromachie."
In June 1990, the New York dealer David P. Tunick bought the work for $1.68 million from Galerie Kornfeld, a well-respected auction house in Bern, Switzerland. Now Mr. Tunick says museum experts and other colleagues who have seen the print are certain the signature is fake. Eberhard Kornfeld, owner of the auction house and a Picasso expert himself, insists it is genuine and has even offered to exchange it for his own version of the print, whose authenticity is not in question. He says Mr. Tunick is trying to get out of the deal.
The incident has led to lawsuits on both sides of the Atlantic. Sixteen months after the purchase, Mr. Tunick filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, citing fraud; reckless misrepresentation; breach of duty, honesty and fair dealing, and breach of fiduciary dealings. He has asked for his money back, along with punitive damages of $20 million. Mr. Kornfeld is also suing Mr. Tunick in Switzerland for the money he is still owed.
"I arrived in Bern the day before the sale, and when I first saw the print I questioned Kornfeld about the signature," Mr. Tunick said. "It was partially erased and seemed odd. But he said he personally guaranteed it. And since Kornfeld is an acknowledged expert on Picasso and has been a longtime friend, I believed him."
Eight months later, in February 1991, the print was the centerpiece of Mr. Tunick's booth at the annual Art Show in Manhattan. It was priced at $2 million and did not sell. Then, in October, Mr. Tunick said, a highly respected and important curator, whom he refused to identify, dropped into his gallery, saw the print and questioned the signature. "Over the weekend we photographed the signature, and on Monday I took it around to about 12 other experts, everyone from museum curators to auctioneers and dealers," he recalled. "Some literally laughed when they saw it. Virtually all of them expressed serious doubts that the signature was by Picasso." Mr. Tunick said he Had also consulted an archive of about 800 Picasso signatures from the 1930's and 40's.
By this time, Mr. Tunick said, he had already given Mr. Kornfeld $1.3 million to $1.4 million of the purchase price in cash and property. In a meeting in Mr. Tunick's office on Oct. 8, the dealer said, he confronted Mr. Kornfeld. The two disagree about what transpired at the meeting, but they do agree that Mr. Tunick declined when Mr. Kornfeld offered his own impression of the print. Mr. Tunick explained that he could not in good conscience go back to his clients with another impression of the print. "They'd think these things grow on trees," Mr. Tunick said.
Mr. Kornfeld said: "I offered him my own print not as a sign of weakness, but as confirmation that the print he bought at auction was right. It was his decision to buy the work in the first place and now it appears, 16 months after the auction, he refuses to pay for it."
Mr. Tunick said: "He thinks he's the Teflon auctioneer, that he's untouchable. Actually, Kornfeld is trying to divert the focus from the real issue: that the signature is false."
 
12 Nicholson Paintings

"If I could have sold real estate, I would have," said Eddy G. Nicholson, the New Hampshire-based collector who made headlines in the 1980's for paying record prices for American furniture and art. "But in this economy it's impossible." Mr. Nicholson owns Granite Partners Ltd., a concern based in Hampton, N.H., that acquires ailing companies and turns them around. "Today's environment offers tremendous business opportunities for me right now," he said.
To increase the company's investing capital, Mr. Nicholson has decided to sell 12 paintings from his private collection at Christie's in New York on May 28. He is also selling eight pieces of his American furniture and eight pieces of 18th-century American silver at Christie's June sales in New York. "We chose things that were fresh to the market and that wouldn't create a gap in our collection," Mr. Nicholson said. Among the works being sold are two paintings by Arthur Fitzwilliam Tait: "Trappers Following the Trail: At Fault" (1852), expected to sell for $350,000 to $450,000, and "Ruffed Grouse Shooting or Flushed" (1857), which is expected to bring $250,000 to $350,000. He is also selling Thomas Birch's "Commodore Perry Leaving the Lawrence for the Niagara at the Battle of Lake Erie," dating from the first half of the 19th century, which is expected to fetch $250,000 to $350,000.
"It wasn't easy deciding what to sell," Mr. Nicholson said.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Who Keeps Score on Commissioner? The Owners

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
The words were so remarkably similar they prompted instant recollection of the first time they were heard. Criticizing the head of the National Hockey League Players Association recently, the head of the owners' board of governors said that the strike leader had miscalculated the stance of the owners.
For the last decade, Bowie Kuhn, who as baseball commissioner presided over a 50-day players' strike in 1981, has said that the players miscalculated the resolve of the owners that year. The owners' resolve, in reality, was such that as soon as their $50 million worth of strike insurance ran out, they capitulated, and the players ended their strike. 
 Kuhn, who miscalculated the resolve of the players and in turn was scorned by them, had his critics among the owners during his 15 1/2-year tenure, but except for the times he came up for re-election or extension, no one kept a running score of his popularity among the owners. As long as Walter O'Malley was alive, scoreboard watching would have been meaningless because the Dodgers' powerful owner kept his colleagues in line.
Scoreboard watching, on the other hand, seems to have become a popular pastime during Fay Vincent's term as commissioner. Periodically through his two and a half years in office, Vincent has been the subject of articles quoting owners -- always anonymously -- saying that he is unpopular among his employers and will not serve beyond his present term. Some even have said he would not complete the term.
In recent months, three lawyers involved in baseball have commented in separate conversations that Vincent was finished, that he had lost the respect of the owners and had become a figurehead. Upon checking closer, it was determined that their view stemmed from information from one person: Jerry Reinsdorf, owner of the Chicago White Sox.
Reinsdorf declined to discuss his view of Vincent, but he is known in ownership circles to be critical of the commissioner.
"It's not appropriate for me to discuss the commissioner, to praise or knock him," Reinsdorf said in a telephone interview. "If I were giving him A's or F's, it wouldn't be appropriate."
Other owners, however, identified Reinsdorf as Vincent's No. 1 critic. These owners said Reinsdorf has failed to generate more than minimal support for his position, and that primarily from Bud Selig of Milwaukee.
Selig, who did not return a telephone call seeking comment, is the chairman of the Player Relations Committee's board of directors, and Reinsdorf is a member. They were instrumental in hiring Richard Ravitch last November as the owners' chief labor representative, a move that prompted additional speculation about Vincent's position.
A recent assessment in a national magazine noted that "the owners already think so little of Vincent" they gave Ravitch a higher salary -- $750,000 -- than the commissioner's -- $650,000. But the problem in that economic blunder wasn't that the owners thought so little of Vincent; they just didn't think.
"I don't think anyone was paying any attention to it when Ravitch was hired," said one owner who was not involved in the hiring. "You know how tidy baseball is."
Reinsdorf said the Player Relations Committee had given Ravitch $750,000 because "that's what it took to hire him and we didn't have jurisdiction over the commissioner's salary."
"It's up to the clubs to raise the commissioner's salary if they want," Reinsdorf said.
The clubs are doing that, but even here Reinsdorf has acted in a way contrary to the view of the other owners.
At their last meeting, in Chicago last month, the owners delegated the executive council, which includes four owners from each league, to put the salaries in the proper order. But while the National League voted unanimously to leave it up to the council, the American League, at Reinsdorf's urging, said it wanted to retain the right to approve whatever the council did.
"Reinsdorf challenges everything relating to Vincent," one member of the council said.
Vincent declined to discuss his status or the Reinsdorf matter. "I'm not going to talk about those things publicly," he said.
In January, when controversy arose over the proposed sale of the Seattle Mariners to a Japanese-led group, Vincent didn't even react when his statement opposing the deal was roundly criticized outside baseball. He had stated the owners' policy against foreign ownership -- not his own -- but in the interest of self-preservation, the owners unanimously refrained from comment, leaving Vincent to take the brunt of the criticism from the outside.
Fred Wilpon of the Mets was willing to talk about the commissioner's status. He said the view that Vincent is in trouble stems more from "newspaper and magazine talk," adding, "I don't see that in one-on-one conversations with owners."
What he sees, Wilpon went on, is that "the commissioner and the commissioner's office have done a terrific job for baseball under very difficult times."
"These are very chaotic times," Wilpon said, "and you do find people who are critical. Some of the criticism I've heard of Fay is unfounded. He has had some very difficult and unpopular issues that he decided based on the facts that he had. The man has unusual integrity and intelligence and he applies it for the benefit of baseball."

HEADLINE: A Parade of Musical Offerings for Easter Week

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
EASTER'S musical offerings this year seem not quite so grand as in the recent past: fewer extended works, fewer orchestras and extra musicians. It is not always pleasing when sacred-music programs and economic realities intertwine, but in an imperfect world, they do. Times have been tough, and this year's Easter presentations may reflect smaller music budgets. The situation probably means a little less work for freelance professional musicians.
Big, ambitious doings are not absent, however. Radio City Music Hall's 60th-anniversary "Easter Show" opens tonight and runs through April 23. Rockettes and Easter bunnies are less Christian statements than old pagan rites with a little glitz thrown in: New York show-business versions of nature reawakened and life in bloom. Mankind has been doing things like this for thousands of years, so why not at Radio City? 
 But the Bach Passions are the true theater of Easter. Various other danced and staged events will happen over the week, but without the benefit of stage, props, movement or costumes, Bach's treatments of the gospels according to Matthew and John lead us through the vivid pictures of Holy Week. A tenor is the narrator, singing the gospel in some of Bach's most exposed and difficult music.
The chorus comments and responds in a manner not all that different from the ancient Greek format. Sometimes the chorus takes part in the play, for example when the mobs call for Christ's execution. Soloists sing elaborate commentary as well, sometimes as anguished bystanders, sometimes as those reflecting back on history. Both pieces will be part of this Easter in New York City.
At the St. Jean Baptiste Church on the Upper East Side, the season begins solemnly today when the Amor Artis Chorus and Chamber Orchestra under Jane Hettrick and a set of soloists that includes John Ostendorf sing Gluck, Salieri and Haydn. At Carnegie Hall tomorrow night, Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg performs Bach's "St. Matthew Passion."
Indeed, some of the most substantial Easter celebrations will be in secular settings. On Monday night at Carnegie Hall, Robert Shaw leads the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the Atlanta Symphony Chamber Chorus in Handel's "Messiah." At 2 P.M. on Easter Sunday, Haydn's "Seven Last Words of Christ," a series of profoundly modest slow movements, takes place at the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village. Alexander Schneider, Isidore Cohen, Steven Tenenbom and Laurence Lesser make up Haydn's string quartet. Schuyler Chapin will read the texts.
Bach's less frequently played but darkly imposing "St. John Passion" returns to a church setting on two occasions next week. Performances with orchestra come on Palm Sunday from St. Paul's Chapel in lower Manhattan and then on Good Friday from Grace Church in the Village. Easter Sunday will bring Bach's long and difficult "Easter Oratorio," in a performance at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on the West Side, with choir, soloists and orchestra.
The vast spaces of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Morningside Heights lend themselves to theater as well. Maundy Thursday will bring the premiere of Nora Gibson's "Women at the Cross" with dancing and singing. On Good Friday in the same church, a series of stagings take place: at noon, the medieval drama "Planctus Mariae," and in the evening at 8, a program that includes Schutz's "Seven Last Words of Christ."
The darker, more reticent weekday vigils preceding Easter will be prefaced on Palm Sunday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church when Mr. Westenburg leads an afternoon of Mozart's liturgical music. Then on Tuesday, St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue offers early English music, and on Maundy Thursday augments it with Kodaly, Durufle and Poulenc. Trinity Church in lower Manhattan and St. John the Divine on Thursday sing Gesualdo's arresting vocal music. Josquin and Tallis from the past and Messiaen from the present are spread across Thursday offerings at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue, the Church of the Ascension in the Village and St. Ignatius Church on West End Avenue. Good Friday is a quieter day of mourning in the Christian calendar, but both at the Church of the Holy Apostles at the General Theological Seminary in Chelsea and at Corpus Christi Church on West 121st Street, William Byrd's "St. John Passion" will be sung. Saturday's vigils will be even quieter.
The major-key mood of Easter Sunday will bring out drums and brass. Calvary Episcopal Church on Park Avenue South performs 20th-century Americans like Calvin Hampton, Lee Hoiby and Randall Thompson. Christ and St. Stephen's on the Upper West Side adds the music of another modern American, Ned Rorem.
At the other end of the stylistic spectrum will be the period-instrument orchestra that plays for Easter services at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in the Village. At the Church of the Intercession in Washington Heights, the traditional "Hallelujah" Chorus will be supported by the Harlem Festival Brass Ensemble.
The Passion performances offer the greatest promise, along with the "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall (if you can get in; it is nominally sold out, but a few return tickets may be available). The Haydn will in body be far removed from the church; in spirit it is intensely religious music, thoughtful, quiet and deeply moving.

HEADLINE: False Fears About Japan's Crash

 BODY:
When the Japanese stock market plummeted 10 percent earlier this week, fear struck Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 100 points in two days and Americans wondered whether Main Street would be next.
The answer to such fears, to use the reigning cliche from the movie "Wayne's World," is, NOT!
For starters, Japanese stock prices have been falling steadily since 1989 with little discernible impact outside Japan. Indeed, the Japanese economy continues to grow. And even if falling stock prices force Wall Street prices down, the impact on U.S. production won't be noticeable. 
 Think back to 1987. U.S. stock prices plunged 508 points in a single day, yet the economy grew steadily thereafter. The Federal Reserve knows how to insulate Main Street from Wall Street.
Even plausible worst-case outcomes shouldn't be nervous-making. Some observers fear that Japanese investors, especially banks, will replenish sagging domestic portfolios by "pulling their money out." That might sound worrisome, but it's not.
Suppose Japanese investors sell real estate and other U.S. assets. They'd first deposit the dollar proceeds in a U.S. bank and then sell the dollars for yen. All that would do is drive the value of the dollar lower, making American exports cheaper, and therefore more attractive, to foreign buyers. And that would be a welcome boost to a recession-plagued U.S. economy.
The United States might have little to fear from Japan's stock market meltdown, but neither does it have much to gain. Americans are often told that Japan's success threatens our own. The truth is closer to the opposite: If the Japanese economy sags -- which is far from certain despite the market decline -- the U.S. is likely to lose export sales. And as Japanese banks are forced to retrench, they might withdraw loans from U.S. borrowers.
But neither of these impacts is likely to be large. Export and capital markets are worldwide. If Japan stumbles, there are plenty of others to help pick up the slack. Stock market crashes can be traumatic. But, as events here and abroad in recent years have shown, they don't need to be economically crippling.

HEADLINE: The Voters, Yes. But Which Ones?

 BODY:
Paul Tsongas honored principle and not just reality yesterday when he said "no, thanks" to the Democratic Presidential race for the second time. The first time, in March, he suspended a candidacy he had launched himself. The one he gave up yesterday was created subsequently by The Voters.
By declining now to pursue a candidacy that would inevitably look personally opportunistic, Mr. Tsongas keeps attention fastened on his sober economic message and recognizes the perils of flattering self-deception. 
 Tuesday's New York primary voters put him back in the spotlight by giving him, a non-candidate, an astonishing second-place finish behind Bill Clinton and ahead of Jerry Brown. That improved even on the support Connecticut gave him March 24, when he drained away enough protest vote to give Mr. Brown a narrow victory.
All this encouragement might have tempted a less principled candidate. What more tempting invitation than one directly from The Voters? But Mr. Tsongas, committed to getting his message across, understands that there are voters and there are voters.
The people who supported him so warmly on Tuesday were, for one thing, not particularly representative of Democrats elsewhere. Indeed, there were striking differences even between them and New York primary voters in 1988. This time, one of six voters was black. In 1988 it was one in four. This time, Jewish voters constituted a third of the electorate, in 1988 only a quarter. This time, voters age 60 and over were 36 percent of the electorate, then 30 percent.
Probably the most striking point about The Voters this year in New York is how few there were. Nearly 1.6 million Democrats voted in the 1988 primary. On Tuesday, there were barely a million. The proportion of all eligible citizens voting, which rose to 12 percent in 1988, dropped to a mere 7 percent.
If the differences between one primary and the next are dramatic, consider the contrast between a 7 percent primary election turnout and the 50-plus percent likely to vote in November. People with higher education, those more likely to vote for Mr. Tsongas, constituted 55 percent of Tuesday's voters, compared with 44 percent in the 1988 primary, and only 35 percent in November. It's unclear that he would do as well in a less educated electorate.
Why did so few New York Democrats vote? There's not much point in sermonizing gravely about a pernicious erosion of citizenship. When people care about a candidate, they vote. In 1988, the Rev. Jesse Jackson pulled out a healthy, enthusiastic black vote. In 1992, as non-candidate Tsongas's showing demonstrated, the voters' most passionate desire was to show how much they didn't care for the announced candidates.
Some of the reason for that concerns personalities. More important, these remain tough times, a fact driven home with special force by the fact that taxes are due next Wednesday. And beyond all that, Americans seem disgusted with politics.
Last summer, the Kettering Foundation issued a carefully researched report on the public's reaction "against a political system that is perceived as so autonomous that the public is no longer able to control and direct it. People talk as though our political system had been taken over by alien beings." That message seems to have been ratified by the protests of The Voters, the 7 percent, on Tuesday. The other 93 percent remain to be heard from.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Voters Boot Centrists

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The results of recent elections in Western Europe and primaries in the U.S. suggest a new, volatile and inward-looking pattern of politics within industrialized democracies.
Voters, from ordinary citizens to skinheads, are angry at mainstream parties for failing to address their problems. They are increasingly turning against both conservative parties long in power and the usual liberal/Socialist alternatives. With the apparent exception of Britain, they are throwing out the bums-in-power without bringing back the familiar bums-in-waiting. 
 Extremists have been the principal beneficiaries. The gainers in Germany, France and Italy represent the far left and right. Protest and fringe candidates have also done relatively well in the U.S. Presidential primaries. Britain's Labor Party picked up votes, but Conservatives seem to be holding onto power by a very narrow margin.
Extremists are far from achieving governmental power, and broader patterns of voter discontent have not yet played themselves out. But even short-run effects are proving troublesome and nasty.
They are forcing the creation of unstable coalitions and coalition-style governments. Britain, despite the Conservative victory, might still end up with some kind of partnership. The ruling Italian coalition, already immobilized, will have to become even broader and more unwieldy to hold power. To run German state governments, Christian Democrats and Social Democrats may have to band together or coalesce separately with fringe parties. French Socialists will also be seeking new partners to retain office next year. Brian Mulroney, the Conservative Prime Minister of Canada, has hit rock bottom in the polls. And there is no telling where Canadian politics will go next.
George Bush will certainly see positive signs for himself in John Major's re-election in Britain. Since World War II the fates of British Conservatives and U.S. Republicans have often run in parallel. Yet the political situation in America remains highly volatile.
In Europe, conservatives and liberals could band with each other to create ruling majorities or governments of national unity. But the present union of Christian Democrats and Socialists in Italy shows this generally does not work.
Center parties, more likely, will align with fringe groups that they think they can tame. But extremists often get the better of the deal on issues that concern them. Patrick Buchanan has tugged President Bush rightward. In Germany and France Chancellor Kohl and President Mitterrand are already sounding anti-immigrant notes. Italy's Christian Democrats will need to accommodate the northern-based Lombardy League's growing appeal to separatism from the Mafia-dominated South.
Separatist, nationalist and racist themes could play havoc with commitments to Western European union. And they certainly will make it harder to bridge the gaps between the ex-Communist East and the West. As for the environmentalist parties rising now in Italy and France, their focus is narrow and their impact still unclear. Greens have already forced a halt in French nuclear testing.
All too clear is that the narrow nationalism of right-wing parties reinforces protectionist pressures. Hard times already make it harder for free-traders to prevail.
Such free-traders and free-marketeers -- first Margaret Thatcher, then Ronald Reagan and Helmut Kohl -- ushered in more than a decade of triumphant conservatism. Now, cold war successes fading in the gloom of economic stagnation, their tide is running out. It is being superseded by eddies of public anger and uncertainty, carrying frightened leaders of mainstream parties inward and down.
It is possible, of course, that leaders of these conservative and liberal parties will take voters' cries to heart and shape up. But most familiar power-holding and power-seeking parties are led by a bunch of tired old politicians, whose minds appear untouched by new ideas and whose actions lack confidence and courage.
The voters, for all their sublime ignorance of issues and candidates' stands, do very well at smelling the stench of decay. Their ballots here and abroad ring with one message to mainstreamers everywhere: You are beginning to stink.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Missile-Mongering

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
First, fellow students of journalism, I want to thank the truth squad of military specialists, outside and inside the Pentagon, who helped me achieve victory over the mighty column-writing team of Evans and Novak.
You will, I trust, remember my investigative reporting on a column by Rowland Evans and Robert Novak. Their story was that the Israelis were trying to sell to China an Israeli air-to-surface missile called STAR. 
 But, said Evans-Novak, STAR is an Israeli steal from a hush-hush American missile called HAVE NAP. They reported that HAVE NAP was equipped with technology to make it "stealthy" and was so important that on the very first day of the Persian Gulf war it was dropped on Iraq from B-52's in a secret mission.
The story outraged military experts not merely because it was one more example of anti-Israeli "leaks" from the Administration to receptive journalists, but because it was so full of Errors and Nofacts that it offended their professional dignity.
So, after checking, I reported that HAVE NAP was not stealthy, that it had not been dropped on Iraq and that the missile had been created, of all places, in Israel -- where it is cabalistically known as Popeye. It is now produced in the U.S. and, coup de grace, jointly by Israel and America.
Evans-Novak sputtered their way through two more columns of trying to salvage their reputation as military scoopists. With each sput they entwined themselves in further error, fury and slur. So let us leave them, gurgling, but with one remark about their story ringing bell-like over American journalism. It was made by Brig. Gen. Buster Glosson, top air war planner during the war, as reported in Defense Week: "Unadulterated bull[excrement]."
But a real problem remains. Stories like STAR-Popeye or the lie about the Israeli sale of Patriots obscure the real missile danger from China.
A clear look is taken in a report by the International Missile Proliferation Project of the Monterey Institute of International Studies. Written by Timothy V. McCarthy, it comes to these conclusions:
1. China is carrying out the world's most comprehensive program of providing "developing" nations with missile know-how.
2. The great danger: Beijing is turning these dictatorships in the Middle East and Asia into missile-producing and missile-transferring states themselves -- North Korea for instance.
3. Chinese missile exports are directed primarily to Mideast or Asian states that have threatened or could threaten the U.S. or its allies.
4. All U.S. diplomatic efforts to restrain Chinese missile exports have failed. American diplomats talk to Chinese diplomats. But the decisions are taken by the web of family-run corporations tied into the Chinese Central Military Commission. Also, as long as the West makes multibillion-dollar arms sales to the Mideast, the Chinese figure they can too.
(And, I believe, Beijing will continue to instruct the U.S. to go to hell as long as President Bush keeps vetoing Congressional legislation to withdraw economic benefits as the price of Chinese missile proliferation and trampling of human rights.)
The report lists scores of cases where Communist China sold missile power to Middle Eastern and Asian dictatorships. Syria emerges as a particular danger -- nearing capability of producing its own Scuds.
The list also details reports of foreign sales to China in the missile field. These include Israeli-Chinese deals other than the phony HAVE NAP and Patriot stories.
By helping China at all, the Israelis are helping the very countries that are aiming all their missiles at Israel.
Israeli officials, Labor and Likud, say Israel needs foreign markets to support its own essential arms industry. True. But national interest and international democratic values dictate sacrificing the Chinese slice of the market because it feeds critical weapons to Mideast dictatorships.
Any country, including the U.S. or Israel, that aids or abets the deliberate Communist Chinese program of missile proliferation helps make more wars more likely.
Yes -- and that goes too for journalists who spread cockamamie stories that divert attention from the real dangers of Chinese missile-mongering.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital Posts Huge Deficit; Intel Net Off

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday announced a record $294 million loss and sharply lower sales for its third fiscal quarter, which ended March 28, and blamed the continuing global economic slump. The Intel Corporation announced increased sales but lower profits, reflecting one-time charges.
Following are the details of the two companies' results:
 
Digital Equipment
 Digital's loss, in contrast to a profit of $117 million in the corresponding quarter last year, was far more severe than Wall Street analysts expected, and Digital's stock fell $5.25, or nearly 10 percent, to $48.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 John F. Smith, Digital's senior vice president for operations, was pessimistic about the current quarter as well and said Digital, which is based in Maynard, Mass., was likely to take another charge against earnings and possibly lay off more people.
The company has already taken $1.65 billion in restructuring charges in the last two years and reduced its staff by 20,000 people, to 106,000. Mr. Smith said Digital would accelerate the closing and consolidation of various operations and noted that the company had already trimmed 7.3 million square feet of space from its ledgers.
The loss announced yesterday was underscored by an 8 percent drop in revenues, $3.25 billion. It was the second consecutive quarterly loss for Digital, which lost $135 million in its second quarter.
Mr. Smith attributed the poor earnings to stagnant markets in the United States, Japan and Europe. He also said severe negative currency translations created $150 million to $200 million in losses.
Mr. Smith also noted that while the company was showing a sharp increase in sales of its desktop computers, it was suffering a serious decline in sales of Digital's most profitable higher end systems, including the VAX 9000, VAX 6000 and VAX 4000 series.
David Wu, an analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company, said the severity of the loss reflected more than a weak economy. He noted that Digital's competitors such as IBM and Hewlett-Packard were facing the same economic conditions but both were showing revenue increases.
 
Intel
 The Intel Corporation yesterday reported increased sales but decreased earnings for the first quarter, which it attributed to a number of one-time charges and pricing pressure on much of its product line. Without the charges, earnings would have been essentially flat relative to a year ago.
For the quarter, Intel had earnings of $184.1 million, or 86 cents a share, down 7 percent from $197.4 million, or 95 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales rose 9 percent, to $1.24 billion, from $1.13 billion in the first quarter of 1991.
First-quarter 1992 earnings reflect a $35 million reserve to cover payment to the Hughes Aircraft Company as part of a patent infringement settlement and a $15 million reserve for a possible payment to Advanced Micro Devices Inc. as part of an arbitration decision. These charges were partly offset by recognition of $23 million in deferred royalty revenue previously received from Advanced Micro. Without the charges, first-quarter income would have been about $202.1 million, or 94 cents a share.
Intel's earnings, which the company released after the close of the market, equaled most analysts' estimates. Intel shares closed yesterday at $2.625 in over-the-counter trading.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 11, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the Intel Corporation's first-quarter earnings misstated the company's closing stock price in over-the-counter trading on Thursday. It was $57.25 a share, down 25 cents.

HEADLINE: Residential Complex For Brighton Beach In Progress, Again

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
After twice failing to win city approval, a developer has begun a new effort to secure the right to build a large residential complex on the site of the historic Brighton Beach Baths.
In a meeting Wednesday night, members of Brooklyn's Community Board 13 voted 31 to 3 in support of zoning changes that would allow 1,600 units to be built in five towers, ranging in size from 22 to 29 stories. 
 The plan will go before Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, who will hold a public hearing on May 8 to hear comments on the proposed development. It then goes before the City Planning Commission. Final zoning approval would be given by the City Council.
It was the third time the community board had endorsed the luxury- and middle-income plan, called "Brighton-by-the-Sea," for the current site of the Brighton Beach Baths & Racquet Club, which has seen its membership dwindle in recent years.
Earlier versions of the plan, proposed by Baths owner and long-time New York City builder Alexander Muss & Sons, were endorsed in 1988 and again in 1989 by the community board, which covers Brighton Beach, Coney Island and Gravesend.
The first two proposals failed at various stages of the city-mandated Uniform Land Use Review Procedure -- once when Mayor Ed Koch stepped in, then again when the City Planning Commission failed to give a majority approval to the project. Since then, the plan has been scaled down and made more environmentally sound, its supporters say.
Most local officials and community board members praise the development as an economic boon for Brighton Beach, a low- to middle-income neighborhood that is home to thousands of Soviet emigres.
Opponents, including the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach & Manhattan Beach and the Sheepshead Bay/Plum Beach Civic Association, say the project poses environmental problems, especially for the local sewage plant, which they say is already working above capacity.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 14, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a residential development planned in Brooklyn for the site of the Brighton Beach Baths misstated the date of a public hearing to be held at the Brooklyn Borough President's office. It is May 6, at 10 A.M.
