HEADLINE: Life on Long Island Is Full of Slow Lanes

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, L.I.

 BODY:
Guido Bonelli lives in Ronkonkoma, nearly 50 miles from midtown Manhattan. In most metropolitan areas -- even in most parts of the sprawling New York region -- Mr. Bonelli's house would be outside the ring of densely populated suburbs. It would be surrounded by woods or open fields and he would drive to work on bucolic back roads.
But Mr. Bonelli lives in the heart of Long Island, and that means he fights his way each morning along the Long Island Expressway to the men's clothing store in the Walt Whitman Shopping Center here, where he works as a tailor. His route covers 16 miles, and would take no more than 25 minutes without traffic. Most days, however, the rush-hour commute takes nearly an hour. 
 "It's bad, very heavy," he said. "There are just not enough roads for the traffic."
 
Traffic as a Way of Life
 Highway congestion, while common in virtually all suburbs, is so severe on Long Island that it has had a profound impact on everything from the industries it attracts to the cultural fabric of its communities to the psyches of its citizens.
Commuters dream up elaborate routes on back roads to avoid the rush-hour crunch. Some say that they avoid driving on Sundays in warm weather because the traffic can be so overwhelming on beach days. And many residents say that they often plan their days with highway congestion in mind.
The facts are simple: Nassau and Suffolk Counties are home to 2.6 million people, most of whom now live and work within the confines of a long, slender sliver of land that is 105 miles long and only 23 miles wide at its broadest point. That means virtually everyone must travel east or west to reach their destinations, and they are served by only three major east-west highways.
"That's basically the major problem with the island, the traffic," said Anthony Serina, who drives around the region every day servicing directories, maps and display advertising at shopping malls. "That and taxes."
Mr. Serina is one of those whose life is ruled by traffic. He drives each workday from his home in Farmingville, a small community in the middle of Suffolk County, to malls across the New York region, including seven in Nassau and Suffolk. He says he has learned some fundamental truths: The afternoon rush hour begins at 3 P.M. on Long Island, and, he insists, it does not pay to use back roads.
Mr. Serina says he switches between the Long Island Expressway and the Northern State Parkway -- express routes that run parallel to one another -- in the hope of avoiding the worst tie-ups. "It kind of helps a little bit," he said. "But there's really no way around it. It's just part of Long Island."
Dozens of Long Islanders, in interviews at shopping malls and business districts, said they, too, accepted traffic as the price for living on the island, with its safe communities, good schools and terrific beaches.
John Lipori, a bank officer who works in Garden City, said a 10-mile trip east to Melville during the middle of the business day often takes 40 minutes. Tony Carfagno, a salesman of small electrical appliances, said that it takes him about 2 hours and 15 minutes -- each way -- to commute between his home in Babylon and his office in Manhattan.
"It's unreal," said Mr. Carfagno, who grew up in Delaware and moved to Long Island three years ago. "You just get acclimated to it. Either that, or you pull your hair out."
But many others said that they found the crush on the highways unbearable.
"A lot of times on Sundays, we won't go out because the traffic is so bad," said Joan Tibball, who is from Bay Shore and who is planning to move with her husband, Dan, to northern Nevada.
Dr. Mike Graham, a medical resident at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, is another who cannot make peace with the congestion. "I hate it, and I'm going to Syracuse on July 1," he said. "I'm dying to get off Long Island. The traffic is one of the reasons.
"People on Long Island think it's tolerable because they haven't been anywhere else," said Dr. Graham, who grew up in Lake Hopatcong, N.J., at the edge of the suburbs in western Morris County. "They don't know there isn't traffic everywhere else."
While there are just three major east-west highways on Long Island -- the Long Island Expressway and the Northern and Southern State Parkways -- there are six major highways that crisscross Westchester, a county with a population less than one-third of Long Island's. And in Bergen and Passaic Counties in northern New Jersey, which have a combined population that is less than half of Long Island's, there are five expressways.
 
Elaborate Warning System
 Long Island officials have tried a variety of strategies to alleviate the commuter crush. They have extended the Long Island Expressway's service roads through Nassau County into Suffolk, and they have installed an elaborate system of road sensors and computerized signs to warn motorists of congestion on the expressway and the Northern State. They also plan to begin widening the expressway, adding a fourth lane in each direction.
Although there is no more room for additional highways, expanding existing routes may solve much of the problem, said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. With the widening of the expressway, he said, "Long Island will be reasonably well-served, from east to west."
Dr. Koppelman also contended that people sometimes exaggerate the congestion on Long Island.
Census data from 1990, when analyzed by the regional planning board, showed that the average Long Island commuter drives only six exits on the expressway, Dr. Koppelman said. The average trip from home to office was 34 minutes, he said.
 
Traffic Has Diminished
 Traffic on some roads has diminished somewhat during the last two years, apparently because of the recession. But data from traffic counters placed on more than a dozen highways and major roads by the State Department of Transportation show an uneven pattern.
The daily volume on the Long Island Expressway was slightly lower in the first three months of this year compared with the same period a year earlier, but the volume on other roads has been slightly higher.
"If you are from an area that has relatively light traffic, then the perception that Long Island has a lot of traffic may be correct," Dr. Koppelman said. "What people are really saying is that they are not used to the psychology of driving on Long Island."
Dozens of Long Islanders disagreed, saying that it was a question not of perception but of fact: There are just too many cars and not enough highways, they said.
But many also said that, while highways may flow better elsewhere, they were resigned to the roads at home. "I have no choice," said Mr. Bonelli, the men's tailor, "because I can find no other jobs."

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Rally; Dow Up 30.41

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices surged for a second straight session yesterday, buoyed by low interest rates and rallies in London and Tokyo.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.41 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 3,255.37. The Dow ended a week of wild price swings with a gain of 6.26 points. 
 Volume was a heavy 199.45 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, where advancing issues outpaced losers, 1,221 to 532.
"There are an awful lot of reasons to have an up day," said Gregory Nie, a market analyst at Kemper Securities.
Stocks continued to enjoy a lift from the Federal Reserve's move Thursday to cut interest rates, although a report yesterday of higher-than-expected inflation dampened hopes that rates would be cut further.
 
'Not Out of the Woods Yet'
 "It is a continuation of yesterday, but I think we are not out of the woods yet," said Ned Collins, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities. "There is still work to be done in terms of consolidation."
The Consumer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported, compared with expectations of a three-tenths of 1 percent gain.
As a result, bond prices fell, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond off almost a quarter of a point, or $3.44 for $1,000 face amount, pushing up its yield to 7.87 percent from 7.85 percent Thursday.
Nevertheless, Wall Street was spurred by strong rebounds in London and Tokyo.
In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei average rose 1,252.51 points, or 7.6 percent, to close at 17,850.66, making up most of its losses for the week. It was the fourth-biggest surge ever on the Tokyo exchange.
"Some kind of rebound was inevitable, especially after the U.S. rate cut, though everybody is surprised the market has bounced this far," one Tokyo analyst said. "But it's too early to say whether we have touched bottom."
British stocks roared ahead by more than 5 percent, fueled by the election victory of the ruling Conservative Party. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 stocks jumped 136.2 points, or 5.6 percent, to 2,572.6.
Some analysts doubted, however, that the rally in the United States would last, given the persistent doubts about first-quarter earnings, which are beginning to roll in.
"It was rather an exciting trip to nowhere," said Jim Schroeder, market analyst at MMS International. "Unless earnings are a bit better, it will be difficult to make a case for us to maintain this."
Indeed Intel dropped 6 1/8, to 51 1/8, on extremely heavy over-the-counter volume after the chip maker reported late Thursday that first-quarter earnings fell short of estimates.
The over-the-counter market as a whole did not share in Wall Street's rally, with the Nasdaq composite index off 2.51 points, to 584.24.
Analysts said shares were likely to resume trading in the fairly narrow range of the last few weeks until more corporate results provided guidance.
Among other active shares, Digital Equipment shed 3, to 45 1/4, after reporting a loss Thursday. Hewlett-Packard fell 4 3/8, to 74 1/4.
 
Bad Day for Computer Issues
 Microsoft fell 4, to 116, ahead of a court hearing on a suit filed by Apple Computer. Apple fell 1 3/4, to 55 1/2.
Telefonos de Mexico rose 1 5/8, to 56 1/4. Traders said Lehman Brothers. had added the company to its recommended buy list.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 3.65 points, to 404.29. The American Stock Exchange index rose 2.07, to 388.01.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 2.17, to 223.27. The average share fell 35 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American Stock Exchange and Nasdaq issues -- was 3,941.424, up 34.107, or 0.87 percent.

HEADLINE: Advance of 7.6% Halts Drop in Tokyo Stocks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
After a week of plunging prices and frayed nerves, Government action in the credit markets in both the United States and Japan finally arrested the slide in Japanese stocks. The market began a sharp, if unsteady, rise from the opening bell here today and posted its fourth-largest one-day gain in a spectacular rally.
Government officials and analysts welcomed the improvement after a two-week decline, but many noted that it still left the market with a big loss for the week and did not appear to have revived badly damaged investor confidence. 
 The 225-stock Nikkei index rebounded 1,252.51 points today, or 7.6 percent, to 17,850.66. In percentage terms, that was the fourth-largest gain on record.
Trading volume remained modest, however, which analysts said was a disappointing sign of the continuing nervousness of large investors. A total of about 380 million shares changed hands, the same as on Thursday, when the market shed 577.38 points. The advance today still left the Nikkei index down by nearly 4 percent for the week.
"It's encouraging, but with that volume it's unconvincing," said Liam Newberg, a senior analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan. "We're waiting for more evidence."
The Governments on both sides of the Pacific helped start today's recovery. First, in New York the Federal Reserve eased short-term interest rates on Thursday, which helped start the big stock market rally on Wall Street. The Fed's move also helped prices in the Japanese Government bond market begin to rise after big declines earlier this week.
Then, after the markets opened here today, the Japanese Government organized more support in the Government bond market, buying a total of 500 billion yen worth of bonds. The bond rally infected stock traders, according to analysts, and added to the upward impetus.
 
No Change in Fundamentals
 "It was a pretty strong statement that they don't want the bond market to fall further, but this doesn't change the fundamentals of the economy and the market," said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist with Salomon Brothers Asia. "I think we've seen the end of the first wave of selling, but it will take more time for the market's psychology to mend. It doesn't fix any of the deeper problems the markets face."
Although it has not been clear precisely what began the relentless decline in prices for two weeks and the negative sentiment in the market, analysts have pointed out that the Japanese economy has been cooling in recent months and the number of bankruptcies has been rising. The economy actually showed negative growth in the fourth quarter of last year and most economists say they do not expect a rebound until the latter half of the year.
Nonetheless, Government officials have issued appeals to investors not to panic and to stop selling shares. "The current low level of stock prices does not reflect Japan's economic fundamentals," insisted Tsutomu Hata, the Finance Minister.
An important sign of how weak confidence remains is the fact that the news that seemed to hearten investors most came from overseas. In addition to the lowering of interest rates in the United States and the market rally, there were reports here that the United States would demand that Japan take firmer measures to stimulate the economy. This is precisely what many investors have been demanding.
The finance ministers of the leading industrial nations are expected to meet later this month to discuss a variety of subjects. Newspapers here reported today that the United States was expected to press the Japanese Government to raise spending and take other measures to insure that the economy picks up momentum.
Washington is concerned that a slowing Japanese economy will just force manufacturers to export their goods more aggressively and cause Japan's trade surplus to rise further. Already Japan is expected to report a record trade surplus this year of well over $100 billion, which is likely to fuel trade frictions with the United States and Europe.
All these factors, analysts said, are likely to keep some pressure on the economy and the stock market in coming days.

HEADLINE: Kenneth L. Dawson, 45, Is Dead; Led Gay and AIDS Organizations

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Kenneth L. Dawson, a leader and adviser of gay and lesbian and AIDS organizations, died on Thursday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 45 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of complications from AIDS, said Jed Mattes, a friend. 
 Mr. Dawson was on the founding board of the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in Manhattan in 1983. The center sponsors cultural, social and educational programs and provides offices and meeting space for numerous organizations for gay men and women.
From 1981 to 1987 he was the executive director of Senior Action in a Gay Environment, an organization for elderly homosexuals.
Starting in 1985 he also organized a series of national conferences for gay and lesbian leaders and advocates for AIDS services to share information and develop strategy.
Mr. Dawson was born in East Rockaway, L.I. He graduated from Wesleyan University in 1968 and earned a master's degree in teaching from Antioch University in 1972 and also graduated from Columbia University's Institute for Not-for-Profit Management.
Earlier in his career, he was the director of the Calhoun Lower School in Manhattan and of the East Harlem Block Elementary School.
In recent years he was a partner and chief operating officer of Strub-Dawson, a direct-mail, fund-raising firm. He was also a consultant to nonprofit organizations and an adjunct teacher at the New School for Social Research's graduate school of management and urban policy.
His companion was Todd Hunter.
Mr. Dawson is survived by his mother, Marjorie Ruth Dawson of Epsom, N.H.; a brother, Steve of Brentwood, N.H., and a sister, Catherine Woodward of Dover, N.H.

HEADLINE: Judge Orders LTV Unit Sold To a French-Linked Group

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 10

 BODY:
A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York ended a tense, spirited auction of the aerospace and missile operations of the LTV Corporation today by ordering the sale of the unit to the Carlyle Group and Thomson-CSF for $450 million.
The decision, which came late in the afternoon after three days of dueling by opposing suitors, brought an immediate warning from the Martin Marietta Corporation, one of the losing bidders, that the deal could jeopardize the nation's military power. 
 Thomson-CSF, which will acquire the LTV missile unit's Army tactical missile system and the multiple-launch rocket system widely used in the Persian Gulf war, is controlled by the French Government.
"We were at a disadvantage, as any U.S. private firm would be, competing against a foreign government" in the auction for the LTV aircraft and missile unit, said Phillip Giaramita, a spokesman for Martin Marietta, a subcontractor on the Patriot missile program and the nation's eighth-largest military supplier.
"That is a pretty serious issue from an economic view these days, but it is heightened by the fact that we're talking about the sale of highly sensitive, national security assets flowing to a foreign government, no matter how friendly they might be," Mr. Giaramita said. "It's a matter of great concern."
Martin Marietta, joining with the Lockheed Corporation, offered $385 million, plus a royalty on future sales of the LTV unit, which is based in Dallas and has 12,000 employees. Judge Burton R. Lifland of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan indicated during the hearings that he delayed a decision until today in an effort to coax a higher offer from Martin Marietta and Lockheed.
In explaining his decision, Judge Lifland was quoted by Reuters today as saying that if the two companies' final offer "does come within the range of reasonableness, it only scrapes the bottom and cannot be considered the best offer."
The choice of Thomson-CSF and the Carlyle Group, a Washington investment firm whose principals include Frank Carlucci, a former Defense Secretary, made bitter losers out of Lockheed and Martin Marietta. The companies had signed a deal with LTV on Feb. 26 to pay $355 million for the unit.
A Lockheed spokesman, Scott Hallman, said that the company was "deeply disappointed" by the decision and that it would "voice our concerns over the national security and economic issues raised by foreign ownership of the defense industrial base."
LTV has been in bankruptcy since 1986. Most of the money raised from the auction of its once-prized aerospace and missile unit will go to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation as payments for three LTV steelworker pensions that are underfunded by $3.1 billion.
The Government agency, which oversees corporation pension plans, said it favored the higher, Carlyle-Thomson bid. Richard Gelfond, an investment banker at Cheviot Capital in New York, who represented Thomson at the hearings, said other LTV creditor groups were nearly unanimous in backing the Thomson offer.
Carlyle will acquire the aircraft business, which assembles the mid-section of the B-2 bomber and tail sections for Boeing Company commercial planes, for $110 million in cash, plus $20 million in preferred stock and another $20 million in either preferred stock or notes. Before the auction began Wednesday, Carlyle's offer was $90 million in cash and $30 million in preferred stock.
 
Thomson-CSF Increased Offer
 Thomson-CSF increased its offer for the missile unit three times during the court hearings, to $300 million in cash, from $280 million. The military-electronics firm also agreed to pay $20 million to LTV if the deal is canceled.
Congress and the Bush Administration have approximately 90 days to oppose Thomson's role in the deal under rules of the Exon-Florio Act. Senator Daniel Inouye, the Hawaiian Democrat who heads the Senate panel governing military spending, said Thursday that he would ask the Defense Department to block a sale to Thomson if Judge Lifland approved it. An assistant to Senator Inouye said today that Senator Inouye might act as soon as next week.
But the Bush Administration may have a different view. Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a Washington research group, said the Pentagon and the White House had been silent on Thomson's role, implying that foreign ownership of military assets in some cases was now acceptable.
"That fits with what I see as a long-term trend here," Mr. Adams said. As military spending shrinks, private suppliers will increasingly link arms or trade assets across borders. "It has some troublesome implications, but I think it's inevitable," he said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Jumps 0.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
Consumer prices posted their biggest increase in 17 months in March, climbing five-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said today. The sharp rise prompted much surprise at first, but little dismay on closer analysis.
The increase, about twice as much as most analysts had expected and largely attributed to higher energy and food costs, sent an initial tremor through the bond market, pushing rates higher. But most of the loss was later recovered as analysts and traders found the rise marked by statistical quirks and temporary factors that in some cases have already been reversed.
"It doesn't seem to signal any sort of resurgence of inflation," asserted Robert A. Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities. He said that every economic recovery in the last 40 years had shown inflation declining during its first year and that he saw no reason why the pattern should be different this time.
 
An Official's Viewpoint
 A relatively benign view was also taken by Patrick C. Jackman, a senior Labor Department economist in charge of studying prices and living conditions. "We are definitely still on track for an increase of less than 4 percent for the year," he said.
The hefty increase in retail prices followed by one day a reassuring report on inflation at the producer level that seemed to have encouraged the Federal Reserve to make another cut in an important short-term interest rate. The Labor Department said producer prices last month edged up just two-tenths of a percent.
For the first three months of the year, the Consumer Price Index has risen at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, slightly above the 3.1 percent rate posted for all of 1991.
Although some analysts, such as those at the New York investment firm of C. J. Lawrence, cling to inflation projections as low as 2 percent this year, the average annual inflation expectation of the 52 economists responding to the Blue Chip survey was reported today as 3.1 percent, unchanged from a month ago. For 1993, they expect inflation to be 3.6 percent.
But there are also those who found in today's figures confirmation of their view that inflation pressures are rising, although none saw a return to even half the double-digit inflation levels of a decade ago. This group expects that economic recovery will prompt companies to seek higher prices rather than greater market share.
Among them is Kathryn L. Kobe, economist at Joel Popkin & Company, a Washington firm headed by a former Labor Department price specialist. While finding that the March increase was exaggerated by "some strangeness in the seasonal factors," Ms. Kobe said she still expected the consumer index to advance by at least 4 percent this year.
The latest report included data for five major metropolitan areas, three of which recorded price increases higher than the five-tenths of 1 percent for the country at large.
For New York, the rise was seven-tenths of 1 percent, paced by a 1.4 percent jump in residential rents and a 1.7 percent jump in owners' rent-equivalency. Mr. Jackman said, however, it would be "a leap" to conclude from this that there has been a firming in the area's real estate market.
Prices in Philadelphia surged eight-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting a big increase for clothing, while prices in the San Francisco area rose six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Energy and Food Rise
 Nationally, the department said, the speeding up of the inflation pace, from the three-tenths of 1 percent posted in February, mainly reflected an upturn in the price of energy and a faster rise for food, almost entirely in fresh fruits and vegetables.
Even when the erratic energy and food components were excluded, however, the advance was five-tenths of 1 percent, up from four-tenths of 1 percent in February and three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Viewed yet another way, divided into indexes of goods and of services, the increase in each category was still five-tenths of 1 percent. The fact that the overall consumer index includes services and imported goods while the producer index does not, was cited as one reason, besides seasonal and statistical aberrations, for the difference between the two gauges.
Some analysts suggested that today's report, while not ruling out further action by the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, made it highly unlikely the Fed would make such a move soon. As it was, some thought the Fed might have embarrassed itself by making an unexpected rate cut on Thursday and then seeing today's somewhat jarring data, even though the rate cut seemed to be largely a response to lagging M-2 money growth.
A Fed governor who is usually accessible declined to respond today to a request for comment.
The inflation figures showed food rising five-tenths of 1 percent, led by a 6.1 percent rise for fresh fruits and vegetables. Tomatoes soared 22.8 percent last month and have more than doubled since New Year's Day. Cereal and bakery products also rose, but the price of eggs dropped 9.9 percent.
Housing rose four-tenths of 1 percent, double the early-year advances, with fuel oil prices falling less than usual for the month and electricity climbing nine-tenths of 1 percent. Furniture and bedding jumped 1.9 percent.
 
Cars, Gas and Air Fares Go Up
 In transportation, where prices climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent after two straight monthly declines, the main factors were higher prices for gasoline, new cars and airline fares. Prices of used cars were unchanged after falling for three straight months.
Clothing prices, for which the seasonal adjustment factors are particularly suspect in light of shifting industry practices, rose six-tenths of 1 percent but this was less than February's 1.5 percent jump.
The cost of medical care, moderating slightly, rose five-tenths of 1 percent to a level 7.8 percent above that of March 1991. Elsewhere, entertainment rose four-tenths of 1 percent while such personal expenses as legal and financial services and funeral expenses advanced five-tenths of 1 percent to bring the first-quarter annual rate to 9.6 percent.
The index now stands at 139.3, meaning that a group of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-1984 period now costs $13.93.
An alternate gauge, the C.P.I.-W., covering urban wage earners and clerical workers, also rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department reported.

HEADLINE: 4 Whole Days Till Tax Time, So Why Panic?

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
If you are among the millions of taxpayers tackling Form 1040 this weekend, don't despair. Even though Wednesday is the tax-filing deadline, you can still avoid running afoul of the Internal Revenue Service and get any tax breaks you are entitled to.
The keys are completeness and accuracy, said Michael Janicki, a partner in Arthur Andersen & Company, the nation's largest accounting firm. 
 "There is a high degree of filing incorrect returns," he said. They are often a result of avoidable errors like the omission of income because of an overlooked Form 1099 from a bank or brokerage, incorrect math, incompleteness, the selection of the wrong number in the tax-rate tables, or the deduction of personal interest, which is no longer allowed.
If the taxpayer overlooks a Form 1099, the Internal Revenue Service is unlikely to do so. "Its computers are up and running," Mr. Janicki said, and they are quite efficient at comparing the income that taxpayers report with the service's own copies of the 1099's, and with the W2 forms that employers use to report wages and salaries. The computers are also sure to catch arithmetic errors and the other mistakes he cited.
 
Take a Break, and Double-Check
 Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and certified public accountant, advised taxpayers not to overlook any sources of interest, dividends and other income reported on Form 1099, and to see if there are any carry-forwards -- items from years past, like net long-term capital losses above $3,000 -- that should be shown on the return.
"If you work on it this weekend, put it away and double-check it the next day when you are fresh," he said.
Mr. Kess also advised taxpayers not to claim the standard deduction simply because it is easier, but instead to see what itemized deductions might be possible by completing Schedule A. Take whichever deduction is greater.
Sometimes a married couple can lower their tax bill by filing separate returns, if that enables one to itemize deductions, he said. For example, medical expenses can be deducted only if they exceed 7 1/2 percent of adjusted gross income, a threshhold that might be easier to meet on a separate return than a joint one.
Some deductions can be overlooked, Mr. Kess said:
*Clothing, books and furniture donated to charity are deductible. "Use some judgment in coming up with a reasonable estimate for what it is worth," he said. Give it a thrift-store value, not its original cost: "Don't be a pig." If the value is greater than $500, Form 8283 must be attached, showing the basis for the valuation.
*In deducting state and local income taxes, include any payment made last April 15, as well as any estimated taxes paid during the year and amounts withheld, as shown on Form W2. (But state tax refunds must be reported as income by those who itemize.)
*People who drive their cars for charitable purposes, like scout leaders or church volunteers, may deduct 12 cents a mile, plus tolls and parking.
 
Getting an Extension
 People who need more time to gather up information or feel insecure about the returns they have prepared should file a Form 4868 for an automatic four-month extension. Then they can double-check their returns or get professional help. But they are expected to pay their tax by the filing deadline.
Complex matters -- like home sales or refinancing, the alternative minimum tax, passive losses and the phase-out of deductions and exemptions for upper-income taxpayers -- are particularly likely to require professional help. This late in the tax season, most professionals will get extensions for any clients now approaching them.
Many taxpayers fear that filing for an extension may lead to an I.R.S. audit, Mr. Janicki said. But there is absolutely no evidence to support such an idea. On the other hand, he did say that sloppy or incorrect returns are likely to be questioned. The I.R.S. sent out inquiries on 4.5 million of the 110 million returns filed last year because of inconsistencies on 1099 and W2 forms, he said; such inquiries often result in the assessment of interest and penalties, as well as additional taxes.
Those who file Form 4868 must remember that they are receiving an extension to file, not an extension to pay. They are expected to pay their taxes when they file the form, estimating the tax liability accurately, and perhaps even overestimating it, to be safe. Any overpayment can be claimed as a refund when the return is filed.
For people who use personal computers, a big timesaver at the last minute can be popular computer programs like Turbotax, Macintax and Taxcut 1040. They print out their own forms, which are acceptable for filing, and they "interview" the taxpayer and provide checklists that help in avoiding errors and omissions, and in getting the math right. Of course, no program can make sure a user does not enter incorrect data or make other errors.
Thomas Hoglund, a C.P.A. who is the product-line manager for Arthur Andersen's A-plus Tax, a software package used by tax professionals, suggested that if you are unsure you have filled out your return correctly, have it reviewed by an accountant. Many charge less for a review than for preparing a return, he said.
Even if the return must be redone by the professional, he said you can hold down the fee if you have complete, well-organized data. You might save even more money if the data are on a computer disk from a tax program, a personal finance program like Quicken or Managing Your Money, or a spreadsheet like Excel or Lotus 1-2-3; in such cases, the accountant will not have to re-enter the data to use his own program.
 
If You Can't Pay, Don't Hide
 Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber Lipshie & Company in New York, noted that with the recession and job losses, some people owe taxes on money they earned early in 1991 but are unable to pay it now. They should file returns to avoid a late-filing penalty, he said, and work out a payment plan with the I.R.S.
The penalty for late filing is 5 percent of the amount due for each month or part of a month that the return is late, up to 25 percent of the tax due. There are also penalties for late payment, but they are lower, usually one half of 1 percent of the unpaid amount for each month the tax is not paid, up to 25 percent, as well as interest charges, currently 9 percent a year.
The I.R.S. says that taxpayers who cannot pay all their 1991 taxes on time should attach a letter to their returns explaining how they plan to pay the rest and include a telephone number so a representative can call to work out a payment agreement.
 
 
 
FINDING FORMS AT LAST SECOND
 Taxpayers who want to file their returns late will not find the necessary form, 4868, in the booklet that the Internal Revenue Service sends taxpayers.
If you need it or other less-common forms -- like 8829 for an office at home, 1040X for an amended return or 4562 for depreciation and amortization -- you must get them elsewhere. The I.R.S. will send forms if you call (800) 829-1040, but it's a bit late to call for the form for an automatic extension.
Few banks and post offices have tax forms anymore, but many public libraries have forms that can be photocopied for a small fee. The Ernst & Young Tax Guide 1992 (John Wiley & Sons, $12.95) also has final I.R.S. forms that can be clipped out or photocopied. And those willing to stand in line can get forms at I.R.S. offices.
The simplest source is a new private service, Forms-U-Need. For $5 a form, which is charged to Visa or Mastercard, you can call (800) IRS-4502, or (800) 477-4502, on a touch-tone phone and have forms sent immediately by fax, simply by following the telephone instructions. The fax must be photocopied for filing.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "I.R.S. Tips for Avoiding Mistakes"
 
Fran Crowley, assistant district direcotor for the Internal Revenue Service in New York, suggests these steps to avoid common filing errors and get speedier refunds processed. The refunds averaged $973.
 
If taking the standard deduction, use the correct one for your situation. People who are age 65 or over, or are blind, qualify for a larger standard deduction.
 
Use the label from your tax package in the name and address block on the return. If you do not have the package, be sure to use your correct Social Security number, address and ZIP code.
 
If sending in a payment, write your Social Security number, day time telephone number and "1991 Form 1040" (or 1040A or 1040EZ) on the check or money order.
 
Don't overlook tax benefits. For example, many eligible people fail to claim the earned inocme credit, which is available for most workers who make less than $21,250 and have a child. If you make so little that you aren't required to file a return, but you are entitled to the earned income credit, file a tax return, and the I.R.S. will send you a check for the credit.
 
Sign and date the return. When filing jointly, both spouses must sign, even if only one had income.

HEADLINE: A New Squeeze On Air Travelers

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
On most flights across the country, passengers have a limited choice of entertainment. They can watch a movie, read and on aircraft with two aisles, stretch their legs a bit.
But now, some airlines are increasing the number of single-aisle, or narrow-bodied, airplanes they use on long-distance domestic flights. This makes it important for long-distance travelers concerned about comfort to ask, when making their reservations, what type of plane they will be on. 
 "I am getting screaming calls from business travelers who are expecting wide-bodied planes," said Joe Brancatelli, the editor of Frequent Flyer, a travel magazine based in New York. "There are three seats on the right of the aisle and three seats on the left; end of discussion. If a flight attendant is in the middle of the aisle with a cart, you can't get through the plane."
The narrow-bodied aircraft typically used on long-distance domestic flights, mostly the coast-to-coast routes, is the Boeing 757. It seats up to 194 passengers, depending on the model used and the number of first-class seats.
While some airlines are increasingly using 757's on longer domestic flights, they are diverting their wide-bodied aircraft for new or expanded international routes, said Tim Smith, the spokesman for American Airlines. "You have to balance the planes that you have on hand," he said.
Recently, American announced it would use 757's when it starts a new service between New York and Seattle. And about 18 months ago, Delta Air Lines equipped its 757's with systems that show movies and play music on long-distance flights, said Neil Monroe, a company spokesman.
 
A Veritable Workhorse
 The aircraft, which has three seats on each side of a center aisle, is a virtual aerial workhorse. It can easily take off on short, high-altitude runways and has the range to make flights across the country.
But on the longer flights, the plane's single aisle and confining seats are drawbacks. When meals are being served, for example, it is more difficult to walk around the serving cart and to get to the restrooms. And the plane's seats are among the narrowest of any long-range aircraft.
"It would be my last choice for a long-distance flight," said Ed Perkins, the editor of the Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
Fortunately, travelers can easily learn what airplane they'll be on by asking their travel agent or the airline's reservation clerk. The same airline will fly different types of aircraft on the same route at various times of the day, so choices are available.
Delta sometimes uses 757's for its off-hour flights, according to Mr. Monroe, the company spokesman. United Airlines flies a 757 on one of its two daily flights between Boston and Los Angeles; on the second flight it uses a wider plane, the Boeing 767.
By contrast, the 767 has two aisles and wider seats.
"The 767 is about the most comfortable plane flying," said Mr. Perkins of Consumer Reports. "It is as good as it gets in economy class and I would always choose it."
Other aircraft with two aisles that are frequently used on long-range domestic flights are Lockheed's L1011, McDonnell Douglas's DC-10 and various models made by Airbus Industrie.
United also may soon use 757's on the five-hour flight between San Francisco and Hawaii, both Mr. Brancatelli and Mr. Perkins said. It is currently using the larger DC-10.
Recently, some travelers expressed concerns about flying on a Fokker F28 after one operated by USAir crashed during a snowstorm at La Guardia Airport in New York, killing 27 people. The possibility that the aircraft is prone to ice buildup on the wings has been raised as a possible cause of that crash.
But Mr. Perkins of Consumer Reports said other planes, including the DC-9, also might be susceptible to icing, a condition that makes taking off more difficult.
"Everyone gets scared of the plane that has had the last crash," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Higher; Election Lift Seen for Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday, but the spotlight was on sterling following the Conservative Party victory in the British national election.
Gold prices were also higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold closed at $341.10 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from Thursday. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $340.65, up $1.25. 
 Traders said the pound was likely to continue strengthening next week after Thursday's election gave the Conservative Party an unexpected majority in government.
Now that the political uncertainty is over, dealers said sterling could rise higher -- particularly against the German mark -- on renewed optimism over Britain's prospects for economic recovery. Other European economies, notably Germany's, face a downturn.
There was little United States news to affect the dollar yesterday, said Mike Faust, a currency dealer with MMS International. New economic data had marginal impact on the dollar, he said.
The Labor Department said consumer prices, jolted by sharp increases for food, gasoline and clothing, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month.
It was the biggest increase in the Consumer Price Index in 17 months, but economists said it was unlikely to be repeated given the economy's prolonged weakness and the expected anemic recovery.
Traders also said the dollar was somewhat supported by the perception the Federal Reserve would not ease interest rates further. The dollar fell Thursday after the Fed added money to the nation's banking system.
The move was widely interpreted to mean the Fed had cut its target for the Federal funds rate, the interest that banks charge each other on overnight loans, from 4 percent to 3.75 percent.
Falling United States interest rates usually erode demand for the dollar by reducing returns on dollar-based holdings. In New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.7660, down from $1.7665 late Thursday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7655, from $1.7635 Thursday. The pound soared to finish at 2.8910 marks, up from 2.8595 marks.
The dollar was quoted at 132.85 Japanese yen in New York, up from 132.05 Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.51 yen, to 132.19. Later, in London, it was quoted at 132.85 yen.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Thursday's late levels, were: 1.6360 German marks, up from 1.6165; 1.5080 Swiss francs, down from 1.7665; 5.5390 French francs, up from 5.4775; 1,232.00 Italian lire, up from 1,221.00, and 1.8675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18755.

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
Best American Men Are Running on Empty In Top Competitions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The first three finishers today in the Columbus, Ohio, marathon for men will represent the United States in the Olympic marathon this summer in Barcelona, Spain. But, given the current state of American distance running, it might not matter who they are.
The last 10 years have provided dramatic evidence that even the best marathoners in the United States have little chance to win major international events like the Olympics. Whether the reasons relate to training, cultural differences, motivation or innate talent, Americans are lagging behind rivals from many other countries, including Japan, Mexico, Australia and African nations like Kenya, Ethiopia and Tanzania. 
 Recently, Americans have rarely broken through the ascending standards set by others. Steve Spence did it by finishing third at the world championships last summer in Tokyo, and so did Ken Martin, who had a second-place finish in 2 hours 9 minutes 38 seconds in the 1989 New York Marathon, the fastest time by an American in more than eight years.
Among the 149 recorded performances under 2:10, Americans account for only 12 of them, and the best, Alberto Salazar's 2:08:52 to win in Boston in 1982, ranks 48th on the list.
 
Taking to the Road
 While there may be no single explanation for the disparity, several factors seem to help explain it.
One is training methods. Without the kind of support programs that exist in other countries, which allow elite runners to focus on major events, many Americans subsist on the lucrative road-racing circuit in North America. That generally means running too often to follow a more disciplined training schedule for success in the marathon.
Frank Shorter, the last American to win an Olympic marathon, in 1972, contends that frequent road racing keeps too many runners away from the track, where they need to develop speed over 10,000 meters for faster times in the marathon.
Once a runner knows he can run the 10,000 in 27 minutes 30 seconds or better, his confidence increases substantially, as Shorter's did 20 years ago. Eight days before the Olympic marathon, he set an American record in the Olympic 10,000.
"So I could go into the marathon, knowing no runner was faster than I was over 10,000 meters," he said. "Psychologically, I was able to control the race. Our Americans are wondering which of 15 other people with better times at 10,000 is going to control the race."
 
10,000 Problems
 The American record at 10,000 meters is 27:20.56, run by Mark Nenow six years ago in Brussels. That time ranks eighth in the world and remains the only entry by an American in the top 10. The world record, 27:08.23, was set by Arturo Barrios of Mexico in 1989.
More telling is what happened in the 10,000 last year. Thirty-one athletes had faster times than the leading American, Shannon Butler (27:59.35), and 10 were Kenyans. In the marathon, the fastest American was Martin with his sixth-place finish of 2:12:06 in Berlin. But more than 40 other runners, including 12 from Japan, had faster times.
"Americans are not focusing on training for a race," Shorter said. "They're too focused on the American road-racing scene. They have become lulled into thinking they can race more often and still be successful in the big events."
Despite Japan's deep tradition for developing successful marathoners, with 3 on the top-10 list for 1991 by Track and Field News, Africans were prominent in other distance events, with 7 of the top 10 in the 10,000, 8 in the 5,000 and 8 in the 3,000-meter steeplechase. Of those 23 athletes, 15 were Kenyans, many of whom will likely become marathoners.
 
Different Life Style in Africa
 Shorter and other runners, like Bill Reifsnyder, the defending champion and course-record holder in Columbus, cite training regimens as a reason Japanese and Kenyan runners, among others, have been more successful. They sometimes train as often as three times a day, a schedule few Americans would attempt.
Runners from Kenya and other African nations are also set apart by the social and economic conditions. Reifsnyder, one of the favorites with Martin, Bob Kempainen, Mark Curp and Spence, recalled a recent conversation that his friend Jill Hunter, the British distance runner, had. She was talking with William Mutwol, who was second in Kenya's 1-2-3 sweep of the world cross-country championships last month.
Mutwol told Hunter that Americans had it too easy, with cars to transport them everywhere. He told her of returning to Nairobi recently after a race abroad and then walking another 31 miles to his small village.
"Why didn't you run part of the way?" Hunter asked.
"Couldn't," he replied. "I was carrying my luggage."

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Rising Tax Load On Middle Class

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
TO the middle-class taxpayers who feel they are saddled with an unfair share of the nation's tax burden, H & R Block Inc., America's biggest tax-preparation firm, is saying, "You're right."
Block, which prepares one in seven of the country's tax returns, commissioned a study by the Tax Policy Research Project at the University of Missouri-Kansas City and released the results this week. "Middle-income taxpayers have been shown to bear increasing effective total tax rates over the last 15 years," the authors concluded. 
 "I believe the more money you make, the greater your ability to pay tax," Thomas M. Bloch, president of the company, said in an interview. "In 1977, we had a much more progressive system, and I would say it was fairer." The Tax Reform Act of 1986 slashed rates and eliminated deductions, with the intent of making the tax code simpler and fairer.
Mr. Bloch hastened to add, "We have a very good tax system in this country and it would be a mistake to throw it out, but we should bring back some progressivity -- it needs to be fine-tuned."
"We did this to help the people we serve," he said. "I'm hopeful that members of Congress will take a look at this and something will be done. I would like to think that tax relief for the middle class is not a dead issue," despite President Bush's veto of a tax bill with that intent last month. The President's main reason was that the bill did not lower taxes on long-term capital gains. Mr. Block agreed, saying, "There are real advantages to a lower capital-gains tax."
On the other hand, David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young, which serves a more affluent clientele, when asked about the study, said, "The country is a vast middle class, and that is why the middle class is bearing the brunt of the tax burden." A millionaires' surtax has populist appeal but would do little to reduce the deficit, he said, because there are relatively few millionaires.
The study, by Dr. Larry R. Garrison, executive director of the university's Tax Policy Project and an associate professor of taxation, and Wanda James, a research associate, analyzed the tax burden of 32 typical taxpayers over the last 15 years.
They used the following filing categories: single, head of household with one dependent, married filing jointly with no dependents, and married filing jointly with two dependents. They calculated taxes using average deductions, based on I.R.S. figures, for each of these categories in eight 1990 income groups: $15,000, $25,000, $35,000, $50,000, $75,000, $100,000, $150,000 and $200,000. They focused on the years 1977, 1984, 1988 and 1990 -- when key tax laws had taken full effect.
"The wealthy received the greatest tax-cut benefit between those years, with decreasing benefits accrued to taxpayers with lower income levels," the authors wrote.
They found that the effective income tax rate (that is the percentage of income actually paid in taxes, as opposed to the marginal tax rate, which is the rate paid on the last dollar earned) for a married couple filing jointly with no dependents in the lowest income group went from 4.2 percent in 1977 to 5.5 percent in 1990, while their total Federal tax burden including Social Security and Medicare taxes went from 10 percent to 13.1 percent.
A couple with income of $50,000 saw their income taxes drop to 11.7 percent, from 14 percent, but their overall taxes rose to 19.3 percent, from 18 percent. In contrast, the couple with $200,000 of income saw their effective income tax rate drop to 21.7 percent, from 30.2 percent, and their overall rate drop to 23.6 percent, from 31.2 percent.
The authors said that they strongly recommended "a more equitable distribution of the Federal tax burden across all income groups." They added that they opposed raising taxes on the middle class to reduce the deficit, invite investment and pay for "sorely needed domestic programs."
To be sure, not all tax experts agree. The authors drew general conclusions from 32 sample tax returns without reference to macroeconomic data.
Mr. Berenson called it "flawed, divisive, almost jingoistic," to pit the middle class against the wealthy. "The biggest problem facing the United States is not someone's perception of equity," he said. "The biggest problem is the loss of jobs, economic position. The greatest benefit you can give the middle class is a job."
Mr. Berenson contends that the country needs incentives for more jobs, capital formation, deficit reduction and economic stimulus to make American industry more competitive.
Furthermore, he said, it is a mistake to lump payroll taxes, which are intended to provide old-age and disability benefits, with income taxes.
Professor Garrison said he had done so because "a lot of people see it as another tax, just like the income tax." He added, "They don't see the benefit at the other end."
He and Mr. Berenson agreed on one point. Payroll taxes -- a flat 7.65 percent on both employees and employers for Social Security and Medicare -- are regressive for both individual taxpayers and for business.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 328 words

HEADLINE: Democracy's Checkpoint

 BODY:
Millions of Americans are hunched over desks and dining room tables this weekend, struggling to meet Wednesday's deadline for filing Form 1040. Too many will skip right past the check-off boxes at the top -- the place to cast your vote for fair Presidential campaign financing.
Each "yes" vote sends a dollar to the fund that finances campaigns and nominating conventions and diminishes the influence of special interests. Voting "no," or not at all, invites a return to the bad old days of unlimited spending and unrestricted fund-raising. 
 Federal financing was established in 1974, in the wake of the 1972 money-laundering scandals. Fixed amounts are allocated for party conventions and their nominees' campaigns; the rest goes, on a matching basis, to primary candidates who qualify by raising $100,000 from small personal donations.
The check-off peaked in 1980, when 41 million taxpayers fed the fund $41 million. It has since fallen back to about $32 million each year -- weak support from the nation's 110 million taxpayers.
Among taxpayers who filed early this year, substantially more checked "yes" than early filers last year did. Whatever the reason, not yet known, that's good news for now but no guarantee for the future. Indeed, the Federal Election Commission estimates it will come up at least $75 million short for the 1996 elections.
People may be disinclined to finance the election of any politician these days. One reason is the corrosive flow of unrestricted "sewer money" contributions that skirt the limits on candidates' national campaigns by funneling funds through state organizations that support them.
It's up to Congress to stanch this corruption of a worthy concept, and to fix the basic financing formula while there's still time. Campaign costs have soared, but the check-off remains at $1; it should be raised to $2.50 or $3, and then indexed to keep pace with inflation.
Taxpayers can help, too, by checking "yes."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: What Coated Windows Can Do

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Because efficient windows are critical to solving many environmental and economic problems I was happy to see your March 21 Consumer's World page article bring these issues to a wide readership. 
 Use of new kinds of windows will save consumers in the United States more energy than is now supplied by the Alaskan oilfields. Windows using low-emissivity coatings, argon gas and insulated frames are all cost-effective in saving huge amounts of energy now lost through windows.
Unfortunately, the experts you consulted gave some misleading and outdated information, which may lead readers to mistaken choices of window technologies. The following four points need correction.
You compare soft and hard low-emissivity, or low-e, coatings, concluding that soft coatings (including Heat Mirror) perform better in containing indoor heat and repelling outdoor heat and ultraviolet rays, while hard coatings are more durable.
Tradeoffs between durability and performance are no longer necessary. I invented completely durable hard low-e coatings that outperform other low-e coatings. Libbey-Owens-Ford and Pilkington Glass have marketed them since 1989. In cold weather, these products conserve more energy than soft coatings, because the hard coatings let more free solar heat into a window. In warm climates, hard coatings are more economical in cutting air-conditioning costs. Hard coatings are durable enough to be used on inexpensive single-glazed windows, which are traditional in Southern architecture.
Readers may incorrectly conclude that all hard coatings have about the same performance, because you report that they vary only slightly in heat reflectivity, from 74 percent to 80 percent. But commercially available hard-coated products have widely different heat reflectivities: Pilkington's K-Glass, 82 percent; Libbey-Owens-Ford's Energy Advantage, 80 percent; A.F.G.'s Comfort-E2, 80 percent; Ford's Sunglas HR, 65 percent; P.P.G.'s Sungate, 63 percent, and A.F.G.'s Comfort-E, 55 percent.
The top three products are so efficient that they are net collectors of solar energy even in this country's coldest winter climates, whereas the lowest three are net losers of energy.
You suggest that saving energy with low-e glass may require a tinted window. Now, however, the best-performing hard low-e coatings have no tint or color at all.
You incorrectly state that hard low-e coatings have a problem with sealing in argon gas and imply that soft coatings do not have such a problem. But it is the soft coatings that have this problem. The glue, which is used to keep the argon inside the double glazing, does not stick to the soft coating. Therefore in production, the soft coating must be carefully removed from the entire edge of the glass sheet. In contrast, the glue sticks even better to the hard coatings than to glass.
It is easy to be misled by the competing claims for various products. An energy rating system is needed for windows, similar to the one that is now used for household appliances. The ratings should show the energy cost of using each product in a particular climate zone. Such a rating system is being introduced in Canada and California, and ought to be adopted elsewhere.
 
ROY G. GORDON
Thomas D. Cabot Professor of Chemistry, Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., March 30, 1992

HEADLINE: As Economy Drops in Japan, Chiefs Vie for Top Cut in Pay

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
American executives often wince and stumble for explanations when their hefty pay packages are compared with the relatively modest compensation received by their Japanese counterparts.
Now the comparison is becoming even more uncomfortable: With Japan's economy hitting the wall and corporate profits dropping, industrial leaders here are suddenly competing with each other to see who can absorb the deepest pay cut. 
 In the last few weeks alone, the chiefs of companies like Hitachi, Fujitsu, IBM Japan and Japan Airlines have called in reporters to say that with business this bad, they are slashing their base pay by upward of 35 percent.
 
'Sign of Our Resolve'
 At the Ricoh Corporation, one of Japan's leading makers of copiers, the company is about to post its first operating loss in decades. Hiroshi Hamada, Ricoh's president, has already taken a 20 percent pay cut. And a few weeks ago the order went out to the company's top executives: Each one must walk around with a formal letter of resignation in his breast pocket.
"It is more a ritual kind of resignation than an actual one, and that could be easily misunderstood in the West, where there is no real equivalent," said Hiroshi Sakagami, a company spokesman, who said none have been accepted. "But it is symbolically important as a sign of our resolve to improve business performance."
Without question, some of the announced pay cuts seem more than a little self-serving. Many executives seem to be hoping that their sacrifices will overshadow some extraordinarily poor decisions and loose spending in the boom times that suddenly ended last year.
But coming just months after the trip here by President Bush was tainted by his accompanying entourage of high-paid executives, several of whom run companies in far worse shape than their Japanese competitors, the political symbolism of the Japanese cuts seems particularly stark.
"In America in tough times, executives might cut their big bonus pay for the year," said Stephen F. O'Byrne, a principal in Towers Perrin, a consulting firm that tracks some executive pay issues. "In Japan, they cut the base salary. That sends a very different message."
While some American executives have also seen their compensation decline, most stock-bonus plans and profit-sharing incentives work according to strict formulas, allowing executives to gather wealth in good years and leaving them little downside risk. The base salary cuts, however, are usually regarded as a more serious -- and often longer-lasting -- matter.
Even with corporate losses, the base pay of American executives does not usually go down, although their performance-based bonuses and other compensation often does. Last year, for example, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, received a rise in base pay of about 6 percent, to $976,378, although his total pay package, including bonuses and incentives, shrank by more than a third. Robert L. Crandall, chairman of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said his base pay of about $600,000 had stayed the same for three years of lower profits and losses. His total compensation in 1990 was off by about a third.
The Japanese are hardly cutting their pay to satisfy shareholders, as have some big American companies. Shareholders here have far less clout than in America. For the Japanese, pay cuts are just another form of apology, perhaps a little more meaningful than a deep, remorseful bow on national television when record-low earnings are announced, but a little less permanent than ritual suicide -- also not unheard of in Japan's unforgiving corporate landscape.
No one is quite sure how much Japanese executives are hurting because no one is quite sure how much they get paid. While many American companies must report such figures in public filings, the Japanese requirements are far less stringent.
 
Plenty of Privileges
 But in 1990, according to estimates made by Graef Crystal, an executive pay expert and professor at the University of California at Berkeley, the chief executives of America's biggest companies typically made about $3.2 million. The comparable figure in Japan is slightly more than $500,000.
But Japanese executives also receive perquisites that make their lives considerably more luxurious than the salary figures would suggest. Most live in company-supported houses or luxurious apartments in exclusive neighborhoods in Tokyo and Osaka, far out of the reach of ordinary white-collar workers. Their expense accounts are virtually unlimited and little scrutinized.
Like many American executives, they are often given club memberships, especially to golf clubs; the difference is that in Japan, such memberships would cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Unlike American executives' perks, theirs are almost all nontaxable.
"People make too much of this whole thing about compensation," said Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, when he was repeatedly challenged on the pay issue during Mr. Bush's visit here in January. "If you spend time scrutinizing Japanese pay, you'll discover they are living very nicely."
Few top American executives, however, would trade their own package for a Japanese one. Mr. Poling, for example, got a total of $1.14 million in pay and other compensation last year, down 6.6 percent from 1990, even though his base pay was unchanged. Japanese auto executives have not been announcing pay cuts lately, but they get only about half of what Detroit chiefs get.
And Japan's tradition of stable, lifetime employment often stops at the board room door. These days especially, the tenure of a Japanese executive can be strikingly short.
 
Many Ousted Recently
 In recent months, many top executives have been demoted or expelled, usually for lending out company money for speculative real estate deals that have gone sour.
In the latest such case, two leading executives of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese consumer electronics concern known for its Panasonic products and its ownership of MCA Inc. were stripped of their titles and sent to the corporate dungeon for $1.3 billion in bad loans. Among the victims was Masahiko Hirata, Matsushita's powerful executive vice president and one of the architects of the acquisition of MCA. Akio Tanii, Matsushita's president, apparently had no knowledge of the deals, but took a self-imposed 50 percent cut in pay for six months for lax supervision.
The Japanese press reported that the demotions did not follow any calls for blood from shareholders, but rather from employees. "It is like taking the money with which you can build three or four fine factories, and dumping it into the sewer," one executive was quoted as telling Aera magazine, a popular Japanese monthly.
The strongest evidence that pay cuts are a Japanese cultural phenomenon comes when one compares what has happened at IBM Japan and at its corporate parent, the International Business Machines Corporation. Late last year I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, came to Tokyo and declared that Takeo Shiina, the president and chief executive of IBM Japan, was a "hero of the I.B.M. Corporation," despite widespread troubles at the Japanese subsidiary that led to a 32 percent decline in net income last year.
 
Reward Is a Cut
 Apparently the reward for heroism at IBM Japan these days is a 10 percent cut in pay. Vice presidents, senior managing directors and managing directors of the company are all taking 8 percent cut pay cuts.
But Mr. Shiina's example is not being followed at I.B.M.'s corporate headquarters, which had a lot worse year than the Japan operation. Worldwide, I.B.M. lost $2.83 billion last year, down from a profit of $6.02 billion in 1990, but Mr. Akers's base pay of $925,000 has stayed the same. The company points out, however, that the total compensation package of Mr. Akers has declined 40 percent, to $1.58 million, because of a large drop in his bonus pay and stock options.
Probably the broadest pay cuts have come at Hitachi. Operating profits at the electronics giant dripped to 120 billion yen, or less than $1 billion, meaning that the huge company eked out a smaller profit than tiny Nintendo, the video-game maker. Eight executives, including the chairman and president, will take a 15 percent cut in their salary, and other board members will suffer a 10 percent cut. The company also announced that 9,000 managers would forgo a scheduled 4.7 percent raise.
 
The 'Me, Too' Industry
 The Hitachi announcement set off a flurry of other cuts in the electronics industry, known for its "yokonarabu" tendencies, a term that roughly translates as "me, too." Fujitsu said last week that it would cut salaries for top executives 15 to 35 percent and freeze the pay of other managers. Yamaha said its president's pay would be cut 20 percent.
"If there is a pay cut, it creates a feeling of a kind of crisis," said a Fujitsu spokesman, Yuri Momomoto.
That, in the end, may be what is at work in the pay cuts. Japan, many Japanese executives have lamented in recent months, not only got rich in the 1980's but fat and happy. And nothing makes the Japanese work harder than a crisis.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California;
Strategies Emerge in Dual Senate Races

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 10

 BODY:
John Seymour's first television commercials for California's June 2 senatorial primary neglect to mention that he is a Senator, but tell viewers that Congress "has botched things up" and is "the epitome of arrogance."
The advertisements have led the Democratic candidates and Mr. Seymour's critics in the Republican Party to call him a hypocrite for disguising the fact that he was appointed to fill the comfortable chair on Capitol Hill that belonged to Gov. Pete Wilson until 1990. 
 But the commercials have aptly captured the commanding theme of anti-incumbency in the primary campaigns here. Californians will chose candidates for two Senate races, the first such political free-for-all in the state.
"In the old days you came back home and bragged about how influential you were in Washington," said Charles E. Cook Jr., editor of The Cook Political Report, a newsletter that tracks Congressional and Presidential races. "Now everyone is running as an outsider."
 
The 'Thornburgh Mistake'
 Dianne Feinstein's campaign manager agreed. "You have to run against the establishment now," said the manager, Ken Kuwata, whose candidate has a wide lead in the polls against her Democratic opponent, Comptroller Gray Davis, and is also running ahead in a matchup with Mr. Seymour. "Nobody is going to make the mistake that Dick Thornburgh did in Pennsylvania and say, 'I know the halls of power.' "
The choices in the two primaries, one to pick candidates to contest for the seat being vacated by Senator Alan Cranston and the other to fill out the remaining two years of Governor Wilson's term, will send a loud message about the importance of incumbency.
Though most of the candidates are insiders by one definition or another, those who serve in Congress are considered more vulnerable, at least for the moment, than those who walk the corridors of the State Capitol.
"The single most visible object of scorn is Congress," said Roy Behr, campaign manager for Leo McCarthy, California's Lieutenant Governor, who is ahead in polls in the Democratic race against two members of the House of Representatives, Barbara Boxer and Mel Levine.
Several other themes are also expected to play out here: the political significance of sex and wealth, the prospects for the right wing of the Republican Party and the role of foreign policy in an election year so far dominated by domestic malaise.
Democratic women, who along with the other Senate candidates from their party will be on display at a state convention this weekend in Los Angeles, are running in both primaries. Ms. Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco and a failed candidate for governor, is seeking the two-year seat, and Representative Boxer is seeking the six-year seat.
The voting will help answer the question of whether the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings, and the anger that many women expressed at the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee, have made women significantly stronger as candidates.
 
Women Want Their Own
 "Gender consciousness has increased immeasurably," said William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute. "Being good on women's rights is not enough anymore. Women are saying, 'We have to have our own.' "
Ms. Feinstein is not known here as a woman's woman, and her record as Mayor left some feminists leery. In her first setback of the young campaign, Ms. Feinstein was sued last week by the State Fair Political Practices Commission, and will likely be fined, for improperly reporting millions of dollars in campaign money in her 1990 run for governor.
Ms. Boxer won notice last fall when she led a group of seven female lawmakers up the steps of the Capitol in Washington, protesting the slowness of the Judiciary Committee's inquiry into allegations that Judge Thomas had sexually harassed an aide.
Since then, however, Ms. Boxer's campaign stumbled with the disclosure that she had overdrawn her checking account at the House bank. Many analysts say her Senate bid is doomed, but she has responded with disarming good humor to headlines about "Barbara Bouncer," saying, "My closets aren't neat either" and predicting that voters will still find her the candidate best able to tweak the Washington establishment.
"One of my opponents is from the most powerful political machine in Southern California," she said. "The other is from the Sacramento machine. It's not like I'm running against H. Ross Perot."
The Sacramento candidate is Mr. McCarthy. The Southern California candidate is Mr. Levine, an obscure Congressmen who was invisible through the early months of the campaign as he built a huge treasury. But late last month he began a $3.5 million television advertising campaign that will bring him into California living rooms more times each week than all the network news anchors combined.
Mr. Levine's blitz, which brags that he "wrote no bad checks," could knock Mr. McCarthy out of the lead he now holds in the polls and push Ms. Boxer from the No. 2 spot.
 
Testing Bounds of Money
 "Mel's campaign will test how far you can get with money," Mr. Schneider said. "I can't think of anyone who's used such a deliberate strategy of waiting and blanketing the state with ads. He's literally trying to buy the California primary."
The gamble is a big one. Duane B. Garrett, Ms. Feinstein's campaign chairman, noted that any major world event, like a Middle East conflict, could drown out Mr. Levine's message.
Even more likely to upstage him is a vigorous Presidential campaign here by Edmund G. Brown Jr., California's native son. "A lot of Mel's strategy depends on the California Presidential primary not mattering," said Bruce Cain, associate director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California at Berkeley.
The two Republican primaries here will draw clear ideological lines like the Goldwater-Rockefeller struggles of old. These races are expected to be particularly heated if Patrick J. Buchanan runs hard in the nation's final Presidential primary and thus galvanizes his right-wing supporters.
 
Big Test for Governor
 More than the Republican candidates themselves, the big winner or loser here in June will be Governor Wilson, who selected, coached, bankrolled and endorsed Mr. Seymour. Mr. Seymour's main opponent in the primary is Representative William E. Dannemeyer, one of the most conservative members of Congress, who made his mark excoriating homosexuals. Also in this race is William Allen, a graduate school professor and a member of the United State Civil Rights Commission.
So far, Mr. Wilson has stayed out of the second primary race, a more competitive contest that pits Representative Tom Campbell, a former Stanford University economist, against Bruce Herschensohn, a right-wing television commentator.
The Campbell-Herschensohn race is thought to be a clearer ideological test because Senator Seymour is a recent convert to moderate positions regarding abortion rights and environmental protection, while Mr. Campbell has consistently held such views.
Running against these two is Mayor Sonny Bono of Palm Springs.
Both primaries will test the strength of the conservative wing of the party, which propelled Ronald Reagan to victory as Governor and then to the Presidency, but has lately lost strength.
"These races will demonstrate whether the religious right is still powerful and whether the anti-gay issues are a major political force," Mr. Schneider said.
Another motif here is how foreign policy will play as campaign issue. Both Mr. Levine and Ms. Feinstein were vocal last year in support of the Persian Gulf war, distinguishing themselves from the rest of the Democratic field.
"A year ago everybody thought this would be the key issue," said Tony Coehlo, the former House Democratic whip. "Now it doesn't matter and it might be a negative."
So far Mr. Levine is the only candidate announcing loud and clear that he is a Washington player. "My ads make very clear that I am Congressman Mel Levine running for Senate," he said. "I am certainly not trying to define myself as an outsider because I am not one."
