HEADLINE: Reichmanns And Official In Dispute

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 10

 BODY:
Because of a clash with the secretive Reichmann brothers over financial disclosure, Thomas S. Johnson, the president just hired to head their company, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., is likely to miss a crucial meeting with creditors on Monday, banking and company officials said today.
 "Let's say that I'd fall over a chair if I saw Mr. Johnson there," said an Olympia official who asked not to be identified. 
Mr. Johnson is the former president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in New York who was appointed only two weeks ago to lead Olympia & York's debt reorganization.
 
No. 2 to Lead Talks
 Heading the talks instead will be Robert S. Miller Jr., who helped save the Chrysler Corporation from collapse in the early 1980's and who was second in command to Mr. Johnson on the giant real estate company's planning and finance committee.
 Olympia issued a statement saying that the role of Mr. Johnson, who continues to hold the title of president, is being "redefined."
 Mr. Miller and Paul Reichmann, the family's chief strategist, are preparing a plan that will analyze each of the more than 50 prime commercial properties of North America's biggest landlord and how Olympia plans to deal with any individual financing problems related to those properties, officials said.
 But Olympia, though still believed to have assets well in excess of its $18.5 billion of debts, is resisting providing global data on its overall financial position.
 Officials said this resistance was at the bottom of the dispute with Mr. Johnson, who felt it was essential to give the banks a full financial picture of the natural resources and real estate empire created over the last two decades by the Reichmann family.
 Another Olympia executive said that Mr. Johnson was upset that his compensation package had not been agreed to and that he left Toronto on April 3 refusing to return unless his demands were met.
 Mr. Miller issued a statement denying there was any rift over disclosure between the rescue team and the Reichmanns.
 It was uncertain what impact Mr. Johnson's absence would have on what amounts to the largest private- sector debt restructuring in history. Olympia's debt load is as high as many third-world countries during the debt crisis of the 1980's.
 "My own sense," said Alain Tuchmaier, financial services analyst for McLean McCarthy Inc., "is that so much is at stake that the importance of a single individual is overwhelmed by the need for the restructuring process to go forward."
 
Big Meeting Monday
 Yet the divisions between Mr. Johnson and the Reichmann family could have echoes at the big Monday meeting. Burns Fry Ltd., Olympia's Canadian investment bankers, have retained the Dominion Ballroom of the Sheraton Center Hotel, one of the city's largest meeting places, and are expecting 400 to 500 representatives of banks, insurance companies, lawyers, accountants and others.
 "I still think the banks are going to persist in demanding global disclosure," one senior bank official commented. "They have to be able to assess the total picture before they go into a restructuring."
 Olympia's cash troubles, which have seen it narrowly miss defaulting on several bond issues and failing to repay a bank loan of $450 million (Canadian), or $378 million (United States), that came due April 1, have been brought on by the recession, declining commercial real estate values and upward spiraling costs at its $7 billion Canary Wharf development in London.
 Mr. Miller, who had been vice chairman of Chrysler, left the automobile company earlier this year to become a partner at James D. Wolfensohn Inc., a financial advisory firm in New York, amid speculation that he was not in the running to become Chrysler chief executive. After the Reichmanns retained the Wolfehsohn firm he came to Olympia as Mr. Johnson's deputy.
 
Tough Tactics Expected
 Mr. Miller is expected to use tactics similar to those he employed in the Chrysler restructuring, negotiating hard with each creditor. That style is said to appeal to Paul Reichmann and his two brothers, Albert and Ralph, who are not only anxious to keep a lid on the operations but reluctant to approve any asset or equity sales that the banks may seek.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Turns Hollow

BYLINE: By Saskia Sassen; Saskia Sassen, professor of urban planning at Columbia University, is author of "The Global City: New York, London, Tokyo."

 BODY:
Japan's bubble economy has burst, revealing systemic problems that preceded the country's recession and are likely to worsen in the future. Some commentators speak of the "hollowing out" of the economy, even of the shrinking of the industrial base. The ailments run so deep that it is deluding to imagine that Japan's economy can serve as a model to remedy our own problems.
Aside from the dramatic rise and fall of the Nikkei index, corporate failures are at a postwar high. Banks are suffering from bad real estate loans and the collapse of the real estate market. The Government is having trouble covering its obligations from expected revenues. 
 Mines, steel factories and shipyards where profits have declined have been closed. Large-scale unemployment in the affected regions has led the Government to designate 38 depressed areas as eligible for special assistance.
And while urban ills have not plumbed the depth of poverty found in New York and London, economic decline and forced displacement of thousands of working-class people in Tokyo have created inner-city problems that are familiar in the West.
Like American companies, Japan's companies seek low wages and high profits by going abroad. By 1989, Japanese companies had set up some 40 factories in Mexico to produce electronics components and auto parts for their U.S. factories. By 1990, they had opened hundreds of plants in Thailand to produce parts and components for their factories in Japan. And in 1991, employment in the manufacturing sector fell by 4 percent.
Since the mid-1980's, manufacturing has been losing its wage-setting power. Increases in earnings for full-time workers in establishments with 30 or more employees have fallen yearly, from 5 percent in 1985, to 3 percent in 1988, to 1 percent in 1990.
While wages in manufacturing are stagnating, professionals in finance are earning the highest salaries ever, if they are men. Women tend to do part-time work, and there is a rapidly increasing number of part-time and casual jobs throughout the economy. The gap between part-time and full-time salaries has increased. In 1977, part-time workers earned 80 percent of full-time earnings; today they earn 60 percent.
There is less job security and more work-related stress. Only 22 percent of all workers have the much-touted lifelong tenure. Many workers suffer from chronic fatigue and work-related illnesses; since 1989, an average of 10,000 a year have died of diagnosed work-related cerebral hemorrhages. Many Japanese will never own a home. There now are 90-year mortgages, which give people a chance to buy a home over three generations.
Household debt, as a percentage of disposable income, rose from 77 percent in 1980 to 114 percent in 1990. (For the U.S., the 1990 figure was 103 percent; for Germany, under 80 percent.)
Everyone pays very high prices for food, clothing and household goods. Except for cars, Japan's manufactured goods are about 50 percent more expensive at home than abroad, and imported goods cost about 80 percent more than in New York, Paris or London.
All this points to a widening chasm between the high-living newly rich and the newly poor -- blue- and white-collar workers struggling to maintain their standard of living but losing ground. At the bottom is a growing mass of the destitute -- day laborers who have lost all Government protection because their numbers have become unmanageable, old people who have become homeless and new illegal immigrants from Asia.
Nowhere is the gulf clearer than in Tokyo. Next to the glamorous central business district lies what might be called the "other Tokyo," a broad area long occupied by the low-income working class and small-scale factories.
In the 1980's, during savage competition to accumulate enough small parcels of land on which to build and expand the business district, some companies resorted to organized crime to meet their needs. Arson and terror were used to drive out longstanding occupants. Criminality and vandalism are growing. There are increasing numbers of homeless old people whose children have left for the suburbs and two-hour round-trip commutes to work.
For 10 years, the world, looking through the bubble, thought Japan's economic leaders had found a better way. Japan built an industrial powerhouse, based on impressive technical development, that came to dominate global markets.
All this was built at a price. The price is now being paid.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
JAZZ, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $21.) In this novel, Ms. Morrison conjures up with absolute authority the Harlem of the 1920's, its scenes and its inhabitants, especially Joe and Violet, a couple who learn again and again that life does not keep its promises.
PLAYING IN THE DARK: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination, by Toni Morrison. (Harvard University, $14.95.) With her critic's hat on, Ms. Morrison argues for a literary scholarship (called "American Africanism") that will bring the black experience to all Americans, casting off the polite habit of ignoring race.
AFTER APARTHEID: The Future of South Africa, by Sebastian Mallaby. (Times Books/Random House, $22.) A British journalist who has covered Africa extensively believes the hardest parts will be achieving democracy and raising living standards.
FIELDS OF GLORY, by Jean Rouaud. (Arcade/Little, Brown, $18.95.) This accomplished first novel, which has sold more than half a million copies in France, deals with the wounds wrought by World War I on a French provincial family.
PARADISE NEWS, by David Lodge. (Viking, $21.) In Mr. Lodge's witty, entertaining ninth novel, a herd of English people descend on Hawaii for a two-week holiday, while a family death and a few other ugly things try to develop in their midst.
AMERICA: WHAT WENT WRONG? by Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele. (Andrews & McMeel, paper, $6.95.) This expanded newspaper series by two Pulitzer Prize winners finds that the economy has been altered to favor the already favored.
PRIMITIVE PEOPLE, by Francine Prose. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Everyone is pretending, disguising, dressing up in a novel so funny it hardly matters that it's about a society in decay.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1790 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Life's Tragic, but Julie Hagerty's Funny

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER; Andy Meisler has written about television for TV Guide and California magazine.

 BODY:
Here's one way to look at it: Julie Hagerty is finished in Hollywood -- at least in sitcoms, at least for now. Gone -- under circumstances both mysterious and ridiculous -- is her starring role in the CBS comedy "Princesses." Gone, too, for that matter, is "Princesses." Just a fond memory is her Universal Studios dressing room; ancient history is her shiny red rented sports car; available for occupancy is her former West Coast base of operations -- an, er, interesting house in the Hollywood Hills.
Who's discouraged or surprised by all this? Not Ms. Hagerty, who can be seen these days in "Noises Off," Peter Bogdanovich's film version of Michael Frayn's backstage farce. In "Noises Off," the actress, who is in her late 30's, plays Poppy Taylor, the spectacularly ineffectual assistant stage manager of a dysfunctional theatrical troupe. 
 In real life, as movie-star profiles put it, she is back in her beloved Upper West Side apartment, where she has been, as they say, mulling her options. In this case the options include: shopping, going to Riverside Park for a frolic with her breadbox-sized Boston terrier, Raisin, or visiting a friend.
The past four months, she says, have been a veritable orgy of theatergoing, aerobics classes and sumptuous, straight out-of-the-Ragu-jar spaghetti dinners. The decidely mixed reviews for "Noises Off" haven't exactly catapulted her to the cover of Vanity Fair.
Has unemployment been trying? "Oh, heavens no! I'm happy as a clam," says Ms. Hagerty in the breathy soprano familiar to fans of her stage and film work. Familiar also are the high cheekbones, the long auburn hair pulled back Alice-in-Wonderland style, and the expression of plucky courage in the face of absurdity first seen in the hit 1980 comedy "Airplane."
In that movie she played the sweet, on-the-edge-of-panic flight attendant who goes to heroic lengths -- including having intimate relations with an inflatable autopilot -- to bring her airliner back to earth safely.
Since then, she has shown an affinity for playing comic heroines in distress: a woman dragged into a manic search for personal fulfillment by her yuppie husband in Albert Brooks's 1985 film "Lost in America"; a neurotic journalist entangled with a philandering bisexual (Jeff Goldblum) in "Beyond Therapy" (1987); a wife who sweetly takes care of business while her psychiatrist husband (Richard Dreyfuss) goes crazy in "What About Bob?" (1991), and the game but inconveniently stone-deaf starlet in the 1986 Lincoln Center production of John Guare's play "The House of Blue Leaves."
In "Noises Off," in which Ms. Hagerty co-stars with Michael Caine, Christopher Reeve, Carol Burnett, John Ritter, Marilu Henner, Mark-Linn Baker and Denholm Elliot, viewers get the physical side of the Hagerty Desperation Spectrum: she is, at various junctures, kicked in the head, forcibly disrobed and impregnated.
The movie is essentially a faithful, only slightly opened-up rendition of the stage play; on stage rehearsals were held for a month before filming began last winter. "It was so much fun," says Ms. Hagerty, at the dining table of her airy, art-filled one-bedroom apartment. "Watching Carol and John and everybody goof around between takes, and listening to Michael's wonderful stories, it was a really joyful time."
A slightly more subtle (and considerably less pleasurable) farce was the saga of "Princesses," which flashed briefly into living rooms last fall. A comedy with the formidable task of competing against ABC's Friday night juggernaut "Family Matters," "Princesses" was created by the writer-producer Barry Kemp ("Newhart," "Coach"). In it, Ms. Hagerty played an unmarried remedial-reading teacher and aspiring actress who lived rent-free, with two other women, in a Manhattan apartment 10 times the size of her real one. Said Mr. Kemp when the show was on the air: "There's a natural buoyancy to Julie. A tendency to look on the good side of things. And she has the ability to be very funny when put into compromising situations."
Unfortunately for Ms. Hagerty, not all the compromising situations were in her scripts. According to several individuals close to the production, Jeff Sagansky, CBS's head of entertainment, had been opposed to Mr. Kemp's decision to cast Ms. Hagerty in the series. She had not received positive response when the pilot episode was shown to test audiences. (Mr. Kemp and Mr. Sagansky declined to comment on Ms. Hagerty or on "Princesses.")
In addition, although Ms. Hagerty had been cast first in the series and the show had ostensibly been built around her, the plots frequently focused on the antics of her more overtly wacky roommates -- a man-hunting Noo Yawkah played by Fran Drescher and a deposed European princess played by the former model Twiggy Lawson.
"It was a very weird situation," says a member of the "Princesses" team, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The way the show developed, she became the person who keeps things fairly grounded in reality. But she didn't want to be the straight person. She wanted to be the quirky one."
Says Ms. Hagerty: "I really adored Fran and Twigs. But it's hard when you're not playing a real person."
Meanwhile, Ms. Hagerty was living another sitcom -- as perhaps the most tragicomically displaced New Yorker west of St. Louis. She rented the first house her Los Angeles real-estate agent showed her. Dug into a hillside, it had a rambling back yard so overgrown that it intimidated both woman and dog. "Sometimes," says Ms. Hagerty, "Raisin and I got in the car and went to find a street where there's a sidewalk. Then we'd get out and take a walk."
She drove the only way recommended for people who have spent the last 20 years flagging down taxicabs. Avoiding the suicidal freeway system at all costs, she gripped the steering wheel so tightly she developed calluses.
After four months, she says, she had made a decent connection with an Italian restaurant that delivered. But by then she had expressed her dissatisfaction to Mr. Kemp, and negotiations had broken down. "We could have changed the part to please her, but it would have ruined the show," explains one person involved in the series. A few weeks after "Princesses" had its premiere, Ms. Hagerty left the show, it was announced, "by mutual decision."
Eight episodes had been filmed; the series was broadcast to dismal ratings. After Ms. Hagerty's departure, Mr. Kemp and CBS shut down the production to regroup and recast. After several meetings, the producers and writers decided that as hard as it was to do the show with Ms. Hagerty, it was even harder to do it without her. And so the show was quietly canceled.
"I got home, gosh, the day after Halloween?" says Ms. Hagerty. Thus far the highlights of her return have included warm welcomes from her neighbors, some unsuccessful experiments in installing track lighting ("These amazing sparks came out of the fuse box") and an interesting offer from David Letterman. "He asked me to bring Raisin with me on the show. I don't think he's ready for his TV debut."
If any one theme runs through Ms. Hagerty's life and art, it's an almost instinctual ability to make the most out of essentially baffling circumstances. Born in Cincinnati, the daughter of a former model and a musician, she spent her childhood around "The Paul Dixon Show," a local television program on which, for its 20-year run, her father, Jerry Hagerty, played saxophone in the orchestra. Sometimes it was Pajama Day, and everybody in the audience had to wear pajamas. One time there was a show for which audience members had to be more than 200 pounds.
Ms. Hagerty attended a local drama school and was discovered by the model agency owner Eileen Ford. But, says Ms. Hagerty, "I had a little problem with modeling. I love to eat. I always managed to pay my rent, which was great, but I was always the one in the bridal gown. Or doing a lot of shampoo ads.
"Also, I always wanted to act, but Eileen would never send me out on auditions where you had to speak because I was so shy."
Discouraged, she moved briefly back to Cincinnati, and then returned to New York to join her older brother Michael, who had founded an Off Off Broadway theater group. With her brother's help she began to overcome her shyness; a brief live-in relationship with the late Bob Fosse prompted a visit to one of her performances at her brother's theater by Mr. Fosse's agent, Sam Cohn. The casting director of "Airplane" was next; Ms. Hagerty was one of 75 actresses asked to audition.
Recalls Jerry Zucker, one of the triumvirate of producer-directors responsible for that seminal spoof: "She was our first choice. We were jumping up and down. 'The movie works,' we said. 'We've got Julie.' "
Is Julie really conscious of how funny she is?
Albert Brooks ponders the question. "Well, above everything else, Julie is an actress. She goes to work and puts on makeup. Still, she's a genuine comedienne. An inherently funny woman. You don't frown when you see her; your mouth starts to go up."
Ms. Hagerty, says Mr. Brooks, was the only actress he could think of who could retain the audience's sympathy after gambling away, as her character did in "Lost in America," her family's entire nest egg in one frenzied night in Las Vegas.
Says Ms. Hagerty: "I don't know how to explain what I do. All I can tell you is that when you do comedy you have to do it from the heart. You can't realize you're doing anything funny. You have to let the director take you through the moment."
In fact, so innocently vulnerable is her demeanor that it takes a bit of gumption to ask Ms. Hagerty about the more serious areas of her life.
"O.K.," she says in a tiny voice, when asked to speak about them.
Bob Fosse, she says, had a quicksilver mind; he was a genius who taught her a new way of looking at the world. Michael Hagerty, who died of AIDS last April, was a feisty, talented man who always supported and prodded her and whom she misses dreadfully. And yes, she and her husband of four and a half years have recently divorced, "but I don't think I should talk about it," she says apologetically.
What she would like to talk about is her pride in "Noises Off," her regret that Benny's Hot Dogs, one of her favorite neighborhood landmarks, was replaced by a high rise, and the realization that after the trauma of "Princesses," it's time to go back to looking for work.
Does that mean she would even be willing to go back to Hollywood?
"Oh, sure," she says, nervously. "But I wouldn't stay there if I didn't have a job. It would be O.K. if I was working, say, 6 or 7 days a week.
"I mean, L.A. is fine for other people. But this is home."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 828 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Are Cartoon Stills Still a Hot Ticket?

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
During the art boom of the 1980's, Herbert Black, a Montreal industrialist, paid record prices at auction for Impressionist art, Chippendale furniture, a John Lennon guitar and Walt Disney celluloids, known as cels.
In the more sober 1990's, Mr. Black is hanging on to Renoir's "Little Gypsy Girl," which he bought for $1.8 million in 1980, then the record for an Impressionist painting. And his collection of 18th-century English antiques is intact. But the Lennon guitar, for which he paid $19,800 in 1984, is gone, raffled to benefit a charity. And he is selling the part of his holdings -- Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Snow White cels -- that so far has remained recession-proof. 
 Mr. Black's collection of 79 Disney drawings, watercolors and cels will be offered for sale at Sotheby's in New York on June 27. Describing the animated art as "the finest ever to be auctioned," David Redden, a senior vice president at Sotheby's, said the holdings are expected to realize $1.5 million.
Since all of these cels were bought in the last five years, the sale is viewed as a significant test of the animation art market. Although many dealers report that prices have not declined, the auction house has placed lower estimates on most of the cels than Mr. Black paid.
In Mr. Redden's view, the internationalization of Disney theme parks -- Euro Disneyland, on the outskirts of Paris, opens today -- is bound to expand interest in this kind of pop culture, including the earliest cels.
Prices for animation art, auctioned at Sotheby's since 1979, exploded during the late 1980's. In 1989, Sotheby's sold more than 900 cels for a total of $2.5 million -- about 10 times the number and dollar total of what it had done the year before. The most valuable offerings to date have been the 1930's black-and-white cels of Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck and the color images of Snow White.
About half the sale of the Black collection is of vintage Mickey Mouse, including the quirkiest and most endearing pictures of him from 1930's and 40's cartoons and from "Fantasia," the 1940 feature-length animated film. The other half consists of scenes from the films "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" (1937), "Pinocchio" (1940), "Sleeping Beauty" (1959) and "Alice in Wonderland" (1951). An outsized ink sketch of Mickey drawn by Walt Disney in 1935 is a rarity, estimated to bring as much as $40,000.
Mr. Black's buying spree, which he said was fueled by nostalgia, began in 1987 and ended two years later. Among the many exceptional pieces he bought was a black-and-white 1934 cel from "Orphan's Benefit" in which an orphaned mouse punches Donald Duck. Mr. Black paid $286,000 for it at Christie's in New York in 1989, a record at auction for animation art. Now Sotheby's estimates that the cel will bring much less -- between $100,000 and $150,000.
"Mr. Black bought at the peak of the market," explained Amanda Deitsch, a Sotheby's specialist in animation art, "and we have to be conservative in this economy."
As collectibles go, animation art is still affordable, with many cels available at $1,000 or less. Two "Pinocchio" images in Mr. Black's collection are expected to sell for $600 to $800 each. "Snow White" cels may realize more: a fierce-faced hag is estimated to bring about $10,000, and one of Snow White in the forest with squirrels and a fawn is expected to sell for about $5,000.
As in all fields of collecting, the earliest and rarest examples of animation art command premium prices. At Sotheby's, there is a second cel from "Orphan's Benefit," this one depicting a crowd of young mice whooping it up in a theater. It is estimated to bring up to $120,000.
Among the many images of Mickey Mouse to be auctioned is a scene from the 1933 short "Ye Olden Days," showing him wooing Minnie in a castle. It is expected to bring about $120,000. Another from "Fantasia," which depicts Mickey atop a mountain conducting the universe, is estimated to sell for about $50,000.
Russ Cochran of West Plains, Mo., a leading dealer in animation art, said he has not seen a dip in sales. "The interest is still there," he said. "But it becomes harder and harder to come up with important pieces."
While the recession has affected his business, Mr. Black said, it did not spur him to sell the Disney material. "I don't collect for business reasons," he said. "I'm selling because I'm going to be living in a smaller house where there won't be room to hang the animation art."
Mr. Redden said Sotheby's envisions a long-term future for animation art as a collectible and has added a specialty department to handle this material. "I have this 3-year-old at home who is balmy about Disney," he said. "Kids today are going to be more familiar with some of these films than we were because they see them on their VCR's. They'll watch them 20 times at a sitting, not merely once as we did. The imprint is going to be stronger in the future than it is now."

LENGTH: 1656 words

HEADLINE: New Lines Seek Niches In the Air

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL covers the travel industry for The Times.

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH Pan Am, Eastern and Midway were shot out of the friendly skies last year, joining such other casualties of the air wars as People Express and Air Florida, a growing group of entrepreneurs is seeking to start new airlines -- not just to fly from one small city to another, but also to Africa, the Caribbean and the Baltic states.
What the newcomers have in common is access to a large pool of experienced pilots, planes and ground personnel, people who worked for the airlines that could no longer compete with such mega-carriers as American, United and Delta. And most of the newcomers also share a common strategy -- trying to carve out a niche too small or too insignificant to invite competition from the big carriers. 
 The odds against their success are high, according to industry analysts. "The overall prospect for startup operations isn't very good," said Daniel M. Kasper, the director of transportation practice for Harbridge House, a Boston-based international management consulting form. "The major carriers are very, very strong, and they have taken advantage of the economies of scale to make it attractive for regular travelers to stick with them. So if you go up against them, you better stay out of their way and be content with off-beat routes."
That is exactly what most of the newcomers intend. "It's the only way we can expect to survive in this environment," said Jack S. Robinson, the president of one such newcomer, Florida Air, which started daily nonstop flights last month from Fort Lauderdale to Nassau, in the Bahamas. "You sure can't beat American, Delta and United by going head-to-head with them."
But avoiding combat does not preclude thinking big. Two proposed airlines hope to fly direct from the East Coast to Johannesburg, South Africa, an 8,000-mile route currently served only by South African Airways.
USAfrica Airways of Washington plans three round trips a week between New York or Washington and Johannesburg. "When sanctions against air travel to South Africa were lifted by Washington last summer, we were quick to apply," said Arthur C. Lewis, USAfrica's chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Lewis, who had been president of Hawaiian Airlines and Eastern Airlines, said he and his nine other board members represent 300 years of experience in airline operations, finances and marketing. "We also represent more than 60 years of experience in Africa," he said, noting that one board member, Chester A. Crocker, was assistant secretary of state for African Affairs from 1981 to 1989.
If its plan is approved by the Department of Transportation, the airline expects to begin service next fall with three leased Boeing 747's. Round-trip fares will compete with those of South African Airways, ranging from about $1,700, with advance purchase, to more than $7,000 for first class, and to break even the airline will need on average to fill about 48 percent, or 168, of the approximately 350 seats. Mr. Lewis said USAfrica would compete by providing superior on-board service.
Pegasus International, a new company in Fairfield, Conn., also has applied to fly the New York-Johannesburg route -- also three times a week, also starting this fall and also with leased 747's. "The difference is that we're affiliated with the largest black transportation association in South Africa, and our intention is for a portion of our profits to go into a trust for the benefit of black South Africans," said Dave Kriz, an executive at Arthur D. Little who is a co-founder and executive vice president of Pegasus. The South African organization is the National African Federated Transport Organization.
Baltia Air Lines plans to begin flying nonstop soon between New York and St. Petersburg, and New York and Riga, Latvia, with continuing flights to Belarus, Ukraine and Georgia.
But Florida is most on the mind of the new airlines, those already in the air and those on the drawing boards. Not only did the state attract 39.3 million visitors last year, but it also lost air service when Pan Am, Eastern and several commuter airlines went out of business.
"YOU can get from anywhere in this state to Orlando and Miami, but you can't get nonstop to most other places," said Mr. Robinson of Florida Air. "At least 25 cities in the state need air service and we're going to go to all of them."
Florida Air got airborne last month with five round trips a day between Fort Lauderdale and Nassau, using a 19-seat turboprop. Eight more are on order.
"Eastern and Pan Am controlled 80 percent of the seats from Florida to the Bahamas, and our plan is to fill the void from Fort Lauderdale," said Mr. Robinson, who formerly headed Eastern's commuter operation in Florida and the Bahamas. With a $99 round-trip fare, a toll-free reservation number and "a reservations system that any travel agency in the world can access to book our flights," in Mr. Robinson's words, Florida Air has ambitious plans for the future.
So does Floridagulf Airlines of Jacksonville, Fla., which began service last December and now flies to 10 cities in Florida (as part of USAir Express) as well as to Charleston, S.C., Savannah, Ga., Shreveport, La., and New Orleans. In mid-April it will add service between New Orleans and Little Rock, Ark., and next month it will add four daily round trips between St. Petersburg and Orlando.
American Dream Airlines of Island Park, L.I., hopes to begin flying daily nonstops this fall between both Kennedy International Airport and Miami and Fort Lauderdale, and between Newark and both of those cities.
"Ours will be all first class service on narrow-body planes that hold roughly 100 passengers," said Tedd Abramson, its founder, "and we're looking to charge slightly more than the lowest coach fare, which is about $200 round trip."
The New York-Florida corridor is already one of the nation's busiest, but that is why it is attractive to newcomers, said Mr. Abramson, a limousine and bus operator. "If you look at traffic flows you're talking about a market that has 1.9 million passengers a year out of New York to Fort Lauderdale, and roughly 2.5 million to Miami," he said.
Destination Sun Airways plans to fly between its home port of Fort Lauderdale and Islip, L.I., a route currently served by Braniff Airlines, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. "We think there's room for more than one," said Guy Lindley, Destination Sun's president. "At one time the island had four, five lines serving it, but they went out of business because they tried to get out of their niche, or because they put on jumbo jets and tried to go up against American Airlines. They handed us our head."
"Our" refers to Northeastern International Airways, of which Mr. Lindley was a founding investor.From 1980 until it failed in 1986, he said, it served 19 cities and had revenues of $350 million a year.
DESTINATION SUN hopes to begin flying in June, and hopes eventually to add flights to Providence, Newark, Hartford, Baltimore-Washington and several other destinations. Flying leased Boeing 727-200's, capable of carrying up to 170 passengers, and charging $119 one way between New York and Fort Lauderdale, the carrier will need a load factor of almost 80 percent to break even.
"We expect to do that," Mr. Lindley said, "because we'll be offering fares with no restrictions and our passengers won't have to stop at a hub. Besides, I think people are tired of reading that they can fly to London cheaper than they can fly to Atlanta."
Other cities may soon have new or additional air service. Ryan International Airlines, a cargo line with headquarters in Wichita, Kan., recently applied to the Department of Transportation to provide business class scheduled service between Newark and Charlottesville, Va. Its hope is to restore the direct jet service those cities enjoyed before Piedmont was absorbed by USAir.
Reno Air in Reno, Nev., wants to fly to West Coast cities, including Los Angeles. Viking International Airlines, a Minneapolis-based cargo carrier, has asked to start scheduled service between Las Vegas and Laughlin-Bullhead City, Nev. And Key Air, which flies charter passengers from five cities each day to its hub in Savannah, Ga., then on to Mexico, Aruba and the Caribbean, has applied to convert those routes to scheduled service, beginning May 1.
"We don't really intend to compete against the major carriers," said Carlisle Vason, Key's director of sales and marketing. "We fly only five flights a week out of Boston, for example, and American Airlines probably flies many more flights out of Boston in one day than we do in a month. We have no aspirations to be a global carrier. We have a little corner of the market picked out, where we don't bother anybody and, so far, nobody bothers us."
Even Sir Freddie Laker, whose Skytrain operation in the 1970's and 1980's helped pioneer low-cost, no-frills flights between the United States and England, is planning to get back into the act. Next month his Laker Airways (Bahamas) expects to begin charter flights between the Bahamas and three Florida cities (Orlando, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach), as well as between the Bahamas and Cincinnati, Cleveland, Nashville, Raleigh-Durham and Richmond. While the charter flights are a contract operation for the Bahamas Princess Resort and Casino on Grand Bahama Island, and are subject to approval by Washington, a spokeswoman for Sir Freddie said "he is not ruling out" the possibility of providing scheduled service in the future.
Following are the names and telephone numbers of the new carriers that are now, or soon will be, in operation:
Baltia Air Lines, , (800) 966-0330; (718) 244-6916.
Destination Sun Airways, (305) 983-0720. Not yet in operation.
Floridagulf Airlines, (800) 428-4322. In Florida, part of USAir.
Florida Air, (800) 538-2471; (305) 359-8264.
Key Airlines, (800) 786-2386; (912) 966-2972.

LENGTH: 1036 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Free-Market Capitalism, Applied to the Stage

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Whatever else people say about him and they say a lot -- nearly everyone agrees that Wiktor Kubiak has chutzpah.
The producer of "Metro," the first Polish musical to reach Broadway, Mr. Kubiak is a Runyonesque character who could only have prospered in the let's-make-a-deal capitalism of Eastern Europe. From his 18th-floor office in the Marriott Hotel, Mr. Kubiak looks upon a Warsaw dotted with his properties and well-connected friends. He owns a newspaper and runs four theaters, two of the city's best cinemas and a chain of bookstores. He is also earning a reputation as a political kingmaker. A major financial backer of the Liberal Democratic Party, which held power in Poland through most of 1991, he says he helped underwrite President Lech Walesa's 1990 campaign. Lately, he has been forging links to the new coalition Government headed by Prime Minister Jan Olszewski. 
 Mr. Kubiak proudly boasts that his $5 million investment in "Metro" -- which opens Thursday at the Minskoff Theater -- makes him the first businessman from Eastern Europe to sink money into America.
"This is like opening a big factory in the middle of Manhattan," he says. Peering through half-closed eyes, his face framed by an unruly shock of longish hair, Mr. Kubiak speaks in a rapid-fire patter of his dreams for leaving his mark on Broadway and his native land.
"I want to be the Cameron Mackintosh of Poland," Mr. Kubiak said of the producer of "Miss Saigon" and other highly profitable musicals. "Everyone thinks that culture loses money, but I was the first in Poland to realize that culture can make money. There's no business like show business."
"Metro" is his first stage vehicle. Its cast was recruited nearly two years ago from talent shows throughout Poland. The young performers, mostly amateurs, were trained for months by Janusz Jozefowicz, an actor and choreographer who is the show's director. Since opening a year ago in Warsaw, "Metro" has been playing regularly to sold-out houses, and while the original cast learned an English-language version for New York, a second group was prepared to continue performances in Warsaw.
The show is often described as a cross between "A Chorus Line" and "Hair." It tells the story of a group of young people who try out for a musical, are rebuffed and then organize their own production in a subway. When their musical becomes a success, they must decide whether to sell out to commercial interests and transfer it to a theater or stay underground.
Little is drawn from Polish experience; Warsaw doesn't have a subway. The score, by Janusz Stoklosa, echoes standard pop more than traditional Polish melodies. Mr. Kubiak insists that the themes reflect the concerns of newly capitalist Eastern Europe, even if the esthetic does not.
The musical was conceived in characteristically impulsive fashion. Mr. Kubiak was in Poland on business in 1986 and saw a television production showcasing Mr. Jozefowicz's work. Two months later, they met and formed the friendship and partnership that eventually led to "Metro."
The 47-year-old Mr. Kubiak was born near the town of Brest-Litovsk. His Jewish parents survived World War II with false papers that said they were gentiles. As a result, they were sent to a Nazi-run slave labor camp instead of a concentration camp.
Mr. Kubiak, who grew up in Warsaw, says he was exiled from Poland in 1968 after participating in student unrest at Warsaw University. Hundreds of thousands of Jews left that year in the face of a Government-sponsored anti-Semitic campaign. Mr. Kubiak, whose return was banned until the mid-80's, went to Sweden as a refugee and completed his education. Immediately after graduating, he entered business for himself, selling Western machine tools to Poland in the boom 1970's, when the country was flush with borrowed Western money. He also developed sidelines in exporting Polish timber and arranging loans for state-run Polish companies.
Although the timber business was controlled by the state, Mr. Kubiak said he persuaded some officials to mislabel the best wood and sell it him as if it were of low quality. "You had to find out how to cheat the bureaucrats," he recalled. "That was the whole war."
Poland's transition to a market economy has only expanded his opportunities. In one deal, he took advantage of tax holidays Poland offered to foreign joint ventures. Just before the deadline for setting up these ventures expired last year, he registered 100 shell companies, which he is now offering for sale at a handsome profit.
"What can I do?" he said when asked about criticism of the deal. "I am a player. They wrote the law. I did what I did."
Mr. Kubiak is among the first of Poland's new generation of entrepreneurs to understand the powerful nexus between politics and money. From the beginning, he was a strong supporter of the Liberal Party, which preaches free-market principles.
Last year, Mr. Kubiak donated office space in Warsaw's Marriott Hotel to the Liberals. During this period, a leader of the party, Privatization Minister Janusz Lewandowski, named him special negotiator in the sale of a state-run television tube factory. Mr. Kubiak said he netted $250,000 for his role in saving the $35 million deal.
As the Liberals' political star waned, Mr. Kubiak cultivated other alliances. He contributed money to a foundation that paid the salaries and office expenses of the Civic Committee, a political group then headed by Mr. Olszewski. After the fall elections, Mr. Olszweski emerged as Prime Minister.
Mr. Kubiak's business gambits are frequently a topic of conversation among foreign consultants in Warsaw and have been the focus of critical articles in newspapers that oppose the Liberals.
But for all of Mr. Kubiak's prominence in Poland as a business and political figure, it is "Metro" that could put him on the world map. He shows a visitor an article in an American theater magazine that quotes him as saying: "We realized that if we are a hit, we won't just be on Broadway, we'll be Broadway. We'll be changing it. People will come to us for ideas."
Mr. Kubiak says: "You call that chutzpah? Without chutzpah you can't get anywhere."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Apartment Layouts;
Designing Buildings 'From the Inside Out'

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE architect Peter Claman is a quick man with a pencil. Zip zip zip and he has sketched the floor of a residential building with its apartment layouts. Then he firmly widens the space inside the front door by a few feet.
"You take the kitchen and slide it back a little," he says. "You increase the size of the foyer, for a dining table, or a desk, or a hobby area." 
 Mr. Claman is the 64-year-old managing partner of the firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron Architects, which was founded 51 years ago and has been telling Manhattan apartment developers how to get maximum value out of residential space ever since. He joined the firm as a draftsman in 1952.
The widened entrance is a case of the old hand squeezing advantage from necessity -- the necessity of complying with the city's handicapped-access law, Local Law 58. Mr. Claman is not alone among architects in thinking that in the long run the law will make for better interior design.
The word "interior" is the key. While Schuman Lichtenstein has put new emphasis on exterior qualities -- the stuff of architectural distinction, in a public sense -- it is the maximum effective use of interior space that has made its name. It is among the handful of architectural firms that have designed a disproportionate share of the apartments in New York City over the years.
Thousands of New Yorkers live in apartments laid out by Emery Roth, H. I. Feldman (both deceased) and Philip Birnbaum. Among current practitioners Emery Roth & Sons, Costas Kondylis, the Vilkas Group and Gruzen Samton Steinglass are notable as specialists in new residential buildings.
"The most successful job is a handsome building that rents or sells quickly -- and is within the cost restraints established by the developer," says Mr. Claman. "The success of the interior plan in my judgment determines marketability."
In the present market builders are not beating down architects' doors to design apartments. Larger firms have shrunk, and their emphasis has shifted to institutional and public work and alterations on existing buildings and apartments. Private applications to the Department of City Planning for land-use actions were down to 170 in the nine months ended March 31, from 219 in the similar period a year earlier. But the rate of decline seems to have slowed. There were 356 applications in the nine months ended March 31, 1990.
At Schuman Lichtenstein, employment shrank from 62 people in 1988 to 42 last year. Hospital-related jobs constitute more than half the work, compared with a third a few years ago. Office buildings are handled as well. One, a 20-story addition to the corporate headquarters of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, at 730 Third Avenue at 45th Street, is currently in construction.
To hear Mr. Claman tell it, a turnaround in planning for residential work has begun. Employment is up a bit too, to 45.
"There is a degree of interest from developers in investigating their sites for future development," he says. "They are calling to check the zoning, and they are working on adapting buildings to new uses."
Others agree that when the interiors of future buildings are laid out, they will show differences from the buildings of the 80's. Richard Roth Jr. says that the obligation to produce apartments accessible to the disabled will produce more spacious-seeming apartments because of wider halls, corridors and doorways. "The law is working positively for the nonhandicapped," said Mr. Roth.
"Small apartments will get hurt," says Costas Kondylis, because the spaces lost in closets and hallways to assure accessibility by the disabled may make smaller apartments unmarketable.
Mr. Claman says that developers are likely to seek out the family market in rentals to a greater extent than they did in the 80's, when condominiums held competitive sway over rentals. Now the swing is toward limiting studios and small one-bedrooms in the apartment mix. "The market is family-oriented," the architect says.
He sees a family quality in the Schuman Lichtenstein partnership itself, which has weathered housing cycles for five decades. The firm was formed in 1941 by Sidney Schuman and Samuel Lichtenstein, who met as draftsmen working for Bell Telephone. They are 84 now. Mr. Schuman is retired. Mr. Lichtenstein is still active, and apartment layouts are his specialty. Al Efron became a partner in 1970. Two other partners were made eight years ago -- Jerold Clark and Enzo DePol.
A FAIR share of what Mr. Claman calls New York's "old-time developers" have been on the client list -- Jack Holland, Millard Shroder, Melvin Senville and Samuel Landau in the 50's; the Cohen brothers, Irving and Hyman Shapiro and the Perlbinders later on. The more recent roster includes Hyman and Daniel Brodsky, Ian Bruce Eichner, Vincent Albanese, David Solomon, Harry Macklowe, Donald Zucker, Jason Carter, Jeffrey Katz, The Related Companies and DeMatteis Construction. In all, the firm has done 112 residential buildings in New York City, with more than 35,000 apartments.
Recent projects include buildings for the high end of the market -- 30 East 85th Street for Donald Zucker and United Nations Plaza for Vincent Albanese, for example -- and the moderate end as well, including 200 West 60th Street for the Brodskys or 235 West 48th Street for Jason Carter.
One project designed by the firm in the 80's is the never-occupied 31-story building at 108 East 96th Street. It turned out to violate height restrictions of a special zoning district, although it was in conformity with an erroneous zoning map and had been approved by the Buildings Department. Civitas, the community organization, brought a lawsuit against the developer and won. The court found that he should have recognized the error and it ordered the 12 excessive floors removed.
THE developers, Albert and Laurence Ginsberg, have filed plans to do so. The plans by Mr. Claman also call for a 19-story addition on open space abutting the existing building. The shortened structure would be left with 72 apartments instead of 97. The addition would have 40 apartments, for a total of 112 in the project. The total floor area of the development would be cut to 109,000 gross square feet from the present 118,000 square feet. The work is expected to begin once the plans are approved.
To those developers who come forward in the 90's, Mr. Claman has a new theme -- multiple bedrooms and larger amounts of usable space.
"People share apartments now in rentals," he said, "and multiple bedrooms are more successful. His notion is to persuade developers to add an O.H.R. -- Federal Housing Administration jargon for "other habitable room" -- to their standard one-bedroom apartments plans. The space can be used as a dining room or converted to an additional bedroom.
"It wasn't done in the 80's but it's an old F.H.A. thing that will come back," he says.
Another change, he predicts, will be in the mix of apartments at the lower price end of the luxury market, with rents in the range of about $24 to $30 a square foot per year. At $30 a square foot, for example, a prototypical 650-square-foot one-bedroom would rent for $1,625 a month, he says. But, while the square-footage of this apartment is down by 8 to 10 percent from that of a similar apartment 10 years ago, there are more of them at the expense of the studio-sized apartments.
STUDIOS of the 70's typically had sleeping alcoves, and gave the occupant 515 net rentable square feet of space. By the 80's they had shrunk to a mere 425 to 450 square feet, Mr. Claman says, and gave nothing more than one room, a kitchen, bath and closet.
The new plans will lower the number of studios to perhaps 25 percent of a building's apartments instead of almost half, while the number of small one-bedrooms grows, he says.
Still another change will come about, he says, if the city approves: larger kitchens, or rather kitchenettes. A kitchenette is a kitchen with no windows, and it is limited to 59 square feet. But the handicapped-access law requires too much space for wheelchair turnaround to permit efficient kitchenettes of that size. A proposal to increase the permissible size of kitchenettes is under review.
That would please the layout specialists struggling for maximum efficiency in the use of space. Whatever the economic level of the market for which the building is produced, that is the Claman goal.
"You don't ignore exterior design," he says. "But you work from the inside out."

HEADLINE: Trenton Frees Trash Haulers to Alter Fees

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A NEW era will dawn on Tuesday for New Jersey's waste haulers and for the millions of homes and businesses that use their services.
On that day, the state will begin to loosen its grip on an industry that has been subject to some of the nation's strictest, most pervasive regulations. For the first time in 20 years, trash haulers will be free to raise or lower the fees they charge customers, within certain limits, without obtaining state approval. 
 The process, under the Regulatory Reform Act, will be gradual, but some effects could be felt quickly.
The goal, said State Senator Harry A. McEnroe, Democrat of South Orange, "is to benefit consumers by allowing market forces to determine the rates people pay to get rid of their trash." He was a sponsor of the 1991 legislation that deregulates the solid waste collection industry over the next four years.
During the first year, haulers will be allowed to raise or lower prices 5 percent plus any percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index. In addition, the haulers will be entitled to pass along any rise in their costs for dumping solid waste at landfills and incinerators. These costs represent a substantial share of haulers' expenses.
Industry experts and state officials say that while they expect competition to result in rate decreases for some customers, the deregulation may also lead to increases for others. They believe that deregulation may lead more communities to contract for townwide trash pickup through competitive bidding. They also predict that the industry's new freedom to vary its charges according to the weight of trash picked up will lead businesses to increase their recycling efforts.
At the time the current regulations were put in place, said Scott A. Weiner, Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, the industry had almost total control over its rates, lived by its own unwritten rules and established its own informal territories. The regulations were intended to eliminate price-fixing and collusion among haulers, and to stimulate competition. Hauling licenses were issued to individuals and businesses only after vigorous background and credential checks by the State Attorney General's office.
Rates charged to customers had to be approved by the state, based upon a formula that permitted companies a "fair rate of return." But as a result, haulers had no financial incentive to improve their efficiency.
"This is an example of an industry with a regulation that ultimately proved to make no sense," Mr. Weiner said.
George A. Loman, chairman of the New Jersey chapter of the National Solid Waste Management Association, a trade organization based in Somerville, said regulations had inhibited competition and stalled the growth of small companies by prohibiting them from gaining new customers by offering lower rates.
Mr. Loman, who is also an owner of Direse & Sons, a solid waste contractor based in Cresskill, said that a few years ago his company offered discounts to elderly residents in Demarest. "The senior citizens have less garbage, and we wanted to offer something to the town because we had been servicing it for many years," Mr. Loman said. The discount, he said, was $1.50 a month.
"We were told point blank by the regulators that that was a violation of our tariff," he said. "We ended up having to pay a $5,000 fine and having to rescind the discount."
 
Uniform Rates Required
 George Dawson, a spokesman for the State Board of Public Utilities, which regulated trash hauler rates until the Environmental Department took over last year, said: "You had to charge uniform rates. If you offer a discount to one group of people, then another group ends up paying a surcharge to make up the difference."
Authorities say that the regulations have, however, been effective in weeding out unscrupulous operators. "The waste collection industry in the state has cleaned itself up," Senator McEnroe said. The new regulations retain the stringent licensing requirements for entry into the industry.
Beth Sztuk, an official in the Environmental Department, said that a customer's bill contained two basic elements -- the service fee, which is what haulers charge to pick up and transport refuse, and the disposal fee, which is what they must pay at landfills and incinerators to dispose of it.
During the first two years of deregulation, haulers will be able to raise or lower their service fees 5 percent a year plus the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index. In the third year, the allowable increase or decrease will go to 10 percent plus the C.P.I. And in the fourth year, only an increase or decrease reflecting the C.P.I. will be permitted.
The new regulations also allow for a dollar-for-dollar pass-through to consumers of increases in the disposal fees charged to haulers. These costs have soared in recent years. Bruce Rosetto, president of Consolidated Waste Services Inc. of Toms River, said landfill fees in New Jersey had risen 3,000 percent in the last 10 years.
 
Many Landfills Closed
 Many landfills have closed, either because they have no room for further trash or because they have failed to meet the state's environmental standards.
"Ten years ago we dumped trash into a hole in the ground," Mr. Rosetto said. Now, he said, landfills must be specially prepared with double plastic liners and other equipment. To prepare a landfill to meet state standards can cost as much as $800,000 an acre, he said.
As a result, increasing quantities of trash are baled or incinerated before dumping, because they reduce the quantity of material to be buried in landfills.
In addition, Ms. Sztuk said, increases in certain special state taxes charged to trash haulers can also be passed along to consumers.
Over all, she said, the potential increases for customers are "pretty significant." But that should be offset, she said, by greater competition in the industry, an opinion shared by many experts.
 
Three Methods of Collection
 In New Jersey, there are three different ways that solid waste is collected. In many of the larger cities, the municipality itself provides the service for residents, using municipal equipment and employees. The costs are included in the property taxes paid by homeowners.
In other cities, the municipality enters into a contract with a trash hauler after putting the contract out for competitive bidding. The costs of contract services are also included in property owners' real-estate taxes.
Under both old and new regulations, private haulers who get municipal contracts after competitive bidding are not regulated on the theory that the bidding process itself serves to insure fair rates.
The third way that trash is collected is through private contracts with haulers. Nearly all commercial and industrial trash is collected that way, and about 150 municipalities require residents to make their own arrangements for trash pickup.
Though deregulation will have no effect on municipalities that do their own trash collection, increased competition is expected to lead to lower bids for public contracts, and to have an even greater effect on the private contracts with residents and businesses.
 
Same Block, Different Haulers
 In towns where residents make their own arrangements for trash removal, it is not unusual to have more than one contractor picking up trash on the same block.
In Westfield, for example, as many as 22 private contractors collect residential trash. In Piscataway, about seven haulers compete for customers among the town's 48,000 residents.
But it is much more cost effective for a trash hauler to pick up trash at every house on a block than at a few houses on the block. Under the new regulations, a hauler will now be able to approach all residents on the block and offer a lower price, which will reflect his potential savings.
Such economies of scale are already being applied in communities that put the whole town's trash collection up for competitive bidding. In Livingston, for example, two haulers formerly served the town. Both were charging about $300 a year for regular household trash pickup. One hauler, however, was charging $300 extra for yard debris, while the other was charging $35 a year for the same service.
 
Saving Achieved in Contract
 By making one full-service townwide contract available to the contractor that bid the lowest rate, officials say they were able to save 80 percent of the residents about $150 a year. In addition, said Charles Tahaney, business administrator of the affluent Essex County community, the residents can deduct the cost of the service on their Federal income tax returns.
John Horensky, director of solid waste management for Somerset County, expects that deregulation will encourage more municipalities to consider public contracts for trash pickup.
"I think the opportunity is better now to go out to bid and get a better price for your residents," Mr. Horensky said. "If it's done properly, a municipality can offer contract collection at a price that would be less than residents pay today for private service."
 
Factors for Businesses
 For businesses, the effects of deregulation will depend upon several factors. "More competition doesn't necessarily translate directly to cheaper service," said Wayne DeFeo, manager of the mid-Atlantic region for the National Solid Waste Management Association.
Now, he said, haulers will be able to offer better rates to their larger customers. At the same time, the haulers could raise rates for other customers. "Your rates could be higher or lower, depending on who you are," Mr. DeFeo said.
Under current regulations, the service fee paid by many business customers depends on the volume of trash they produce, but the disposal fee that haulers pay for dumping the trash at landfills or incinerators is based upon weight. As a result, Mr. Rosetto of Consolidated Waste Services said, "customers with less trash have essentially subsidized those with heavier volumes."
Under deregulation, haulers will be able to charge according to weight. And that, in turn, Mr. Rosetto said, will encourage greater recycling by business.
State law requires that businesses recycle 25 percent of their waste, but since trash removal rates have been based on volume, they have had no special incentive to lower the weight of their trash by recycling it. When the haulers' rates are geared to weight, Mr. Rosetto said, many businesses are apt to change their ways.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:
PYSANKY DEMONSTRATION
 According to ancient folk lore surrounding pysanky, the term for Easter eggs decorated in elaborate Ukrainian style, a bowlful of the colorful eggs kept in the house at all times protects the family from fire and lightning. In fact, the practice of decorating eggs at Easter time was believed to be essential to the continued existence of the world: without it a monster would appear and destroy the planet.
Ukrainian Easter will be celebrated in two Yonkers libraries, with Maria Kozicky showing about 20 of the eggs she has decorated and explaining how it was done. She will appear at 3:45 P.M. in the Getty Square branch at 7 Main Street and will repeat the program Thursday at 3:45 P.M. in the Grinton I. Will Branch at 1500 Central Park Avenue. 
 "I use powdered food dyes from a Ukrainian shop and real eggs," Ms. Kozicky said. She described the process as similar to batik, in which melted wax is used as masking when each color is applied. The contents of the egg are blown out after the painting is completed, "and the egg will last forever" she said. The eggs must be fresh. An old, hardened yolk could break the shell during the blowing-out process.
Both of her presentations will be accompanied by a videotape made by Canadian Ukrainians explaining the origins of the custom and showing the process step by step. Ms. Kozicky is unable to do a complete demonstration because of a prohibition against lighting a fire in the library. A flame is necessary to melt the wax.
At the Will Branch, a Ukrainian Easter display by the Women's Association for the Defense of the Four Freedoms for Ukraine will open tomorrow and remain through April 30. It will include a collection of pysanky eggs and a typical Easter basket containing the foods eaten on Easter morning. In addition, replicas of Trypillian ceramics dating from the Ukrainian region of 6,000 years ago will be shown. "The Trypillians were our stone-age people," Ms. Kozicky said. The ceramics were done in white, burnt umber and black with geometric designs similar to those of American Indians.
The library is open Mondays through Thursdays from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sundays from noon to 5 P.M. Call 337-1500 for more information.
 
FILM FESTIVAL ENDING
 The Schoolhouse Center for the Arts in Croton Falls and the film department at the State University of New York at Purchase have cooperated in their first joint venture: a film festival of original feature, documentary, animated and experimental works. The final selections can be seen today, beginning at 4 P.M. with "Prelude," a teen-ager's narrative about the divorce of his parents and the arrival of a stepfather.
"Okefenokee" deals with a young homeless man who encounters his older alter ego, and "Frankie" is a documentary detailing the family life of a young black man in the ghetto. A spoof of Italian movies, called "Colpovole d'Amore," is the last of the afternoon films.
A second session gets under way at 7 P.M. with "Daymaker," an animated piece about what makes the world go around. "Weird Girls in Love" follows, focused on young women's first crushes, and "The Big Dump" is a black comedy in which a wife kills her husband with a roast chicken. The last three films are "The Dark Side," a comedy; "Cartographer's Girlfriend," a philosophical view of the male-female relationship, and "Enrico the Magician," a spoof of silent movies.
The Schoolhouse is on Owens Road. Admission is $5, and the phone number for more information is 277-8477.
 
STEVE FORBERT CONCERT
 Steve Forbert was a 21-year-old recording star when "Romeo's Tune" on his "Jackrabbit Slim" album was released in 1979 and reached the Top 20. Two more albums followed, establishing his status, but in 1984 he had a falling-out with his producer at Columbia Records and by 1986 he was a has-been.
The long road back began by hitting the road in a van with a band of his own. Today, his songs and style have matured, and he is polishing a different image for himself. His new album on Geffen Records, called "The American in Me," is a departure from the old rock 'n' roll Forbert, and listeners attending his forthcoming performances will hear a more thoughtful collection of songs.
Mr. Forbert will appear at the Towne Crier Cafe in Pawling on Saturday at 9 P.M. and at the Music Hall in Tarrytown on April 25 at 8 P.M. Admission in Pawling will be $16. (Call 855-1300 for reservations.) Tarrytown tickets will be $18.50. (Call 332-8497.) The Music Hall is downtown on Main Street, and the address in Pawling is 62 Route 22.
 
CONGRESSIONAL REPORT
 "Hate Congress but love my own Congressman" seems to be the consensus of the fractious American electorate these days. Well, Westchester residents will have an opportunity to hear a report from Washington from their four representatives at a luncheon Thursday in the Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown.
Appearing at the Westchester County Association event will be Eliot L. Engel from the 19th District, Nita M. Lowey from the 20th, Hamilton Fish Jr. from the 21st and Benjamin A. Gilman from the 22d District. Among them, they represent the county on the following committees: Foreign Affairs, Judiciary, Education and Labor, Post Office and Civil Service, Small Business, Merchant Marine and Fisheries, and Joint Economic, giving the audience wide latitude for questions.
Taxation and budget issues and their effect on health care, education and housing are expected to dominate the presentation.
Tickets are $40, and the reservations deadline is tomorrow. The program opens with a reception at 11:30 A.M. Lunch is at 12:15 P.M., followed by the Congressional dialogue, which is to end by 2 P.M. Call 948-6444 for reservations or more information.
 
RECYCLING LESSON
 People are not the only creatures who can recycle their waste. Earthworms, sowbugs, millipedes and crayfish are equally resourceful in that regard, and a family program called "Meet the Recycling Animals" will explain all this on Saturday at 2 P.M. at the Greenburgh Nature Center.
In addition to a lecture by staff naturalists, there will be a tour of the current exhibition, "Westchester or Wastechester: Preserving Our Natural Resources," and an excursion into the nature center's fields, woods and ponds to examine first hand the creatures under discussion.
The center is on Dromore Road off Central Avenue, and admission is $3. Call 723-3470 for more information.
 
FIBER ARTIST EXHIBITS
 Eva Harper is a fiber artist who works in a wider variety of textiles than most people in her field. Her work can be seen at the Greenburgh Public Library at 300 Tarrytown Road in Elmsford through April 30.
Some of her things are wearable, others are suitable for framing or for various uses around the house as throws, pillows, hangings or spreads. She taught 18th-century textile arts at Philipsburg Manor for 19 years and conducted classes in various fiber disciplines at the New York Botanical Gardens.
In addition to patchwork, place mats, knitted vests and sweaters, all of which she endows with her own innovative techniques, she works in mola -- a time-consuming method of applique developed by the Cuna Indians of Central America. The fabric is applied in many layers, each one cut separately to create a different outline.
Her crewel embroidery is done in cotton instead of wool, creating a two-dimensional effect by building up the stitches -- many hundreds more of them than would be required by working in wool.
A piece of hers chosen for exhibition in 1988 by the Mid-Atlantic Fiber Conference -- organized yearly at various locations by several weaver's guilds -- was called "My Mother's Garden." It was woven on a loom like a tapestry but consisted entirely of rags. The result resembled a bas relief. "It looked like a garden path framed by plants," she said.
The library is open Mondays from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Tuesdays through Thursdays from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; and Sundays from 12:30 to 5 P.M.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 28; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1033 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Calling Forth the Shock of Recognition

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
FOR the last three or four years it has been one thing after another -- the student revolt in Tiananmen Square, the collapse of the Berlin Wall, the disintegration of the Soviet Union. Mandela came out of jail; Noriega went in. Haiti, having ousted the long-running Duvalier family, elected Aristide only to lose him in a coup.
This list is short but the one represented by news photos and clippings in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson (478-4141) is long -- so long that it covers all the walls and several partitions. It was compiled by Jo Anne Seador, a photographer teaching at the School of Visual Arts and since 1987 the editor in charge of the library at Magnum Photos, both in Manhattan. 
 "Images That Speak of Our Time," as the show is called, may leave a stone unturned but viewers will have a hard time finding it. That is to assume they will have the energy to look, for hundreds of pictures taken at the critical moment make exhausting fare, because there is not only the tension of the moment but also the tension exerted by the photographer in capturing it.
Not that every image is a classic; in fact, few if any can be so categorized. It is, rather, a matter of their immediacy coupled with the shock of recognition they arouse in the viewer.
Take Stephane Compoint's shot of Texas technicians capping an oil well in Kuwait: this is all action, with everyone coated in oil. Yet color confers a Norman Rockwell-style robustness on the proceedings, which leads the observer to conclude that Sebastaio Salgado gets closer to the truth in his black and whites of the same operation now on view at the Yale University Art Gallery.
Photographic color conveys more information but it makes disaster picturesque. Were it in color, Leonard Freed's dead man on a Romanian sidewalk would be half the picture, notwithstanding the presence of the official who put the bullet in the victim's brain -- "in front of the photographer," the caption says needlessly.
The same goes for G. Pinkhassov's view of Felix Dzerzhinsky's statue being toppled by a crane at night. Dzerzhinsky founded the K.G.B. in 1927, and his larger-than-life effigy stood outside the headquarters of the secret police, presumably in Moscow. Statues seem to be the first to go in uprisings, and in this display, Lenin's gets its comeuppance in Russia as well as in Ethiopia. Furnishing Communist countries with the appropriate icons must have been as rewarding a business as keeping the British Empire in Queen Victorias, the majority of which, however, are still in place.
The most moving pictures come from Romania, a country that seems no better off for having disposed of its tyrant, Ceausescu.
Two particularly eloquent prints come from Ellen Binder, who recently won an award for her coverage of alcoholism in Russia. One is of a man in a psychiatric hospital for incurables who stands chained to his bed; the other focuses on a girl in a children's detention center who kneels on a floor that seemingly she has washed and turns her shaved head toward the photographer. Talk about "The Little Match Girl" and other child martyrs in Victorian literature.
It is all very well to rejoice in the demolition of the Berlin Wall -- German graffiti is neater and more legible than American, by the way -- and Guy LeQuenec's shot of fireworks over the Brandenburg Gate is terrific. But clearly, Communism's dissolution raises questions: can the globe physically accommodate millions avid to make up for lost time as consumers? What about the Wild West aspects of a free-market economy taking root in, so to speak, virgin soil, not to mention the volatile situation in East Africa? Whatever happens, there are certain to be photo opportunities galore.
Drawing on the archives of the agencies Magnum, SABA, Sygma and Visions, Ms. Seador and her assistants, Susan Franz and Linda Schneiderman, have succeeded -- perhaps more than they meant to -- in portraying a world convulsed. "Images That Speak of Our Time," not a jolly show, remains through May 10.
Across the Tappan Zee Bridge in Nyack is the Hopper House Art Center with a solo show by Sister Adele Myers -- her first. The founder and director of the now-defunct Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill, Sister Adele is gradually making a name for herself with reliefs in mediums ancient and modern -- fresco and cement. That is, she builds the reliefs in cement laid over lightweight plastic armatures and emphasizes the forms with the flower-fresh colors that are only possible in fresco.
The largest are two steles seven and eight feet tall with surfaces that are slathered smooth, combed into horizontal ridges and garnished with gravel or left the consistency of congealed oatmeal. Both are plain except for a roughly 18-inch-long stripe shading from white to orange.
At the other extreme is the wall filled with tile-size pieces that range from a relief like a Japanese character on a white ground to something resembling a chocolate cake.
The artist concedes that she often feels like a baker, and some of these and the mid-size works look good enough to eat, especially the relief with diagonal ridges interspersed by lobster-pink strips and that work called "On the Wings of the Wind." The title of this may come from the Book of Psalms, but the shapes might as well be giant slices of cucumber -- 15 of them overlapping in a horizontal row and casting shadows on the wall.
The unwitting metaphors for food are a new development in the artist's work but so, too, are the cosmic implications in "As the Sun in the Temple." Here, half a disk painted orange and white nestles in a broad frame of cement, which is ridged like corduroy and is split corner to corner.
Also on view are several handsome abstractions -- flickering shapes, crosshatchings in fine lines -- each drawn in oil pastel over a neutral-colored rectangle and most bordered by lines of dots in metallic colors.
It is a fine display but one that needs a dark setting and dramatic spotlights, neither of which is available in the house that Edward Hopper called home. The show remains on view through April 26, but the gallery is onlyopen on weekends. Call 358-4381.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
What A Show! But How Low Can the Fed Go?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
You want action? You want quick profits? You want embarrassed market analysts? Just step right up and place your bets. Anybody can win. All you need is timing, or luck.
The world's financial markets may not be quite ready to hire carnival touts, but they might as well. Last week's action, with its reversals of fortune, may seem more familiar to denizens of Las Vegas than to readers of treatises on the efficient market theorem. 
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 fell 11 percent in four days, amid talk of recession and worse, then gained most of it back in one glorious session. In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average had its worst day of the year but ended the week up 6.26 points, at 3,255.37.
The turnaround came after the Federal Reserve cut its target for the Federal funds rate to 3.75 percent from 4 percent. That sparked buying in New York, and New York's recovery encouraged Tokyo. If you wonder why letting banks borrow for a quarter-point less is the cure for all ills, then you're not in tune with the dominant belief that has sustained share prices in America for much of the past year.
"People believe that the Fed, with its $331 billion balance sheet, has the power to right the world's wrongs," said a skeptical Jim Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
The prospects for economic recovery might be better if the Fed were not so alone in its battle, but political gridlock and huge budget deficits seem to have ruled out a meaningful fiscal response in Washington, and the Bank of Japan evidently is determined to fight inflation even as prices collapse.
With or without help, however, Alan Greenspan is dedicated to keeping this recovery alive whatever happens overseas. The recent downward drift in the money supply, along with the obvious deflation of stock and land prices in Tokyo, had shaken confidence, so action was needed. Mr. Greenspan's Fed, said Mr. Grant, seems to be "willing to stop at nothing to head off a 30's-style collapse and prevent the failure of some of the more venturesome lenders."
That "stop-at-nothing" line could yet seem important. The Fed cannot push interest rates below zero, but if this is an era of deflation, and Olympia & York's problems would seem to argue that it might be, then even a zero Fed-funds rate could be a high real interest rate, and as such a deterrent to growth.
Unless and until that is proven, the markets may stumble along. Among Wall Street sayings, "Don't fight the Fed" is among the most reliable, and it is clear that the Fed wants prices to be high.
And with short-term interest rates low, Americans seem to be willing to buy stocks regardless of valuations. The theory, it seems, is that an 8 percent return is an entitlement that must be available somewhere.
Perhaps the wisest course is to stop trying to understand markets, and just sit back and enjoy them. Unlike the county fair, this show never ends.
