HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 5-10

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Worry Around the World as Japan's Stock Market Wobbles 

These days, Japanese money managers are up late -- and it's not because of any partying. They are tossing and turning over the slow collapse of the Nikkei index of 225 stocks. It lost more than 11 percent of its value last week, before making most of it back. The Nikkei lost about 50 percent of its value since 1989. Those losses are staggering: hundreds of billions of dollars. And Japanese banks have been pummeled the worst. They lost about 40 percent of the value of their equity capital since the stock slide began. But what's keeping investors up nights outside of the Ginza, is worrying over where Tokyo will get the cash to cover its losses. "Since 1986, Japan exported about $502 billion of portfolio capital," said Carl Weinberg chief economist at High Frequency Economics, in New York. "We could see repatriations of that capital at the rate of $10 billion to $12 billion a month." he said. "Everybody thinks it's inevitable."
 
The Toff Wins a Squeaker
 
Last week, Britain's Conservative Party won a "magnificent victory, a victory many people thought was beyond our grasp," said Prime Minister John Major. It may have been magnificent, especially to Mr. Major, but in truth, the Tories squeaked by with only a 21-seat majority in Britain's 651-member House of Commons. But any win is sweet in politics, and this one may be viewed especially warmly in the White House. Since the days of Ronald Reagan, America's Republicans and Britain's Tories have been soulmates. The Tories also won while Britain is in a recession, and they did it -- in part -- by running against their own budget deficit. The Tories' platform also had a familiar ring: They won't raise taxes.

America's Ascendancy in Chips
 
While American and Japanese negotiators bicker about trade, the market has been working its magic. American chip makers have been winning back market share from Japan, analysts said last week. American companies have just under 40 percent of the world market. Japan has about 50 percent, according to VSLI Logic, a market research firm in San Jose, Calif. But America's share of the market is rising as Japan's falls. And the figures don't include so-called "captive" producers -- behemoths like the International Business Machines Corporation -- that produce chips mainly for their own use. Include captives and each country now has about the same market share, VSLI says. Each sells about $31 billion worth of chips. "It is possible to build a case now that you couldn't make five years ago," said Michael Borrus, of the University of California at Berkeley. "The American semiconductor industry is in a better position than the Japanese."

A Switch on Aircraft Subsidies
 
Two weeks ago, when European and American negotiators announced they had cut a deal on limiting subsidies to their aircraft manufacturers, many feared it was too good to be true. Negotiations have been under way for six years. Last week, their fears were confirmed. Each side is accusing the other of changing its mind. The Europeans wanted to limit indirect subsidies of American products to 4 percent of an airliner's development costs. The Americans now want to make it 5 percent. Indirect subsidies come from the military. Both sides still agree on limiting to 33 percent direct government subsidies of aircraft development, but not on whether those subsidies should be paid back. And some -- like Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, want no deal at all.
 
Olympia & York Out on a Limb
 
Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the big Canadian real estate developer, is saddled with $18.5 billion in debt and lots of vacant office space. Olympia needs cash. Its banks refused to extend a $430 million outstanding loan for another year until the company opens its books. (Olympia said it will do that later this week.) In the meantime, Li Ka-shing, the big Hong Kong property developer, said he is thinking of buying some of Olympia's properties. With personal assets of about $3 billion, Mr. Li has the cash to do it.

Domestic Uses of Foreign Aid
 
When President Bush announced that the world's wealthiest countries would give Russia $24 billion in aid, Japan politely termed Mr. Bush's figures "hypothetical." Tokyo -- counted on as a major donor -- has not announced what it will kick in. It is still negotiating with Russia over the return of the Kurile Islands. Now other parts of the package look murky. Last week, the Administration said the International Monetary Fund would pay $4.5 billion toward the plan. The British put that figure at $6 billion. The Germans said the I.M.F. would pay $5.5 billion. And Moscow isn't helping any either. Yegor T. Gaidar, the architect of the plan from the Russian side, was sacked as Finance Minister by Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin. So why unveil the package now? Elections. "To a certain extent, everyone is addressing their domestic political audience," said a British official.

Explosions in London
 
Four explosions rocked the center of London's financial district last week, killing at least three people and injuring 50. London police suspected Irish terrorists of planting the bombs. The explosions took place a block from the Bank of England.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Reality Intrudes at G.M.
 
It sometimes seemed as if top management at the General Motors corporation lived in the corporate equivalent of Tibet. G.M. lost market share, shut down plants, said it would layoff 73,000 workers and lost $4.5 billion last year. But its leaders remained sublimely detached, perks intact. Last week, G.M.'s board of directors got tough. John G. Smale, former chairman of the Proctor & Gamble Company and a G.M. board member, was made chairman of the executive committee, a job formerly held by Robert C. Stempel, the company's chairman. Mr. Smale's new assignment meant a demotion for Mr. Stempel. Also demoted were Lloyd Reuss -- formerly president, now executive vice president, and Robert T. O'Connell. Mr. O'Connell was demoted to senior vice president from executive vice president. But John F. Smith Jr., head of G.M.'s profitable international division, was promoted to president last week. If the new junta doesn't put G.M. back in the black, Mr. Smith could replace Mr. Stempel as president, analysts say.

American Air Simplifies
 
Airlines operate in near-perfect competition. Since their products are roughly equal, their only edge is price. That kind of market, economists are quick to point out, is one in which most competitors teeter on the verge of extinction. Last week, to make its prices more attractive -- not to mention simpler -- American Airlines announced a new fare structure. Rather than 16 different fares to each destination, beginning tomorrow, American will offer only four, most of them cheaper than current fares. American, which projected 2 percent growth this year, expects the new fares to give it "3 or 4 percent growth in traffic," said Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman. Other airlines will match some of the fares.

Eyeball to Eyeball at Caterpillar
 
For five months, members of the United Automobile Workers union have struck Caterpillar Inc. The company told workers to return to their jobs last Tuesday or risk being replaced by nonunion workers. Only about 300 of its 12,600 workers crossed the line. Later in the week, talks resumed.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Why Slow Growth Is Good
 
At least one advantage comes from wimpish levels of economic growth: prices hold flat. Last month, the Commerce Department's Producer Price Index climbed by only 0.2 percent, which translates into an annual inflation rate at the producer level of about 0.7 percent. Falling food prices pulled the index down and offset a steep rise in energy prices. As long as this recovery remains a 98-pound weakling, price are expected to behave. "We are forecasting good inflation news lasting probably until 1994," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.
 
Though the Commerce Department's Consumer Price Index increased by a surprisingly strong 0.5 percent in March most analysts say well-behaved producer prices will keep consumer prices from rising steeply.

Bringing HDTV Into the Home
 
For those who like to spend time glued to the tube, high-definition television, which will bring movie-quality pictures to couch potatoes, moved a step closer to commercialization last week. The Federal Communications Commission outlined new regulations for introducing HDTV that allow broadcast stations to have an extra channel for 15 years. During that time, broadcasters will use one channel for HDTV and the other for regular TV. After 15 years, the stations will have to give up their second frequency and broadcast HDTV signals only. But broadcasters, sensing a windfall from that second channel, may be reluctant to give it up. "If broadcasters get a second allotment of spectrum, it will be a miracle if it ever comes out of their hands," said Dale Cripps, publisher of HDTV Newsletter, in Alsea, Ore.

Giving Life to the Economy
 
Dr. Frankenstein used electricity to put some life into his monster. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, can only use interest rates to make the economy's muscles twitch. Last week, Mr. Greenspan pulled one of those rates down. The Fed lowered the funds rate to 3.75 percent from 4 percent. Lowering the funds rate, which is what banks charge each other for short-term loans, is likely to drive down other rates as well. Why lower rates now? "The Fed has to be worried about keeping the little recovery we have going," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "It cannot afford to have a "triple dip" or anything like that." Especially in an election year.

More Debt -- and Less
 
Consumers are a paradoxical lot. According to the Federal Reserve Board, consumers used their credit cards more in February -- they put $1.19 billion on plastic. But while they put new charges on the cards, they paid off other debts. Overall consumer installment credit -- including cards -- fell by $199 million in February.

Freeing the Natural Gas Market
 
Consumers can't exactly shop around for natural gas. The pipes go where they go. But last week Federal regulators changed the rules so companies that supply homes with natural gas can shop around for supplies and use the pipelines simply for transportation. That is expected to bring down prices. "This takes away the pipelines' monopoly to merchandise gas to the pipeline customers," said Edward J. Sondey, senior vice president for gas supplies at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Is Japan Ready to Bottom Out?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Fiona Biggs, portfolio manager for the Dreyfus Strategic World Investing Fund, has been bearish on the Japanese stock market, and she looked very smart last week. The Nikkei index of 225 shares fell 10.6 percent through Thursday, to its lowest level since October 1986. The market was down 27.8 percent for the year and 57.4 percent since its all-time high at the end of 1989.
On Friday in Tokyo, however, Ms. Biggs was buying a few stocks as the Nikkei index surged 7.6 percent, regaining some of the ground lost earlier in the week. The rally was partly a response to the steep falls that preceded it. In addition, the rally on Thursday in New York of the Dow Jones industrial average, which followed an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, helped. 
 Ms. Biggs's buying is not a signal of a fundamental change of mind yet. But it is part of her preparation for a turn in the market. For her, the Japanese market has fallen far enough to uncover some good values, like Sony, Panasonic and NEC. But the broader economic conditions have not changed enough for her to want to bet on the market over all.
"I put in some of the names that I liked," she said. "But I kept my limits. I am not going to chase anything. I expect you will see a two- or three-day rally and then some consolidation."
Ms. Biggs is one of several bears who have been sifting through the rubble in Tokyo looking for bargains. She has missed some calls in Japan but has had a solid record in picking international stocks. At the end of 1991, Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund research group, ranked Dreyfus Strategic World as the No. 1 mutual fund in its group for the last three years.
There are others who, while they are not ready to renew long-term investing in Japan, think the market could rebound in the second quarter if the Japanese Government moves to cut interest rates further and takes other actions to support the economy and the stock market. This means that it may not be the time to bet against Japan. But this does not mean the market will not fall again.
"I do not think it changes the story over all," Michael Howell, head of global strategy at Baring Securities in London, said of the rally in Tokyo on Friday. While he expects the market to rally a little in the second quarter, it might then retreat later in the year. "Looking at Japanese monetary policy, I have not seen enough to convince me that we will see a sustained rally," he said. "The Bank of Japan clearly has to pour a little more gasoline on the fire."
Ms. Biggs looks at the Japanese market in two ways. One view is from the bottom, looking at individual stocks. The other is from the top, looking at the economy and interest rates. She said now is the time for investors to begin drawing up a list of stocks that are good values because of the drop in the overall market. "There are some securities that in the next few weeks will look good," she said, especially if the market retreats further.
But her list of good values includes only 10 or 15 stocks now. So she will be cautious. She said that once the list gets to 30 or 40 stocks, an investor would have better evidence that the market was near its bottom. "If you come up with only five or six companies that are good values, the market has further to go down," she said.
Her top-down approach is more negative because she sees problems in the Japanese economy in the future, including the restructuring needed to shift the engine of growth in Japan from capital investment and manufacturing toward consumer spending. This approach makes whole sectors, including automobiles and banks, look unattractive.
Ron Napier of Mitchinson, Napier Bedford & Company in London, consultants specializing in investing in Japan, also argues that the possibility of a quick turnaround in the Japanese economy is less likely than many analysts think.
"Before there is a rally, you have to see the signs of the economic bottom," he said. "But that could be delayed until next year if we are right about the investment cycle and the inventory cycle." He believes that Japanese capital investment, which powered the boom of the 1980's but is now in decline, will not recover fast. And he thinks that the buildup in inventories in Japanese manufacturing will mean a sharper dropoff in economic growth than expected.
Mr. Howell at Baring said he expected the stock market to rally 10 or 15 percent in the second quarter, a move that would bring the Nikkei to 19,000. It closed on Friday at 17,850.66. But he said that investors could quickly be disappointed unless there are signs that the Government and the central bank, the Bank of Japan, are really easing monetary conditions.
For him, current data, particularly money-growth figures, do not indicate the Bank of Japan is "seeking to ease monetary policy significantly," despite the recent cut of three-quarters of a percent in its official discount rate. In the United States, he said, the Federal Reserve has made its intention to fuel a recovery very clear, especially with its cut in rates last week. But not the Bank of Japan. "I am not ready to go back into Japan on a long-term view," he said.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Building a Better Nuclear Nest Egg

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The Yankee Atomic Electric Company in Bolton, Mass., announced recently that it will pull the plug on its controversial Yankee Rowe nuclear power plant. The utility decided it was simply impractical to spend the money required to refurbish the 32-year-old facility, whose continued operation has been opposed by environmental activists for years.
For the combatants in the long battle over Yankee Rowe, as is the case in most arguments about atomic energy across the country, the question of what to do about aging nuclear power plants provokes answers framed by politics, by economics, by scientific and environmental concerns. 
 But for a small set of Wall Street money managers who specialize in overseeing funds known as "nuclear decommissioning trusts," the debate over nuclear power comes down to a purely practical matter: When a power plant's life is over, will there be enough money to pay for a safe and decent funeral?
Unless Congress takes a fresh look at the limits imposed on these trusts, these managers warn, the answer to that practical question may become as cloudy and contentious as the rest of the nuclear power debate.
Public utilities are required by Federal law to set money aside to cover the highly unpredictable costs of shutting down and dismantling their nuclear plants in the future. So far, an estimated $3 billion has accumulated in these decommissioning trusts. At first glance, the trusts seem to be an odd sort of pension fund -- a fund to retire an elderly power plant. But a closer look reveals some remarkable differences.
For one thing, decommissioning trusts are not tax-exempt, as pensions funds are; they are subject to Federal taxation at the standard corporate rate of about 34 percent. Moreover, while corporations may list a pension fund contribution as a business expense for tax purposes, utilities only get to count trust contributions if the trust is a so-called qualified trust -- that is, one that abides by limits set by the Federal tax code.
Under these limits, qualified trusts may invest only in Unites States Treasury securities, municipal bonds and bank demand notes. No common stocks, no preferred stocks, no corporate bonds, no mortgage-backed securities.
Some state utility regulators impose even stricter rules of their own; a few require nuclear trusts to buy only in-state municipal bonds, which may be in scarce supply. The Federal limits do not apply to non-qualified trusts -- but many of the state restrictions do, and contributions to those trusts are treated less favorably by the tax collectors, as well. As a result, non-qualified trusts account for only about 20 percent of the total assets in decommissioning trusts.
Understandably, given the tax bite and the investment limits, most of these decommissioning trusts are invested in municipal bonds -- a portfolio choice that, while certainly conservative, seems unlikely to generate the amounts of money that may be called for in the years ahead, as the nation's nuclear power plants grow older. Over time, common stocks typically outperform both Treasuries and municipals.
For several years, a coalition of utilities, supported by regulators and by consumer and environmental groups, has been pushing in Congress to have the nuclear trust restrictions lifted. Gregory L. Nelson, an associate partner at Reid & Priest, a Washington law firm representing the coalition, said the group is also seeking a reduction in the tax rates that apply to the trusts, from 34 percent to 20 percent.
Those changes were incorporated into the most recent tax bill, which was vetoed earlier this year by President Bush. While there is almost no chance of a new tax bill emerging until after the election, Mr. Nelson said the coalition will continue its effort to get the investment limits and tax rate changed.
"Obviously, the more money that can be earned on decommissioning funds, the more you have available to do the work -- which is a social good," said Mr. Nelson. "And it would also lower the amount the utilities have to collect from their customers." (Or from their shareholders, if regulators prove intractable about rate increases.)
Whatever the procedural roadblocks in Congress, the proposals have the heart-felt support of most professional money-managers in this arcane but increasingly important field. "These restrictions are totally inappropriate for today's investment world," said Rust Muirhead of RCM Capital Management in San Francisco, one of the largest managers of decommissioning trusts. "If you build a plant for $2 billion, and 30 to 40 years from now you have to decommission it, how do you keep up with inflation?"
Some utilities can try to gain on inflation by putting all of their non-qualified trust accounts into equities, said James P. Meehan, a vice president at Delaware Investment Advisors in Philadelphia, another major nuclear trust manager. "But those are only a small percentage of the total. And sometimes state regulators do not permit even that."
Added to the difficulty of outpacing inflation is the problem of hitting an invisible target, said Daniel J. Fuss, executive vice president at Loomis-Sayles & Company in Boston, which handles a number of nuclear trusts. "No one really knows what the ultimate costs will be, and you may have to pay to maintain a site and guard it for a long, long time," said Mr. Fuss. "In fact, the decommissioning trust has many of the same investment management characteristics as the old cemetery trusts -- you have to be prepared to maintain a tract 'in perpetuity.' "
This specialized corner of Wall Street will be watching the Yankee Rowe experience closely for clues to how the future may play out for other plants, said Mr. Fuss. "I think a lot of the guidelines that have guided decommissioning trusts will be re-examined in light of this experience, and will have to change."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Small and Medium Are Beautiful

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Carlene Murphy, co-manager of the Strong Common Stock Fund in Milwaukee, specializes in smaller company stocks. She did exceptionally well swimming against the current in the 1980's and could do even better now that the tide seems to have turned.
The fund returned a sparkling 35.7 percent for the year that ended on March 31, compared with 14.6 percent for growth funds, on average. Before signing on with Strong in March 1991, Ms. Murphy and her co-manager, Richard T. Weiss, ran the SteinRoe Special Fund, which gained 14 percent annually for the previous five years, compared with 9.9 percent for the group. 
 They are top-flight managers who are very comfortable with small- and medium-capitalization stocks, says Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a mutual-fund research group. And they built their track record during a period of lean years for small-cap stocks, leading him to ask, "What can they do when they have a tail wind?"
Despite the recent run-up in small stocks, Ms. Murphy believes the sector will continue to shine. She says the economy will probably grow slowly for several years. The 80's, a decade of easy credit and abundant access to overseas markets, favored bigger stocks. This decade, the pendulum seems to be swinging back to smaller, more sharply focused companies that can grow with niche products even if the overall economy falters. Then too, mid-cap stocks have become the new favorites of institutional investors.
Two-thirds of the $75 million Strong Common Stock Fund is invested in companies with market capitalizations of less than $500 million; the remaining one-third has capitalizations of up to $2 billion. Ms. Murphy and Mr. Weiss also run the $170 million Strong Opportunity Fund, a more conservative fund, which reverses the proportion between small- and mid-cap companies. About one-third of the holdings of the two funds overlap.
Ms. Murphy describes her stock-picking approach as "growth at a price." The stocks resemble growth stocks because they grow at an average yearly rate of 20 percent. But she is like "value" managers in that she tries to buy companies for less than their probable worth. She has been buying shares selling for only 10 or 12 times estimated earnings, not the huge multiples that growth managers sometimes pay. The fund's price-earnings ratio is 13.5, about five points less than the market as a whole.
The Common Stock Fund is divided among seven sectors: energy (10 percent), retail (10), cyclical (18), financial (14), health care (8), technology (18) and consumer, including media and entertainment (22). The largest holding is only 2.5 percent of the fund. The managers like to take a stake of 1 to 2 percent in each company they hold. Cash ranges from 5 to 20 percent of the fund's holdings; right now, about 12 percent is in cash, mainly because the fund is growing so rapidly.
Ms. Murphy, who is 35 years old, studied French as an undergraduate and graduate student at the University of Illinois. Dissatisfied with her job prospects, she became a research assistant at SteinRoe in 1980, where she was assigned to work with Mr. Weiss. At the same time, she completed her M.B.A. at the University of Chicago and then began co-managing the SteinRoe Special Fund in 1986. Mr. Weiss is among the largest individual shareholders in the Strong Common Stock Fund; Ms. Murphy has invested "nearly all the money that isn't invested in my house." Mr. Phillips said this commitment by the managers was uncommon but "a very healthy thing to see."
From a risk standpoint, Ms. Murphy said she and Mr. Weiss "spend more time assessing the downside than the upside." This means buying companies at a discount and selling before price-earnings ratios climb too high. Strong Common Stock owns 70 stocks.
The goal is to find neglected companies, based on the principle that the fewer the analysts following a company, the greater the return. The negative side of this approach is what she calls "estimation risk," the danger of having incomplete information because of narrow coverage. The danger is that the companies remain neglected; to avoid this, Ms. Murphy and Mr. Weiss look for companies with new products, ad campaigns or new management likely to grab Wall Street attention. In her travels, Ms. Murphy often gets royal treatment. "You wouldn't believe how many companies I see that haven't had visitors for years," she said.
While both pick stocks, Mr. Weiss concentrates more on the portfolios' "strategic direction." Many prospects are found in "quiet" areas of the stock market. Right now, one quiet area is oil. Because oil-and-gas prices are low, investors are avoiding the industry.
A second quiet area is small banks and thrift institutions. Many community-based financial institutions have clean portfolios and sell cheaply, Ms. Murphy says, while most investors concentrate on the problems of the big money-center banks.
The largest holding of the Common Stock Fund is Newbridge Networks, a Canadian company that sells high-speed voice and data transmission technology to large users. Next is Telefonos de Mexico. Then comes Wheatley TXT, which makes pumps and valves for the oil-and-gas industry.

HEADLINE: A Capitalist Free-for-All in Czechoslovakia

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
In Czechoslovakia, the most socialized economy in Eastern Europe, more than 2,000 large enterprises are on the block. The occasion is a Government auction meant to spin off everything from pollution-spewing steel works to the 700-year-old brewery that makes a great little lager named Budweiser.
The zealously capitalist Government has set tight deadlines for companies to either find foreign buyers or hand over their shares for a one-shot giveaway to the public. "They're privatizing the privatization process," said Daniel Arbess, from the New York law firm of White & Case, an adviser to the Government. 
 Much rides on the outcome of the experiment. If the whirlwind transition yields a burst of productivity, it could serve as the model for a dozen other centralized economies. If it gets mired in scandal or forces the hasty liquidation of seemingly viable businesses, hopes for a German-style economic miracle could be crushed.
Privatizing small businesses has proved relatively easy. An estimated 13,000 shops, cafes and the like have been restored to their original owners or auctioned off to the highest bidders. But with big enterprises, no one knows where to start -- how to price shares when there is no open-market track record for the enterprises, how to make sure managers don't manipulate the auction and/or its aftermath, how to attract capital to a country that has yet to create a securities market or a competitive banking system.
On the other hand, delay carries its own risks. Efficient companies may founder in the uncharted seas between central planning and free markets. "The driving force is time," said Charles Jelinek-Francis, an adviser to the Czech Republic.
Under the Government's plan, corporate managers, not bureaucrats, are obliged to take the lead on privatization. And by almost everyone's reckoning, the preference is marriage to foreign investors, with their dowries of 1990's management, marketing and technological skills. Volkswagen has embraced Skoda, the local car company. Air France has supplied CSA, the national airline, with fuel-efficient jets and credibility with travel agents. Kmart is trading cash, plus the opportunity to sell Czechoslovak housewares through its American branches, for a chain of local department stores.
Most firms, however, are slated to be given away to Czechoslovak citizens this year and next in a grand scheme that is the brainchild of Vaclav Klaus, the current Finance Minister and leading candidate for Prime Minister in the June elections.
Under his plan, each of the nation's 11 million adults had the right to purchase one voucher book for 1,035 crowns, or $36 at the current exchange rate. Some 8.6 million people elected to do so by the Feb. 29 deadline.
The books, looking rather like oversized checkbooks, contain coupons to be used in bidding on enterprises that the Government estimates have a combined book value of 260 billion crowns. Each voucher book, therefore, should be worth more than 30,000 crowns.
Once shares are distributed through a series of computerized auctions, their owners will be free to sell them to anyone. A second and last wave of voucher-driven privatization is planned by the end of 1992.
One potential pitfall is the lack of rules for disclosure or insider dealing. Another is the unexpectedly large role being played by newly created Czechoslovak mutual funds.
When vouchers were first offered, privatization officials guessed that only one-fifth of those eligible would participate. They did not reckon with the marketing savvy of the young, American-educated Viktor Kozeny. Mr. Kozeny's Harvard Capital and Consulting Corporation (no relation to the university) guaranteed a 10,000-crown return after just one year to anyone consigning a 1,035-crown voucher to the corporation's mutual funds. Soon, competing funds offered even juicier guarantees. But supersalesman Kozeny expects to end up with the largest single block, 20 percent of all vouchers bought.
The Czechoslovak Parliament's answer to this concentration of power was to limit a mutual fund's ownership to just 40 percent of any single enterprise, at least for now. But "the law is like a cheese," Mr. Kozeny scoffs, "full of holes."
Ivan Svitek, an adviser to Finance Minister Klaus (and no fan of Mr. Kozeny), admits that concentrated ownership of single firms is not necessarily a problem. Indeed, he believes that effective restructuring of individual enterprises will require control by motivated owners.
What may prove a problem is paying off fund shareholders in Czechoslovak crowns. The assets are there, if the enterprises are worth anything close to the 30,000-per-voucher book value. But cash?
Jan Vanous, a Czech-American who runs the PlanEcon consulting firm in Washington, argues that if investors demand their money, and the funds are forced to unload shares or assets, there could be a stock market meltdown in which foreigners could gain control of Czechoslovak businesses for just pfennigs on the mark.
Equally problematically, state-owned banks might intervene, lending money to individual funds against vouchers of unknowable value -- a process Mr. Vanous likens to Washington's bailout of savings and loans and which Mr. Arbess labels "reverse privatization." Or foreign banks might extend credit to the mutual funds, effectively allowing consumption-starved Czechoslovaks to trade their pieces of industry for Walkmans and package tours to Paris.
The central bank certainly has the power to stop a private-bank bailout, a fire sale to foreigners or a voucher-profit consumption binge. But Mr. Kozeny doubts that any Government agency is ready to take the blame for effectively nullifying the funds' guarantees of riches to millions of voters. Mr. Kozeny's own fix of choice: a stiff capital gains tax on voucher profits, to be waived if the money is reinvested rather than spent.
Many Czechoslovak analysts say that the troubling liquidity scenarios are a distraction from the even scarier scenario that motivated the Government to make its headlong dash to privatization: continued state ownership. If large-enterprise privatization is not well along by the time of the June elections, they warn, the transition could be postponed for years. And as Vaclav Klaus is fond of repeating, "When you drive through the mud, you do not slow down."
 
 
 
FROM HARVARD, THE ULTIMATE SALESMAN
 From button-down broadcloth to brisk and confident manner, 28-year-old Viktor Kozeny seems the very model of a young investment banker on the make. But even in the heady 1980's, few dreamed dreams as big as his and fewer still built great financial empires, even on paper, in a matter of months.
The head of Harvard Capital and Consulting, whose family emigrated to the United States when he was a teen-ager, is a graduate of Harvard College and has only a brief stint at the London investment firm of James Fleming to show on his resume. But unlike the Finance Ministry, Mr. Kozeny did understand one of the basics of investment banking. "It's necessary to pre-sell an initial public offering," he said, in a rare excursion into understatement.
In this case, pre-selling meant guaranteeing a 10-for-1 return for investors in his new mutual funds. It meant saturating television with advertising and recruiting some 22,000 salespeople, who in the great traditions of Amway and Tupperware passed on the good news to anyone who would listen.
Even in Czechoslovakia, such an effort does not come cheap. Some of the millions of dollars already spent, Mr. Kozeny suggested, came from his consulting business and some from his family. What if there is a rush of share redemptions? "We have offers from New York banks" to cover such an eventuality, he said.
Mr. Kozeny may well have saved the Government from the embarrassment of throwing a privatization party to which hardly anyone came. But that has not made him popular with privatization officials, who never imagined how potent his pitch would be. To them, the mogul-in-waiting hastens to offer reassurances. "We don't want to run the country," he says. "We want to make money." In the next breath, he is not so reassuring: "We want to stay out of politics as much as possible, but we will defend our interests."

HEADLINE: Stimulating Students Toward Science

 BODY:
As a science educator I would like to respond to Steven Weinberg's interview in Connecticut Q & A (March 15).
I absolutely agree with Mr. Weinberg that there is a shortage of scientists and a tremendous need to stimulate and attract qualified students to careers in science by offering them exciting and challenging opportunities to develop critical thinking, problem-solving and decision-making skills through the scientific process. However, Mr. Weinberg would have you believe that animals are the best "vehicle for teaching the processes of science." 
 The scientific process is used in all sciences, not just the biological. Concepts and principles of physical, chemical, ecological, environmental and earth science are being taught to students through hands-on experiences that develop observational skills, formulate hypotheses, test those hypotheses, analyze results and draw conclusions.
In a biology course students use the scientific method in investigations on the molecular, cellular and multicellular level. Students perform biochemical analyses in investigations and many physiological studies on themselves. Is Mr. Weinberg suggesting that elementary students learn the scientific process by performing experiments on animals in their classrooms, when there are so many other hands-on experiences that could challenge and excite them?
Even to suggest that elementary-level students should experiment on animals is inappropriate and could prove to be traumatic at their delicate stage of development. Why the push for animal research in elementary classrooms? It appears to me from the article that it may be more of a question of economics than human and animal welfare, since he makes reference to companies in Connecticut that might relocate because there are not enough knowlegeable workers to staff them. Maybe these companies should re-evaluate biomedical research methods that might be of a concern to prospective employees.
A good way to learn about an organism is to have hands-on experiences, and young children in an elementary classroom might learn from observing, nurturing and caring for a classroom pet. However, there is a difference between a classroom pet and a research animal.
Every organism on this planet has achieved its present development and has functioned in its environment through millions of years of evolutionary change. Each organism has a unique role to play in the delicate balance of nature, and the human impact on that balance has already seriously threatened and endangered hundreds of species.
To remove any animal from its natural surroundings and cage it in a classroom, so children can make observations, is not providing the student with the opportunity to learn about the real world and life of that organism. Its existence involves its search for food and shelter and its struggle for survival against its predators. If you cage it, you have denied that organism the right to its evolutionary journey. The child will learn much more about the organism by observing it in its natural surroundings and seeing how it interacts with its physical environment and with other living organisms.
Furthermore, there are two statements that I believe are hypocritical and contradictory to Mr. Weinberg's beliefs. In speaking for the Educators for Responsible Science, he says that "we feel strongly about developing a sense of wise and humane stewardship of all forms of life." Promoting the use of animal research in elementary school classrooms, to remove animals from their natural environment, is a contradiction to that statement. If they truly believed this, then all animals studies would be performed as fieldwork.
Another disturbing statement is that "the animals used in research are not their cuddly little pets," since Mr. Weinberg might argue that animals are bred for research studies. However, many companion animals are used in research, and they once were someone's cuddly pet, because many of these animals were acquired from pounds, and oftentimes from precarious dealers for profit.
In today's environmentally conscious and concerned society, I believe we have a responsibility to instill in our students a respect for all living things. That respect will develop through an appreciation of the importance of that organism in its own right. Students need to study how organisms behave and function in their own environment, how they protect themselves and how they relate to other organisms. Mr. Weinberg gives the impression that animals are simply a tool for human use, and that concept is not conducive to teaching young children a reverence and respect for all forms of life.
 
PAULA P. MEACHEN
The writer is a member of the Ethical Science Education Coalition Advisory Board and a science teacher at New Canaan High School.

HEADLINE: Treating Alcoholics In Russia

 BODY:
The article "Russians Learn About Helping Alcoholics" (March 8) was informative and inspiring in many ways, but it presented some inaccurate facts about what is actually progressing in the former Soviet Union with regard to alcoholism treatment and recovery. Your readers deserve to know the history and the facts about what is currently transpiring in the Commonwealth of Independent States.
In the 1970's the Soviet government acknowledged for the first time the devastating effect that the disease of alcoholism was having on its citizenry. The country reported four million registered alcoholics, most of whom were being treated with such primitive methods as punishment in labor camps, starvation or antiquated medical care. 
 More recently the number of alcohol abusers was re-estimated at more than 30 million, a virtual epidemic. In response to the concern expressed by both the United States and Russia about this problem, a delegation of American medical, psychiatric, education and administrative personnel from leading alcoholism-treatment centers traveled to Russia in 1989 to examine first hand this growing menace.
A second conference in Stamford, later the same year, fundamentally changed the way Russians viewed this disease. After visiting several American rehabilitation centers and seeing the latest in effective treatment, the Russians concluded that there is a better way, and that the time had come to learn more about it.
In 1990 the International Institute for Alcoholism Education and Training, a nonprofit organization, was founded to help address these problems. Working with a group of Russian colleagues, the institute opened the first westernized treatment center, the American-Russian Rehabilitation Center, in Moscow, in November 1990.
The American-Russian Rehabilitation Center is a 42-bed inpatient treatment center based on the Minnesota model and approved by both the current governments. The current director is an American, and the Russian staff has had extensive training both in the United States and in Russia.
The center offers inpatient and outpatient services that include group and individual counseling, a program designated for the family, educational lectures, after care, translated literature and recovery videos that have been dubbed in Russian.
In October 1991 the center celebrated its first anniversary. Hundreds of sober former patients traveled from miles away to participate in and talk about how their lives had been transformed. Many were far too familiar with the Russian alternatives and were now sober for the first time. The gratitude was overwhelming. Their successes gave the current patients a lot of hope.
This is just a beginning. There is still much work to be done. The International Institute for Alcoholism Education and Training applauds the efforts of other organizations, like Geunster House. At a time when there is so much economic, political and social turmoil in the Commonwealth of Independent States, it is comforting to know that treatment and recovery from the disease of alcoholism is increasing and spreading.
 
ALLISON HANLEY
Greenwich
 
The writer is assistant director of the International Institute for Alcoholism Education and Training.

HEADLINE: Camera

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
"Change, change, change," is coming at the Image Bank, a New York picture agency acquired by the Eastman Kodak Company last fall. Those are the words of Pete Turner, a longtime photographer for the agency, which specializes in stock pictures used in commercial photography.
First, the Image Bank will move its corporate headquarters to Dallas in July, said Rex Jobe, the agency's new president. The office in New York will continue to be part of the agency's network. 
 The company is also determined to expand its global enterprise. Mr. Jobe has recently traveled to the agency's franchise offices in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Seoul, South Korea. "I will have flown 100,000 miles this year," he said. "Our business has to be worldwide."
Through franchising its offices, selling stock still pictures for advertising and publishing, and selling motion-picture stock film, the company grossed more than $60 million last year, and half of that came from its overseas operations. The Image Bank has 11 franchises in the United States, 1 in Canada and 65 in Europe. Rick Fleury, a company spokesman, estimated that in all, these offices have some 20 million photographs on hand and serve 30,000 clients.
Stock-picture sales do very well in bad economic times because using stock photos is cheaper than hiring a photographer. A stock photograph is a generic one kept on file, rather than a photograph made for, say, a specific advertisement.
Mr. Jobe has shut down unprofitable operations like the book-publishing division, which delivered books using Image Bank photographs, and has moved to improve communications between franchises and photographers. He has also made other efforts to stabilize the company financially. Like the move to Dallas.
The move will lead to "lower costs," Mr. Jobe said, "and we have easier access to both coasts." "Facilities in Dallas are state of the art," he continued. "Office buildings in the suburbs are excellent, and there's easy access to airports. We're internationally oriented, and people from all over this country and the world will be coming in to see us." Dallas also happens to be Mr. Jobe's hometown.
"We are remaking this company," Mr. Jobe said. "We are carefully monitoring changes of photography's directions. Our investments are being made for the next level of growth in this business."
And that means gathering new data on what types of pictures sell and researching new methods of transmitting images. Electronics and systems for holding photographs on compact disks will be forces in expanding the size of the stock-photo marketplace, company officials say.
The Image Bank's motion-picture division is also being reorganized. "The cinematography program is where still stock was 15 years ago," Mr. Jobe said. The company's film library has the work of more than 125 film makers, whose images are sold for television advertising and for use in motion pictures.
Mr. Jobe, 41 years old, started his first business in Dallas, the Color Place processing lab, which also has since added a computer graphics division, and he later added a second photo lab, Total Color in Dallas. He still owns both. Last year, Mr. Jobe, who also owned a four-state Image Bank franchise in the West, sold Eastman Kodak on the idea of acquiring the company. Kodak was interested, provided Mr. Jobe would assume the presidency. (To avoid conflicts of interest, he subsequently sold his Image Bank franchise.)
At first, staff photographers questioned the agency's new directions. But now, "all the fires are out," Mr. Jobe said. "I can put my attention elsewhere."
Mr. Turner, the photographer, admitted that he had some initial fears about the change. Now, he is a member of a group of staff photographers that meets monthly to discuss problems and new ideas.
In five to 10 years, computerized technology and satellites are likely to revolutionize how photos will be transmitted and used, Mr. Jobe said. "Change happens," he said. "If you're not changing, you're not dynamic."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A New Sporty Coupe From Mazda

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
WHEN I think of the car that I have most wanted in my life, it is a model that was neither particularly exotic nor very rare. But it is still there in my fantasy, a new 1960 Cadillac coupe standing on the showroom floor at Mayo Motors in Trexlertown, Pa., glittering in its coat of dark turquoise paint.
At the time, and for me, the price was outrageous and the moment passed. What is very much with us in 1992, though, is a resurrection of the long-gone Cadillac's color. Along with a lot of other bright shades, blue-green is In with a capital I. 
 There is a turquoise car in the driveway right now, in fact. It is one of Mazda's latest offerings, an MX-3 sports coupe that is part of an intensive overhaul of the company's product line. And, when the roll-out is done, Mazda will have five new and completely redesigned models in the American market.
The MX-3 is a front-wheel-drive hatchback that is reasonably quick, that can carry four passengers in a pinch and that delivers as much as 35 miles per gallon.
According to the company, the new coupe "promises to give younger buyers a new way to express their individuality while staying within their budgets." Those budgets, of course, will have to be in the mid-teens, since base prices range from $11,000 to $13,800.
The variation has to do with the two models offered, a base MX-3 and the fancier MX-3 GS. The basic car also carries a four-cylinder engine, while the GS is powered by the only V6 in the small-sport segment.
The tester was a GS with the 1.8-liter six, which also is the smallest mass-produced V6 sold in America. Mazda engineers say the primary reason for development of the little six was its smoothness, particularly when compared to a four-cylinder engine of the same size.
Like the engine, the body was also made as smooth as possible, with design aided by a supercomputer. Slick contours and a low front end, plus short overhangs front and rear, give the car a solid, sporty feel and good aerodynamics, helped on the GS by a spoiler across the hatch.
From the front, there is a look that is almost animal, with cat's-eye headlights and a wide stance. Bright trim is absent, even around the grille, which is simply a slot across the nose. Bumpers blend into the body and are the same color, and the car has the alloy wheels that are de rigueur in this sort of vehicle.
Visibility is good, thanks to large glass areas, the biggest of which is the rear hatch. Unfortunately, the hatch is heavy as well, and even though it rises on gas struts, loading is a chore. The
liftover is part of that problem, since it is almost waist-high, meaning that cargo has to be lifted and then put down into a sort of well.
The back seat does fold flat, and the cargo cover that is hinged to the hatch can be removed. That improves carrying capacity, but the car is still less than practical as a hauler.
Inside, there are problems, too. First off, the car is low, somewhat cramped and hard to get into. The front buckets also are stiff, with very short cushions, and leg room is at a premium. Those things are factors of turning a small coupe into a four-seater, and they make a trip of any length something to think twice about. But rear passengers are even more unfortunate. The seatback is less a cushion than it is a padded wall between the interior and the hatch.
The other big complaint in the MX-3 is that it lacks an air bag and thus has motorized seat belts, with all the attendant annoyance and danger.
As an economical driver's car, though, the
MX-3 may be worth considering, either with the standard five-speed transmission or the optional automatic.
With 15-inch tires, anti-roll bars front and rear and fully independent suspension, it handles well. And, while the 1.6-liter four produces only 88 horsepower, the V6 puts out 130 horses, more than sufficient in a coupe that weighs only 2,500 pounds.
The black interior also was nicely put together, with color accents in the seating areas and soft gray cloth on the overhead. The tester's three-spoke wheel had cruise-control buttons on the right side of its hub, and the dash was neatly arranged around an optimistic 150-m.p.h. speedometer.
The GS also had full power equipment, including central locking and a power sunroof, and those are things to value in a small car. Most of all, of course, I liked the turquoise paint.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mazda's new MX-3 coupe has smooth lines, a wide stance, bright colors and a choice of four-cylinder or V6 power. The MX-3 hatchback can be had as an $11,000 basic model or as a fancier GS. Power equipment includes a sunroof. (Mazda Motor of America)

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The British Message

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Any Democrat who thinks it will be easy to beat George Bush because this country is in a recession should look at the British election results. Economic misery is worse in Britain and has been going on far longer. Yet the Conservatives, in power for 13 years, won again.
Why? Of course there are many reasons for the Tory victory. But first among them, I am convinced, is that millions of Britons are now middle-class property-owners, more interested in raising their own living standards than in alleviating public squalor. 
 During the campaign, The Independent newspaper published a series of articles by well-known persons on how they would vote. Sir Claus Moser, the Warden of Wadham College, Oxford, said he was for Labor because of its "caring attitudes" on health, education and poverty. He continued:
"I'm looking for a government which cares crucially about our public services. Our general infrastructure is appalling and compares poorly with Europe, as everybody who travels knows. I look to Labor to give top priority to these, even if this does mean somewhat higher taxes. . . . I put all that higher than personal wealth."
Sir Claus was right about run-down public services in Britain: dirty streets, delayed subways, a struggling National Health Service. But he was evidently in a minority in being willing to pay for improvements.
As the campaign began, Labor's chief economic spokesman, John Smith, published detailed economic plans. A Labor Government, he said, would increase spending on the Health Service and other public needs, and pay for it by raising taxes on "the rich."
But the tax increases he outlined covered many who did not consider themselves "the rich." There would be increases on anyone earning over the equivalent of about $37,000 a year. The maximum income tax rate, on incomes over about $70,000 a year, would rise from 40 percent to 50 percent.
The Conservatives spent much of their campaign denouncing those tax plans. And the strategy worked. In exit polls many voters said they were troubled by Labor's tax proposals.
Mr. Smith, in short, paid for his honesty. He and others in the Labor Party may have learned what George McGovern did when he made his proposal in 1972 to tax away all inheritances over $500,000. Only a small percentage of Americans would have that much to leave. People who are not rich may nevertheless hope to do better -- and not want the Government to take it.
Another reason for Labor's disappointing showing was undoubtedly the historical baggage the party carries. Neil Kinnock, its leader, has done a remarkable job in pruning its extreme left. But voters still remember the Marxist rhetoric, and the excesses of union power. Perhaps it will just take time, and a new party leader, to give Labor the modern look of a European social democratic party.
History has also helped the Conservative Party by dividing its opposition. Before this century, it was Conservatives vs. Liberals. Then the Labor Party became the dominant force on the left. But the Liberals and successor parties, now the Liberal Democrats, continue to compete.
Because of Britain's voting system, with the winner in each of 651 districts going to Parliament, a third party gets few seats. Most of its votes, scattered around the country, are wasted. This is how the parties did last week in percentage of the popular vote and in the number of seats won.

	VOTE %	SEATS	CONS.	42	336	LABOR	34	271	LIB-DEM	18	20	The Liberal Democrats want to change the voting system to proportional representation, which will have given them about 117 seats. There will be increased pressure within Labor to support that profound change. For without some compact with the Liberal Democrats, Labor may have little chance to win.
The election, finally, was a personal triumph for Prime Minister John Major. He took over a tired and embittered party from Margaret Thatcher. Perhaps now, free of her ghost, he will be able to produce a Government more competent in economics and less negative in its most important policy: toward the European Community.

HEADLINE: Cleanup Project Can Be Inspiration

 BODY:
Mike Booth's splendid cleanup project in Long Branch by the unemployed, described in "How One Idea Solved Two Problems, Lifting a City's Spirits" (March 22), should inspire other communities to start similar ventures.
Mr. Booth's concern about Federal or state regulations concerning such projects prompts a question: how did our nation become the idol of the world years ago without all such regulations imposed by Big Brother meddling? 
 No wonder voters across the nation are staging a "bloodless voting-booth rebellion," to retire bungling bureaucrats to their home turfs. A big deregulation campaign is needed.
For over 30 years, I've been picking up litter daily. It helps keep my back in shape. Years ago, during winters, I wouldn't exercise. Then in spring, suddenly I'd do too much yard and garden work and end up in bed with back trouble. Not so now, exercising the back regularly.
By picking up litter, one is rewarded by seeing the area look better. It also keeps the litter from being washed by rains into storm sewers, thus ending up in our streams and the ocean.
My slogan has been "God made the earth beautiful, and it's everybody's job to keep it beautiful."
 
HAROLD LINDEMANN
Eatontown

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Election-Year Gridlock Fouls Washington Mood

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So far this year, Congress and President Bush have made one important law, enacting a second extension of unemployment benefits. The rest of the time they have been exchanging partisan insults and political declarations, sometimes in the form of bills and veto messages.
The House of Representatives, rarely a place for bipartisan legislative cooperation in the best of times, has been preoccupied for weeks with its dubious checks and uncertain re-election prospects. The Senate has been much more civil, but distracted by a sense that in times of staggering deficits there is little a legislative body can do about the nation's deepest problems. 
 And the White House has no shortage of political strategies, many of them involving middle-bore legislative proposals, but no legislative follow-through to speak of. For example, Mr. Bush has not held a single meeting with Democratic Congressional leaders on domestic issues, or any one domestic issue, this year.
There may be no plausible middle ground to find on some fundamental political issues. Mr. Bush supports term limits for lawmakers and they don't. Democrats want campaign spending limits and he rejects them. Democrats want to raise taxes on higher incomes to pay for cuts for the middle class, and he doesn't. An election year invites a sharpening of those differences, sometimes to extreme degrees. But that's what elections are for, to settle irreconcilable policy differences.
But on other questions, no one knows whether compromise can be found because there is no consultation. Health care is the issue lawmakers hear the most complaints about from their constituents. And it is exactly the sort of major issue where even a generally partisan Democratic leader like Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine acknowledges that "active, aggressive support" from the President is needed.
But Mr. Bush's modest health proposal, largely a knockoff of Senator Lloyd Bentsen's curbs on health insurance abuses, still has not been sent to Capitol Hill in bill form, though it was announced with much hoopla two months ago. And when they left town Friday for their Easter recess, Democrats were still treading water on the issue, with no consensus on a broader solutions, no roadmap for reaching one and an election-year concern that if they pass a slim bill that the President will sign, he will get political credit they would prefer to deny him.
A smaller example came this week when Lynn Martin, the Secretary of Labor, proclaimed her desire to work with Congress on more unemployment legislation and called for swift action, but refused to appear before the subcommittee writing the bill the House will consider the first week of May. But if some of the blame for the capital's newest cliche, "legislative gridlock," must be shared between Congress and the Bush Administration, there is quite a bit left over for Congress, especially the House, to claim for its own.
The atmosphere in the House these days is poisonous. Thursday's debates on campaign spending and House reform offered insults like "coverup" and "McCarthyism" far more often than they presented reasoned argument about how to fix the way lawmakers are elected or the way they do business.
Indeed, the most thoughtful statement of the day on politics and the House was issued, but not on the floor, by the 47th member of the House to announce this year that he would not seek re-election. Representative Vin Weber, a 39-year-old, six-term Minnesota Republican who is one of the House's most respected conservatives, but wrote quite a few overdrafts on the House bank, said he would not run again. He said he could raise $2 million, had his family and the party behind him, but had looked at himself and concluded:
"I'm simply not ready to put myself and my family through what is sure to be a vicious and highly personal campaign. Make no mistake. I know how to dish it out as well as anyone, but I don't want to. I don't want to face an entire campaign that focuses on nothing more than personal attacks, with no attention to the critical issues."
That's a fair description of the House itself these days. Each party sees its own frustrations and the other's hyperbole, but rarely stops and thinks about its own exaggerations or the other side's problems.
These days the Republicans are dishing it out, obstructing and being obnoxious, petty and personal on procedural and administrative matters. They are responding as best they can to being ground down by the Rules Committee Democrats who routinely rig procedures so Republicans hardly ever win a vote.
Mr. Bush often joins in, calling as he did Friday for "reform that is necessary because of the laxity of one-party control of the House of Representatives for 48 out of the last 52 years."
But that dominance is not the result of the sloppy supervision of the House bank or rules allowing proxy voting. It is not even the result of, though it is surely helped by, such perks as excessive franked mail. As Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, taunted Republicans Thursday night, Democrats control the House because they win more elections. That is the root of the Republicans' bad temper.
In the Senate, the frustrations are less partisan. When Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, last week became the seventh Senator to announce retirement, his complaints about how tough it now is to legislate echoed, if inexactly, complaints from retiring Republicans.
The Senate, which has passed far more serious legislation than has the House so far this session, spent the week debating budget priorities. Several Senators sought to limit on how fast spending on entitlements would be allowed to grow. Liberal Democrats like Senators Mitchell and Edward M. Kennedy challenged this approach, arguing that the honest way to curb growing entitlements was to enact health care legislation that would control the explosion in medical costs behind soaring Medicare and Medicaid spending.
But in the end the issue was not settled over that fundamental argument. Instead, proponents abandoned it after the Senate voted to exempt the benefits for disabled veterans. It is, after all, an election year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Tim Wirth announcing last week in Denver that he will not seek re-election because working in Congress is too frustrating. Six other Senators and 47 members of the House have also said they would not seek re-election this year. (ssociated Press)

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
In Connecticut, It's a Whole New April 15

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Everywhere else, tax season may be routine, but not here. At Connecticut's Department of Revenue Services, the first-ever filing season for the state's first-ever tax on wages is an exercise in controlled panic.
Since the 4.5 percent flat-rate wage tax was passed by a razor-thin margin in the Legislature last August, the tax department has careered from one crisis-etched deadline to another -- with pressures made all the worse by the atmosphere of hostility among many residents and deep ambivalence in the Legislature. 
 Because of a state hiring freeze, the agency has been able to fill only 45 of the 277 new positions it requested last year to handle the more than tripled volume of paperwork. State officials have warned that any resident filing between this weekend and the April 15 deadline could easily wait eight weeks for a refund.
With the future of the whole tax code still in question -- and some politicians still pledging repeal of the law in 1993 -- tax agency officials also fear that some residents may not be viewing the law as a permanent feature of the Connecticut landscape. As of late last week, less than half of the expected number of returns had come in.
And they're not even sure how many should come in. Having never processed a broad-based income tax before, agency officials lack the great psychological crutch of bureaucracies everywhere: a data base. Connecticut's tax collectors do not know how many people worked in the state in 1991 but lived elsewhere, or how much the final refund payout is expected to be. With nothing to guide them, officials don't know whether the flow of returns is behind schedule or not.
"It's the ultimate ratification of Murphy's law -- anything that you could imagine happening has happened," said A.J. Janschewitz, a spokesman for the tax department. "We're flying with no instruments."
Lawmakers and tax professionals generally praise the agency for its work in writing regulations and instruction books and printing forms over the eight months since the law was passed.
The tax code was enacted in the midst of a deep financial crisis on Aug. 22, after the state had operated for six weeks without a budget. Starting from scratch, the revenue agency had just nine days before the bill -- a last-minute compromise that few tax experts had even read -- became law. Payroll withholding began 30 days later, on Oct. 1. Five days after that, 40,000 screaming tax protesters converged on the capitol lawn.
"It's unfortunate that they had such little time to implement a bad tax," said William W. Wigglesworth, a principal at Tax and Business Services Inc., a tax-preparation company in Vernon, Conn. Mr. Wigglesworth said that aside from the delays in getting some forms, he has found few errors, but at least one major mystery: last year small business owners had one tax deadline; this year they have two, two weeks apart, with two returns that must be sent to two different Hartford addresses.
"I haven't the faintest idea why," he said.
Some glitches are not the state's fault. The Federal Government, for example, never got around to withholding money for the Connecticut tax last year from the paychecks of its workers in the state, according to Mr. Janschewitz of the tax department. That means that Federal employees, including nearly 13,000 postal workers, either saved to pay the Connecticut tax or are only now facing the grim reality of what they owe.
And a quality-control check conducted on Friday within the department revealed the latest snag: the private company hired to do data processing is making errors on about 10 percent of the returns it handles. One resident entitled to a $1.67 refund got a check for $167.
Some tax experts say that the number of people who had under withholding or no tax withholding at all is one reason why the tide of returns has lagged, since those people will definitely not be getting refunds and thus have reason to procrastinate. Another reason is probably simple unfamiliarity. Last month the agency logged 60,000 phone questions from taxpayers, more than would typically be received in a full year before the new tax law.
 
113 Amendments
 By late last week, however, only about 41 percent of the projected 1.6 million returns had come in, compared to 53 percent in New York and about 75 percent at the Federal Internal Revenue Service.
The Legislature is also considering 113 pages of amendments to the tax code -- some that are purely technical, to clean up mistakes, and others that go to the basic issue of whether the state should tax wages at all.
One bill, which the co-chairman of the General Assembly's tax writing committee, Representative Richard T. Mulready, has given a 50-50 chance of success, would lower taxes for most residents by raising the rate for the wealthy. It would then phase the tax out entirely at the end of next year, while allowing residents a referendum on the issue even as the law is heading toward its automatic sunset.
The Republican Party has begun a drumbeat to elect a new Legislature in November pledged to repealing the law even sooner, and last week the state party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., encouraged all comers.
National tax experts say that with continued pressure on state governments in the 1990's, other states without income taxes, such as New Hampshire, Tennessee and South Dakota, might be forced to follow Connecticut's lead.
Mr. Janschewitz said his advice to revenuers everywhere would be to "beg, borrow and plead with your legislature for as much time as possible, because the calendar is your enemy." And then, he said, "fasten your seat belt -- there's turbulence ahead."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Hispanic Politicans Seek a Recipe for Raw Numbers

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
The "geraldomander" is what some in Texas call the 29th Congressional District, which was created for the express purpose of giving Houston's Hispanic voters a voice in Washington. Zigging and zagging across the city to encompass Hispanic enclaves, its jagged lines are said to resemble a drawing of the winged Aztec god Quetzalcoatl.
Across the country Hispanic groups are bidding for increased political power through the redistricting process, based on the 1990 census, to demand greater representation at every level of elected office from school boards to Congress. 
 With unusual unanimity, communities as diverse as the Puerto Ricans of the Bronx and Mexican-Americans in California's San Joaquin Valley have pursued a strategy that began with efforts to ensure the fullest possible count of Hispanic residents in the census, then shifted to courts and state legislatures for redistricting battles. The strategy has now entered its final phase with the 1992 election season. Altogether, it represents the largest effort at political empowerment under way by an American minority group. It is also an element in the process of cultural change as these communities try to find a niche in American society.
Houston's 29th Congressional District illustrates the strengths and weaknesses of one part of the strategy, the drawing of districts that give minorities a chance to win elections whenever possible, as required by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
Nationwide, the Latino population grew by 53 percent between 1980 and 1990, from 14.6 million people to 22.4 million, a growth rate more than five times the national average. In Houston, the country's fourth largest city, Mexican-Americans and other Hispanic residents represent 28 percent of the population of 1.7 million, but until now have had little chance at a Congressional seat.
Such raw numbers are required, under the Federal law, to be taken into account in redistricting. The figures, however, include huge numbers of immigrants and young people -- and in elections, only voters count. Within the zany lines of the "geraldomander," 60 percent of the people are Hispanic, but they account for only 35 percent of the registered voters.
There is no guarantee that this district will elect a Hispanic Congressman. Clark Kent Ervin, who is black, defeated a Hispanic hopeful in the Republican primary last month. In a Democratic primary runoff Tuesday, City Councilman Ben Reyes, Houston's senior Hispanic politician, faces a close contest against State Senator Gene Green. The mere possibility that Houston's Hispanic voters might fail to elect one of their own points up the problems Latinos nationwide have encountered as they try to translate population numbers into political clout.
A study of census and voting figures recently published by the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials shows that Hispanic political influence is limited by demographic facts.
 
Why Low Turnouts?
 Nearly 38 percent of all Hispanic adults are non-citizens. Combined with low registration figures, this means adult Hispanic immigrants actually outnumber the 4.4 million Hispanic citizens registered to vote. And, compared to the nation as a whole, Hispanic voters are younger, poorer and worse educated, all factors associated with low turnouts.
Hispanic leaders also see themselves opposing a legacy of discrimination. "Court decisions in many states show that Hispanic votes have been diluted by the way districts have been drawn in the past, and that when the Voting Rights Act is applied, Hispanics can achieve representation," said Harry Pchon, director of Naleo.
The current round of redistricting has brought mixed results. There are new Hispanic Congressional seats virtually assured in Chicago, Los Angeles and San Antonio and, if Mr. Reyes wins in Houston, there will be 14 Hispanic members in Congress, up from 10. Another seat is possible in New York where the redistricting process is still under way, and perhaps another in northern New Jersey where strong Hispanic candidates are expected to contest the seat that Representative Frank J. Guarini recently said he would give up.
But there were widespread hopes that California, with the largest number of Hispanic voters by far, would produce as many as three or four new seats instead of just one.
 
Getting Involved
 "We have a lot of people who don't bother to vote even though they are citizens and we have a lot of immigrants who could become citizens but don't bother to do that," said Andy Hernandez, director of the Southwest Voters Registration Project, a San Antonio-based organization that has led several major redistricting efforts. "Redistricting gives them a reason to get involved in the political process by showing them they can elect their own representatives. It creates a climate of inclusion, and it is shaping the identity of our community for citizen and immigrant alike."
As they assess what has been accomplished so far, some Hispanic leaders have begun to suggest that new strategies are needed.
Linda Chavez, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research organization in New York, argues in her recent book "Out of the Barrio" that Hispanic residents have to find ways out of their ethnic enclaves and assimilate more fully. Redistricting efforts run counter to this goal because they rely on concentrations of voters.
Ms. Chavez agrees that Hispanic voters should have the right to elect Hispanic officials. "But," she writes "in order for this political strategy to work, Hispanics must remain in the barrio. It is a political victory that can be won only at the expense of the ultimate social and economic integration of Hispanics in this society."
Others, such as Arturo Vargas, a vice president of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, argue that the existing strategy needs to be expanded. "In the past our focus has been on the census, redistricting and elections," he said. "But now we have to add a fourth element with a major naturalization campaign in which we devote much greater resources to encouraging the immigrants in our communities to become Americans."
