HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Details Aren't the Crux of the Caterpillar Strike

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
As the strikers at Caterpillar Inc. walk the picket line together in the pre-dawn darkness, they often recount their 207-day strike in 1982 and the 80-day strike in 1979. Striking is nothing new to these 12,600 members of the United Auto Workers. Yet this time much is new in their dispute with Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of construction machinery, with ramifications unforeseen a few weeks ago. Now the talk on the line inevitably turns to what, for many, has become the most vexing question: what has brought them and their company to this precipice?
The strikers are not the only ones asking the question. Though loath to admit it publicly, many people involved in this drama -- from Caterpillar's managers, shareholders, customers and competitors to Wall Street analysts -- wonder why the union and management have collided so deliberately. The strike, many suggest, could be one of the crucial chapters in the history of the American labor movement, perhaps the Patco of the 1990's, as some have suggested, in a reference to President Reagan's replacement of striking members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization a decade ago. But it is too soon to tell. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service announced Friday that company and union officials would resume negotiations tomorrow. And many people who have studied the confrontation contend that when the larger philosophical issues are set aside, the workaday items that would be left in the conflict appear resolvable. 
 People who have studied the details of the company's offer and the contract signed last year by the United Auto Workers and Deere & Company estimate that the disagreement centers on less than $1,000 a year per employee, a few additional hundred dollars a year in medical premiums and a host of other, less weighty issues. Yet union and management are espousing larger philosophical objectives. Caterpillar is challenging the union's strategy of "pattern bargaining," in which a contract reached with one concern in an industry sets the standards for bargaining with others. And the union, its leaders say, is fighting for its survival, positioning itself for next year's contract negotiations with the big three automobile makers in Detroit.
"The difference between the two sides is purely philosophical and conceptual and not really based on detail," said Allen Luther Webster, an economist and professor of finance at Bradley University here. "One gets the impression that if the union were to relinquish its stand on pattern bargaining, the contract they would eventually reach with Caterpillar would be a whole lot like the one they would get under pattern bargaining."
That analysis has added to the frustration of the strikers, many tormented by facing a decision to either cross the picket line or see their incomes sacrificed, possibly forever. Finding new jobs with salaries of $35,000 or more will be particularly difficult.
For Caterpillar, the dispute represents a frontal assault on the tradition of pattern bargaining. The company insists that with nearly 60 percent of its products sold to customers overseas and 75 percent of them made in the United States, Caterpillar cannot have labor costs that unfailingly mirror those of other companies that have far lower levels of exports. It maintains that a fairer comparison would be the labor costs of its major competitors, particularly Komatsu Ltd. of Japan. Caterpillar can be seen as taking a stand for the remaining industries affected by pattern bargaining. The practice -- once common in such industries as steel, tires and automobiles -- has waned, principally because of the growing competition with industries outside the country where labor rates have been far lower. If Caterpillar ends its practice of falling in line with the industry pattern, so too, can General Motors, Ford and Chrysler.
 
Inventory Declines
 The strike comes at a crucial time. Caterpillar lost $404 million last year, mainly because the recession crippled demand in the United States and growth overseas was lackluster. While the company built inventory in anticipation of a strike, it has been whittled down considerably. And the company does not want to miss the expected rebound in demand as it seems the United States economy is slowly starting to make headway.
For the U.A.W., there are several issues. The union, which lost more than a half million workers in the last 15 years, is attempting to re-assert its strength, positioning itself for the negotiations with automakers. A setback at Caterpillar, which employs less than 2 percent of the union's membership, would spell disaster down the road, union leaders assert. The union's position also tests the influence of its more conservative wing, which is less inclined to accommodate industries' demands for more flexibility in wage patterns and work rules. That strategy of flexibility, illustrated by the union's role in the innovative Saturn project at General Motors, has been pursued by many in the United Auto Workers leadership.
"But the U.A.W. is being pulled in two directions," said Thomas Mahoney, professor of management at Vanderbilt University. "This will determine what course the United Auto Workers will follow for the next decade. Whether it will follow a more militant, confrontational line or a more accommodationist line."
Many strikers may care deeply about these issues, but they are more concerned about their immediate needs. .
"It just seems like they could settle this if they really wanted to," said George E. Petty, a 46-year-old heat treatment technician at the company's plant in East Peoria who has worked for Caterpillar for 27 years. "But it seems that each side has some other agenda."

HEADLINE: What's Good for General Motors?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The troubles at General Motors spilled over into the boardroom last week, when the giant automaker's chairman was removed as head of a powerful board committee and its president was demoted. Chairman Robert C. Stempel had announced plans in December to shut down 21 plants and cut 74,000 workers from the payroll. But declaring that "a more aggressive management approach" was needed, the board served notice that the overhaul of the company was not going fast enough.
The moves were clearly a reprimand for Mr. Stempel. Not only did he lose his post as head of the board's executive committee, replaced by John G. Smale, a director who is a former chief executive of Procter & Gamble, but the unseated president, Lloyd E. Reuss, had been fulsomely praised earlier this year by Mr. Stempel, saying "Lloyd's my man." 
 The G.M. shake-up last Monday sent a ripple across corporate America, where outside directors, often under pressure from institutional investors, are being pressed to get tougher with managers. That the directors dressed down the top executives at G.M., long known as one of America's most clubby companies, gave added weight to the gesture.
So why now? The answer is the scale of the problem G.M. faces, as the economy remains sluggish and consumers reluctant to buy cars. G.M. had a $4.5 billion loss last year, the biggest in corporate history. It shares its problems with Ford, which lost a company record $2.3 billion last year, and Chrysler, which lost a record $795 million. Chryler's board last month plucked an outsider, Robert J. Eaton, head of G.M.'s profitable European operations, to be its next chief executive, while telling Lee A. Iacocca that his Dec. 31 retirement date was firm.
But the stakes are highest at G.M., the nation's biggest automaker and largest industrial employer.
G.M.'s week of woe had a Long Island coda: John McNamara, a G.M. dealer in Port Jefferson, was accused of fraud in procuring hundreds of millions of dollars in loans from the company's finance unit, General Motors Acceptance Corporation. G.M. claims Mr. McNamara owes the company $436 million. With a dealers-- or corporate financial controls -- like that, who needs the Japanese?

HEADLINE: UNEASY CHOICES;
Clinton, Among Others, Prevails With the Help of Grudging Voters

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Given what he had gone through in the preceding two weeks, quadruple victory was especially sweet for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas on Tuesday. He won the big one, the New York Presidential primary, by a good margin, added Wisconsin and Kansas to his string and even prevailed in the non-binding Minnesota "beauty contest." He fairly glowed with bonhomie.
Unless some unforeseen disaster befalls his campaign, Mr. Clinton is going to be the Democratic Presidential nominee. Paul E. Tsongas as much as conceded that when he announced on Thursday that he had decided against getting back in the race. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Mr. Clinton's only active rival, concedes these days that he finds it difficult to put together a scenario for his own triumph. 
 That should be great news for the Democrats, who have longed for an early resolution of their contest. Ronald H. Brown, the party chairman, thinks it's essential to start soon on the development of a fall contest against President Bush -- fashioning programs, raising money, fleshing out campaign staffs.
But if that's so, if Mr. Clinton is on the verge of a famous victory, why are people so uneasy with the course of the campaign so far?
A considerable segment of the public is uneasy, it would seem, because it has developed deep-seated doubts about what kind of man the Arkansas Governor is. People told interviewers at the polls in New York that they doubted that he had the integrity needed to be President (46 percent of the Democrats), and that they wished they had other choices (66 percent). Close to a third backed Mr. Tsongas, a ghost candidate with no advertising and only a couple of speeches. Almost three-quarters of the eligible voters stayed home.
 
Doubting Nixon
 The doubts are not as profound as those many had and have about Richard M. Nixon; Mr. Clinton hasn't been on the national scene very long. But they are not wholly dissimilar, as the resemblance between "Tricky Dick" and "Slick Willie" suggests. If Mr. Clinton is to shake off the character issue, he will have to distract the electorate and stop sounding, as an old law-school friend puts it, "like a Big Man on Campus who thinks he can talk his way out of anything."
Democratic pros aren't worried about Mr. Clinton's character. They know him and, for the most part, like him. But they can read the polls, and they fear that he will prove unable to beat Mr. Bush, unable even to help Democrats in Congress hold their seats in the face of evident distaste for incumbents. That explains the reluctance of people on Capitol Hill to endorse him, even though they see his nomination as almost inevitable. The endorsements will come, but not quickly and not gladly.
Former Vice President Walter S. Mondale said the other day that in his long political career he had never seen the public so disgusted with politics and politicians, so reluctant to repose any faith in government, so dubious about the possibilities of their lives and their children's lives improving.
Mr. Tsongas and other outsiders have benefited from that environment, but in the end, Mr. Clinton, a professional politician despite his efforts to avoid that label, managed to prevail. Likewise Mr. Bush. And likewise John Major in Great Britain, who last week managed to pull his Tories through to a fourth straight general-election victory, a feat unprecedented since Napoleonic times.
All politics, they say, is local, but there is clearly an unsettled political mood right across the Western world. It would be surprising if there were not; economies almost everywhere have been reeling, with widespread unemployment and near-record foreclosures on homes. That has been happening, furthermore, at a time when the West has been trying to readjust its values and priorities to reflect the disappearance of the great Communist threat.
"Government no longer looks to the average European or American like the heroic defender of the ramparts," said Robert Hormats, a managing director of Goldman Sachs International who has worked for several Presidents. "The generation that looked to government to rebuild after the war is dying out. And most governments find themselves unable to fulfill the expectations of rising generations for broader government services."
The normal impulse in times of discontent, of course, is to "throw the bums out," in the pungent American phrase, and replace them with the opposition. But that has not been happening automatically this year. The great parties of the center-left and center-right are in trouble.
No longer concerned about whose finger rests on the nuclear trigger, voters seem more interested in economic affairs and less worried about the capacity of parties or leaders to devise and carry out complex international strategies.
In local elections last Sunday in two German states, Schleswig-Holstein in the north of the country and Baden-Wurttemburg in the south, voters took out their frustrations over the course of events on both the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats. The beneficiaries were the environmentalists on the left and a pair of extremist parties on the right that promised to do something about the flood of asylum-seekers from Eastern Europe.
In France, resentment over foreign residents, largely economic , has helped to fuel the rise of Jean-Marie Le Pen, a charismatic right-wing orator who, like the German extremists, promises simple solutions. President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists have fared so poorly in local elections that he replaced his Prime Minister in a desperate move to turn things around.
In Italy, regional tensions generated an electoral windfall not for the Christian Democrats or the Socialists but for the Lombardy League, a group that seeks autonomy for the wealthy north because of alleged links between the Government and the Mafia in the south.
 
British Similarities
 Election-week polls suggested that something similar might happen in Britain, with the Conservatives and Labor battling to a near-draw and a small third party, the Liberal Democrats, holding the balance of power. But in Britain's winner-take-all system, third parties seldom do as well on election day as in the polls because people fear wasting their votes. (H. Ross Perot may find the same phenomenon here come November).
If the trend is international, in other words, the way it works is governed by local details. The Tories were helped not only by the electoral system, but also by other particularly British phenomena -- the Labor party's old reputation as a wild and woolly bunch, which the party leader Neal Kinnock was never quite able to eradicate, and the tremendous number of seats Labor needed to gain to reach a clear majority.
"Protest votes are as hard to cast in general elections in Britain as in the United States," said Peter Jenkins of The Independent, who is a leading political columnist. "But make no mistake, this was a choice for a lot of voters between a repugnant government and an opposition that people didn't trust."
Such is the case in the United States as well. President Bush was obviously delighted that Mr. Major had won, congratulating him on "a sterling victory," not least because he, too, is a relatively colorless, centrist conservative who succeeded an ideological superstar. No doubt Mr. Bush hopes he, too, will seem the more reasonable choice this fall. But Mr. Clinton has the potential to represent a greater break with the past than Mr. Kinnock did. In Britain, it was Mr. Kinnock who proposed higher taxes; in the United States it is Mr. Bush who has already done so.
In a season of discontent, the trends change direction as often as a shallow, meandering river. So it has been in the Democratic campaign, and it may become the pattern in the fall showdown between Mr. Bush and, as now seems likely, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot. The President is April's favorite, but he would be foolish to think that that is enough.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Life Can Be Sweet on Europe's Subsidized Farms

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: OFFOY, France

 BODY:
Standing in the midst of the great green wheat fields of Picardy with the pungent stench of fertilizer in his nostrils, Dominique Mathieu condenses the myriad intricacies of Europe's agricultural policy into a single phrase:
"The more wheat I produce, the more I'm paid," says this French gentleman farmer in a tawny jacket. "It's as simple as that." 
 But thereby hangs a complex tale. It involves charges and countercharges of unfair subsidies between the United States and Europe, intractable discussions on agricultural reform, and a clash in world trade talks that is clouding trans-Atlantic relations and holding up a conclusion of the so-called Uruguay Round of negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Tranquil as this rural scene appears, with its furrowed fields stretching away to distant church spires, it has in effect become one of the ultimate theaters of the conflict affecting the world's $4.5 trillion in annual trade. And, in the post-Soviet world, trade is a subject for the sort of big-time summitry once reserved for arms. Economists and others have observed that the subject of trade has assumed an entirely new level in diplomacy.
The level, as it happens, of Mr. Mathieu, who lives in the middle of Europe's breadbasket. A prosperous man who also boasts a citrus farm in Texas, he owns 1,175 acres of very fertile land about 80 miles north of Paris on which he raises wheat, beets and potatoes.
Mr. Mathieu, like the 12-nation European Community's other 12 million farmers, does business under the terms of the so-called Common Agricultural Policy. This was introduced 31 years ago to insure Europe's self-sufficiency in basic foodstuffs and prevent the desertion of the countryside. It has served its purpose, but has also become unwieldy and costly. Last year, 63 percent of the Community's $70 billion budget was spent on agriculture.
Some of this money helped Mr. Mathieu make a nice living. He says he has profit margins of 15 percent on annual sales of about $1.2 million. He sells his entire wheat production to a big local cooperative called Agro Picardie at a price, guaranteed by the Community, of 100 francs -- $18 -- for each 100 kilograms, or about $163 per ton. This, he said, compares to a market price of about 60 francs -- $10.90 -- per 100 kilograms, or $99 per ton. Agro Picardie then exports at world market prices and gets a Community subsidy to make up the difference. Last year, France, the Community's largest grain producer, earned $5.2 billion from grain exports, its third largest export item behind cars and auto parts. Local grain farmers are thus able to ship as much wheat as they can produce to Agro Picardie -- a fact that leads Mr. Mathieu to use fertilizer at least three times a year and secure yields three or four times higher than American wheat farmers. The results have been dramatic. In a decade, the Community's share of the world wheat market has risen from 16 to 21 percent and the American share has tumbled to 31 percent from 46. The Community's share of all agricultural trade grew to 18 percent from 14 percent between 1983 and 1990, while America's dropped to 19 percent from 23 percent, according to United States figures.
Community farmers, led by the French, do not dispute that their share of world markets is growing. But they say American agriculture is equally subsidized. "This is all about the U.S. quest for hegemony in the world grain markets," said Alain Jeanroy, the director of the French Association of Corn Producers. "U.S. farmers are just as subsidized as we are and they want everything."
Farmers in the United States are indeed subsidized under the so-called Deficiency Payment System. But there is a difference: The European system encourages unlimited production by guaranteeing an above-market price for all produce, while American farmers have to take some land out of production to receive subsidies and there are limits on how much they may receive. One study by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found that subsidies represent 50 percent of the value of all agricultural production in the Community, compared to 30 percent in the United States.
A proposal by Arthur Dunkel, the director general of GATT, to cut the volume of subsidized agricultural exports by 24 percent -- a measure that would affect Europe and particularly France far more than the United States -- is now the chief sticking point in the GATT talks. Put bluntly, Mr. Mathieu and other farmers perceive a direct attack on their livelihoods, and the French Government sees a threat to over $5 billion worth of annual export revenue.
Nonetheless, while their position on GATT seems firm, European farmers do see the need for changing the common agricultural policy. With vast mountains of grain, butter, beef and other products being piled up under the current system, and the Community budget under strain, they concede that a gradual reform is needed. The Community commission wants to shift to a policy more like the American, under which farmers would receive payments for taking land out of cultivation and subsidies would often be tied to the size of farms rather than the amount produced. "Maybe when we have similar subsidy systems, it will be clearer what each side has and easier to compromise," Mr. Jeanroy suggested.
But time presses. A GATT failure would lead to more protectionism, lost growth, more difficulties for Eastern Europe and trans-Atlantic tensions. In Washington on April 22, President Bush and Jacques Delors, President of the European Community's Commission, are to try again to bring the five years of GATT talks to a successful conclusion. But first they will have to deal with the likes of Mr. Mathieu, who prefers the slow and steady pace of the seasons to abrupt decisions. "I cannot accept an overnight change," he said, gesturing to the expanse of his farm. "The problem is the U.S. lost its share of the world market and it wants it back."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why Japan's Influence Doesn't Match Its Economic Power

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
In East Asia no less than anywhere else, the collapse of the Soviet Union and Communism was supposed to lead to vast new influence for Japan, the region's economic superpower. But recent months have shown, instead, just how deeply Japan remains mired in the debates and anxieties of the past.
At least to its neighbors, the new Japan looks suspiciously like the old Japan. And in Japanese eyes, Asia is still a place for caution, if not paralysis. "The cold war is at an end, but Japanese don't really know how to disengage from it," said Terumasa Nakanishi, professor of international relations at the University of Shizuoka. "We lack any kind of national consensus on how to act." 
 Some of Japan's self-confidence has been deflated, in any case, by its poor economic performance recently. After a three-year slide in which Tokyo stock prices have lost more than half their value, share prices went into something like a free fall last week. Despite a rebound Friday, fears persist that the current mild recession could deepen and drag down the world economy. Privately, Japanese leaders say this may be a bad time for bold actions, especially costly ones.
Toward Russia, for example, financial concerns are an impediment to direct Japanese participation in an economic bailout. But the main concern here is still political. The same dispute over four tiny islands in the Kurile chain that has blocked improvement of relations since the end of World War II, when the Soviet Union seized them, has resisted all recent attempts at a settlement. Though negligible in strategic value, the islands are a powerful symbol of past unresolved grievances.
Japanese politicians, especially nationalists, say the final chapter of the country's climb back to legitimacy after defeat cannot be written until the islands are returned. But diplomats have begun reluctantly to conclude that with Russian nationalism flaring anew in Siberia, President Boris N. Yeltsin may find it more difficult to give up the islands than even Mikhail S. Gorbachev did.
The practical effect is that Japan continues to be a reluctant partner in the Western scramble to assemble a package of assistance to help Mr. Yeltsin out of his economic problems. The $24 billion aid package announced 10 days ago by the United States and Germany made Japan decidedly uncomfortable. Japanese diplomats said it was inappropriate to announce the package because all the details had not been worked out, and because a premature announcement might send the wrong signal to the Russians: that they had the money in hand and could ease up on austerity.
 
'Political Constraints'
 Japanese leaders said that although Tokyo would join multilateral efforts to stabilize the ruble, Japan would not increase its own aid beyond what it announced last year after the failed coup against Mr. Gorbachev. "We face political constraints," said Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata.
There has also long been talk here of investing in the exploration of natural gas and oil in eastern Russia or other parts of what was the Soviet Union. But it remains just talk. Japanese industrialists, cautious in normal times, are not about to invest during the current recession in a resource for which there may not be a need until well into the 21st century. They also look to the Government for insurance or guarantees, and Japanese leaders are not ready to cooperate until the territorial issues are resolved.
But Russia is not the only place over which Japan is showing caution. Many people had expected Tokyo to play a role in rebuilding Cambodia. Indeed, Yasushi Akashi, a United Nations diplomat who heads the peacekeeping efforts there, expects his country to pay for at least one-third of the cost of stationing troops. But for now it looks as if Japan will not send its own troops, despite the best efforts of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. As in the Persian Gulf war last year, Japan will help foot the bill without putting its people on the line.
The Cambodians say they would like Japanese troops, if only in a logistical role, but other Asian nations are less sure. Last week, Jiang Zemin, the Chinese Communist Party General Secretary, visited Japan and, in diplomatic language, recommended caution. The idea of Japanese troops going overseas for the first time since World War II was a "sensitive" issue for "well-known reasons," he said.
If Japanese officials were disappointed that Mr. Jiang was not warmer to Japan's playing a more robust role in the region, Japanese relations with other Asian countries are also troubled. A growing trade imbalance with South Korea is rankling President Roh Tae Woo and other leaders in Seoul. And three years of intensive efforts to improve ties with South Korea have resulted in more tensions than ever, this time over Japan's dismissal of claims for compensation by South Korean women who say they were kidnapped from their communities and forced to become sex slaves for Japanese front-line troops during the war.
Because it continues to be dogged by the past, Japan has had a hard time implementing its pledge to join a "global partnership" with Washington to combat poverty and tyranny in the world. Not only does Japan refuse to criticize China on human rights, but it has also looked the other way when Burma and Thailand suppressed their democratic stirrings.
Japan had pinned a lot of its hopes for a new order in Asia on a long-planned visit by Emperor Akihito to China later this year. But because of lingering Korean and Chinese resentments, the visit is now uncertain. What was to have been a symbol of the progress Tokyo had made in being accepted has thus instead become a victim of the lingering doubts in Japan's own backyard.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong-China Fence: No Barrier to Commerce

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
The wire fence between Hong Kong and China is as sturdy as ever, but it no longer seems to be much of a barrier. Telephone operators for Hong Kong may soon be based in China, and already some citizens here are finding that it would be cheaper to spend eternity in a burial plot in China.
With the growing integration of Hong Kong and southern China's Guangdong Province, an economic partnership is emerging that in the coming years may become a formidable force in Asia. Hong Kong is becoming the financial capital for southern China, and it sometimes seems that Hong Kong is taking over China instead of the other way around. 
 While many people in Hong Kong still worry deeply about China's plans to assume control over the territory beginning on July 1, 1997, when Britain's 99-year lease expires, there also is a sparkle of hope these days with the growing recognition that the merger will create opportunities as well as dangers for Hong Kong. That new burst of optimism has sent the local stock market rising about 25 percent since last fall, and real-estate prices have doubled in some residential areas in the last year and a half.
"Hong Kong is the prime driver of the greatest economic takeoff in world history," said William H. Overholt, executive director at Bankers Trust Company in the territory. "It's much more important to China than New York is to the United States."
 
Selfless Hero Meets Rolls Royce
 Such enthusiasm is far from universal, and the general improvement in the public mood -- which was bleak for long after the bloody Tiananmen crackdown in June 1989 -- may be fickle. Apprehension is certain to grow in the tense final years before the hand-over of power from Britain to China. But for now, many seem to believe that the considerable political risks of integration may be matched by substantial economic benefits.
"The sky is the limit," said Richard Y. C. Wong, director of the Hong Kong Center for Economic Research at Chinese University, adding that Guangdong Province is coming to recognize its dependence on Hong Kong. "If Hong Kong were to disappear in an earthquake, China's economic activity would slowly grind to a halt. There is no economic center in China."
The growing integration reflects a remarkable synergy between a monument to capitalism and a bastion of Communism, between a society that flaunts diamond rings and Rolls Royces and one that is supposed to emulate the selfless soldier-hero, Lei Feng.
In part, the surge of optimism is a tribute to Hong Kong's historic vitality and resilience. Repeatedly in the lives of people here -- after the Communist Revolution in 1949, the 1967 Communist-inspired riots, the stock slump in the early 1970's in which shares lost more than 90 percent of their value, the gloom during tough negotiations in the early 1980's over Hong Kong's post-1997 future -- prospects have seemed grim, only to improve with time.
 
Manufacturing in China
 "On a bad day when I think it isn't going to work, I freshen up my memory with what we have actually done in Hong Kong, what are we, how strong are we and how prepared are we for the future: you've got to look at history a little bit," said Simon Murray, group managing director of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., during an interview in his big-windowed office.
"Hong Kong, five and a half million people, piece of land not much bigger than a large Texas cattle ranch, no natural resources, not even enough water to drink," he said. "And here we are, the 11th largest trading nation in the world. That ain't bad for starters."
A tiny, barren patch of land that seems to grow buildings rather than rice, Hong Kong has had to turn to China for decades for its daily food and water. But in recent years, that dependence has blossomed into a formula for economic growth.
In a bid to remain competitive on world markets, Hong Kong has moved its manufacturing base to Guangdong Province across the border: Hong Kong shares its brains and expertise and gets cheaper land and labor in return. The result is that total exports from Hong Kong -- including goods made in China en route to the outside world -- have soared nearly 20 percent on average in each of the last four years.
 
Capitalist Influences
 The economy here still depends heavily on the United States, whose appetite for toys -- including Barbies, G. I. Joes and Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles spinoffs -- as well as electronics, watches, clothes and other products, accounted for nearly 23 percent of the territory's total exports last year.
But China is an even more significant trading partner. Last year, it took 27 percent of Hong Kong exports -- many of them parts that are assembled in China and then exported -- and a total share in Hong Kong's trade of 32.4 percent.
Through frequent contacts, Hong Kong's lifestyle and values are being projected throughout Guangdong. There is a yearning in Canton and other cities for the wealth and sophistication in the territory, and perhaps as a result the most popular music in Guangdong is that of Hong Kong singers, the most popular books include many Hong Kong titles, and out-dated Hong Kong fashion magazines are passed around among friends as treasures. Even the Cantonese dialect as used in Guangdong is picking up some Hong Kong expressions.
"Hong Kong people have had a real impact in Guangdong," said a Cantonese businessman posted in Hong Kong. "But Guangdong hasn't had any influence on Hong Kong. We can easily absorb capitalist influences, but socialism doesn't have much to offer Hong Kong."
While Hong Kong may continue to profit significantly from links with China, economists and analysts acknowledge that that dependency also carries problems and high risks.
 
Role of Trade Status
 About 1,150 people are still emigrating from Hong Kong each week, contributing to a significant labor shortage. The shortage lures waves of Chinese illegal immigrants. Last year, Hong Kong turned back 33,000 Chinese and the number was 5,000 in the first two months of this year.
Hong Kong admits a small number of legal immigrants from China, but the vast majority are illegal immigrants who often turn to crime, and criminal gangs on both sides of the border are forming partnerships in the same way as orthodox businesses. Last year, more than 10 cars were stolen from the territory each day -- among them Mercedes-Benzes stolen at the rate of one nearly every 40 hours. Many of them were smuggled to China on powerful speedboats that travel at night without lights. Smugglers can make enormous profits by selling those cars on the Chinese black market.
Another indication of the integration of Hong Kong and Guangdong are the joint ventures in bank robbery. Criminal gangs from Guangdong, sometimes working with local thugs, cross illegally from China in the morning, rob a Hong Kong bank or jewelry store in midday, and return to safety in China in the evening.
Partly because of proximity, this territory chugs and churns on events in China. The local stock market is much more likely to zigzag on news from China rather than from Japan or the United States. One continuing source of fear in Hong Kong is the risk that the United States will punish China for its human-rights abuses by cutting off low tariffs known as most-favored-nation trade status. That would have a major effect on Hong Kong, through which much of Chinese-American trade passes.
 
Cross-Border Investments
 One reason optimism has soared lately is the January visit by Deng Xiaoping, China's 87-year-old senior leader, to the cities of Zhuhai and Shenzhen, right across the border from Hong Kong. Mr. Deng reaffirmed the market-oriented development strategy of Guangdong, and asserted that Hong Kong could keep its capitalist ways not just for 50 years after 1997, as he had earlier said, but for 100 years.
Such comments boosted the stock market, and the property market has also been rising. One banker who purchased an apartment in a middle-class area for nearly $250,000 in the summer of 1990 has seen her home more than double in value.
"Agents call me all the time and they leave messages in my mailbox," the banker said. "People are willing to pay more than $500,000 for my place now. Unfortunately, I have to live there so I can't sell it."
The property boom is beginning to subside and commercial real estate prices have not done nearly as well. But Hong Kong investment in China hardly shows signs of ebbing. In the first nine months of last year, Hong Kong invested $1.4 billion in China, compared to $1.89 billion for all of 1990, according to Chinese statistics. Total Hong Kong investment in China in the 1980's was about $23 billion, economists here say, with about 80 percent going to Guangdong Province.
 
A Generation's Confidence
 Industry experts say 80 percent of Hong Kong's toy manufacturers have operations in Guangdong. In Hong Kong, only 680,000 of the territory's workers have jobs in manufacturing, but across the border, some three million Chinese work in manufacturing industries for Hong Kong companies, according to the Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions.
Yet for all the opportunities created by integration with China, many Hong Kong residents remain wary -- and remember that the territory is largely populated by people whose parents already fled Communism once.
"A lot of industrialists here came from Shanghai" and are deeply suspicious of the Communists, said Paul M. F. Cheng, chairman of Inchape Pacific Ltd.
"But my generation went to the U.S. or the U.K. and came back with a lot of enthusiasm and confidence. The older generation said, 'I've been through it once.' We said, 'Don't worry.' "
Mr. Cheng continued, "Tiananmen Square jolted our generation, so even though the optimism has returned, it's guarded."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1254 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
BUSH ATTACKS WAY UNIONS ARE USING NONMEMBERS' FEES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
In a move long sought by conservatives, President Bush will soon take steps to prevent labor unions from using money collected from nonunion workers for political activities that those workers oppose.
In a speech planned for Monday, Mr. Bush will describe his actions as a way to enforce a 1988 Supreme Court decision that held that workers who choose not to join a union may not be required to pay for any union activities other than collective bargaining and representation on labor-management issues. 
 The measures are intended, in part, to limit the activities of unions in support of Democratic candidates this year. Labor leaders vehemently oppose the restrictions, saying that the rules will impose an undue accounting burden by requiring unions to keep detailed records of spending in different categories. The labor leaders also say that Mr. Bush is pandering to the right wing and that his plan will impede unions' legitimate political activities.
 
$2.4 Billion a Year
 White House officials estimate that the President's actions will eventually keep $2.4 billion a year out of union coffers and in workers' pockets. The actual amount depends on many factors, including the number of workers who demand refunds. Labor economists estimate that 17 million workers belong to unions and nearly two million nonmembers are represented by unions in collective bargaining.
A White House official said President Bush's actions would "protect workers' rights recognized by the Supreme Court" in the 1988 case, Communications Workers of America v. Beck.
Harry E. Beck, an electronics technician whose feud with the union led to the 1988 decision, said that he had been invited to the White House for Mr. Bush's announcement on Monday and that he planned to attend.
 
No Effect on Union Members
 Unions endorse Democratic candidates far more often than Republicans. "There's no doubt about that," said Laurence Gold, general counsel of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. But public opinion polls show that Republican candidates have won about one-third of the votes of union households in recent Congressional elections, and slightly more than that in Presidential races.
In many states, workers who do not belong to a union but are covered by a union contract may be required to pay dues or fees to the union. Under the new policy to be announced by Mr. Bush, such workers may request and obtain a refund of any portion of their fees used to finance political work, lobbying, organizing activities or social and charitable events.
The refunds are not available to union members. A member of a teachers' union, for example, could not get a reduction in dues if he or she objected to the union's political activities. But members could resign from a union and get a reduction in fees if they did not want to pay for its political activities. Or members could work within the union to change its policies through debate and voting at union meetings.
Under Federal law, unions may not use dues for direct campaign contributions. But they can use the money to mobilize workers through such activities as telephone banks, newsletters and tapes supporting particular candidates and get-out-the-vote drives, including transportation to the polls.
Mr. Bush intends to issue an executive order requiring Federal contractors to post notices telling employees of their right to object to unions' use of their money for political activities.
In addition, he will order the Labor Department to require unions to report separately on the amounts they spend for political activities, lobbying and contract negotiations, so workers can identify spending for any political purposes they oppose.
 
Action on Complaints
 Finally, Mr. Bush is urging the National Labor Relations Board to speed the handling of workers' complaints about union spending.
As an example, a skilled aircraft mechanic, who earns $25 to $30 an hour, now pays union dues of about $30 a month to the International Association of Machinists. Union officials said that a nonmember who objected to paying the full fee could get a reduction of 20 percent, or $6 a month, representing the amount used for lobbying, organizing and political activity.
The theme linking all the actions planned by Mr. Bush is that no workers should be forced to have money taken out of their paychecks to help politicians that they disagree with.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the steps planned by Mr. Bush demonstrated "his willingness to pander to union-bashing, right-wing extremists in his party." But Administration officials note that it was a liberal Justice, William J. Brennan Jr., who wrote the 1988 Court decision saying nonunion workers may not be required to finance the political activities of a union with which they disagree.
In an interview, Mr. Beck, whose suit led to the ruling, said: "I am glad that President Bush is instituting employee protections that were granted by the Supreme Court in 1988. But I wish he had moved sooner. People are losing jobs and being harassed because they are trying to invoke their rights under that decision."
An Administration official said, "We want to make sure workers know that they have these rights, and that they needn't fear intimidation if they exercise them." The official spoke on the condition that his name not be used because he was not authorized to discuss the issue with reporters prior to Mr. Bush's speech on Monday.
Mr. Kirkland said Mr. Bush's actions would weaken unions and undermine workers' rights. "It is laughable for the President, after vetoing unemployment insurance improvements and failing to show concern for the millions of jobless in the longest recession since the 1930's, now to pretend that he's the friend of workers," Mr. Kirkland said.
Allison Beck, general counsel of the International Association of Machinists, said Mr. Bush's plan would impose "a tremendous burden" on unions. "The President's order could very well mean that every one of our 1,450 local lodges will have to hire an accountant or auditor" to keep detailed records of spending, said Ms. Beck, who is not related to Harry Beck.
The machinists union has 550,000 active workers on its membership rolls. About 550 nonmembers have objected to the use of their fees by the union.
Timothy M. McConville, vice president of the National Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation, which provides legal aid to workers who feel their rights have been violated, said: "The Supreme Court gave employees the right to cut off use of their compulsory union dues for politics, but the performance of the National Labor Relations Board in enforcing that decision has been terrible. There are hundreds of cases at the board, some pending for five or six years, and the employees who brought them are still waiting for relief."
Jerry M. Hunter, general counsel of the board, said his office had found merit in more than 300 complaints by employees who said their rights were being violated by unions.
Mr. Hunter said the agency had not carried out the Supreme Court decision as quickly as some people might like because "the Court created a whole new area of the law, and it took some time for us to plow through all the cases that were pending at the board." Many cases had been "put on hold, pending the outcome of the Beck case in the Supreme Court," he said.
Under many contracts, employees who do not wish to join a union must pay fees to the union, known as agency fees, equivalent to union dues.

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 10; Column 4; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviets to Get a $12 Billion Loan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The World Bank plans to lend $12 billion to $15 billion to the former Soviet republics by 1995 to bankroll food and oil-production projects and pay for critical imports like spare parts, according to the international lending institution's president.
The official, Lewis T. Preston, said that by the end of December, the World Bank expects to have lent $1.5 billion of the $24 billion in assistance pledged in a seven-nation package announced by President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany on April 1. 
 After that, loans by the bank to the republics will increase until they reach an annual $4.5 billion to $5 billion three years from now, Mr. Preston said.
His remarks, made Thursday during his first interview since he was named to the job a year ago, represent the first time that the World Bank has set forth specific figures and dates for how much it is prepared to contribute. The numbers were roughly in line with expectations.
The Bush Administration and other Western governments, short of money and struggling to cope with economic weakness at home, have increasingly looked to the bank and to another major agency, the International Monetary Fund, for aid to the republics.
The first World Bank loan is likely to be a credit to Russia at the end of June for the purchase of imports like spare parts for machinery, Mr. Preston said.
To limit the possibilities of fraud and corruption, the bank will probably not lend the money directly to the republics' governments. Instead, it will pay the bills for specific import shipments that its staff believes necessary, and require eventual repayment with interest by the republics. This is standard practice for the World Bank.
Later loans will be made for farm and energy projects in order to increase food and oil production, he said, declining to discuss specific loans and amounts. Officials of the former Soviet republics have been slow to suggest projects because their best economists are trying to solve monetary problems first, said John P. Hardt, the senior specialist in the region's economics at the Congressional Research Service.
The World Bank was created at the end of World War II to help finance the rebuilding of Europe. Since the late 1950's, it has specialized in helping the world's poorest countries. Some of these nations now worry that the most qualified development economists will be assigned to work on problems of the former Soviet republics.
"There is a fear, there is a danger, that the best staff" of the World Bank will be diverted to aid for the former Soviet lands, said Charles M. Nyirabu, Tanzania's Ambassador to the United States. He acknowledged that no one in the bank's Tanzania section had been transferred and that lending to his country had not been cut back.
Mr. Preston was asked to explain why his organization should focus on the former Soviet republics, rather than the third world, unless this was a way to oblige the biggest donor nations.
"There is so much to do, there clearly isn't enough in the way of resources," he said initially. "The donors are going to be cautious in terms of their own budgetary programs."
Pressed for a further explanation, he responded that the European economies would benefit from growth in the republics' markets. Asked for his view of the World Bank's mission, Mr. Preston replied that it was "the alleviation of poverty." Only three of the former Soviet republics qualify as very poor countries eligible for loans at the bank's most preferential rates, he said.
World Bank officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said the new section of the bank for the former Soviet republics had been given its choice of employees, and that the best and brightest bank officials were volunteering for the section because they thought they would be visible there.
Mr. Preston initially responded that the bank's senior management had prevented this from happening by screening proposed transfers. But a World Bank official who insisted on anonymity said none of the transfers had been blocked. Later in the interview, Mr. Preston said that "if there's a diversion of resources, it's human rather than financial."
The bank has moved more slowly than the International Monetary Fund to address the republics' economic ills, in part because it had indicated a greater willingness to heed the Bush Administration's initial opposition more than a year ago to a role there for the lending institutions.
The World Bank focuses on specific projects and sections of poor countries' economies, while the International Monetary Fund concentrates on policies like insuring a stable currency.
 
Must Give to Receive
 Mr. Preston said the I.M.F.'s leadership was to some extent inevitable because it determines the formula controlling how large a stake in each institution an applying country may obtain.
The size of the stake depends on a country's economy, with affluent nations allowed to pay for larger stakes and then borrow more money.
Mr. Preston said that he expected the former Soviet republics to buy a total of 5.15 percent of World Bank shares, led by Russia with 2.99 percent. Ukraine will have a stake of seven-tenths to eight-tenths of 1 percent, and Kazakhstan, two-tenths of 1 percent, he added, declining to indicate figures for the remaining republics.
Purchasing the shares requires commitments by the republics to make up to $9.3 billion available to the World Bank if required. But only $560 million in immediate cash is required, and most of that can be paid in rubles, a bank official said.
The World Bank's board of governors will most likely vote to admit all 15 republics at the end of this month, a few days after the I.M.F. takes similar action, Mr. Preston said.
